column2: ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 25.--It was at one time the custom to have, in connection with the ceremonies attending the inauguration of a Governor of Minnesota, the grand inauguration bail.
W.A. Ogden Hegeman died early yesterday morning of pneumonia at the residence of his brother-in-law, Chauneey M. Depew, 22 East Forty-fifth-street, after an illness of but three days.

Christmas is one of the poorest days in the year for matinee performances at the theatres. Everybody who has a home prefers to spend the afternoon there to any other place, and the theatres have to rely practically upon the floating and boarding-house population of the city. It has taken a long time for the world to appreciate George Meredith, to even understand him, but to-day the recognition of him has come, and there is no question but the he will be fully remembered and live among the romance writers of the last half of the present century.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 25.--A most remarkable shooting match took place here to-day between Capt. A.H. Bogardus of Elkhart, Ind., and A Bandle of ths city. It was at 100 lives birds. Hurlingham rules, execept in the case of Bandle, whose gun was a 9 -pound ten-guage gun. The score was: Al Randle, 100; A.H. Bogardus, 95 Bogardus used a 7 -pound twele-bore gun.

German Turners are a jolly lot by habit, but when they settle right down to determined enjoyment they usually kick up such a merriment that neither they nor their neighbors recover from it for days afterward. Christmas is one of the occasions when they get into organized working time.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 25.--Gov. Foraker today pardoned two men serving life sentences in the penitentiary for murder. One, George Oliver, was received from Cincinnati in 1884.

The inmates of the institutions in Westchester County fared well yesterday. In the county jail at White Plains 300 pounds of chicken formed one of the component parts of the Christmas dinner.

A Christmas reveler, full of Bowery whisky, passed 79 Bowery just before 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and sobered up a bit whey a puff of hot smoke from Siegfried Wolfert's stationery store made him cough. He found that the place was on fire and sought Officer James I. Ryan, the patrolman on post. In a few seconds an alarm was sent out and the policeman was active in saving those who were in the building.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 25.--There was a great fire in Cincinnati to-day. It began at 8:30 in the morning and burned to ashes factories and and dwellings covering three acres of ground. At the corner of Budd and Harriet streets, in the rope walks of the Charles C. Jacobs Cordage Company, the fire started. The fire spread rapidly in this building, in which tow and other material fed the flames, and it soon extended to ...

About 9 o'clock last night Thomas Jercle man, aged 85. one of the wealthiest men in Esses County, N.J., was called to the door of his house in Belleville. As he opened the door one of three men struck him in the face and knocked him down. The men then ransacked the honse, but secured only $3 and a gold watch and chain. Mr. Jorolomau thinks he could identify the robbers.
Mr. Dockstader's entire company will appear without burnt cork in a concert at the Academy of Music next Sunday evening. Levy, the cornestist has been engaged for the occasion.

Once more to the breach did the indefatlgable newsboy march least evening about 7 o'clock. The time the scene of battle was the Newsboys' Lodging House, 9 Duane-street, and it was a nebly-contested field.

BERLIN, Dec. 25.--The burden of the Christmas comment of press and pulpit reverts to the anxieties prevalent at the same period for the last three years and to the existing prospects of peace. Germany holds the Weihnacht breathing peace, while conscious that the war drum still rolls afar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25.--The widely concerted Republican plan of contesting the election of Democratic members in all the close districts, and to increase their slender majority in the next House by force, seems to have been extended. It is now proposed to contest districts in which the Democratic majorities were decisive and apparently final.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 25.--This afternoon, at Charleston, Fount Horner, 20 years old, became crazy from drink, and, obtaining a club, he ran amuck through the streets, knocking down and severely injuring several people. The last man he struck, Edward Aimes, drew a knife and killed his assailant. Almes was arrested but discharged.

PASADENA, Cal., Dec. 20.--The San Gabriel Mission was founded in 1771 and now, after years of change, stands on the main street of the town of San Gabriel, a suburb of the American city of Pasadens, San Gabriel is famous for its saloons and its mission; both have reached the acme of perfection in their several directions, and both astonish the beholder.
FALL RIVER, Mass, Dec. 25.--John Hartford this city owns a cat that in some respects differ from otheres of its kind.

READING, Penn., Dec. 25.--Blacksmith's Assembly No. 5,391, Knights of Labor, of this city has disbauded, The members were blcksmiths employed in the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad shops, and at one time had a strongth of over 400. The membership graduatly dwindled down to 27, and it was then found that they were no longer able to keep up expenses, an 1 $750, which was in the treasury, was divided amoung the survivors.

Mr. Daly has followed his usual custom of decorating his theatre in honor of the holidays, and yesterday patrons of the house were treated to a pretty picture in green and red and white as they entered the foyer. Large strings of smilax and evergreen, pointed at intervals by glimpses of red and white immortelles, are carried along the walls of the balcony overlooking the lobby, and stars and wreaths hung ...

MUSCOGEE, Indian Territory, Dec. 25.--A double murder occurred Sunday night on the Rogers farm, five miles west of here. A widow named Sarah Johnson, and her family of four children occupied the farm.
The shocking death of a female tamer of wild beasts is reported from Hohenmuth, in Bohemia. She was a girl 26 years old, named Bertha Baumgartner.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 25.--The steamer Leif Ericksen was burned to the water's edge at 5 o'clock last evening off Alkali Point, five miles west of this city. Seven lives were lost. The Ericksen was a propeller, 24 tons burden, and plied between Seattle and Sidney, Mason County, and was on route to that point when the accident occurred. Fire broke out in the pilot house, and it is believed to have been ...

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 25.--John Martin, the mate of the schooner Annie Carl, was murdered to-night on board the vessel, which is lying at anchor in this port. Andrew Grimes, a Colored man, Committed the crime, and is now locked up in the city prison awaiting a hearing ...

Yesterday afternoon great excitement was occasioned at Snaresbrook, Essex, by an accident to "Proffessor" Higgins, who made an ascent from grounds adjoining the Eagle public house, intending to descend by a parachute, after the manner of Baldwin.
The Rev. John M. Grady died yesterday morning at the parochial residence of St. Cecilia's Church, 123 East One Hundred and Fifthstreet. He was born in New-York March 12, 1851.

Among the living sovereigns mentioned in the new Almanach de Gotha, which has just been published, those who have reigned longest are the Emperor of Brazil, who ascended the throne in 1831, at the age of 6; Queen Victoria, in 1837, and Duke Ernst of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, crowned in 1844. The oldest sovereign is Pope Leo XIII., who is 78 years old, the youngest is the King of Spain, not yet 3.

COCOANUT CAY, Bahamas, Dec. 13.--"Vat ha pritty gen'lemman!" Thus Aunty Tryance voices her admiration. She has just given me a handful of her best guavas, I have brought her wealth by the gift of a "sheck," (tuppence ha'penny,) and after a Queen Anne courtesy she makes, in a stage aside, the observation quoted.

There will be grave disappointments in Wall-Street if the bull market does not continue. Everybody has the point to buy. The fever of hopefulness and expectancy is on. Bull poole have been formed in almost every stock on the list.
Mr. James Selby, the celebrated whip of the "Old Times" Brighton coach, died yesterday afternoon in London from acute bronchitis.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., Dec. 25.--Police Captain Banford was hurriedly summoned at 5 o'clock this afternoon to the house of Charles Cavanaugh, in Jeffrey-street, a most disreputable locality.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 26.--The President of the Board of Trade of Quebec has addressed a communication to Sir John Macdonald asking the Government to grant a subsidy for the establishment of a line of swift mail steamers between Quebec and Liverpool. The communication poins out the urgent necessity for the proposed line to compete with lines of mail steamers running between New-York and Liverpool.

A Christmas tree, full 30 feet in height and aglow with 75 incandescent electric lights carefully hidden in pretty lanterns, made the interior of Durland's Riding Academy at Fiftyninth-street and Eighth-avenue, even more attractive than it usually is of a Wednesday night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26.--Three fatalities and a number of minor casualties resulting from accidents at Christmas festivities in this vicinity are reported. At Geneva, I11., John M. Stillwell was impersonating Santa Claus at a church festival.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Yesterday afternoon the body of a respectably-dressed man was found in the cleft of a rock near Stony Point about 1,000 feet above the level of the Hudson River.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26.--The Court of Pardons to-day commuted the sentence of Patrick Coffey to imprisonment at hard labor for life. Coffey killed his aweatheart in Jersey City and was under sentense of death.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 26.--A cablegram from Pau, France, this morning states that the Rev. Dr. Boyce. Chairman of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, is dying at that place. He went abroad for his health several months ago, but began falling rapidly three weeks ago. Dr. Boyce is one of the foremost Baptist divines and scholars in America.

RED CLOUD, Neb., Dec. 26.--The closing of the doors of the Red Cloud National Bank in this city caused great excitement among the people. It seems that the bank has been financially embarrassed for some weeks.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26.--Leonard Gundell, an employe of an oll works in this city, was presented with a goose by his employers Monday night. He boarded a Kinsman-street car for his home, and upon alighting at his door on Chadwick-street was assaulted by three men. They knocked him to the ground, kicked him in the abdomen, and then stole his goose and his week's wages. At 9 o'clock last night he fell to the floor dead.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Enormous catches of pickerel are being made in ponds in localities in Sullivan County. A day or two ago Albert Crawford caught 200 pounds in 18 hours' time in Wolf Pond. The pickerel run large in size. The ponds are a fisherman's paradise.

Stanley and his aide in jail, was arrested to-day on a warrant issued by Justice Stuart for contempt of his court, and his trial is now in progress. United States District Attorney Kleberg is expected here to-night or to-morrow to institute legal proceedings against Stuart.

The Stock Exchange continues to have life in it, and the bulls are still happy and confident.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec., 26.--Abaca, a yearling bay filly by King Alfonse, dam Jamaica, has been shipped by her owner, Legrand Lucas, to A.J. Cassatt's Pennsylvania farm, where she will be trained. She cost $1,850 at the Woodburn sale last Spring. She is very promising.

At yesterday's quarterly meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society Dr. McGlynn made some pointed remarks about the labor political movement and the corruption that prevailed in the last county campaign of the United Labor Party.

PARIS, Dec. 26.--The Senators and Deputies of the Republican groups held a meeting to-day and adopted a resolution in favor of the candidature of M. Pierre Baudin against Gen. Boulanger.

BOSTON, Dec. 26.--The quaint old town of Marblehead presents a pitiable sight to-day, with the manufacturing centre a mass of smoking ruins. Its most important industry, that of shoe manufacturing, is completely obliterated, and it is feared that it has suffered a blow that will be irreparable.

Only two steamers left this port for Europe yesterday, the White Star steamer Celtic and the North German Lloyd steamer Lahn. The passenger lists were very light, few people caring to cross the ocean at the present season of the year.

Mr. Booth repeated his powerful and moving portrayal of the jester in "The Fool's Revenge" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening, and that performance was supplemented with a neat, brisk, and enjoyable representation of "David Garrick" with Mr. Barrett in the title role.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 26.--By the finding of three old deeds in the garret of her house, the widow of a we11-known citizen of Pittsburg and her relatives hope to establish a claim for the recovery of over 600 acres of land situated in what is now supposed to be the heart of Philadelphia.

ROME, Dec. 26.--The Pope has sent to the Bishop of Piacenza $4,000 for a training college for missionaries to be sent to America to care for Italian emigrants.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26.--In the suit of George B. Jenkinson and John S. Stanton against the Ohio Central Railway Company, the Toledo and Ohio Central Railway Company, was made a defendant.

The Committee on Art and Exhibition of the centennial celebration of Washington's inauguration to be held in this city in April have issued a circular asking contributions to a loan exhibition of historical portraits and relies. It is proposed that such an exhibition shall be opened at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 17, and shall continue for three weeks.

ALBANY, Dec. 26.--The accommodations of the hotels will be severely tested next Tuesday. Every room has been secured, and some of the delegations that have arranged to attend the inaugural ceremonies have had difficulty in getting quarters. The order of procession is nearly completed, the delay being occasioned by the failure of the civic organizations to report promptly.

Little Dot Winters, the child actress, was laid at rest in the Cemetery of the Evergreens yesterday afternoon. During the four years of her career she had made herself a pet of all who knew her.

Thirty inmates were sent on Christmas Day from the male department of the workhouse on Blackwell's Island to the wharf to work about the storehouse there and assist in loading and unloading the boats that touch at the different points on the Island. When the gang returned to the workhouse in the evening James Barrett and John Heffner were missing. Barrett was under a month's sentence.

The Executive Committee of the Business Men's Democratic Club, which is the successor or the Down-town Business Men's Cleveland and Thurman Club, decided last night that the club would celebrate the anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans, or Jackson's Day, Jan. 8, with a reception and a collation. President Cleveland, Gov. Hill, and many other distinguished citizens will be invited to the festival.

The Harlem Democratic Club held an adjourned semi-monthly meeting at its lecture hall last night that was rather slimly attended.

For the last year the Protestant Eipscopal Church of the Redeemer, which is erecting a new edifice at Part-avenua and Eighty-second-street, has been having a rather troublesome controversy with the Sinking Fund Commissioners and city authorities over the eight lots of ground upon which their now house of worship is to stand.

Robert Bonner's grand trotting stallion Startle is dead. He was a great pet of his owner and his end was particularly pitiable. He suffered from an ulcer in the mouth, caused by a bad tooth. The Turf, Field and Farm says that when pain had racked the nervous system of the horse and he had begun to grow weak for lack of nourishment Mr. Bonner tried to keep...

Insurance rates in this city will not be raised with the incoming year, as was hoped by some of the companies and feared by the insured at the opening of the Fall season. Indeed, those who know what labor is involved in putting a new schedule into operation did not at any time expect a change se soon, and rumors to the contrary have been based on misinformation.

Far back in the mountains of Ulster County, in this State, near the headwaters of the Neversink River, line a little settlement called Sholum, which is supposed to have been settled by a colony of people from Poland in the early days of the present century. To the majority of the inhabitants of Ulster County this community is but little known, as few people have ever penetrated the mountain fastnesses where the settlement lies.

May wheat yesterday picked up some of the points it dropped on Wednesday on the Produce Exchange. It closed yesterday at $1.06 , against $1.04 7/8 on Wednesday. The market was fairly active, and there was a good deal in covering. One of the things which influenced the market was the reported decrease of the amount on passage by 1,288,000 bushels during the week.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 27.--Paul Hopkins was killed at Fairmount, Smith County, on Monday, by James Jones, a prominent citizen and merchant. Hopkins was stabbed in the neck.
A heavy squall passed over the Upper Bay about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. It lasted for a half hour. The wind blew a gale from the west-south west, accompanied by torrents of rain and hail.

YANKTON, Dakota, Dec. 27.--A rumor has been received of a riot and fight between Russian settlers and Americans near Scotland, Dakota, on Christmas Day. There has been more or less race feeling for some time, and it has at last broke out in open war. Particulars at thin writing are very difficult to obtain, but it is said that one American was killed and that several on both sides are badly hurt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--Capt. Isaac Bassett, the Assistant Doorkeeper of the Senate, whose face is familiar to every visitor to the Senate Chamber for the past half century, celebrated to-day the fiftieth anniversary of his marriage.

Since Jan. 1, 1888, 6,430 miles of railroad have been built in the United States. This mileage was built, according to statistics sellected by the Engineering News, on 286 different lines by 190 companies.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 27.--Pauline Barth of East Hampton and Napoleon Burke of Holyoke were arrested to-day for complicity in the assault upon Frank Maguire at the house of Joseph Wood, at the former place, on Christmas night, from the effects of which Maguire died yesterday. Joseph Wood was arrested last night. The Selectmen of East Hampton have ordered a post-mortem examination, which will determine the charge upon which the prisoners will be held.

ALBANY, Dec. 28.--Minna Mayer, aged 25 years, committed suicide at her boarding house, 78 Hudson-avenue, last night by taking poison. She died, after suffering extreme agony, at 11:30 to-day. Her parents reside on Arbor Hill. The refusal of a man named John Flanigan to marry her seems to have been the cause of her rash act.

DUBLIN, Dec. 28.--The Freeman's Journal, referring to the Parnell Commission inquiry, says: "The Times prolonged the amount of evidence regarding outrages in the hope of securing testimony to justify the statements made by Attorney-General Webster in his opening address.
Jacob Hess of 212 Bowery was arraigned before Justice Gorman at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning on the complaint of Herman Seigel, an immigrant, who alleged that he was a swindler.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Dec. 28.--One hundred families with teams crossed the South Canadian River at Purcell, Indian Territory, yesterday, entering the Oklahoma country at that point, and settled on claims along the Canadian River, near Purcell.

The committee having in charge the cause of the patrons of the Hoboken ferry as against the management of the company's boats and its failure to provide sufficient accommodations, worked vigorously yesterday.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The ice in the Hudson River from this place to a point near Albany was moving to-day.
SHARBOT LAKE, Ontario, Dec. 28.--Perry's Hotel was burned this morning. Joshua Fraser, a boarder, perished. Other persons narrowly escaped with their lives. The loss is $4,000.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 28.--The miners of the anthracite region are stirred up considerably over the powder question, and it is the one topic of discussion among them to-day. LOUISVILLE, Dec. 28.--Sam Bryant to-day answered the published offer of George Hankins of Chicago to run Galen against Proctor Knott in a sweepstake at $5,000 a corner.
Augusta Gall, residing on Central-avenue, Jersey City, was severely beaten by her husband a week ago. She became so ill that she had to be taken to the City Hospital, where she died last night.
Mayor Hewitt has decided to let the resolution of the Board of Aldermen, giving the Harlem Railroad Company permission to use electric motors on its horse car tracks, become operative.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 28.--Senator John C. Spooner was in the city to-day and held a conference with Henry C. Payne. It was said that he was going to Madison next to arrange a compromise with Gov. Rusk as to Wisconsin's representation in Gen. Harrison's Cabinet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--Frank Maggiola has deposited $100 with Jacob Schaefer and challenged Eugene Carter to play a match at straight-rail billiards, 3,000 points, for $500 a side, the play to cover three nights, at 1,000 points each night. Carter is in Ohio and has not yet been heard from.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 28.--A bold robbery was committed on Olive-street this morning while the thoroughfare was crowded with people. George Ashoff, an employe of the wholesale house of Rosenheim, Lewis Co., was sent to the Bank of Commerce to draw out $3,000 for the firm.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--The Board of Directors of the Southern Cotton Oil Company to-day declared a dividend of 4 per cent., payable on Feb. 1, 1889, to the holders of the capital stock as they stand registered on the books of the company at the close of business on Jan. 15, 1889.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 28.--John B. Mayes of Tahlequah, Indian Territory, the chief of the Cherokee Nation, arrived here to-day. He is accompanied by William Jackson, also a member of the nation.

Cadby, who for years conducted a music store in this city, Kingston, Poughkeepsie, Newburg, and Catskill, convicted two years ago of forgery in the Circuit Court of Columbia County and sentenced to three years' imprisonment in the Albany Penitentiary, has been pardoned by Gov. The special election in the Sixth Senate District yesterday resulted, as it was expected to result, in the choice of Thomas F. Grady for Senator to serve out the unexpired term of County Clerk-elect Reilly. It was an uneventful election. Little interest in it was shown by the voters in the district.

Huntington left for the East this evening after a hurried inspection of his new short line, 160 miles in length, connecting Cincinnati with the Chesapeake and Ohio proper and Chicago as well, by way of the "Big Four." Pond, Democrat, legally elected Mayor. C.C. The total value of imports at the port of New-York was $510,268,432, and at all other ports in the country $273,026,668; total, $783,295,100.

DENNING, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Out here in the wilds of Ulster County the work of preparing the State Deer Park, authorized last Summer by the Stete Forest Commissioners, is rapidly being completed. The 200 acres, which have been inclosed, are admirably adapted for the purpose in view.

The graduates of Yale have decided to commemorate the victories won in recent years by that university in rowing, baseball, football, and other athletic contests by uniting in a dinner at Delmonico's next February.

ALBANY, Dec. 28.--There is a hitch in Gov. Hill's circus and the original plan is likely to be modified. It all arose from the Governor's superserviceable friends starting in to appropriate the Assembly Chamber on Tuesday without asking the consent of the Assemblymen. NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Mamie Wood, the girl who was implicated in the Brooklyn Schoonmaker scandal and who attempted suicide on board the propeller Newburg last night, is resting comfortably in St. Luke's Hospital and will recover.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 28.--Webb Brandon, the wife murderer, was hanged this morning. He displayed great fortitude on the scaffold. The parting between Brandon and his three children was affecting in the extreme. Brandon killed his wife while drunk.

Thank you so much, dear Santa Claus, for our merry Christmas. Of course, you know all about the nice things that were sent to us and the kindness and self-sacrifice of so many of your dear little ones. We needn't try to thank them--we couldn't--but God knows it all, and He'll be sure to give them a very happy New Year. THE LITTLE FOUNDLINGS. DEC. 28.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 29.--Another big mass meeting of Oklahoma boomers was held here to-day. Delegates were present from all the towns in southern Kansas, and the reports they submitted showed that 10,000 "boomers" were now on the northern line waiting a signal to invade the Territory.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29.--The friends of the condemned Blad Knobbers raided the Ozark Jail last night and liberated all the Prisoners besides five train robbers. There were four Bald Knobbers under sentence of death. They were Dave Waiker, Bill Walker, John Matthews, and Wiley Matthews.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--The mutilated body of a boy was found in an outhouse at Bradford this morning. It was recognized as that of John Gill, 8 years of age, who, when last seen alive, was sliding on the ice with some companions. The boy had been brutally murdered.

When the new year comes in the Bayonne Electric Company of Bayonne City, N.J., will have lost a valuable franchise under peculiar circumstances. About the middle of January, 1887, an ordinance granting the company a franchise was introduced in the City Council which proved obnoxious to the members.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--It is stated that further papers relating to the Sackville affair are about to be given out for publication by the Foreign Office. Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister, will remain in London until some time after the Lord Mayor's banquet, which will be given on Jan. 24.

CHAMBERSBURG, Dec. 26.--Dr. William A. Hammil of Martinsburg, West Va., and Lillian Benton Hammil of Hagerstown, Md., arrived at Chambersburg Christmas night on the late train, having eloped from Hagerstown, Md.

Col. John S. Mosby announces through a San Francisco paper that he will go to Washington next month and remain until after the inauguaration. The Colonel thinks it is not unlikely that he may be appointed to some Concular position, but says he would like to be sent elsewhere than Hong-Hong, as he has spent already six years on that "rock in the sea."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29.--Considered from a social standpoint Christmas week, as is usual, has been comparatively stupid, and but few entertainments of any sort have been given. Many invitations, however, have lately been issued, and it is expected that it will be very gay after New Year's.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 29.--Sheriff Ragsdale of Dinwiddie County to-day levied on the stock, fixtures, and farming implements of the State Central Lunatic Asylum, near this city, to satisfy a claim for rent for $3,500 for the building formerly used for asylum purposes in Richmond. The Board of Directors of the institution will, it is understood, fight the matter in the courts.

A telegram was received in Richmond yesterday announcing the death, in Maysville, Ky., of Mr. W.W. Richeson. He was a native at King William County, Va., graduated at the University of Virginia, and was engaged in teaching in Kentucky.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 29.--The steamer Idaho arrived from Alaskan ports this evening, bringing news concerning the wreck of the steam schooner Leo at Prince Frederick Sound, about 70 miles southeast of Juneau, on Nov. 25. The Leo left Seattle one month previous, laden with a general cargo of furs.

Warfel, in Millersville, carried a safe weighing over a thousand pounds to the rear yeard and blew it open with dynamite, securing over $600. BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 29.--The Boston Athletic Club entered its new seven-story home to-night, and it is safe to say that muscular science is the coming "fad" at the Hub. WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--The total amount of bonds purchased to date under the circular of April 19 is $101,705,500, of which $51,396,650 were 4 per cents. and $50,308,850 were 4 per cents. The United States steamer Grant is still lying at the Delamater Iron Works instead of at her anchors in the harbor. The work of repair on her engines is being rapidly pushed to completion, and it is expected that she will be ready to go in commission Jan. 15.

HELENA, Montana, Dec. 29.--N.J. McConnell, District Judge of the counties of Lewis and Clarke, Jefferson, and Beaverhead, comprising the First Judicial District of Montana, and who is also Chief-Justice of the Territory, has forwarded his resignation to the President. CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--For several days the creditors of the Baker Theatre have been in court seeking an order to turn certain portions of the property over to them. The most persistent of the claimants have been those with chattel mortgages who have been seeking to close the house.

The Goverment will have no need to worry about a surplus if it pays all the claims for damages by reason of the overflow of the Fox River. The Commissioners have been making awards at a lively rate, and the sums are quite respectable in every case.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29.--Mme. Hading played on Thursday evening, on the occasion of her benefit, the part of Claire de Beaulieu, in "Le Maitre des Forges." The house was packed to overflowing and the largest receipts of the engagement were recorded. Mme. Hading played superbly and scored another great success. Coquelin takes his benefit this evening, and another big house is expected.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 29.--Dr. Carver's right hand was powerless when he took up his rifle at 9 o'clock this morning, and he hadn't the strength to throw the lever of his Winchester down.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 29.--A year ago last November there began probably the most difficult electric light venture the world ever saw when the Fitchburg Railroad Company contracted with the Westinghouse Electric Light Company of Pittsburg to supply the Hoosac Tunnel with electric light.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--A fire occurred this evening in the residence of Moses P. Handy, the well-known journalist, 4,318 Osage-avenue. West Philadelphia, and though the building was not seriously damaged Mr. Handy's valuable library was badly drenched by water, and furniture, carpets, c., were ruined.

The Evangelical Alliance of Philadelphia and Vicinity has just secured the Rev. James L. Phillips, M.D., D.D., for the position of General Secretary. He is to enter upon the duties of his office immediately.

ALBANY, Dec. 29.--The Sagamore Club of the City of New-York has been incorporated. The object is to enable its members to take part in political affairs of the country and to perpetuate the principles of the Democratic Party of the Nation and State.

PUYALLUP, Washington, Dec. 29.--An exploion of giant powder yesterday blew a cabin on the outskirts of the town to pieces. James Blagg was killed and Leroy Gow was badly injured. The men were engaged in clearing land, and had the powder stored in the cabin. How it was exploded is a mystery, as Gow was too badly hurt to talk.

Very nearly four score of the friends of Henry George assembled to the Hotel Hungaria, in Union-square, last night and gave him a welcome such as might make him well contented to have returned home again. Mr. George bore his honors modestly and acted as a source of inspiration to the speakers.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Dec. 29.--The Rev. E.S. Stokes, D.D., President of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, has issued the nineteenth annual report of that corporation. It gives many facts of value to those who spend their Summers "down by the sea." The 66page pamphlet is entitled "Gladness by the Sea."

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 29.--At a meeting of the Order of American Patriots, secret society, held here to-day the sentiment of those present that, inasmuch as the order proved a failure, it was better to disband.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29.--Patrolman Henry Fehle of the city police force died from hydrophobia last night. Last September the officer while walking his beat was bitten in the right leg by a small dog.

A Sheriff's jury, consisting of 12 wellknown business men of Brooklyn, was discharged yesterday after having been locked up over night, and its members went their ways vowing to sue the commission which locked them up for false imprisonment.

LENOX, Mass., Dec. 29.--There will be more society people at Lenox during the holidays than ever before at this season. Fifty or more are expected to come up early next week, and the most of them will have quarters at the Curtis Hotel.

BOSTON, Dec. 29.--John P. Singleton and his wife separated several months ago because John was addicted to drink, and his wife found it hard work to support the family and supply John with money for rum.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29.--Ex-Mayor Doremus of Paterson, and widely known here and in New-York business circles, died here to-night of injuries sustained by a fall Christmas morning.

The Park Commissioners listened yesterday to the request of the Aldermen that consideration be given to the establishment of a public market in the Twenty-third Ward, if possible within the new park lands.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29.--Information has been received of a desperate fight between the police sloop Julia Hamilton and a fleet of illegal dredgers that took place last Thursday afternoon in Fishing Bay, on the Dorchester County coast.
TROY, Dec. 29.--The hundreth anniversary of the naming of Troy will be celebrated next week by interesting exercises. On Jan. 5, 1789, the village name changed from Vanderheyden's Ferry to Troy.

The Board of Education's Sub-Committee on Evening Schools has decided upon a course of free lectures, beginning Jan. 14. These will be given every Monday and Thursday during January, February, March, and April.

ROME, Dec. 30.--Opening with the words, "excunte jam anno," the Papal encyclical thanks God for the consolations which the jubilee rejoicings have brought to the Pope, and his Holiness thanks the Catholic world for its tokens of affection and devotion.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--So far as the appearance of Albany is concerned no one would imagine from the number of statesman in town to-night that the time for convening the Legislature was but two days distant. Not more than 8 Senators out of 32, and 30 Assemblymen out of the 128 are in town to-night.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 30.--A fire to-night partially destroyed the residence of Michael McGuire, on Fifth-avenue, and caused the death of his 8-yearold daughter Mary. The fire was caused by the igniting of a Christmas tree. The little girl became terrified when the tree began to burn, and ran up stairs and hid herself. When discovered she had been suffocated by the smoke. The lose will not exceed $5,000.

Taylor of Medina from carrying out his contract for deopening old Orchard Creek to properly drain the Tonawanda swamps. The work has been in progress over a year, and the State owes Taylor $14,000. The price of flowers for New Year's is just one-half of what was charged at Christmas. MONTREAL, Jan. 1.--The customs receipts for the port of Montreal for the past year were $8,778,291, against $8,745,526 in 1887, an increase of $32,765. The inland revenue receipts were $1,848,125, against $1,721,708 last year, an increase of $126,417.

From 7 o'clock last night until midnight the men who had been following in procession in Albany David B. Hill's triumph came scattering back, wearied and all more or less disgusted.

The handball contest between James Lawlor, the Irish champion, and W.C. Courtney, a Brooklyn player, which began on Christmas Day, ended yesterday at Phil Casey's court, in Degraw-street, Brooklyn, in a victory for Lawlor.

The only striking bits of color in the Mayor's office at noon yesterday were the blush of modesty of the cheeks of Mayor Hugh J. Grant and the red necktie of his Secretary, Thomas C.T. Crain. Seldom has there been such a throng at the City Hall on a New Year's Day to welcome an incoming Mayor.

John Mulholland, a Harlem contractor, registered at the Mansion House, at Third-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, Monday night, and was found dead in bed there yesterday. The gas was turned on and he had died of suffocation.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 1.--A collision occurred last night on Pearl River, near Pearlington, Miss., between the steamers Sarah and H.C. Warmoth, resulting in the sinking of the latter and the drowning of Mrs. Sarah Gabriel, a passenger.
John Deisel, a bright-looking boy, appeared as complainant against Ernest Brown of 216 Broome-street at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

John Neary, a brick handler, 22 years old, living at 136 West Thirty-third-street, was shot and almost instantly killed early yesterday morning while passing through Tenthavenue. It is believed that the pistol ball which caused his death was fired by some reckless person celebrating the coming of the new year by firing a loaded revolver.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 1.--Lowell's police court was crowded this morning to witness the first act in the greatest scandal that has ever come to light in the little town of Billerica. Yesterday a suit for $10,000 brought on behalf Mrs. Mary C. Wilkinson against Mrs. Mary A. Haskell for alienating her husband's affections was settled ...
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 1.--The negro who murdered Policeman Seal was captured at Barboursville to-day, brought here, and then taken to Richmond to avoid lynching.
Herrmann's entertaining exhibition of sleight-of-hand and mechanical mysteries may be enjoyed at the Harlem Theatre Comique this week.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1--The immense six-story brick building of the Richardson Drug Com pany, on the northwest corner of Fourth-street and Clark-avenue, was reduced to ruins in 40 minutes after 2 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--A more beautiful day than this which ushered in the new year at the national capital it would be impossible to imagine. The air was soft and balmy and the grass in the parks still a vivid green.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--There was no session of the Board of Trade to-day, but the brokers celebrated the New Year yesterday. At noon the gallery began filling with strangers anxious to see the fun. Trading was in full blast, and in an hour more the business year would end.

No such balmy breezes as those of yesterday ushered in the year 1839. David V. Brower of Ridgefield, N.J., distinctly remembers that it snowed on that day and was cold, and as his remembrance is reinforced by that of Mrs. Brower, it would be decidedly absurd to hint that he is at fault.

Gen. Contreras, the military envoy of Gen. Legitime to the United States, was seen at the Hotel Martin last night and emphatically contradicted the statements made by the Gonaives newspaper, La Patric, of Dec. 13.

The young year set the better one of his dimpled feet forward yesterday and gave this city such a combination of clear skies, sunshine with springlike weather, delicious atmosphere and hearty good nature among its populace as well-nigh reached perfection.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 1, via Galveston.--The false report originating in Chihuahua of a clerical uprising in this city caused tremendous excitement here. Many merchants and bankers in other places sent telegrams inquiring about the report.

LIMA, Ohio, Jan. 1.--The yards of the Lake Erie and Western Railroad in this city are blockaded with freight trains which were run in after the strike of the yardmen last night, and to-day the freight brakemen decided to back up the yardmen, and have all refused to work, notwithstanding the fact that their wages were raised to-day.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 1.--The Pennsylvania Legislature met at noon to-day in biennial session, and both branches were promptly organized by the election of officers selected by the Republican caucuses and slates committees.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1.--The holiday week just ended will be remembered here as one of the most pleasant in the history of the place as a health resort.

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--The General Term in the case of Edgar Bronk against the Albany Penitentiary Commissioners reverses the order of the court below in temporarily restraining the Commissioners from removing the machinery ...
There was the usual holiday crowd at Clifton yesterday. The following are the winners:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1.--The pigeon match which was to have been held at Belmont Park to-day by John McNabb of Sixty-sixth-street and Haverford-road was broken up by officers of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The crowd resented the interference of the officers and there was a free fight, which lasted until the officers withdrew.

John and James Sharkey and John McCourt dissolved their partnership as plumbers last week. Yesterday they got into a fight over a division of their tools and John Sharkey received injuries which may prove fatal.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 1.--Two thousand people witnessed a half-mile running race on Main-avenue to-day between Founder James A. Bradley's Kentucky mare. Borough Collector, Milan Ross's roan mustang, and William Coward's white gelding. Mr. Bradley's thoroughbred won two straight heats and captured the purse.

LONDON, Jan. 2.--The Daily Telegraph in a leading article on the subject of Ministers to England, says: "We have always contrived to make them more English than they were before they came to England. Should Mr. Blame come to London as United States Minister, Englishmen would take it as a great compliment. But whoever Mr. Harrison chooses is certain to be a persona grata here."

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--The one hundred and twelfth session of the Legislature commenced to-day. Lieut.-Gov. Jones began his second term as President of the Senate, and Fremont Cole his second session as Speaker of the Assembly. Both houses were delayed in meeting in consequence of the inaugural of the Governor.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1.--Mrs. Schropp, the wife of the murderer of Anton Schilling, made an unsuccessful attempt to commit suicide early this morning in the Philadelphia Hospital.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--John B. Jeffrey has failed again, this time in the name of the Jeffrey Printing Company, and a confession of Judgment was filed in the Superior Court in favor of the First National Bank ...

ANAGUA, Texas, Jan. 1.--Charles de la Garza and Jesus Barbo, between whom bad blood had existed for some time, met yesterday. They immediately opened fire on each other from horseback, but dismounting after a few shots, advanced on foot firing on each other.

The date for the appearance of Mr. A.M. Palmer's stock company in Palmer's Theatre and the return of that house to the position which it hold under Lester Wallack as the home of a stock organization has again been postponed. Mr. Palmer originally intended to give ...

Mayor Cleveland kept open house in Jersey City and entertained about 200 callers with coffee and lemonade yesterday.

In the Old John-Street Methodist Episcopal Church the first of the special evangelistic services, which will be conducted every week day throughout the month of January, was held yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Wellesley W. Bowdish opened the services with a brief address, at the close of which he introduced the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, Rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church.

BOSTON, Jan. 1.--It is stated that John Donahue, alias John Bull, who was reported to have died in a Western town, is alive and is coming back to Boston to prove his claim to the $1,000 deposited here by Adrian L. Mellon to be paid to ...

PARIS, Jan. 1.--Deputy La Guerre today entertained Gen. Boulanger and a select party at dinner. Gen. Boulanger expressed himself as being sure that he would win the seat for the Department of the Seine.
The ice on Van Cortland Lake was smooth as glass yesterday morning, when a small army of skaters and curlers took possession of it.

FOXCROFT, Me., Jan. 1.--John Butler, an aged Frenchman, who yesterday set fire to the buildings he occupied, killed his colt and goats, stabbed himself four times, took paris green, and fled to the woods, died this morning.

A brother of Mrs. Catherine Horton, who died at her home, 100 Tremont-street, Brooklyn, on Monday, of what her doctor said was consumption, complained to the police yesterday that she had died from the result of beatings received at the hands of her husband.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 1.--Shortly before daylight this morning the steamboat Natchez, while on her way up the river, stuck fast on a reef at Wyly's Landing, just below Lake Providence. She was shortly after pulled off, but it was found that her timbers had started the oakum from the seams.

When the Senate adjourned for the holidays it was with the understanding that immediately upon reassembling the Tariff bill should be taken up and that a final vote upon it should be taken on or before the 21st of January.

BERLIN, Jan. 1.--The Emperor's remarks during the reception to-day were without special interest. He singled out from the personages passing before him Count Herbert Bismarck, Herr von Wedell-Piesdorf, Gen. Count von Schellendorf, Count Szechenyi, the Austrian Ambassador, and several others, speaking a few words to each.

There were few people yesterday at the grounds of the New-York Shooting Grounds Association at Claremont. The weather was all that could be desired, however, and several boxes of clay pigeons were slaughtered.

CROCKETT, Texas, Jan. 1.--United States Senator James McMillan of Michigan has given $16,000 to make an extension to the Mary Allen Institute. This school is for colored girls, and is under the management of Prof. J.B. Smith. There are now in attendance 150 girls, and the school is in a prosperous condition.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--Henry Horner Co., wholesale grocers, are minus $15,000, and their city collector, a relative of the members of the firm, is missing.

Dr. Jared G. Baldwin of 8 East Forty-firststreet, yesterday afternoon, while driving up Fifth-avenue, near the entrance of the Park at Fifty-ninth-street, saw a horse with a lady on its back galloping wildly toward his coupe.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 1.--The projectors of the new memorial hospital at this place have one patient already. He will be admitted to the institution as soon as the necessary linen, mattresses, and other necessaries have been provided. It was made a rule of the hospital that no patient able to pay should be treated free of charge.

A fight occurred early yesterday morning in Prince-street, near Elizabeth-street, during which Cornelius O'Connor, 22 years old, of 331 East Ninth-street, was struck on the head with a brick and his skull was fractured.
ST. JOHN, N.B., Jan. 1.--During the year 1888 40 vessels, of 17,348 tons, wholly or partially owned in St. John, have been swept out of existence. Their value is estimated at $550,000.
There was no difference made in the daily routine at Sing Sing Prison yesterday except that the convicts were given a little extra rations. These consisted of boiled ham, mashed potatoes, ...

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--Albany resembled a military camp this morning. Troops poured into the city all night and this forenoon, and the blare of the bass drum was heard in the land. BOSTON, Jan. 1.--Henry E. Stickney, of Chelsea, is wanted for forgery, and the story of his crime contains a warning for trusting employers. Charles L. Davenport is at the head of the Chelsea Salt Company, doing business at 170 State-street, in Boston, and for ten years Stickney has been his bookkeeper.

John A. Mackay, comedian, did not begin his tour in Leonard Grover's "A Noble Son" at the Orange Opera House last night. The company was there, and several hundred people went to the theatre, but there was a bulletin outside which announced that the performance would not be given, owing to the illness of Mr. Mackay.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 1.--The new City Council failed to organize to-night. Councilman Connelly was elected temporary Chairman, and then the Mayor's annual message was read by the clerk and listened to with respectful attention.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1.--Charles Swift and Jacob Reislock, pupils at the Institute for the Deaf and Dumb, were drowned to-day by the breaking of ice on a pond. S. Dresbach, another pupil, was rescued and will recover.

The first homicide of the year was committed soon after midnight in a drunken brawl at First-avenue and Forty-eighth-street. The victim was Michael Crowe, and Irish plasterer, 28 years old, who lived with his wife and two children at 317 East Forty-eighth-street.

During the celebration of mass at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Long Island City, yesterday morning, the evergreen decorations around the altar pillars caught fire from a candle and a panic was narrowly averted. Father McGuire was celebrating mass.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 1.--Into the midst of Gen. Harrison's New-Year's festivities stalked the aggressive, not to say wearisome personality of Senator Blair, charged to the full with arguments in favor of national prohibition and national education. Gen. Harrison had really been enjoying himself all day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--A national convention of colored Catholics, composed of delegates from nearly all of the colored Catholic churches and societies throughout the country, began its sessions this morning in the St. Augustine Colored Catholic Church in this city.
A fire broke out at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the basement of the three-story brick building 823 Broadway, occupied by Wilson Brothers, manufacturers of fine furniture.
For the first time in many years a cricket match was played in Prospect Park, yesterday, on New Year's Day. Members of the Manhattan, Albion, and Kings County Clubs took part.

It was just 12 o'clock yesterday when two men met on Broadway at the corner of Twentieth-street and clasped hands in a cordial New Year's greeting. One was tall and rather thin, while the other was his exact opposite, being short, squat, and abdominally impressive.

The Pastor's New Year's reception that became so prominent an institution in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, during the life of Henry Ward Beecher, was very pleasantly revived yesterday by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Lyman Abbott at their residence, 148 Willow-street.
The Anchoria had a strange experience during her last trip from Glasgow.
MACON, Ga., Jan. 1.--The details of a terrible fratricide in Wilcox County, in which Edward Jordan shot and killed his brother, R.L. Jordan, have been received.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--The new year was opened in Chicago by Mayor Roche grappling promptly with the latest phase of the Anarchist problem. To-day he sent a letter to the Police Department stating that he had instructed the Corporation Counsel to ask the Court to declare plainly whether the Arbeiter Bund has a legal right to hold public meetings. If it has such a right, he says, the police must not interfere with it.

Eighteen hundred and eighty-eight was a great year for Uncle Sam's forces at the SubTreasury. Although the December figures had to be in part approximated, the record shows a big increase in the transactions for the year.

William Dunlap, who owns a tenement house at 57 Nelson-street, Brooklyn, and lives in the basement, became so angry at 2 o'clock yesterday morning because one of his tenants, John Henry, began to sing, that he shot and probably killed him.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 1.--The Legislature just adjourned, passed a special school bill for the city of Macon, which provides for supplying money collected for taxes in that county ...

Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn received callers at the City Hall yesterday, but, owing to the absence of several hundred of the local politicians, had shaken the hand of the last man in the line in less than an hour after he grasped that of the first.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 1.--Capt. Pat Hamilton, a wealthy citizen of Aberdeen, Miss., was murdered at his yard gate at an early hour last night.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 1.--Negroes celebrated Emancipation Day here to-day with great pomp and display. A procession of mounted horsemen paraded the streets at noon and there was speaking at the Metropolitan Opera House in the afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 1.--The steamship Lake Ontario, (Br.,) Capt. Campbell, from New-York Dec. 23 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head to-day.

ATHENS, N.Y., Jan. 1.--The chair in which Gov. Clinton sat when the first meeting of the Legislature of this State was held in Kingston, in 1777, is now one of the pieces of furniture in the residence of Dr. A.H. Getty, in this Greene County village.

There will be much surprise in financial circles to-day when it is learned that the office of United States National Bank Examiner for the New-York District has become vacant through the resignation of Mr. Valentine P. Snyder.

The Executive Board of National District Assembly No. 226, horse railroad employes, has drawn up a new agreement for 1889, to be signed by the various railroad companies in this city. TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 1.--The Mercer County Medical Society devoted the better part of its session this afternoon to the examination of William King, the colored man who is said to have two hearts. He is about 45 years of age.

The Hibernian gateman on the Jersey City end of the Pavonia Ferry scratched his head in a mystified sort of way yesterday afternoon and his good-natured face was screwed up into an expression of profound contemplation. He was puzzled over a question of rates.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 1.--Louis Schmidt, an inmate of the Soldiers' Home, 65 years of age, stabbed a fellow-veteran named W.F. Ruder with fatal effect this afternoon, causing instant death.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--Ex-Secretary William Windom passed the first day of the new year in Chicago, while making the journey from NewYork to his home, Winona, Minn.

SARNIA, Ontario, Jan. 1.--A firebug named Matthew Jones, for burning the barns of Henry Roebuck and John Pollock, was tried here to-day. The Judge said that such men as the prisoner had no business to be at large and sentenced him to the penitentiary for life.

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--In the early part of the century there was not much show or demonstration when the Governors were inaugurated. They usually took the oath of office quietly, and walked into the Executive Chamber on the day assigned for the purpose with Democratic simplicity and took command of the ship without any hurrah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--The Department of State has received a telegram from the United States Consul at St. John's N.F., stating that the American brig Atalaya, Brown, master, from Rouen to Philadelphia, is a total loss at Renews. The Captain is the only survivor.

Cadet G.F. Sylvia, United States Revenue Marine, recently made a series of charges to the Department in Washington that his life on board the United States ship Chase was unendurable; that he was constantly nagged by the other cadets, and that his existence was little else than that of a pariah. The resignation of Cadet Sylvia accompanied these charges and was promptly accepted.

OZARK, Mo., Jan. 1.--John Matthews, one of the condemned Bald Knobbers who was released from the jail here a few nights ago, was brought back yesterday by James Cellins, who captured him on the road three miles south of Ozark Sunday night. He was almost exhausted by hunger and cold, having had but one meal since he left the jail.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1.--A summing up of the iron and steel trade of the United States during 1888, as made by the Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association, shows that last year was not a particularly prosperous one for the iron trade, and in many respects fell below 1887 and 1886. The total production of pig iron ...

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1.--A few minutes after 5 o'clook this morning fire broke out in a cheap lodging house on North Sixth-street, opposite the Union Market, and in the panic that followed among the lodgers three women leaped through the third-story windows.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 2. Advices from Quitman, Kemper County, indicate probable trouble between the whites and blacks. A respectable farmer in the neighborhood named H.H. WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The President to-day nominated Leslie Cullom of Tennessee to be Collector of Customs for the District of Puget Sound, in the State of Oregon and Territory of Washington. This appointment is in place of Quincy A. Brooks, who was suspended some time ago.

LONDON, Jan. 2.--The ship Stephen D. Horton, (Br.,) Capt. Lawis, from Calcutta Oct. 8 for NewYork, has been burned at sea, the carpenter and a seaman were drowned. The remainder of the crew landed at Pernambuce.

The experts to be chosen by the Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Association will probably have a difficult task determining the prize plans. The competition closed yesterday, and the suppls of designs was increased by half a dozen, thus swelling the aggregate number of drawings and models to nearly a round hundred.

"Prison Reform" was the subject of discussion last evening at the January meeting of the Plymouth League, which met in the Sunday school room of Plymouth Church. About as many as the room would comfortably seat listened to the discussion.

Last night 122 of the dry goods stores on the east side out of a total of 132 closed up at 7 o'clock instead of 10 as a result, it is said by the clerks, of the agitation of the East Side branch of the Dry Goods Clerks' Early Closing and Benevolent Association.

Paul Bauer, known to hosts of people as the former proprietor of Bauer's Hotel and Bauer's Pavilion at West Brighton Beach, died yesterday at Bloomingdale Insane Asylum where he had been confined since the middle of June last, a victim of paresis.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Jan. 2.--An accident occurred yesterday two miles from Sumney town, this county, two young men, named Erb and Schoecker, being literally blown to atoms by an explosion of a half-bucket of dynamite.

John Hart, the well-known minstrel, fell from the front platform of a Fourth-avenue car at Bowery and Brooms-street last night about 7 o'clock, his head striking the pavement. There is a curve at this place. He was quite seriously injured, and was removed to St. Vincent's Hospital.

Col. Elliott F. Shepard had a great time at Cooper Union last night. Compliments flew thick and face, and a majority came his way. He had a chance to run a big meeting and to talk politics and ballot reform, while enterprising little boys peddled copies of his newspaper in the lobbies and occasionally appeared in the auditorium with bundles of the journal of scripture texts under their arms.
The vote cast at the recent special election in the Sixth Senate District was canvassed by the Alderman, acting as county canvassers, yesterday.
Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald, Medical Superintendent of the State Asylum for Insane Criminals at Auburn, has just issued the twentyninth annual report of the work among his patients.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 2.--Many friends witnessed at Grace Church this evening the marriage of Miss Estelle Van Zandt, daughter of Thaddeus Avery Van Zandt, to Mr. Herbert Lowell Montague of New-York. The wedding march from "Lohongrin" was sung by the Grace Church choir boys, who preceded the bridal ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--Capt. F.C. Ainsworth, As sistant Surgeon, has been ordered to temporary duty in New-York and Brooklyn. Second Lieut. J. H. Weber, Signal Corps. has been granted two months extension of leave of absence. Seventy recruits have been ordered to the Fourth Cavalty, 30 to the Sixth Cavalry and 30 to the Twenty-second Infantry. Lieut. Col. George B. Dandy. Deputy Quartermaster-General has been ordered to temporary duty at Richmond.

BUFFALO, Jan. 2.--Elevator men are considerably stirred up over the confirming by the General Term of the Superior Court of the conviction of J. Tallman Budd for a violation of the law regulating elevator charges.

ERIE, Ponn., Jan. 2.--The United States Court officials here were notified to-day of the burglary of the Clarendon Post Office by cracksmen. The gang, after going through several of the stores in the town, attacked the Post Office and got about $400 in stamps and some money, and destroyed a lot of valuable letters.

LIMA, Ohio, Jan. 2.--The Lake Erie and Western Railroad switchmen's strike was settled this morning. An increase of 15 cents per day was granted. Trains are now running the usual, time card.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 2.--Chief of Police Hennessy has turned loose his detectives to discover the identity of a person who has amused himself by shooting into the windows of the Charity Hospital.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 2.--The game of baseball between the Chicago and All America nines to-day resulted in a score of 14 to 7 in favor of the Chicagos.

Perhaps there is no unhappy augury in a bad start. For, Wall-street's sake it's to be hoped there isn't. Yesterday's opening of the 1889 stock market hadn't much that was cheerful in it. Business was not brisk. Quotations drooped.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 2.--Detectives Funk and Keller returned from Cincinnati this afternoon, having fully identified the negro Charles Howard, whom they were seeking, as the highway murderer of Old Soldier Theodore Trampeneau, a veteran of the Sixteenth Illinois Cavalry.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan, 2.--John M. Caruthers, a Receiver and clerk for the Philadelphia Traction Company, was arrested to-day by Detective William Henderson charged with the embezzlement of $5,000 from the company and with altering books and accounts belonging to them. He was taken before Magistrate London, where he waived a hearing and was held in $10,000 bail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--If the Republican and Democratic Senators had spent the holiday recess in devising some scheme by which to stave off action upon the details of the pending Tariff bill they would probably have mapped out just such a course as was followed in the Senate today.
