CINCINNATE, Jan. 2.--Mr. E.F.J. Mlles, the veteran manager, has retired from the management of the Grand Opera House here, and Mr. Harry Rainforth assumes the entire management. The two men remain partners, however, in other theatrical ventures. "Bob" miles, as he is familiarly called, has a wide acquaintance in the theatrical world.

The Chamber of Commerce has forwarded to Washington a petition signed by nearly 300 of its members, asking that the location of the new public stores, which it is proposed to erect in New-York, be situated near the Battery. Loading the signatures are such names as Andrew ...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2.--Freddie, the 7year-old son of Alfred E. Reese, fell into the river here yesterday and was drowned. His body was recovered within 15 minutes, but, the cold water had chilied it beyond resuscitation.

The Rev. Dr. G.R. Van De Water conducted yesterday afternoon's interdenominational evangelical services at the old John-Street Church. There was a good attendance. Dr. Van De Water took for his text "Thy Strength ...

Part I. of the Court of General Sessions is undergoing very much needed renovation. New carpets, new paint, and new upholstery will make it much more presentable. Recorder Smyth will open the January term there Monday, but will probably adjourn for a few days after swearing in the Grand Jury, to give the mechanics a chance to finish their work.

Richmond Lodge, No. 80, Knights of Pythias, Tottenville.--Fast Chancellor--Israel Butler, Chancellor Commander--C.A. Thrall; Vice-Chancellor--M. L. Joline: Prelate--Charles Watson; Keeper of Records and Seal--A. Spaniding; Master of Arms-- G. Thrall: Master of Exchequer--H. Dunham; Master of Finance--F.F. Edwards.
The plans for the steel-clad war ship which have just been completed are in several respects among the most novel and interesting of the various designs adopted for our new fleet.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan,. 2.--Goodall, Fito James, wholesale clothiers and furnishers of this city, assigned to-day for the benefit of their creditors, who are in Nashville, New-York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Cincinnati. The liabilities are $92,000 and the assets $100,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2.--Prof. Pickering of the Harvard University party telegraphs from Willows regarding yesterday's eclipse that the sun was perfectly clear during totality. Over 50 photographs were secured.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2.--It is said that in none of the original 13 States of America are there such a number of handsome and historic colonial mansions still standing in good condition as in Connecticut. The eldest and most picturesque house in Lyme is still in a remarkable state of preservation.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2.--The dead body of the Hon. John R. Martin of Washington, Mo., one of the most widely-known Republican politicians of the State, was found this morning on the Iron Mountain track near Gratiot.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 2.--The public accounts of the Dominion for the fiscal year 1887-8 show that the gross debt increased during the year from $273,187,626 to $284,513,841, an increase of nearly $11,500,000. The net debt increased from $227,314,775 in 1887 to $234,513,358 on the 30th of June last.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--The United States gunboat Yorktown left her whart at Cramp's shipyard at 7:30 o'clock this morning for a second speed trial over the Government course.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Lottle Lyons and her 15year-old son William had finished their supper at their home on the second story of a Divisionstreet apartment house this evening, and the woman was putting the dishes away, when ...

GREENVILLE, S.C., Jan. 2.--Last evening Miss Fannie Heldman, daughter and only child of George Heldman a respected German citizen, broke away from her father's house and ran a distance of several blocks and slipped softly into Reedy River, evading all persons who were in close pursuit of her.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2.--There are more than 3,000,000 bushels of corn and wheat in the Baltimore elevators, which accumulated during the halt in foreign exportations incident to the wheat speculation in the West.

David Lannigan, a brakeman, who has been in the employ of the elevated railway company for several years and was regarded as careful and entirely trustworthy, had charge yesterday of the rear car, of a five-car train which left One Hundred and Twenty-ninthstreet and Third-avenue at 4:37 o'clock in charge of Conductor Cramsey.
Moderate weather and a consequent slack demand has had a tendency to discourage coal men. They say business is abnormally dull and nobody is making money in the trade.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 2.--Messrs. John Dymond, President, and Henry McCall, and Henry C. Mlaer, Vice-Presidents of the Louisiana Sugar Planters' Association, accompanied by John Foos of St. Mary, one of the most extensive sugar planters in the State, left this evening for Washington to look after the interests of ...

Holiday festivities have closed and the society people who have been entertaining in town or at the country resorts are now giving their attention to preparations for the Charity Ball, which is to be held next Tuesday evening.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 2.--Twenty-eight years ago when Mrs. Sarah Rothermal gave birth to a son there was a mark upon the back part of the infant's head just below and to the right of the base of the brain.

After the performance at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last night Lawrence Barrett started for Boston on a special train to be present at the marriage of his younger daughter to Joseph Anderson, the brother of Mary Anderson, which is to take place to-day. Mr. Barrett will return to night to appear at the Fifth-Avenue.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2.--Tom Vines, the Chicago defaulter, who tried to escape from that city packed and locked in a Saratogo trunk, was an object of great interest at the Four Courts today. A stream of callers paused at his cell, and he repeated to them the story of his strange adventure.

The Amateur Athletic Union's boxing and wrestling championships this year will be held where they were so successfully given last year, on the Metropolitan Opera House stage, and probably on Saturday evening, March 23.
The success achieved by E.H. Sothern in "Lord Chumley" at Hooley's Theatre, Chicago, has been far beyond the expectations of Managers Frohman and Hooley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The second day's session of the Colored Catholic Convention was begun this morning in the basement of St. Augustine's Church. The report of the Committee on Permanent Officers recommended the ...
There was a lively drop in the wheat market, on the Produce Exchange yesterday. The opening was strong, enough, May quotations starting in at $1.07 and advancing to 31.08 .

While the active politicians of the Republican Party are intensely interested at the present moment in the question of Mr. HARRISON'S Cabinet appointments, there is one consequence that must follow those appointments that is apparently not thought of at all.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--The yearly report of the Secretary of State on the criminal statistics shows: Total convictions reported by County Clerks in courts of record, 3,199; whole number last year, 3,301; decrease, 102. Of these it is shown that 506 were for offences against the person, against 505 last year; 803 against ...
TROY, N.Y., Jan. 2.--Last Friday night two safes were blown open in the general store of W.P. Mattison, at South Shaftsbury, Vt., $400 ...

The rumor that ex-Boodle Alderman Ludolph A. Fullgraff would not come back from St. Paul, where he is engaged in business, to testify in the case that will be tried at the Extraordinary Term of Oyer and Terminer, does not disturb Col. Fellows. He says that Fullgraff will be back here when wanted. He is under $20,000 bail, furnished by George E. Faile of 841 East One Hundred and Sixtyfourth-street, and Mrs. Fullgraff.
ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Reports for the past year (ended Sept. 30) made to the State Railroad Commission afford these comparisons:

The first public observations of Presidents-elect after their election are apt to be taken as the "keynotes" of their Administration. Gen. HARRISON made at a meeting of his Grand Army post in Indianapolis on New Year's Day some remarks that were reported, and that it is fair to assume were considered beforehand.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2.--A profound sensation was created here to-day by a report from Philadelphia that Manuel Kline had blown his brains out in one of the hotels there. An investigation showed that the suicide was not Kline, and that the dead man bore no resemblance to him at all.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 2.--The report of Fire Inspector Charles T. Holloway for the year 1888 states that the total losses by fire were $1,297,756, an increase of $132,101 over those of 1887.

The United States Illuminating Company in its suit against the Board of Electrical Control and its fight to avoid putting its wires under ground received a set-back yesterday in the decision of Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--Hronek, the Anarchist convicted of conspiring to assassinate with dynamite Inspector Boufield and Judges Gary and Grinneli, was refused a new trial, to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--A change in the management and control of Baker's Theatre will occur tomorrow. The details were agreed upon today, but it remains for the formal order in the matter to be entered, which will be made tomorrow morning.

Many of Mr. Chauncey Mitchell Depew's friends were horror-stricken last evening to hear that he is to lose one of his legs to-day. In order to obtatn official information on the subject a TIMES reporter called upon Mr. Depew in his office at the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon. Mr. Depew had none of the nervousness that would be expected in a man with such an operation before him.

Transportation not yet being open through the West Point Tunnel the passengers of the West Shore Road are transferred in stages between Cranston's Station on the south and Target Hill Station on the north. Conductor Charles Sinsapaugh had the 10:45 train into New-York last Friday night, and on board was a crowd of nearly half a hundred Italian laborers returning to their homes in this city.

READING, Penn., Jan. 2.--The extensive foundry of the Reading Foundry Company, where large iron pipe for gas and water mains for many of the larger cities are made finally closed down indefinitely today, throwing 160 men out of employment. Dull trade is given as the cause for closing the works.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The Secretary of the Treasary this afternoon accpted 4 per cent. registered bonds to the amount of $685,000 at 108 and ...

Following the announcement of a new ocean steamship of 10,500 tons by the White Star Line, to make its trip trip in May, comes the report that the Guton Company has a vessel of 11,500 tons in contemplation. The model, which is the last by Sir William Pearce, has been on exhibition at the Maritime Exchange ...

Joseph J. O'Donohue is still interesting the members of the coffee trade by seeking the scalp of Mr. Herman Sleicken with soulful earnestness. His suit for $100,000 damages before the Supreme Court against Mr. Sielcken was withdrawn on Monday, and yesterday a new suit for the same amount was begun in the Court of Common Pleas. The summons was served upon the defendant rather early in the day.

On New Year's Day an old cab horse was standing asleep at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street. His ears drooped listlessly, his eyes were half shut, his long under lip hung down from his yellow teeth, and his whitening whiskers waved back and forth with the regularity of his respiration.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--R.J. Prins, retail shoe dealer, was closed up by the Sheriff this evening. The liabilities are $23,000, of which $12,000 is to Eastern manufacturers. Prins offers 55 cents cash on the dollar for an immediate to settlement.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 2.--When the employee of railroads centring in this city complete the annual statements upon which they are now busily engaged some surprising figures will be the result. The havoc which the rate wars make in the earnings will be the most noticeable but least interesting feature of many of these annual reports.
The usual influences of Christmas cheer were not exerted in smoothing the ruffled relations between the Faculty of the Medical Department of the University of the City of NewYork and its students.

The members of the Anthropological Society, at their meeting at Cooper Union yesterday, listened to an address entitled "From Barbarism to Civilization," which had previously been delivered by Major Powell of the smithsonian ...

ST. PAUL, Jan. 2.--The Railroad and Warehouse Commissioners were engaged to-day in hearing a complaint made by Spencer Co., Duluth grain dealers, against Inspector James. The gist of the matter, as far as could be ascertained, was that Spencer Co, had some wheat ...

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2.--Frank Gregory, the former proprietor of the Winter Garden, and one of the oldest and best known of liquor men in the West, drooped dead at an early hour this morning. He leaves a large family well provided for.
"J.K.B."--See report of public departments proceedings in to-day's TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 2.--Mr. Gladstone's telegram disclaiming the accuracy of the tranlation of his letter suggesting that the position of the Pope be made the subject of international arbitration has led to correspondence on the subject, which will appear in the Tablet to-morrow.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2.--All the flouring mills in this city excepting one closed down to-day under the agreement entered into by the Millers' Association at its late convention at Milwaukee. The exception is the Anchor Mill, which will also shut down as soon as it fills two or three important orders on hand. Under the agreement noted 250 mills in the Fall wheat bolt will either close down or run on half time during January.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Attorney-General Tabor has been asked all sorts of questions regarding the support of indigent soldiers, and marines, or their destitute families, under the law passed in 1887 regarding this subject. Yesterday he issued an exhanstive opinion, in which he shows that the statute did not intend to ...

A man may wear the most fashionably cut clothing, the latest shaped hat, and boots that are faultlees, but if his linen be either soiled or of poor quality the effect of the whole is lost. Many men who desire and spend money enough to be classed among the well dressed fail in just this particular.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 2.--A farmer near this city saw a man in the woods Monday, and later in the evening saw the man sitting by a fire that he had kindled. About 10 o'clock, on looking down the railroad, the farmer saw an object apparently on fire running at full speed, but it soon disappeared, and he thougnt nothing more about it.
The Park Commissioners gave permission yesterday for the opening of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the American Museum of Natural History two evenings in each week.

Tax Commissioner Edwin L. Parris writes to THE TIMES saying that his remark to Mayor Grant Tuesday was misunderstood. He did not tell Mr. Grant that he had done all he could to put him into office. He said he had done what he could to prevent his election.

DETROIT, Jan. 2.--The joint caucus of the Republican members of both branches of the State Legislature, which convened at Lansing in regular biennial session to-day, was held this evening for the purpose of nominating a candidate for United States Senator in place of ...
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2.--Michael Carney died yesterday in Waterbury at the age of 107 years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2.--Two subjects have engrossed the attention of politicians here to-day-- Gen. Harrison's speech at the Grand Army meeting last evening and the visit of Senator Frank Hiscock, who will arrive to-morrow noon.
The entries to the five races at Guttenborg to-day are as follows:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2.--There is a great commotion in the neighboring village of Liberty, on the Ontario and Western Railroad, over the domestic infelicities of Mr. and Mrs. Addison J. Clemente, and their contest for the possession of the Clements House, a valuable hotel property in a locality which is one of the most popular Summer resorts of Sullivan County.

MONTREAL, Jan. 2.--General Manager Dwight of the Great Northwestern Telegraph Company from Toronto held a conference this morning with Mr. Girouard, Queen's Counsel, solicitor for the company, in connection with the payment to the Montreal Telegraph Company of the 8 per cent. dividend.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 2.--There are troubled times ahead for the Pennsylvania liquor interests. Something more portentous than high license, and something more ponderous than either the license court or Law and Order League is now being systematically arranged to worry them in a comprehensive way.

Comrades of Lloyd Aspinwall Post, No. 600, G.A.R., have completed arrangements which assure a thoroughly enjoyable time for themselves and friends this evening at the Athenaeum, on One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street ...

WINNIPEG, Jan. 9.--Surveyor Ogilvie, whose arrival from Edmonton was reported two days since, reached here last night from the North Country, about 100 miles north of Fort Goodhorse, a Hudson's Bay Company post on Mackenzie River. Mr. Ogilvie fell in with Lord Lonsdale's party.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 2.--The State Waterway Commission made its annual report to the Governor to-day. The commission expresses itself as much pleased at the apparent disposition of Congress to deal liberally with needed waterway improvements in Minnesota.

The hospital collection returns from all sources, as made to the general Treasurer of the association, Mr. Charles Lanier, 17 Nassau-street, continue of the most encouraging sort. Almost none of the larger congregations have as yet brought in their offerings, as none are complete until absentees are heard from.

The distillers outside the so-called Whisky Trust are full of fight. The chief opponent is Henry Shufeldt Co. of Chicago. The firm has had an agency in this city for over seven years, doing an extensive export trade, especially in gin. J.H. Bird, its agent, at 21 Beaverstreet, said yesterday: "It is simply impossible for the trust to do anything with us.

Few changes were made at the beginning of 1889 in Wall-street firms. Marcus Mayer, the theatrical manager, becomes a member of the brokerage firm of H.I. Nicholas Co., McPherson Kennedy retiring. William Stewart Tod joins J. Kennedy Tod Co.
Following is a letter written by President J. Hampden Robb to Mayor Grant, at the latter's request, for views as to the disposition and development of the new park lands:

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 2.--Ever since the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company throw the Ithaca, Auburn and Western Branch of the Southern Central Railroad back on the hands of the Southern Central Company the latter has been looking around for a chance to get rid of the branch.
The New-Jersey Junction Railroad has completed a freight station just south of the bridge by which Newark-avenue, in Jersy City, passes over the railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--M. Thomas Sons sold at auction to-day $614,000 Ohio and Northwestern Railroad Company bonds. They were bought by the Investment Company of Philadelphia, which paid 60 for the block ofn $600,000--on which were overdue coupons from July, ...

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Speaker Cole has promised to give the State the best committees the Assembly has had in 50 years. He has overcome much of the pressure that has been applied to him for places by members and their friends who are not entitled to posts of honor by experience or ability.

A majority of the Aldermanic Committee on Bridges and Tunnels reported yesterday in favor of the adoption of the resolution to give permission to the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company to build a tunnel under East River and across the island under Forty-secondstreet. The report was laid over for the consideration at the next Board of Aldermen.

Milan Day Barnas of 618 Lexington-avenue wants a wife. Yesterday the following advertisement appeared in a morning newspaper: WANTED--The acquaintance of a young lady of vigorous health, medium in complexion, fond of home and friends, courageous, cheerful, reverent, by a well-educated young man; object, matrimony, Phi Beta Kappa, 618 Lexington-av., New-York City.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2.--The State added another to its oyster war victories this morning. Capt. Kerr, commanding the State sloop Helen Baughman, started to drive about 40 piratical vessels from the prohibited territory in Chester River.

BOSTON, Jan. 2.--The Massachusetts Legislature assembled to-day, and the only contest of moment over its organization was settled, at a session of the Republican caucus by the nomination of William E. Barrett for Speaker.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 2.--Some years ago Dr. L. M. Denslow, formerly connected with the Ballevue Hospital, New-York, and now a prominent physician of St. Paul, Minn., married the daughter of E.W. Smith, a wealthy sugar merchant ...
In the five races run at the Clifton track yesterday the winners were as follows:

ZANZIBAR, Jan. 2.--All the British traders have deserted Dar-es-Salam. Previous to their departure an attack was made upon the place by coast tribes. During the tight many of the insurgents were killed and much property was destroyed.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 2.--In a country like Canada, which observes many old-fashioned customs, particulary at this season of the year, the recent utterances of Senator Blair of NewHampshire seem like the mouthing of a person who has lingered too long at the shrine of Bacchus, or of one who should no longer be allowed to go at large unaccompanied by a nurse.

The second annual report of the Board of Electrical Control informs the Governor that the total length of trench excavated in this city for the laying of subways is 240,155 feet. The total construction of single duct for telephone and telegraph service is 2,287,880 feet, less 325,429 feet for distributing service and connections.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 2.--There are indications of another strike in the coke regions. The workmen's new scale, based on one-dollar-and-thirtyfive-cent coke, and providing for an advance of 4 cents in wages with every 10 cents advance per ton in the price of coke caused considerable comment among the coke operations to-day, and just what the result will be is a matter of conjecture.

Default was made yesterday by the South Carolina Railway on its second mortgage coupons. The second mortgage bonds have dropped 25 points during the last week and the income bonds have gone to a merely nominal quotation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--Upon the application of C.B. Wright, who holds $30,000 worth of the bonds of the Fairmount Coal and Iron Company, Judge Fell to-day appointed William M. Stewart Receiver of the company, which has been in default for 18 months upon its interest.

FLUSHING, Long Island, Jan. 2.--E.V.W. Rossiter, Treasurer of the New-York Central Railroad, was elected President of this village yesterday by his fellow-Trustees. Police Justice Clinton B. Smith was elected Clerk of the village.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 2.--The Rev. Albert Hayford Heath, D.D., Pastor of the North Congregational Church for 12 years, goes to Plymouth Church at St. Paul, Minn.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2.--The celebrated Kirkland divorce suit was decided by Judge Dennis today. The case has been a series of sensations. Over a year ago a young man named J. Graham Pearre distinguished himself by clambering ...

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court, in deciding that the actress Miss Margaret Mather must not act, except under the management of J.M. Hill, granted a stay until the case could be argued, in January, before the General Term.

PARIS, Ill, Jan. 2.--Lester Woods, 22 years old, was murdered two miles east of this city last night. The Sunday school of the district had a social gathering at the school house, and during the exercises a scuffle took place and ...

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--The report of the Superintendent, of Public Works on the canals at the State for the year ended Sept. 30, 1888, and on trade and tonnage of the canals for the entire year of 1888, shows a total expenditure of $742,263 for ordinary repairs and operating expenses of the canals.

Mayor Grant had a busy day yesterday. As soon as he arrived at his office, about 10 o'clock in the morning, visitors began to stream in and congratulate him. Among the more prominent of them were Col. Joel B. Erhardt, his Republican opponent in the campaign; ex-District ...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 2.--Another case of smallpox was discovered in the Onondaga Penitentiary yesterday, and this morning a quarantine was established over the entire institution.
LONDON, Jan. 2.--The steamship Danmark, (Dan.,) Capt. Knudsen, from New-York Dec. 15, arr. at Copenhagen to-day.
Katharine C. McKoon, dressmaker at 499 Fifth-avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Joseph Martin. She had been in business about saven years and had a good custom.

The cable summary of the Papal letter to American Bishops--coming, as it did, through English news agencies--ignored the more important of its features, and the extracts quoted were calculated to give the impression that the authority of American prelates was about to be superseded as far as the missionaries sent here to look after the wants of Italian immigrants were concerned.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2.--The Democratic Senatorial Convertion held here this afternoon to nominate a candidate for the seat made vacant by the death of Henry R. Low selected for the place by acclamation ex-Mayor Peter Ward of Newburg.

There is a remarkable agreement between the Democratic Governor of this State and the Republican Speaker of the Assembly as to the extent and threatening character of the practice of bribery at elections.

Eugene Boyle, a young bartender, lay dying yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital from a pistol wound in the abdomen, received during a brawl early in the morning at 1 Varick-place. Pasquale Maolso, an Italian builder, who hails from New-London, Conn., is a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Prison on suspicion of having shot Boyle.

DETROIT, Jan. 2.--Preparations are now being made on both sides of the river to recommence work on the great railroad tunnel under the St. Clair River at Port Huron. Early last year considerable preliminary work was done and $125,000 was expended, but, after two or three months, work was suspended, and has remained in that condition ever since.

SUAKIN, Jan. 2.--A parade was held here today by the Egyptian officers and men who had been especially commanded by the Khedive for the bravery displayed by them in the recent battle. Gen. Grenfell made an address and afterward presented the men with gratuities. The General will soon return to Cairo.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--To-day all the dies, numbering between 800 and 900, used during the year 1888 in the United States Mint, were destroyed, under the direction of Superintendent Fox, in the presence of the chief coiner and assayer.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--The annual report of the New-York State Soldiers and Sailors' Home for the year ended Sept. 30. 1888, shows the total number of inmates for the close of the year to be 1,061; average number present during ...
ST. PAUL, Jan. 2.--Somebody had said that Gen. Washburn is opposed to the inter-State commerce law, and ought not therefore to be a Senator from Minnesota.

The gloom which has hung over the Opera House for a few nights has passed away. The two tenors who succumbed to the intolerable fickleness of our climate are once more able to sing. One of them, Herr Perotti, made his reappearance last evening in the title role of Gounod's "Faust."

At the annual meeting of the New-York Historical Society last night the Executive Committee was directed to apply to the Legislature this session for several modifications in its charter. This is a preliminary step toward the new building, for which the society has ...

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 3.--Four young girls of this place have just completed a notable New Year's work by preventing an old man from being sent to the poorhouse. The names of the young girls are Geraldine Andrew, Jennie Williams, Louisa Stewart, and Norma Swan.

The committee appointed by the featherworkers to present the revised uniform price list to the manufacturers reported last night that Thomas H. Wood Co. had adopted it already, and that M.J. Taylor Co., E. Capel Sons, Depinna Son, and Joseph Kaufmann Co.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to day ordered a favorable report to be made upon the army staff nominations: Capt. Peter D. Vroom, Third Cavalry, to be InspectorGeneral, with the rank of Major, vice Farnsworth, deceased; Capt. Edward Hunter, First Cavalry, to be Judge-Advocate, with the rank of...

A dispatch from Albany yesterday announced that Adjt. Gen. Porter had issued an order disbanding the Eleventh Regiment. The order was by no means unexpected, for a ver since the quarrel that arose among the officers at the State Camp, last July, the regiment has become rapidly demoralized.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 3.--James H. O'Neil, deck hand, another of the unfortunates of the ill-fated steamboat John H. Hanna, died at the hospital this afternoon from the effects of his injuries.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3.--An aged German entered an up-town police station late last night and informed the Sergeant that he had just taken poison.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 3.--Thanks to the prompt and effective action of the National Bureau of Animal Industry, represented here by Inspector A.R. McLean, the outbreak of pleuro-pneumonia among the dairy cattle of...

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 3.--Another "deal" has fallen through and the new City Council has again failed to organize. The crowd outside the ralling which surrounds the seat of the City Fathers was even larger than on New Year's Night.
Mr. C.P. HUNTINGTON should visit Indianapolis without delay and lay before the President-elect his proposal for the repeal or nullification of the Chinese Exclusion act.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 3.--The exaggerated reports which have been sent from here regarding an epidemic of diphtheria in this city are entirely misleading. During the last month there were an unusual number of cases reported, but few of them were malignant, and the proportion of fatal cases has been much smaller than usual

LONDON, Jan. 4.--Sir R. D. Morier, the British Ambassador to Russia, has furnished to the press the correspondence that has passed between him and Count Herbert Bismarck in relation to the Cologne Gazette's charges.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 3.--Judge Cooley, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, passed through the city to-day on his way from Toledo to Washington. While at Toledo Judge Cooley held a conference with a number of the loading railroad managers in regard to paying commissions on tickets.

A meeting was held last night of the committees of the various scientific societies which have in charge the raising of a fund to erect a monument to the memory of John James Audubon, the celebrated ornithologist.
Sixteen members constitute a quorum of the Kings County Board of Supervisors. Only a dozen were present yesterday, and Supervisor at Large Quintard was compelled to adjourn the meeting.

Sergt. O'Toole of the Central Office with a squad of police made a raid laet last night on the gambling establishment known as the Volunteer Club, on the second floor of the premises, 70 East Twelfth-street, of which a man named Nichols is said to be the proprietor.
Miss Fannie Stebbins, daughter of James H. Stebbins, was married at noon yesterday to Herr Gottileb Rucker of Kial, Germany, at the residence of her parents, 20 East Thirty-seventh-street.
James W. Woods, an experienced diver employed by the Merritt Wrecking Company, while at work yesterday morning in the fore hatch of the French steamer Iberia--sunk off Rookaway beach--was drowned.

The Bolt and Nut Trust has practically gone to the wall. It was organized in 1868 and for a number of years was quite successful in regulating prices and wages also, until the labor organizations interfered.

According to the records of the Signal Service in the Equitable tower the past year was, meteorologically, the most remarkable one in the records of the Signal Service. For high winds, blizzards, warm June, cool July,...

Margaret Mather is drawing large audiences at Niblo's this week and she seems to be pleasing them. On Wednesday night she appeared as Juliet and last night she essayed the difficult part of Peg Woffington in the interesting comedy by Charles Reade and Tom Taylor.

Major J.W. Powell, chief of the United States Geological Survey and President of the American Aesociation for the Advancement of Science, lectured last night on "Human Evolution, its Scope and Limitations," before an audience which crowded the big hall of the Brooklyn Institute, in Washington-street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--There was a large attendance at the third day's meeting of the Colored Catholic Convention. Archbishop Eider of Cincinnati addressed the delegates, urging them to continue on in their good work. The commit tee appointed to wait upon the President reported...

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Jan. 3.--About three weeks ago H.C. Bigham arrived in the city, accompanied by his wife, and secured quarters at the Randall House. He was presumably a tourist. Bigham had a wealthy father in Baltimore.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 3.--Gov. Beaver has extended the respite of Samuel Johnson, under sentence of death for the murder of John Sharpless inDelaware County, from Jan. 16 to Wednesday, April 17.
SAN JUAN DEL SUR, Nicaragua, Jan. 3, via Galveston.--San Jose de Costa Rica was the scene on the night of Dec. 29 and the morning of Dec. 30 of a series of earthquake shocks of great severity.

LAREDO, Texas, Jan. 3.--Information reached this city to-day of a tragedy which occurred at San Luis Potosi, Mexico, on the night of Dec. 31 in which two Americans were killed. The details are related by passengers arriving over the Mexican National Road to-night.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 3.--The Favorite Stove Works, employing 300 men, has closed for the purpose of removing its entire plant to Piqua, Ohio. This change of position is made because of larger grounds, cheaper fuel, which is natural gas, lower taxes, and cheaper rent for workmen. They expect to take with them the greater number of their employes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 3.--This has been the greatest day for Indianapolis since Senator Quay came and went away "satisfied" with Gen. Harrison. Two United States Senators have been here at once, to say nothing of a lot of smaller fry, and great has been the excitement among the local politicians.

At yesterday's meeting of the Chamber of Commerce President Smith announced that a letter had been received from A.A. Low, inclosing one from C.P. Huntington, which dealt with the drawbacks of the Chinese Exclusion blll and urged the Chamber to take some action about it.

The prospects of horse railroad employes, both in this city and Brooklyn, to get their new agreements signed by the Presidents of the various railroad companies do not look very bright, and perhaps the leaders of the men do not expect that the railroad companies will accept the contracts without at least some modification of their terms.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 3.--John H. Neal of Poughkeepsie, aged 60, dropped dead in the reading room of the Ringland House this evening.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.--Ferd W. Peck of the Auditorium Association is to leave for the East next week on business connected with the big structure in which President-elect Harrison was nominated.

ASBURY PARK, Jan. 3.--Gen. E. Burd Grubb, Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic of New-Jersey, accompanied by his staff, visited C.K. Hall Post to-night and installed the following officers: Commander--Frank Herbert;...
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Jan. 3.--The Canada and St. Louis Railroad, which began operations Monday, recorded its first fatal accident yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 3.--This morning at 7 o'clock a dynamite and powder magazine at the Inman mines blew up. No one was injured, but the blacksmith's shop way smashed into kindling wood. The ground was felt to tremble at South Pittsburg, 15 miles away, and it was supposed to be abn earthquake shock.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 3.--A terrible disaster has happened at Sabumtschi, near Tiflis, in Georgia. A train became blocked in an immense snowdrift, and before aid could be sent 14 of the passengers perished from the intense cold, and 20 others were badly frostbitten. A relief party which started out to rescue the imperilled passengers lost their way and died in the snow.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 3.--News of the death of Miss Maria S. Pierson at her home on Bayou Bartholomew, in Ashley County, near the Louisiana border, under remarkable circumstances, was received here last night.

The Riparian Commissioners and the Joint Legislative Committee held a final meeting yesterday at Jersey City to receive propositions to fill in the Jersey City water front between the Central Railroad docks and Robbin's Reef.

To meet the needs of the city's growth the Tompkins-Avenue Congregational Church, although it had a substantial church structure at Tompkins-avenue and McDonough-street, Brooklyn, gave it up and built a larger one on the opposite corner.

The rumor that Hippolyte, the Haytian insurrectionist, was making efforts, through agents in this city, to buy a steamer which he could transform into a man-of-war took material form yesterday when it was announced that the iron steamship Madrid, now lying in the Erie Basin, Brooklyn, in good condition and ready for active service, had been sold for $60,000.

Weakness continued yesterday to rule in the stock market. Few things went up; many went down. The fluctuations were in no cases of any sensational interest, but the tendency toward the shading off process was so marked as to make erstwhile hopeful bulls feel a tritle discensolate.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3.--The Committee of Citizens which has in charge the midwinter carnival to be held in this city on the three closing days of January announced its programme last evening.

BOSTON, Jan. 3.--Judge Bolster of the Roxbury District Court was bombarded with tin ware to-day in open court. Minnie Pearson, an 18-year-old girl, was charged with a second offense of drunkenness.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 3.--The residence of Mrs. William Gerald was burned here yesterday. When the fire department arrived it was found that Mrs. Gerald, her son, aged 4, and a daughter, aged 6, were in the house.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--The President has sent the following nominations to the Senate: Solomon Claypool of Indiana to be United States Attorney for the district of Indiana; T. Carlos Jewett of Minnesota to be Commissioner in and for the District of Alaska, to reside at Sitka. Postmasters.--Francis A. Dowden, at Babylon, N.Y.; Robert E. Adkins, Kansas City, Mo. The vacancy in the Post Office at Kansas City was caused by the removal of the former Postmaster.

NORTH HANOVER, Mass., Jan. 3.--The stitchers at the shoe faotory of C. Groice Sons have quit work because of a reduction in wages.
The Sixth-Avenue Railroad Company has taken a stand with reference to "Labor" which every employer of labor would benefit the men in his employ as well as himself by imitating.

Wall-street was astounded yesterday by news from the West. Only a fortnight ago all the Western railway managers met and solemnly pledged themselves, one and all, to put up rates and to indulge in no more fights. Only two days ago the rates were put up.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3.--The Harvard Athletic Committee, at its meeting last night, voted to repeal that section of the regulations governing athletic sports which forbids any college athletic team to play or compete with professionals and to substitute a regulation making the aesent of the committee necessary to all contests arranged by any college athletic association.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 3.--Otto Lugger, State Entomologist, has made a report to the Governor. On the whole, his report as to the condition of affairs among the wheat growers of the Red River Valley is not encouraging. In Otter Tall County he found that the wheat had been injured more by rust than by frost.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 3.--A discovery which promises to be of the utmost importance to the Southern States has been made by Dr. C.F. Panknin of Charleston. It is not practicable at this time to give the details, but sufficient can be said to show the nature of the discovery and its value.

HAVANA, Jan. 3.--A telegram received here states that the American brig Addie Hale, Capt. Howes, foundered 35 miles from Cape San Antonio, and that the crew landed at that place. They afterward embarked on the schooner Amistad for this port.

LONDON, Jan. 3.--The English new year begins with a gruesome epidemic of murder, and murder literature, which fills the newspapers and forms the most frequent topic of conversation. The frightful murder and mutilation of a little boy at Bradford last week, with attendant atrocities ...

DETROIT, Jan. 3.--Gov. Luce sent his biennial message to the Legislature to-day. It is wholly devoted to State affairs, and shows the State to be in a highly prosperous condition. There is no debt not provided for by sinking funds, except something over $5,000,000 of perpetual...

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3.--Three bids of the construction of a superstructure of a lift bridge over the Erie Canal at Main-street, Rochester, were received by Superintendent of Public Works Shanahan to-day. The contract was let to the Hilton Bridge Construction Company of this city at $20,960.
The jewelry store of P.G. See of 23 Mainstreet, Yonkers, was entered by burglars early yesterday morning and $300 worth of jewelry, watches, and clocks was taken.

READING, Penn., Jan. 3.--Unknown persons placed dynamite on the Pennsylvania and Reading Railroad, in front of Maurer's store, Mahonoy Plane, early to-day, and then put a lighted fuse to it. The dynamite exploded with terrific force, breaking windows in many houses on both sides of the street and shattering the rails.
ALBANY, Jan. 3.--The Court of Appeals reconvened at 10 o'clock this morning for the purpose of consultation.

ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., Jan. 3.--This village has been in a state of great excitement for some time over charges preferred against John W. Gaskill, the village school teacher, by some of the prominent people of the village, who assert that Gaskill is unfit for his position.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 3.--To-day at Clinton a boiler in the hoop factory of Col. John Ashford exploded, instantly killing two sons of Col. Ashford and a negro, and fatally injuring Col. Ashford himself, who is now in a dying condition. A man named W.H. Britt was also seriously, and perhaps fatally, wounded.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 3, via Galveston.--The news of the "clerical rising in the City of Mexico," the Government has discovered, was first published in El Diario del Pueblo of Chihuahua. Sefior Francisco Ortiz republished the story at El Paso, and from that city it was telegraphed to the United States. The Government has taken steps to punish the originator.

Little Ernest Heider is lying on a cot in Bellevue Hospital, recovering from a severe attack of typhoid fever. He is a German lad, about 16 years of age. He speaks English fairly well, and tells an awful story of bardship and privation.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 3.--Col. A.E. Gordon, United States Marshal for New-Jersey and the editor and proprietor of the Times of this city, was stricken with paralysis this evening, and, though he has rallied, it is feared that he cannot recover.

A few members of the dramatic profession went to the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon to attend an odd matinee. Auctioneer Draper was announced to sell Dion Boucicault's plays to the highest bidder.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 3.--The United States Inspectors who are investigating the burning of the steamer Kate Adams have obtained evidence which satisfies them that 42 persons were lost instead of 14, as they reported several days ago. It now appears that 18 children were among the deck passengers and 10 of the boat's crew perished in addition to the victims already noted.

The Board of Electrical Control is criticised for permitting new electric wires to be strung overhead in streets where underground conduits have not yet been provided. Whether or not this criticism is just depends upon circumstances.

Several days ago the family of Capt. John N. Bruns of Arlington-avenue, Jersey City, missed some pieces of new silk and a diamond ring valued at $80. Suspicion attached to Annie Dale, a domestic in the family. Detective Holtic was put on the case.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 3.--There is good reason to believe that changes of an important nature in the Canadian Pacific management will soon occur. Rumor has already been busy over the matter, but little has leaked out concerning the plans of the company.

NEWBURG, Jan. 3.--The Steamer Norwich, with a tug helping her, passed Newburg this afternoon going south, with about a dozen loaded barges in tow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--The Secretary of the Treasary this afternoon accepted the following bond offers: Fours registered, $50,000 at 127 ; 4 s registered, $481,800 at 108 .

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.--Mr. Rice is having a hard time of it in the West with his prima donne. Fay Templeton deserted him here two weeks ago, and is now in France.

The will of Edmund H. Pryor, who lived in the town of New-Castle, Westchester County, has been filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court at White Plains. He left an estate worth $300,000. He left no widow, children, father, or mother.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 3.--At noon to-day Noah Stropp, a 13-year-old white boy, was killed at his father's home on Lepage-street. The manner of his death is most unusual. All the rear portion of his skull was blown away by a charge of water fired from an old army musket, a relie of the war.
ST. CATHABINES, Ontario, Dec. 3.--The Lincoln Pulp Mill, a frame structure, was destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is $30,000; insurance, $9,500. A man named John Boyle was burned to death.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 4--The people of Goldsborough, in Wayne County, are in a state at excitement about the action of the railroad officials competing for the traffic of negroes going South to work in the turpentine forests of South Carolina and Georgia.

CHICAGO, Jan 4.--The Zeta Psi boys continued their grand chapter meeting to day at Oriental Hall. In the morning there were reports from delegates upon the condition of their chapters. The fraternity has 3,700 members. Important changes in the constitution were considered at the afternoon session. Action upon most of the amendments was deferred until to-morrow.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 4.--The jury in the Carroll murder case this morning reported a verdict of manslaughter, and sentence was deferred until the 15 th inst.

BOSTON, Jan. 4.--The announcement of the a ndidacy of J. Edwin Addicks for the seat in the United States Senate from Delaware, now occupied by Eli Saulsbury, was received with incredulity in Boston, where he is President of the Bay State Gas Company and where his Winter residence is. He has never been suspected of entertaining political ambitions, and ...
The Executive Board of District Assemble No. 75, horse car employes of Brooklyn, had a long conference yesterday with President Lewis, of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, ...

A movement has been started in Pittsburg, Penn., which is expected to extend throughout the country, to make April 30, the centenary of the inauguration of George Washington as the President of the United States, a ...

MADRID, Jan. 4.--While the audience was leaving the Opera Theatre to-night, a bomb exploded with a tremendous report. Every one in the vicinity was thrown into a panic and great excitement prevailed for a time. No persons were injured, however, but buildings in the neighborhood were damaged.

The annual report of Gen. Austia Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, for the year 1888 contains much interesting matter. He announces with regret "that the prisons have distinctly and positively receded in condition and in their tendency during the last year."

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4.--Leon C. Duchesne, who was the Republican candidate for Congress in the Sixth District, has served notice of contest on Col. T.R. Stockdale for the seat in the Fifty-first Congress.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 4.--One of the men who aided in the murder of two contractors, one named McClave, in Pennsylvania a short time ago and robbed them of $14,000 has been arrested and has made a confession. He is an Italian and is known as "Red Nose Mike."
Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday listened to argument on a motion in the suit of John Keenan against Aqueduct Contractors ...
The Clinton Hall Association met yesterday at 17 Spruce-street and adopted a resolution to advertise for plans for a new structure to be ...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 4.--The hearing in the Andover heresy case given by ex-Gov. Robinson as Commissioner appointed by the Supreme Court to take evidence in the case brought by Prof. Egbert C. Smyth of Andover Theological Seminary to show that the late ...
The special committee appointed by the New-York Mercantile Exchange to report on the proper site for the new Appraiser's warehouses has sent a letter to the Secretary of the ...

W.P. Clagett, a young and active Produce Exchange broker, known among his fellowmembers as "Prince," name in for a large share of attention from them yesterday. He bore it with the patience of a man who realizes that he is a sufferer from a practical joke.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--James J. West, editor of the Chicago Times, and Joseph R. Dunlop, city editor of the same paper, were arrested late this afternoon on warrants sworn out by Police Inspector John Bonfield and Police Captain Michael Schaack, charging them ...

PANAMA, Jan. 4, via Galveston.--Great uneasiness prevails here regarding canal affairs, as no news has been received of any settlement having been effected. Work on the canal is being lessened daily, and its total suspension is feared.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 4.--The Pioneer Press learns of a riot at Seattle, Washington Terri tory, between Knights of Labor and the miners' ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 4--George A. Baker, one of the original stockholders of the Standard Oil Company, committed suicide in the Weddell House yesterday by taking a dose of morphine. Baker not long since was one of the millionaires of the town. High living was the cause of his ruin and consequent suicide. He leaves a widow and three children.
Steamship The Queen, (Br.,) Heeley, Liverpool and Queenstown 15 ds., with mdse. and passengers to F.W.J. Hurst.

SUAKIN, Jan. 4.--Gen. Grenfell and his staff sailed to-day on board the Damanhour. LONDON, Jan. 4.--Sir William Pearce, who died recently, left an estate valued at 1,250000. His will provides that the property should be divided between his widow and son.

Some excitement has been occasioned in Jewish circles by the publication in the secular press of reports of an alleged Christmas entertainment last Saturday night at the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum, at One Hundred and Thirty-sixth-street and Tenth-avenue.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 4.--Ben Hopkins, ex-Cashier of the late Fidelity National Bank, having received his pardon, arriven here from Columbus Penitentiary at 6 o'clook this evening. A hospital ambulance was in waiting for him at the station and it conveyed him to his home on Richmond-street. His spirits have greatly improved.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 4.--The Rev. Dr. George E. Reed Pastor of Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church in this city, has concluded to accept the Presidency of Dickinson College, Carlisle, Penn. The position was tendered him several months ago.

WINNIPEG, Jan. 4.--A judgement was rendered yestarday by Chief-Justice Taylor which has caused consternation in the province and which will be far reaching in its effects. Lieut.-Gov. Schultz obtained an injunction to restrain the city of Winnipeg from selliing his lands for taxes ...

George C. Magoun, the well-known Wallstreet banker, gave a dinner to two dozen of his friends at the Union League Club last evening The round table at which they sat was superbly decorated and the central floral piece was six feet in diameter.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4.--Valentine Cooper, a member of the Board of Water Commissioners, was found dead in his bed this morning from apoylexy.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 4.--Representatives of the baseball organizations of Galveston, Houston, Waco and Fort Worth met here today and formed a Texas State league for the coming season. Letters were read from Austin, Texarkana and Denison asking admission. A salary limit of $800 was agreed upon, with an extra salary of $125 per month for the manger.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted 4 per cent. registered bonds to the amount of $526,000 at 108 .

Among the artists who will assist Mr. William H. Sherwood at his concert, which will be given at Chickering Hall Jan. 15, are Miss Julia Waldron, Miss Ellie Long, Miss Burnham, and Mr. Ward Stephens. The programme will be most attractive.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--The Board of Managers of the Reading Railroad Company will meet on Monday for the purpose of examining the annual statement and deciding the question of the payment of interest on the preference bonds.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--It was reported in railroadcircles to-day that the Manitoba Railway Company had decided to make a decided innovation with the passenger conductors in its employ. It to the idea, so it is alleged, to raise the wages of conductors $50 a month, place them under $1,000 bonds, and provide for the forfeiture of those bonds in case the company proves any sort of crookedness.
CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 4, via Galveston.--The Government is considering a proposition to erect Federal buildings in the capitals of all the States and Territories.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--Charles M. Heald, General Freight Agent of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, has been elected President of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company. He has accepted the position, and to-night he left for New-York to enter upon his new duties.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 4.--The centennial reception of Kingston Lodge, No. 10, Free and Accepted Masons, was celebrated to-night in the rooms of that ancient order in this old historic city.

James R. Pitcher of Short Bills said yesterday that the movement to secure a more efficient service from the Hoboken Ferry corporation was growing more formidable daily. The agitation started by THE TIMES has aroused the long-suffering communities to take an active interact in the war.
Mrs. Greenhaus, a pretty German widow, game to Jersey City from Philadalphia seven years ago. She was accompanied by her husband, to whom she had been married in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Judge Baker delivered today a decision which is of interest to telegraph companies and their patrons. The decision was in a motion for a new trial by the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company in a suit brought against them some time ago by C.L. Lathrop Co.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 4.--An answer was filed in the Common Pleas Court to-day by Mahlon C. Martin, surviving Executor of Christopher Meyer, in the suit which was some time ago brought against Mr. Meyer by Albert Netter for the recovery of $80,000 as his share of the ...

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The Pall Mall Gazette, refer ring to the correspondence between Count Herbert Bismarck and Sir Robert Morier, the British Ambassador to Russia, in reference to the charges that the latter sent information to Marshal Bazaine of German military movements during the war of 1870, says it regrets ...

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4.--Since Jan. 1 cotton bagging has declined more than 1 cent, and the falling off has attracted general attention among buyers of this market. It was rumored that trouble in the combination had started the members of the trust to cutting, and that a heavy ...

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--It transpires that the meeting in Chicago last week of the prominent officials and stockholders of the Duluth and Winnipeg Railroad was for the purpose of forming a construction syndicate to provide means for the completion of the road. The movement was entirely successful, resulting in the ...

I understand that the Queen is desirous that Sir Theodore Martin should undertake to write an elaborate biography of the Emperor Frederick, on the same scale as his "Life of the Prince Consort." It may be hoped that the Empress will not be so injudicious as to confide this work to any Englishman, as she would give very great and justifiable offense in Germany by doing so.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The Senate Finance Committee has concluded that there is room for improvement in that part of the Tariff bill which fixes the duties upon stockings, hose, half hose, gloves, shirts, drawers, and other knitted goods, and so Mr. Allison asked to-day ...

RKD BANK, N.J., N.J., Jan. 4.--The officers of Arrowsmith Post, No. 61, G.A.R., were installed last night in the post, rooms by Past Post Commander Robert R. Mount. The officers are: Commander-- Henry S. White; Senior Vice-Commander--Charles Curtis; Junior Vice-Commander--William J. Sickles; ...

RACINE, Wis., Jan. 4.--J.I. Case yesterday sold the trotting horse James G., record 2:20, to A.J. Feek of Syracuse, N.Y., for $6,000. The animal was purchased for parties residing at Frankfort, Germany, and will be shipped to that country. James G. is a chestnut horse 15 hands high, was foaled in 1881, and was sired by William H. Godfrey of Dixon, Ill.
The Brewery Employes' Protective Association held an indignation meeting yesterday at Ledwith Hall, Third-avenue and Forty-fifth-street, to protest against the arrest of their President, ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 4.--Last Thanksgiving Day Flora C. Burrows, a widow 40 years of age and having four children, married a farmer 75 years old in the town of Northeast named Brown. Three days after the wedding she packed up her things and left him.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4.--Perth Amboy is as dark as Egypt every night, and no way has been found of securing lights for the streets of the city for some time to come. The city authorities entered into a contract some months ...

At the business meeting following the prayer meeting at Plymouth Church last night the members of the church were surprised to receive a letter from the Congregational Club asking them to appoint a committee to join with committees from other churches in furthering the work of church extension in Brooklyn.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 4.--The store of M. Stein, one of the largest merchants here, was closed by an attachment to-day. Bad collections and dull business are generally alleged to be the causes of the failure.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4.--The eviction of tenants on the Olphent estates, at Falcarragh, County Donegal, was continued to-day. The evictors went to the house of a tenant named Doogan, but found the place defended by a score of men armed with rifles, who had entrenched themselves behind the loopholed walls.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4.--The strange domestic history of Joseph B. Postlewaite, one of the leading musicians of the city, was disclosed yesterday shortly after his death. He lived on South Ninth-street with his family, and a few hours after his demise another woman with four children entered the house, stating that she was the only legal widow of Mr. Postlewaite.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4.--The inquest on the body of Mrs. Benson, who was shot by her husband, closed to-day, but the jury were enable to agree upon a verdict. The eight Englishmen were in favor of a verdict of justifiable homicide, as it was clearly shown that the woman had been guilty of infidelity, but the six French-Canadians held out for willful murder.

The distinguishing feature of the measure introduced into Congress at the present session for the sale of a part of the Sioux reservation is that it is not conditioned on that consent of the Indians which was required by the act passed at the previous session. But the graded prices provided by the act seem to be liberal.
Three wires of the East River Electric Light Company set on fire last night a telegraph pole of the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company standing in front of 68 First-avenue.

The Electric Sugar Refining Company, with headquarters at 69 Wall-street, has come to grief. Its shares, when sold at all, bring only nominal prices. Its stockholders are in doubt whether their investments are completely wiped out or not.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 4.--When Gov. Beaver reiterated in an interview published to-day what he had said in his message, that Message Clerk Taylor of the last House had so delayed the State Revenue bill of 1887 with its million-dollar tax contingent, he only stirred up John B.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--A report was current here to-day that the market was flooded with Milwaukee and Omaha mileage, and that brokers were selling it freely. This would enable those roads through the brokers to do the bulk of the business at a rate low enough to "freeze out" competitors, for the first-class rate would be about $8.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4.--There is a decided falling off in the receipts of oysters at present and a rise of from 5 to 8 cents in the price per bushel. A good grade of oysters sells at from 65 to 70 cents per bushel.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4.--A special to the American from Lineborough, a small village on Mason and Dixon's line, says that a band of incendiaries has been at work in that region during the last two months. So far seven barns have been burned. Six of them were insured in the Cordorus Insurance Company.

There were no developments yesterday in the newly-declared passenger rate war. The Missouri Pacific and the Rock Island Companies continued to lay upon each other the responsibility for the Kansas City cuts.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 4.--A.J. Alexander, Spring Station, Ky., has bought of the estate of R.B. Conklin, New-York City, the brown stallion King Wilkes, sire of Oliver K., by George Wilkes, dam Massie, by Brignoll. The price was $15,000.

Capt. Louverson of the bark Kate Carnie, who, with his newly-made bride on board, sailed from Brunswick, Ga., for Rotterdam, Dec. 1, had anything but a pleasant wedding tour. The couple, with the nine men forming the bark's crew, were brought to this port yesterday by the bark Bella Weoster, having abandoned their own vessel in midocean Dec. 16.

Capt. S.S. Brown, the Pittsburg turfman, has engaged Martin Bergen as his first jockey for next season. Bergen's riding at the NewJersey tracks has attracted general attention, and it was doubtless upon his showing at the minor courses that Capt. Brown signed with him.

HELENA, Montana, Jan. 4.--The records of the dividend-paying mines of Montana for the last year exceeds that of any previous year. The total amount was over $3,300,000 for the 12 months of 1888, which is over one-fourth of all dividends paid by the United States and Mexican mines for the same period.

After two unsuccessful attempts to hold a meeting the commission appointed to revise the exciso laws met yesterday morning in the Law Library. This was for the convenience of the Law Committee, which has not yet completed its work, and which caused the postponement of the meetings that were to have been held on Wednesday and Thursday of this week.

WASEKA, Minn., Jan. 4.--David Irwin, aged 115 years, a resident of this county, died yesterday and was buried to-day. He was acquainted with President George Washington and other statesmen of his time, and served in the war of 1812. He was widely known.

Ski-running, Scandinavian sport, is becoming popular in Minnesota. The performer slides down hill on long wooden skates, or foot toboggans, and at a prepared jolt makes a leap into space. Ninety-five feet is the longest ski jump on record is Norway. It may be remarked that a ski jump does not take the performer sky high.
BOSTON, Jan. 4.--J. Edward Addicks, President of the Bay State Gas Company, arrived in Boston to-day and confirmed the report that he had succeeded in placing in London a loan for $12,000,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Dr. Chalmer C. Prentice of Norwalk, Ohio, recovered a verdict for $10,000 before Judge Gresham, in the Federal Court, today, against the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad Company. Dr. Prentice sued the company for alleged false arrest and imprisonment Oct. 12, 1886.
LONDON, Jan. 4.--A deputation headed by Lord Armstrong visited Lord Salisbury to-day to urge the adoption by the Government of a comprehensive scheme for the defence of the British mercantile ports.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 4.--Two men entered the place of Charile Sing, a Chinese laundryman, on West Jersey-street, the evening, and while one held the Chinaman the other broke ...
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--Max Goldberger, the South-street clothing dealer who was recently convicted of murder in the second degree in ...

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4.--The Colorado rate war is attracting the attention of all the local railway men. The Missouri Pacific denies making the first cut, and its General Passenger Agent says that the Chicago, Kansas and Nebraska made it. Whether it was acting under a misapprehension of facts or with malice aforethought remains to be seen.

Israel J. Merritt, Jr., of the Merritt Wrecking Company, was of the opinion yesterday that the death of Diver James W. Woods while at work under water on the wreck of the Iberia, Thursday, was due to Woods's own carelessness.
HARTFORD, Jan. 4.--Gov. Bulkeley has appointed Samuel O. Prentice of this city to the position of Executive Secretary. This is the most important of the personal appointments made by the Governor.

It is the custom nowadays to talk about the rudeness of women to women, not alone in the big stores, but also in the cars and streets. There happen to be once in a while exceedingly pleasing exceptions to the rule. One of these occurred a few days ago in a Fourth-avenue ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--War is by no means to be regarded as a thing only of the past, and Senator Blair has just expressed the opinion that it ought to be a thing of the immediate future for the United States, "in the interests of peace" and the acquisition of Canada.

The experiment made some five or six years ago of growing German carp as a food fish in American waters has turned out a great success and the cultivation of that fish has taken its place among the fish industries of the country.

The family of John Wanamaker, Philadelphia's noted merchant, are all away in Europe, and Mr. Wanamaker is so lonely and downcast in consequence that Logan C. Murray, President of the United States National Bank, gave a dinner in his honor at the Union League Club last night for the expressed purpose of cheering him up.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 4.--John J. Cooney is a member of the Board of Education here and an ex-Alderman. He has been a hotel keeper, and is now engaged in various business pursuits. This afternoon he was arraigned before Recorder John Hussey, charged with grand larceny., Ceoney, with A.H. Lawitch, was engaged in the grist-mill business. Jointly then gave a mortgage on the mill building to Margaret Cooney, wife of the accused man.

A fire started about 1:15 this morning in the five-story building, 131 Bowery, and soon enveloped the building in flames. Three alarms were sent out in rapid succession, and the firemen were promptly on hand. The ground floor is used by Patrick Farley as a liquor store, and it is thought the fire started there. Much alarm was felt, as large tenements adjoin the building, and the elevated road was threatened.

A lumber merchant was discussing, a day or two ago, the introduction of California redwood into the trade of the East and its extraordinary growth in popularity. "Six years ago," he said, "this wood was comparatively unknown to the general trade.

HARRISBURG, N.Y., Jan. 4.--A beer hunt up here in the woods of Lewis County on the 1st day of January is a rare thing, because the good old-fashioned Winters of the Black River country usually set in in November.

Foreign creditors of Henry Lewie, importer of diamonds, late at 120 Chambersstreet, are trying to get their money, but so far have been unsuccessful. Several of the European creditors have sued him for past due accounts and judgments have been entered against him aggregating $27,239, in favor of ...

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The steamship Llandaff City, (Br.,) Capt. Gere, from New-York Dec. 23 for Bristol, passed Brow Head to-day. The steamship Otlanto, (Br.,) Capt. Rippeth, sid. from Hull for New-York to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 4.--The Standard Oil Company, which is to establish a distributing station and refinery in this city, has also purchased land in Waterbury for a similar purpose. The station in this city will have food water frontage and railroad location.
New-Yorkers are adopting the Southern fashion in a modified way of using finely-bred mules as a substitute for horses for drawing phaetons and smaller vehicles in the Park.

READING, Penn., Jan. --Seldom has a community been so alarmed as are the country people along the line of Berks and Lehigh Counties, where the two counties join and where diphtheria rages in such a violent epidemic form. Nothing like it has ever affected a similar stretch of country in this section with such fatal results.

As it was growing dark yesterday afternoon longsheremen at work on Pier 35 North River, at the foot of Franklin-street, noticed a man about 45 years old take two briks from a pile, and, placing them in his pocket, spring into the river.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 4.--Early Wednesday morning the barn of W.R. Lockwood was fired by an incendiary and burned wish contents, consisting of 15 cows, 20 tons of hay, and a number of wagons, the loss amounting to over $2,000, which is partly covered by insurance.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 4.--The strikers tried to compel men at 11:20 to-day to quit work. The police charged them and did some clubbing. The men dispersed. This afternoon about 400 men held a meetingg at Rice's Point to decide on a plan for future action. They were angry over the interference of the police and threaten violence.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 4.--One of the biggest land deals on record has been made with the Brazillian Government by New-York, Pittsburg, and Washington capitalists.

Walter S. Woodbury, a well-known blind peddler, was burned to death yesterday morning in his room on the top floor of the four-story lodging house at 40 City Hail-place. He retired at about 1:30 o'clock, and soon afterward a strong odor of smoke awoke the occupant of the adjoining apartment, who arose and, going into ...

WINNIPEG, Jan. 4.--Litigation will be shortly commenced over the bill incurred for the troops at the railway crossing during the late riot. The Dominion Government refuse to pay, and insist that winnipeg must foot tho bill. The city claims that, inasmuch as the troops were called out by three magistrates in the employ of the Canadian Pacific, it will not pay, particularly as there was no necessity for the troops.

Mr. and Mrs. A.L. Felten on Thursday night celebrated their golden wedding at their home, 1,723 Gratz-street. Mrs. Felten is the last of five granddaughters of George Esher, who was a drummer boy in the Continental Army at the battle of Germantown, to celebrate her golden wedding.

LONDON, Jan. 4.--A very remarkable ball was given at the Hotel Metropole to-night. It was not only remarkable in size and lavish expenditure, the cost being 8,000, but it furthermore punctuated strongly the gradual rise of finance in England over the old aristocracy.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--H.C. Barnabee, the veteral comedian of the operatic stage, said to-day; "My first idea on reading of the proposal to bar out foreign actors was that it was right and should be done. But my sober view of it is that it is nonsense and all wrong.

ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 4.--Commander P.F. Harrington, Commandant of Naval Cadets, delivered to-night before the Naval Institute here the fifth lecture of the series upon "The Ram as a Naval Weapon." In a former lecture the use of the ram as opposed to the gun vessel had been discussed.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 4.--The dead body of M. Moses Williams was found to day on the roadside just out of Wrightsville. It was absolutely riddled with shot. He had been too attentive to the wife of a neighbor, Mrs. James Johnson, and as Johnson is missing he is regarded as the murderer.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 4.--A desperate but unsuccessful attempt to escape from the State Criminal Insane Asylum of this city was made to-night by five insane criminals. The attempt occurred while most of the attendants were at supper.
Ex-Coroner Henry Woltman was taken to Ballevue Hospital Thursday night suffering from menia. He had an attack of the same kind about two years ago.

At the Amberg Theatre last evening Mr. August Junkermann appeared here for the first time this season. The series of performance given by him at the Thalia Theatre last year made this German comedian not only well known but well liked in this city, and a host of old ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. Capt. James H. Gageby, Third Infantry, has been granted four months' leave of absense. Major William E. Waters, Surgeon, line been granted an extension of leave of abence for two months.

The troubles among the Tammany Hall man in the Sixteenth Assembly District, which nearly caused a riot at the primary election last Saturday night, are likely to be settled. The General Committee of the district was organized last night.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 4.--Last Spring Thomas Stone, a teamster, was bitten by a little dog that he picked up in the street. The dog then bit Stone's horse, which died shortly afterward.

NEW-YORKERS who at present have many of their out-of-town friends visiting them may take the latter on a very profitable trip of sightseeing by going to One Hundred and Fifty-firststreet and Eighth-avenue. There the elevated railway has its coal stores.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--Proposals for $260,000 Water Department bonds, payable in 30 years and bearing 4 per cent interest, were opened by the Council Committee on Ways and Means in the presence of Mayor Smith and Controller Roche yesterday. There were 15 bids in all, must of them from St. Paul and Minneapolis banks and banking houses of Chicago, NewYork, and Boston.
CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 4.--The Constitutional Convention reassembled this morning. Many amendments were prepared and laid over.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--By far the most important suit that has been instituted in the State of Minnesota for many years was filed yesterday with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court. The offense charged in the complaint is one of long standing, and every effort will be strained to the utmost to secure a conviction.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4.--Counterfeit money is being circulated here. Arthur Scullion was arrested by Detectives Areand and Trempe, on St. Catherine-street, on a charge of circulating a five-dollar Confederate States bill. The detective had placed his private mark upon the bill a week previously and traced it to the prisoner.

After drooping dismally all day the stock market braced up in the closing hour of business yesterday, put on a better face, and rallied prettily. The coverting of short contracts produced the rally, whose figures left the market showing a material net gain for the day.

SALEM, Mass., Jan. 4.--This evening the Rev. Fields Israel was found dead in the study of his church, the First Unitarian, sitting in his chair with his throat cut. He committed suicide in a ilt of temporary insanity, having been unable to sleep, and was unsettled mentally since the burning of the steamer Maryland, on which he was a passenger and had a narrow escape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The bill to incorporate the Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua was passed to-day in the House of Representatives, with several amendments already adopted in Committee of the Whole, and has gone to the Senate. It will now fall into the hands of a conference committee, and its fate will ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--In accordance with the arrangement made yesterday the Grievance Committee of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers appeared at the general offices of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company this morning for a further conference with the officers of the road in regard to the proposed settlement of the strike.

DETROIT, Jan. 4.--James L. Babcock, the Chicago young man whose bachelor uncle died a few months ago near Ann Arbor, has now taken up his residenoe at that university town. By the conditions of his uncle's will he was to receive $500,000 it he marries within five years; otherwise the money goes elsewhere.

HARTFORD, Jan. 4.--Edward O. Wolcott, who has received the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Colorado, is a native of this State. He was born at Eufield, being the son of the Rev. Samuel Wolcott, who was, 40 years ago, one of the prominent Congregational clergymen of the State. Mr. Wolcott is a lawyer by profession. In 1883 he received the degree of A.M. from Yale College.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4.--The facts concerning the ownership of the Baltimore Baseball Club were made public to-night for the first time.

No intelligent citizen of this State can read the annual report of the Superintendent of Prisons without a sense of shame at the disgraceful manner in which the Legislature has dealt with the subject of prison labor.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 4.--"There will probably be no ice palace and carnival this year," said President VAn Slyko to-day. Mr. Van Slyke says that at the meeting this afternoon the project was formally abandoned.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--A sewer which was in course of construction for the purpose of draining the Belmont Driving Track was being inspected by the contractor, Jonn W. Buckley, President Frank Bower of the Belmont Association, and 10 other people this afternoon, whom it caved in.
GRAND FORKS, Dakota, Jan. 4.--Thomas Hogan came to Dakota from Albany, N.Y., two years ago. He left his wife and child behind and became addicted to drink and went down ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The members of the Colored Catholic Congress called at the White House to-day and paid their respects to the President. Mr. Robert L. Ruffin of Boston made an address to the President, in which he thanked ...

The reported sale of the iron steamship Madrid to agents of Hippolyte for war purposes in Hayti was practically confirmed yesterday. She had not taken out a Custom House register, and the persons who bought her were determined to still maintian the secrecy of their movements.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 4.--Ex-Senator Windom was asked to-day about the possibility of his being a candidate for the Senate. He said that he would not under and circumstances be a candidate. So far as his visit here at this time has anything to do with politics, he would work and talk in favor of Gen. Washburn's candidacy.
Gen. John G. Parke of West Point, is at the Brevoort House. Congressman Edward Burnett of Massachusetts, is at the Hotel Brunswick.
