NEW-BURNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4.--The temperance people last night began their fight for local option with a mass meeting in Temperance Hall at which many local optionists, some of than strong party men and not prohibitionists, made speeches. The meetings will be conducted all over the country from now till election day, and the temperance men have strong hopes of carrying the election.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 4.--Burglars entered the residence of James E. Ballard Wednesday night and were frightened away. They carried off a quantity of silver and clothing. They also entered the parsonage of the Episcopal Church, where they found more silver and one of the Rev. Mr. French's sermons, which they took away.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 4.--Nathan C. Blanchard, a wealthy farmer of Aurolius, committed suicide by hanging this morning.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 4.--The New-York Central is to build in this city one of the handsomest stations on the road. The station will be of Buffalo pressed brick, trimmed with light Medina gray sandstone, with a tower, an antique chimney, and Bangor dark blue slate roof.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 4.--The steamer Providence of the Fall River Line left here to-night with a very sick man on board, Isaac Bell, ex-Minister to the Netherlands.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 4.--It was discovered yesterday that several houses on the Snell lands, from which settlers have been evicted, have been almost totally wrecked. The windows were broken, sashes and frames out up, doors and sills sawed through, and other serious damage done. Snell says it is the work of river land settlers or sympathizers.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 4.--The Texas Legislature meets Tuesday, Jan. 8. The House will have 54 farmers, 24 lawyers, 4 or 5 merchants, and the remainder doctors, wool growers, and stockmen. The Legislature, it is understood, is in full sympathy with the Railroad Commission.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5.--The Rev. John Rose has been Pastor of St. Paul's Chapel, Crownsville, and St. Stephen's Church, Millersville, Md., for the past six years. DEADWOOD, Dakota, Jan. 6.--The Deadwood and Lead City chartered toll road has enjoined the Deadwood Central Railway and brought suit against it for $50,000 damages. He is of the opinion that eight clubs in the league are quite enough. The Toronto club yesterday released Connotis.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Jan. 9.--The challenge made recently by A.C. Owen of this city to run any man in the United States of his age (79) a quarter or one-eighth of a mile foot race for from $500 to $1,000 a side is about to be accepted by John Bolton, former proprietor of the Bolton House of Sheffield. Both men are well preserved, and the match will be one of the most unique on record.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 10.--Latest advices from Congressman James Laird say that he is suffering from softening of the brain, that there is no longer any question that his deep-seated melancholia is developing into insanity, and that he is growing more morbid and morose every day. WICHITA, Kan., San. 11.--J.W. Cooke and a posse pursued a hand of horse thieves along the bank of the Canadian River Wednesday and killed two of them. At the rendezvous of the theives a book was found which contained a memoranda of the murder of Jacob Baughman, 12 miles from Zanesville, Ohio, Oct. 17, 1863. The writer and two others murdered Baughman with an axe, and robbed him of $1,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 11.--The mission of Lieut.-Col. Walton and the committee from the Eleventh Regiment to this city proved fruitless, and the gentlemen returned to New-York this evening without having accomplished anything. Gov. Hill would not listen to their appeal for a revocation of the order disbanding the regiment in the absence of the Adjutant-General, and as that official did not return to the city matters remain as when the order was promulgated.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12.--Baltimore has more saloons per capita that any Eastern city, and to-day the Grand Jury reported upon the liquor question. Seven favored high license; five brought in a minority report favoring prohibition. ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 12.--The White Cap epidemic has broken out in Ithaca. A house situated at the inlet was visited last night by unknown parties who painted red crosses on the door and posted a notice warning one of the inmates to leave. It is said that the warning had the desired effect, and that, acting on the hint, the threatened individual left town to-day.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 12.--The body of the Rev. W.L. Parker, Rector of Christ Episcopal Church of this city, who mysteriously disappeared on Nov. 30, St. Andrew's Day, was found on the lake shore near here this morning. The violent gale of Wednesday brought the body to the surface. It is now certain that the unfortunate man, who constantly gave to the needy more than he could afford, committed suicide to escape his creditors.

A meeting of creditors of Joseph A. Long, dealer in furniture in Worcester, Mass., was held in Boston yesterday. The investigating committee reported the liabilities to be $18,383, and the nominal assets, $17,081. An assignment has been made to James Boyd. After being in session over three hours the meeting adjourned without having fixed on a basis of adjustment. Mr. Long will go into insolvency.
Wheat pursued its downward path again yesterday and the Produce Exchange bears were in high feather. For May delivery it opened here at $1.02 , or on a level with Saturday's closing quotation.

Joseph Rothschild, a crockery merchant of 522 Sixth-street, died last night of poisoning by carbolic acid, which he took with suicidal intent. He was 61 years old, and had twice attempted to kill himself when despondent on account of an attack of apoplexy and the opinion of his physician that he would have a second and fatal stroke before long.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--The residence of S.W. Lamson, a Board of Trade broker, was seriously damaged by fire yesterday morning, and Lottie Erickson, a domestic, was suffocated by smoke.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 14.--The twentyseventh session of the State Legislature convened here at noon to-day. The House organized by electing the Hon. Brice B. Hudgins Speaker.

SEATTLE--Washington Territory, Jan. 14.-- Register Baird of the Land Office has rendered a decision in the case of Frank Burns, Jr., of Baltimore, who attempted to file upon 120 acres of tide land in the harbor, basing his application upon what is known as Valentine scrip.
The police were very active yesterday in searching for Leroy F. Sheppard of Utica. He is represented as 45 years old, 5 feet 9 inches high, with white hair and dark mustache.

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 14.--After a tedious trial of six days in the County Court of Greensville, Waiter Harris, a negro, was convicted on Saturday of murder in the first degree. The court postponed passing sentence of death until to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--Capt. Thomas Sharp, Seventeenth Infantry, has been granted leave of absence for six months. Major Tully McCrea, Fifth Artillery, has been relieved from duty in the Department of the Columbia and ordered to duty in the Division of the Atlantic.

Among the bills submitted to the Legislature by the Railroad Commissioners is one relating to the crossing of highways at grade. It is not a new bill, but is one of those sent to the Legislature last year, not one of which was passed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 14.--The Long Branch Athletic Association will open its new track on July 1. Stock to the amount of $20,000 has been subscribed for, the association's indebtedness has been paid off, and there is a large balance in the treasury. George W. Brown has been elected President of the association, Philip Daly, Sr., Vice-President, C. Asa Francis Secretary, and A.C. Newing Treasurer.
TRENTON, Jan. 14.--In the Assembly to-day Judson C. Francois, the new Hudson County member, was sworn in. The Speaker deferred announcing committees until to-morrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 14.--The case of J. Tallman Budd, who was convicted in the Superior Court of Erie County for violating the provisions of the Grain Elevator bill, will be argued before the Court of Appeals on Wednesday. District Attorney Quinby of Erie is in town to represent the people, and Spencer Clinton will represent the defendant. This is the first case of the kind, and is attracting widespread attention.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Jan. 14.-- The Coquelin-Hading Company closed last night the first week of their engagement at the Nacional Theatre. They played all the week to large and enthusiastic audiences. They will remain here until the 24th of this month and sail on the 25th for Havana.

WABASH, Ind., Jan. 14.--Henry A. Strohm, son of Abraham Strohm of New-Paris, who was last year captured and held prisoner by cannibals on the Island of Gaun, one of the South Sea group, has been heard from. The young man is now on his way home.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--By the fall of an elevator at the W.A. Wood Mowing Machine Works, at Hoosick Falls, this morning William Carroll and Octave Boseley were killed and Thomas Haren and Vego Jensen seriously injured. The men were employed at the works. The elevator was intended for freight only.

ALBANY, Jan. 14.--The Electoral College of 1888 met in the Senate Chamber at noon to-day and deposited the official ballot of the State of New-York for Benjamin Harrison of Indiana as President and Levi P. Morton of New-York as Vice-President.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra will be heard in a programme wholly made of orchestral music at Steinway Hall to-night.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee for 1889 held its first meeting at Jefferson Hall, Brooklyn, last night. The only fight was over the election of a Recording Secretary, and in that the contest was not at all heated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The Secretary of the Navy has issued instructions to Rear-Admiral Kimberly, commanding the Pacific station, to proceed in the Trenton to Samoa for the purpose of protecting American interests on that island.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 14.--Two years ago the Wilkinson Brothers, bankers, failed for over $500,000, owing large sums to New-York creditors.
The Architectural League of New-York held their third annual banquet at Morello's restaurant last evening. Over 100 members were present.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 14.--The water tubes of a locomotive on the Pennsylvania Railroad blew out to-day while the engine was standing at Allaire Station, just south of this place. The fireman, Albert Vose, was thrown a distance of over 40 feet, down a steep embankment, and into a brook. He was terribly scalded and injured internally. Traffic was delayed for some time by the accident.

The session of the Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge yesterday had more than ordinary interest. Mayor Grant was present, and was introduced all around. Controller Myers was also in attendance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 14.--An east-bound passenger train on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio main line ran into a broken section of a west-bound freight train at 3 o'clock this morning five miles east of Akron.
BERLIN, Jan. 14.--The Landtag was opened to-day. The Emperor in his speech opening the session declared that all the foreign relations of the country were friendly.

The bulls redeemed a good many of their promises yesterday. There was not exactly a riot on the Stock Exchange because of the anxieties of the brokers and traders to buy up everything all at once, but there was a healthy buying tendency shown all day, and closing quotations generally showed net advances--not large, but still advances.

Pedro Berganzoli Pedrazzi, an Italian fresco painter, aged 77 years, was found dead in his rooms at 226 East Thirty-fifth-street yesterday morning by his housekeeper, Mrs. Mary Granger. He had hanged himself from his bedroom door and had been dead for some hours.

A Mexican mustang ran away yesterday afternoon at Forty-second-street and Ninthavenue, and in his wild career knocked down and injured four persons and was so badly injured himself that his owner was compelled to have him killed.

The Harlem Democratic Club decided last night not to be incorported. A majority of the members who attended the meeting were of the opinion that if it were incorporated some person, overcome by the heat of partisanship in the heighth of a campaign and displeased by the policy advocated by it, might drag the club into court on some pretext and so weaken its influ ence as well as increase its expenses.

The Board of Medical Officers convened at Philadelphia for the examination of applicants for appointment as Assistant Surgeons in the navy has been ordered to meet at the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, April 1, and to remain there until the following October. The change is made to enable students at the New-York and Brooklyn hospitals to be examined by the board without the expense of leaving their homes.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The eleventh annual convention of the National Guard Association, State of New York, which assembled here today in the armory of Company B, Tenth Battalion, was uncommonly well attended, every military organization in the State, with the exception of the First Brigade, New York City, and the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, being represented.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.--Edward De Veaux Morrell of 506 South Broad-streat to-day took out a marriage license for himself and Louise Bovier Drexel of 1,503 Walnut-street. Mr. Morrell was born at Newport, R.I., on Aug. 7, 1862. Miss Drexel, daughter of the late Francis A. Drexel, was born in Philadelphia on Oct. 5, 1864. The wedding takes place to-morrow at the cathedral.

All prospect of an agreement as to racing dates between the Brooklyn and American Jockey Clubs is past. They will both race on Memorial Day, the American Jockey Club having announced its dates as from May 30 to June 13 inclusive. Brooklyn will probably close its Spring meeting on May 30.

A banquet will be given at Delmonico's to-night, under the auspices of the American Protective Tariff League, at which some of the most prominent of the Republican stump orators who took part in the recent campaign will grow eloquent again over the various sub-divisions of the party shibboleth.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--W.H. Dixon, Assistant General Passenger Agent of the Milwaukee, has received orders to dispense with his "street men," that is, the employes who stand on the side walks and solicit business from pedestrians.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--Mr. Greene, who is apparently not a bit discourged by his failure of last year, poppod up serenely in the Assembly to-day with his little bill to incorporate the New-York and New-Jersey Railroad Bridge Campany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Neither Democratic nor Republican Senators had anything material to add to-day to the debate which began on Monday on the Vest amendment, to substitute salt for attar of roses on the free list of the pending tariff bill.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 16.--Rumor has had it for some time that a divorce suit, involving two well-known families, would soon be upon the records of the courts of Allegheny County. The rumor has proved correct, as Carrie B. Coleman has entered suit for divorce against her husband, William H. Coleman.

The colored cartoons by Mr. Louis C. Tiffany, which were recently described in this journal among the exhibits at the Architectural League, are not for the building to be erected on the corner of the Yale campus, but for the new library.

Frank R. Lawrence, Grand Master of Masons in the State, said yesterday that the indebtedness of the fraternity was paid off and that the yearly revenues of the Temple, $40,000, will now be devoted to the erection and maintenance of the proposed Asylum for the Widows and Orphans of New-York State Masons.

BERLIN, Jan 16.--In accordance with a command of Emperor William the Reichsanzeiger today publishes the indictment that was found against Prof. Geffcken in order that the people may be enabled to form their own judgment regarding the administration of justice in Germany.

John Rourke of Woodstock and Michael Fortunate of One Hundred and Sixty-fifthstreet and Tenth-avenue, two contractors on the new aqueduct, were fined $10 each by Justice White in the Barlem Police Court yesterday on a charge of reckless driving.

Half a dozen young men on the west side of the city about six weeks ago started the Independent Democratic Ballot Reform Club, and established its headquarters at 533 Eighthavenue. They now have an organization which will make itself felt at the next election.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 16.--In joint session of the General Assembly to-day the election of Authony Higgins as United States Senator was completed.

SOUTHOLD, Long Island, Jan. 16.--New-Suffolk, a small village near here, is greatly disturbed over the sudden disappearance of Thomas Conway, a young man employed as clerk in one of the village stores.

BOSTON, Jan. 16.--Edmund Woods, senior member of the firm of Henry Woods, Son Co., dealers in paints and oils, who were reported yesterday as having failed, states that the firm has only suspened payment temporarily. Arrangements have been made whereby business will be carried on as usual. He claims the suspension was brought about by certain damaging reports as to their standing circulated by an agency.
R.B. Angus of Montreal is at the Hotel Brunswick.

HANNIBAL, Mo., Jan. 16.--The developments in the Stillwell murder mystery are assuming a very sensational phase, and nothing else is talked of but the arrests made late last night. About a month ago Amos J. Stillwell, one of the oldest and wealthiest citizens of the city, was killed in his bed with an axe, and the motive for the crime was supposed to be robbery.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 16.--There is no sign yet of the mail steamer Sarmatian from Liverpool. She is now 12 days out, and it is thought some mishap has befallen her.

Little Tommy Russell, in his character of Lord Fauntleroy, again entertained a crowded audience at the Broadway Theatre yesterday afternoon, the prominent feature of which was a band of 175 poor children, who occupied excellent seats in the balcony on invitation of Manager Frank W. Sanger.

J.J. Powell of Birmingham, England, arrived on the Gallia yesterday and is stopping at the Metropolitan Hotel. He has come here to investigate the affairs of the Electric Sugar Refining Company, both in his own interest and in that of other stockholders. He has retained counsel here, but beyond this Mr. Powell declined to make any statement.

DETROIT, Jan. 16.--Last September two bunko men swindled John K. Lemon of Allegheny, Penn., out of $10,000. Detective Matt Pinkerton, after tracking the men all over the United States, finally located one of them Windsor, opposite this city, where he was registered at the hotel as C.W. Goodyear. The officers arrested Goodyear last night, and he is now in jail awaiting examination for robbery.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 15.--Orrin Donnet, General Superintendent of the Knickerbocker Ice Company, made a tour along the Hudson River to-day and found it entirely free of ice. At one or two points the company has purchased ice on ponds and has arranged to buy ice that may form on lakes in the near future. The outlook for securing an ice crop along the Hudson is dismal indeed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 16.--The west-bound train on the Little Rock and Fort Smith Road ran into a slide one mile from Ozark yesterday. The whole train was wrecked and the engineer, W.A. Voss, was buried beneath the wreck. The fireman and a number of others were seriously injured.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 16.--Representative kitchen will introduce a bill at an early day making some very important amendments to the parole law now in force.

A report which was circulated yesterday that the Whisky Trust had bought the distillery at St. Paul, which was built avowedly to undersell and break the trust, is generally considered correct by whisky men here. WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bond offers: Registered 4 s. $1,114,000 at 109, $260,000 at 108 , and $113,000 at 103 7/8.

The Assembly Rooms of the Brooklyn Academy of Music were handsomely decorated with plants and elegant pieces of Gobelin tapestry last evening on the occasion of the annual Inpetonga Ball. This society is composed of the leaders of social life in Brooklyn, and is the feature of every Winter season. The guests began to arrive last night about 10:30 o'clock, but the cotillion did not begin until after midnight.
ALBANY, Jan. 16.--Assemblyman Creamer is not pleased with the manner in which his mysterious railway bill was received by the press.
The Tammany Sachems yesterday selected Commissioner of Accounts Holahan to be Scribe in place of John T. Toal.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 16.--The Northwestern Miller to-day says:

The annual report of the Board of Excise has been received by Mayor Grant. It states that the total number of licensed places in the city is 8,780. The number, other than hotels, restaurants, and steamboats, is 6,820. It is stated that there has been a decrease of 454 during the year.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The firm of Obermeyer Liebman was incorporated to-day, with a capital of $300,000, to operate in New-York and Brooklyn in the manufacture of malt and malt liquors. The Trustees are Joseph Liebmann, Theodore Obermeyer, and Henry Liebmann.

The revenue cutter Dexter has started her life-saving record of this year by rescuing the crew of the British brig Leo, Capt. Hammond, of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, while bound to that port with a cargo of coal from this city. The brig was struck by a heavy squall on the night of Jan. 10 off Race Rock.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16.--Gen. Harrison would have had a peaceful time to-day, for the politicians have pretty much let him alone, if it had not been for the sickness of his little grandson, Benjamin Harrison Mckee, in whom he is bound up.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 16.--At midnight tonight the clouds broke, and the heavens about the vicinity of the moon cleared and disclosed the eclipse. Over two-thirds of the moon's surface was covered, and the shadow showed strikingly.
Agnes Givan Crosby, daughter of the Rev. Howard Crosby, was married yesterday to the Rev. Arthur Huntington Allen of Troy at the Fourth-Avenue Presbyterian Chruch, which was packed to the doors.
Pedro Bosch, owner of a famous museum in Madrid, Spain, has been a sorrowful man for many a day.

DETROIT, Jan. 16.--President Henry B. Led yard of the Michigan Central is out in a long interview in response to the sharp animadversions made at the Eastern, Western, and Southwestern railroad Managers, in the course of which he makes what the public will be quick to say are some most sweeping and extraordinary statements.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 16.--The athletes at Yale anticipate that Harvard will put an unusually strong baseball team in the field next season, as they now may have practice games with professionals.
HURON, Dakota, Jan. 16.--The heavy snowstorm that has prevailed since midnight has delayed all trains, and the Statehood Convention did not meet until 3 o'clock. Much caucusing was done this morning.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 16.--Wesleyan University at Middletown has started a subscription for the support of the Baseball Association, and $250 has already been secured. The gymnasium will be enlarged so as to make a cage 75 feet long. The association will probably seek admission to the New-England Intercollegiate League.

DETROIT, Jan. 16.--The Collector of Customs at this port is taking a new turn of the screw under, the foreign labor law. By his order a Windsor musician, having pupils in Detroit and bringing certain instruments over with him, has been told that he must pay duty on his instruments every time he crosses.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16.--F. S. Higgins, station agent at Bevington on the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road, has been missing since Friday night. He is short $250 in railroad funds and $950 is his United States Express Company funds. He leaves an invalid wife and two children in destitute circumstances.
DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 16--This morning Tom Angus, a haekman, shot and killed Bradley, a celebrated professional baseball catcher.

ST. PAUL., Jan. 16.--One of the Chicago lines has a ticket on the market which is not only a new dodge, but effects a cut in the rates. It is probably this ticket of some similar cut which led the "Soo" line to make a reduction in pas- senger rates to the East.

ROME, Jan. 16.--The obsequies of the Marquis de Torrearsa at Palermo to-day had to be suspended on account of the fall of a roof during the passing of the cortege. There were 36 persons on the roof at the time, and 24 were badly injured. The wounded were taken to a hospital, where they were afterward visited by the Minister of Education, who left $600 for the sufferers.
The American Society of Civil Engineers began its thirty-sixth annual meeting yesterday morning at 127 East Twenty-third-street.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 16.--The unusual sight of tows going out and coming in here regularly every day is witnessed. To-day large consignments of bluestone were shipped to New-York City.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 16.--The Republican Senators have been driven from the highhanded position that they would not organize the Senate unless the Democrats pledged themselves to declare Goff's election.

Hill resorts to some of his characteristic methods he will announce to-morrow the new branch of the Court of Appeals, which is expected to relieve the present court of all its accumulated labors. The biggest betting game of the bookmakers' cushion carrom tournament was played last night by Charles Davis, who was handicapped at 150 points, and John Reeves, who had to score 170. Fully $10,000 was wagered on the result of the game before three shots had been made.

Two political clubs in Brooklyn, the Constitution and the Brooklyn, are fighting over the successor of the late Surrogate Lott. The contest began on Sunday night, when Mr. Lott's body was not yet cold, and has become more heated every hour.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 16.--The announcement has been made that a syndicate of wealthy citizens, prominent among whom is Mr. Frank T. Howard, had secured a 30 days' refusal of the French Opera House in this city at $50,000.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16.--In its editorial to-day on Judge Woods's charge to the Grand Jury yesterday upon the Dudley letter the Indianapolis News says:

The wedding of Miss Cornelia Carnochan Roosevelt, daughter of the late Charles Y. Roosevelt and granddaughter of the late exJudge Roosevelt, to Baron Clement Zedlitz will take place at Grace Chruch in the latter part of this month.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16.--The Executive Board of the Iowa Jobbers' Association met in secret session at their hotel club room this morning to discuss the ways and means of enforcing the Railway Commissioners' schedule and avoid Judge Brewer's injunction.

The Board of Education yesterday received the first report of the special committee of eight appointed to investigate the operation of the examination and marking system in vogue at present. It will be considered at a special meeting Jan. 30.

The valuable paintings presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the news of which was published exclusively in THE TIMES of yesterday, are now on exhibition in the new Eastern Gallery, O. of the museum. They were loaned to the Museum some time ago by Mr. Marquand and have never been removed.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 16--E.R. Gasper, a member of the firm of H.O. Price Co., formerely the leading pool sellers of Pittsburg, has gone to Europe for the purpose of introducing the American system of pool selling in London, Paris, and Berlin.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 16.--The message of the retiring Governor of Arkansas, Simon P. Hughes, was read in joint session of the Legislature to-day.

Mrs. August L. Stuhler, rather pretty, about 24, and in sore distress, told a story in the Nineteenth Precinct Station House last night that was almost as remarkable and out of the common as the affair which introduced her to the police.
A cablegram from Munich announces that Dr. Kruss, a chemist of that city, has succeeded in decomposing cobalt and nickel, both of which have hitherto been supposed to be elementary substances.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Mrs. Cleveland is more fully occupied with social duties than she has been at any time since she became the "Lady of the White House."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 16.--Commander Sampson, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, recently appointed Commander Harrington, Lieut.-Commander Todd, and Lieut. Potter as a board to investigate charges of firing crackers in quarters by cadets. The board examined every cadet, and each stated on his honor that he knew nothing as to who committed the breach of discipline.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan., 16.--Byron D. Halstead, formerly editor of the American Agriculturist, and now Professor in the Iowa State College, has been selected as Professor of Botany and Horticulture in Rutgers College. His appointment makes the fourth addition to the Faculty of Rutgers within a year.

Nearly four years ago William J. Irwin of Orange, N.J., was arrested for an assault on Henry S. Hiscock of 229 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street, in which the latter's leg was broken. The Police Justice dismissed the case, and Hiscock sued for damages in the Supreme Court and got a judgment for $7,500. Then he induced the District Attorney to have Irwin indicted.
Final services over the body of Mrs. Jay Gould took place yesterday, at the family mansion, Forty-seventh-street and Fifth-avenue.

The funeral services over the body of Abraham Lott, Surrogate of Kings County, who died on Sunday last at his home in Flatbush Village, were held at the Reformed Dutch Church there yesterday afternoon. The services were attended by fully 1,500 people.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 16.--Tax Collector Norch of Moscow, a well-known resident of Lackawanna County, was killed by a passenger train on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad near Moscow at noon to-day. He was walking on the truck in company with a priest and stepped from one track to avoid a stook train in front of the express.

The patrons of the Hoboken Ferry yesterday enjoyed the first fruits of the reform movement instituted some time ago. One of their grievances was that passengers and teams were both released at once, and went pell mell up the gangplank in a confusion that greatly endangered life and limb. The ferry management saw the justice of this complaint, and in future the teams will be held until the passengers are all off.

LOCKPORT DEPOT, N.Y. Jan. 18.--Sheriff Pickard yesterday sold the Niagara Falls Racing and Fair Grounds Association property at Niagara Falls, valued at $250,000, for $16,000. The price was cash, and it was bid in by some of the Directors subject to the large mortgages existing on it.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 18.--The Wharton Valley Railroad is practically completed, the last spike having been driven yesterday, in the presence of a large gathering of people, at the Edmeston terminus.

ALABNY, Jan. 18.--Senator Walker introduced in the Senate to-day 10 railroad bills prepared by the Railroad Commissioners. Nine of them were before the Legislature last year. The tenth and new bill provides for the placing of a Fahrenheit thermometer about the middle of every passenger car running within this State, and for the maintaining of the temperature at the point of 70 , under a penalty of $10 for each car.

Anglers for pleasure rather than profit are objecting to the weather. January is a decidedly off month in the anglers' calendar. It is about the only month when he cannot find fishing of some kind without having to go far South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The omnibus substitute for the Senate bill to admit Dakota to the Union was psssed by the House this afternoon by the vote of 144 to 98. The bill as passed provides for the admission of Dakota as one or two States, to be decided by a preliminary election, and for the admission of Montana, Washington, and New-Mexico.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 18.--The report that there are between 700 and 800 cases of smallpox in this city and that people are fleeing from the epidemic is false. From 40 to 50 cases have been reported at the Health Office up to date, which is not greater than usual at this season of the year. The cases are very mild, and only three deaths have resulted so far.

ULSTER PARK, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Benjamin Post, a farmer of this place, was killed on the West Shore Railroad near here last evening. With two other men he was walking on the track. To avoid a train approaching on the south-bound track they stepped on the northern track. Another train approached unobserved on the latter. Post was thrown down an embankment. The other two men escaped. Post leaves a widow and five children.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 18.--Through a proposition made to the local Board of Workhouse Directors by C.C. Corner of Columbus, Ohio, it is learned that a trust has been formed to control the sale of all common or prison-made brushes in America.
COATZACOALCOAS, Mexico, via Galveston, Jan. 18.--The steamer Faraday, owned by Siemens Brothers Co. of London, arrived off here this morning.

Yesterday's public rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society prefatory to this evening's concert was an extremely interesting entertainment.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18.--Friends of Johns Hopkins University are considering plans to aid it financially. Seven gentlemen have offered to give $5,000 each, provided a fund of $100,000 is subscribed.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Jan. 18.--The trial of Mnason Huntzman, the religious fanatic, ended last night in his conviction. He was sent to the county jail for six months and ordered to pay a fine of $100 and costs of the trial.

It is announced that the Chicago, Burlington and Quiney Railway has purchased four blocks in the northern part of St. Louis, on which, it is supposed, the company will construct terminals and tracks. The property is reported to have cost in the neighborhood of $700,000 and, as the Burlington has never had any yards in St. Louis, the report regarding the terminals seems to be well founded.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--Gov. Shuman, who for nearly 33 years has been connected with the Chicago Evening Journal, to-day retired from the editership of the paper on account of ill health and the positive orders of his physician.

WINDSOR, Ontario, Jan. 18.--A Political Union Club has been organized here, with Dr. Smith as President and Councilman Timms as Secretary. A mass meeting will be held on Thursday. The Political Unionists propose to form an aggressive organization and be ready for the Parliamentary election.

ST. PAUL, JAN. 18.--Senator Ward dropped a mild bomb into the Senate to-day by introducing a resolution calling for the appointment of a committee to investigate the charges of bribery in the Senatorial caucus, the committee to have the power to send for persons and papers and thoroughly sift the charges.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 18.--Senator-elect Higgins was tendered a serenade this evening by the Young Men's Republican Club. The club members and Republicans generally, making a crowd of about 1,000, marched to the residence of Mr. Higgins headed by the First Regiment Band.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--Judge Clifford this morning issued a capias for the arrest of Mr. J.J. West, proprietor of the Times, on a charge of criminal libel preferred by Police Captain M.J. Schaack.

BERLIN, Jan. 18.--The East Africa bill was submitted to the Bundesrath to-day. It is entitled "A blil for the protection of German interests and combating the slave trade in East Africa." It asks a grant of 2,000,000 marks.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 18.--On the ninety-seventh ballot to-night the Senate adjourned without having reached an election. McCallister and Prichard, the two refractory Democrats, went into caucus immediately before the night session began and agreed not to vote or effect an organization unless under a Democratic President.
LONDON, Jan. 18.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Suevia, Capt. Lndwig, from New-York Jan. 5, arr. at Hamburg to-day.
Mr. William Ludwig and his company will give a concert of Irish national music, under the auspices of the Gaelic Society, in Steinway Hall, Monday evening.

Harriett E. Coffin, the handsome young brunette who of late years has gained considerable notoriety in this city and Boston by her queer actions in public places, such as theaters, hotels, and stages, was arrested at Palmer's Theatre last evening for disorderly conduct.

He is charged with being an accessory in the crime.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Jan. 18.--The thermometer has registered as high as 60 here to-day. Forwell C. Bryant, Saco's veteran ice dealer, aged 92, is plowing on his farm. He says he never saw the equal of this January weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--The musicale given at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the residence of the Secretary of the Navy was one of the most elegant entertainments of the brilliant series to which Mrs. Whitney has bid her friends welcome during her stay in Washington.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Jan. 19.--Reports of a most extraordinary discovery of gold come from the State of Guanajuato, where one the eastern slope range which runs through the State are said to have been found hitherto unsuspected deposits of gold-bearing quartz.

LONDON, Jan. 19.--This has turned out to be the most important week in British politics since the general election of 1886. The Gladstonian Liberals unexpectedly find themselves almost embarrassed by the sweeping character of the victories they have won, and their papers to-day speak of the multiplied triumphs that have come to them in a tone of bewilderment.

As a result of a broil last night in a saloon at 85 South-street Morris Callahan, a speculator, of 94 Roosevelt-street, lies critically ill at the Chambers-Street Hospital with a stab wound through the left lung. His assailant is locked up in the Old-slip station house.

The young members of the German Liederkranz gave a complimentary dinner to Anton Seidl, the composer, at the Hotel Brunswick last night in honor of the successful production of "The Rheingold" in America under his direction. Carl Schurz was the speaker of the evening.

There were reported at the Sanitary Bu reau during the past week 779 deaths, 770 births, and 231 marriages. Of the deaths 536 occurred in tenement houses and 145 in public institutions; 357 were of children under 5 years.

FAYETTE, Mo., Jan. 19.--A love-crazed little girl, 16 years of age, and a Colt's revolver figured in an awful tragedy here this morning. The girl was Flora Rohr, one of the prettiest and most intelligent girls in the town. She was attending school.

Young Nagle's parents are the keepers of the large double house at the above number, the property of Lloyd Phoenix of 21 East Thirtythird-street. Mr. Eugene W. Glaenzer, the American representative of Messrs. Boussod, Valadon Co. of Paris, has purchased from George Inness six of the latter's paintings. They are all landscapes, and Mr. Glaenzer is very enthusiastic in their praise.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 19.--The case of Richard H. Allen Co. of New-York against B.S. Bibb Co. of Selma was decided in the United States Court here to-day. It had been pending two years, and went to a jury three times before a verdict was obtained. The suit was based on cotton-future contracts made with Allen Co. under the rules and regulations of the New-York Cotton Exchange.

There was very little change yesterday in the aspect of the Cuban cigarmakers' strike. The manufacturers said that they had not yet done anything, and had held no conferences among themselves. The men felt more confident and reported that four small manufacturers had yielded to the terms of the union and would resume work on Monday.

Assembled at Delmonico's last night were 17 gentlemen who celebrated the silver anniversary of their graduation by the College of the City of New-York in 1864. There were 40 members of the class, but the remainder are now either not interested in mundane anniversaries or have bid a lasting farewell to their youthful associates in this city.

Messrs. Myers and Sulzberger, proprietors of the Arcade, 239 and 241 South-street, Philadelphia, have made an assignment for the benent of their creditors. MATAWAN, N.J., Jan. 19.--The annual meeting of the Midway Shooting Association was held yesterday and the following officers were elected: President--James H. Bedle; Vice-President--Charles Muirhead; Treasurer--James Van Brackle. A shoot took place after the election, and James H. Bedle won the first prize by shooting 13 birds straight; Thomas Compton, second prize, 8 out of 9; Charles Muirhead, third prize, 7 out of 9, and Samuel Hall, fourth prize, 7 out of 12.

ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 19.--From passengers who came up on the Brunswick and Western train to-day the following facts were learned about the riot at Ty Ty: A bailiff had a warrant for a negro, and when he went to take his prisoner the negro drew a pistol and fired at the officer, with no effect. BALTIMORE, Jan. 19.--For eight years Mme. Peynand, an old French woman, has lived in a hut near Catonsville, about 15 miles from this city. No one knew her except a Catholic priest. Her only companions were cats, dogs, and birds. She prayed a great deal, and was zealous in all religious devotions. Last night she died, and to-day the mystery of her hermit life was explained.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 19.--Word has just been received here that the entire art collection of the late ex-Senator Bosenbury of Hunterdon County has been left to the Plainfield Public Art Gallery by his widow, recently decased. The collection is one of the most noted in Central New-Jersey, including many valuable paintings, and is worth many thousand dollars. The art gallery building is the gift of Mayor Male, and already boasts of a large collection.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21.--A ghost story of large proportions has been radiating from the Southern Hotel for three days. In Room 144, in April, 1885, Maxwell chloroformed C.A. Preller to death. Then after robbing the body he packed it in a trunk, where it lay for two weeks.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 21.--One hundred Swedish laborers have been brought to Charleston from Chicago for employment in the Bradley Phosphate Mines. Heretofore negroes and Italians have been employed exclusively in this work.

Edward Cooper, Abram S. Hewitt, and their associate Trustees have submitted to the Legislature and the Board of Aldermen their annual statement of the receipts and expenditures of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. CHATTTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 22.--The Coroner's jury in the case of the three men killed in an accident at Rador's switch, Saturday, rendered a verdict to-day. They found that the deceased men came to their death by the negligence of Conductor Harbison and his flagman in failing to change the switch after running on a side track.

The London Gaiety Company will not return home next Spring as was intended. Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn yesterday completed his negotiations for the purchase of the handsome brownstone house at 24 Eighth-avenue, in the Twenty-second Ward, Brooklyn.
An unusually intelligent and respectable looking group of 10 persons was to be seen among the steerage passengers of the Servia who were detained at Castle Garden Monday and yesterday.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 22.--The annual review of the whale fishery of this country is published in the Whalemen's Shipping List. It shows that the catchings for the year have been 16,625 barrels sperm oil, 17,185 barrels whale oil, and 334,572 pounds of whalebone.

About 140 members of the Stationers' Board of Trade gathered last night at the banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick to celebrate their thirteenth annual dinner. George L. Pease, President of the board, presided. At the speakers' table by his side sat the Rev. Dr. T. L. Cuyler, the Hon. Warner Miller, the...

Eddie Hutton, a bright, manly fellow, 14 years old, who lives at 19 East Forty-fourthstreet, and is a pupil at the Trinity School in Twenty-fifth-street, between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, was a prisoner at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on the heinous charge of snowballing.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Jan. 22.--A circular letter has been received by the Pioneer Press, which shows one of the abuses to which railroad tickets are subjected, and illistrates the boldness with which a certain class of scalpers ply their trade.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 22.--The divergence between Senators Brown and Colquitt of this State is growing more marked every day. The Sparta Ishmaelile, whose editor, Sid Lewis, is Colquitt's private secretary and who is supposed...
Israel Leitsky, a peddler, who lives at 3 Forsyth-street, in Justice Walsh's court in Brooklyn yesterday charged Mrs. Mary Gough, who keeps a saloon at Classon-avenue and the...

The relatives of Henry Peters, formerly of St. Petersburg, Russian, are very anxious to discover his whereabouts. He was last heard of in New-York, and this fact led to an advertisement in yesterday's newspapers, addressed to the missing man and saying:

Some progress in the work of removing wire and pole obstructions from the streets of Brooklyn is shown by the fifth annual report, just issued, of the Electrical Subway Board of that city. The aggregate length of wire conductors under ground has been increased during the year from 1,133 to 2,928 miles,...

ALBANY, Jan. 22.--The Assembly Excise Com mittee gave its first public hearing this afternoon on the Excise Commission bill. The advocates of the bill present were Dr. Crosby of the commission, Dorman B. Eaton, John B. Pine, Col. B.F. Watson, and Bishop Doane; against the bill, either in its entirly or in certain of its details,...

The capture in Philadelphia of Thomas Barton, an Englishman charged with forgery to the extent of $100,000, was reported yesterday by the Pinkertons. Barton was, up to 1886, they say, a silk weaver in Macelesfield, Cheshire, England.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 22.--The House of Representatives to-day passed finally the reso lution providing for the submission to the people of the amendment to the Constitution prohibiting the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors in the State.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--Fred W. Bidwell, Treasurer and Western agent of the Manufacturers' Paper Company of New-York, was found dead in his room at the Hotel Grace to-day.
The thoroughfare just west of Eighth-avenue and running from Edgecomb-avenue to One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street used to be known as Coogan-avenue, James J. Coogan has large real estate...
A sale of paintings and etchings which belonged to collections of A. Thill of New-Haven and Benjamin Lewis of Brooklyn was begun last night at the Lihon Art Gallery, 8-15 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--The great fly wheel, 14 feet in diameter and weighing six tons, in the engine house of the Northwestern Parlor Suite Company, in the outskirts of the city, burst asunder with a terrific crash this morning.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22--The Grain Comm it mittee of the Commercial Exchange to-day received communications from General Manager McLeod of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad...

CAPE MAY, N.J., Jan. 22.--Charles Lamphear, a woodchopper, about 60 years old, was found murdered in the woods near his cabin, on the line of the West Jersey Railroad, just below Manumuskin Station, last night.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 22.--A convention of Confederate pensioners of the State methere to day for the purpose of petitioning the Legislature to increase the pension appropriation. Two hundred one-armed and one-legged veterans are in attendance.

The people who write anonymous letters were busy yesterday. "A Lady Thinker" sent a note to the Rev. Dr. John Hall and "A Friend" attended to Chauncey M. Depew. Both writers advised the gentlemen not to speak at the annual meeting of the Society for the Suppression...
The ninth annual ball of the Union Boat Club, which occurred last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, added one more successful affair to the list of entertainments given by that organization.

SENATOR COKE RE-ELECTED. AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 22.--Senator Richard Coke was unanimously re-elected by both houses of the Legislature to-day, the three Republican members of the House voting for Coke amid applause. The two houses will meet in joint session to-morrow to announce the result.

Capt. Joshua Slocum, known in marine circles as the master of the bark Aquidneck, was in port yesterday telling his friends that he is on a new tack, one that courses in diplomatic channels and is inspired by a claim for $10,000 against the Brazilian Government.

ALBANY, Jan. 22.--The Eclectic Club of NewYork is incorporated, with Theordore Abels, Harry Hoyt, William G. Hoyt, Harry H. Lloyd, and Thomas N. Mackey as Directors. The object is for social, mutual benefit, musical, dramatic, and literary purposes in New-York.

A row occurred in the Board of Alderman yesterday. Its cause was practically the same that made the final disturbance in the last board on Dec. 31, 1888, when Aldermen Sullivan, Butler, Tait, Oakley, Walker, Holland, Joseph Murray, Rinckhoff, and Gunther walked out of the Aldermanic Chamber and threatened to kill the...

LONDON, Jan. 22.--Lady Salisbury and Lady Rosebery called at the residence of Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister in Lowndes-square this afternoon, and informally presented Mrs. Phelps with a superb bracelet inscribed: "Presented to Mrs. Phelps, on her leaving England, as a token of affectionate regard from some of her English friends, Jan. 22, 1889."

Underneath a wealth of decorations of silver-spangled tulle and gold-embroidered velvet some 2,000 guests and members of the Central Turn Vorien danced and promenaded at Terrace Garden in a bewildering variety of funny and elegant costumes last night at the...

Carl Schubert was arraigned before Judges Lippincott and Paxton, in the Hudson County Court, yesterday, for robbing a Hoboken Hotel. Judge Paxton was a boarder at the hotel, and part of his wardrobe was among the things taken.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 22.--There are indications that the National Steel Beam and Structural Steel Trust, or pool, is on the eve of a split. For some time rates have been disorganized, and it was said that some member of the combination had accepted contracts at rates below those agreed upon.

Luzon J. Finch, a manufacturing druggist of 36 Gold-street, was arrested yesterday on a bench warrant issued by Recorder Smyth, based you an indictment accusing Finch of using a trade mark without consent of the owner.
The final game in the bookmakers' cushioncarrom tournament was to have been played by Davy Johnson and Charles Heineman last evening, but Heineman forfeited.

A resolution was presented to the Board of Aldermen yesterday to prevent the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad Company from running "bobtail" cars. Alderman Clancy presented it, and moved that it be referred to the Committee on Streets.
DALTON, Ga., JaN. 22.--Quite a number of people have been digging for buried treasure two miles east of Dalton, near the fork of the roads for Spring Place.
Telegrams from San Fernando report that the naval authorities have offered Commander Peral an old wooden corvette for his experiments with his new submarine torpedo vessel.
A.V. Van Tuyl and Frank A. Selle, two well-to-do residents of South Brooklyn, converted themselves into "sandwich" men on Monday and spend most of that day and yesterday riding on surface railroads.
Five historical swords have been left by the old German Emperor to the Berlin Arsenal. They are the long sword, with a leather sheath, which the monarch wore from 1810 to 1834;

Several hundred men are actively working at Anthony's Nose preparing for the foundation of the eastern tower of the Peckskill Bridge. They are employed in removing the mass of rock displayed from the mountain side by blasting.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Jan. 22.--About 2 o'clock this morning the residence of Daniel Downey at Vineland was discovered to be on fire. Neighbors rushed to the scene, and, upon breaking in the door, the body of Mrs. Downey was...

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22.--The final winding up of Elizabeth's Adjustment Commission, appointed nearly three years ago to revise the unpaid assets of the city, took place yesterday. The job has cost the city over $39,000.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22.--H.B.D. Lefferts, an ex-Justice and City Recorder, has disappeared from the city. He is charged with picking the pockets of the late George W. Reed of the Brooklyn Eagle while he was watching at the bedside of the dying man.

PARIS, Jan. 22.--The Boulangists are showing great energy all along the line. Boulanger will not have himself to blame if does not head the poll next Sunday. During this week he will keep his house open to all comers, the reception lasting from 7 A. M. to 7 P. M.

The Ossipee has been ordered to proceed without delay to Aspinwall for the protection of American interests on the isthmus. This vessel is now at Kingston, Jamaica. She towed the steamer Haytian Republic from Port au Prince to that port. Her departure for Aspinwall will leave the United States unrepresented by a war vessel in Haytian...
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 22.--The citizens of Elizabeth are preparing for a grand demonstration of welcome to President-elect Harrison of the occasion of his passing through the city next April.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22.--Patrick Bradley, a married man, who was arrested last week charged with assaulting little girls, was to-day convicted, the jury not leaving the box. Two of his young victims identified him. Judge Gordon then sentenced Bradley to 29 years and S. months' imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22.--The Rev. Dr. W.J. McKnight, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, spoke last evening, at the church prayer meeting on the Christian alliance recently formed here with a flourish of trumpets.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Two cases of importance were tried in the County Court today. The first was an indictment against Darius N. Case, charged with stealing a pair of horses and a wagon from E.M. Vandeburgh, of Lithgow, Dutchess County.

The storm clouds which have been hanging over the Appraiser's Stores on Laight-street for the past two weeks broke yesterday and eight persons suffered from the deluge. Since the removal of Appraiser McMullen by President...

The fragrance of the jessamine is as aggreeable as over. "Nancy and Company," revived at Daly's Theatre last evening for the sixth subscription performance, was found to possess all its old charm. Many persons regard this piece as the best of all the successful series...

A remarkably quick passage for a sailing vessel was that which was completed by the ship William H. Connor of Searsport, yesterday, on her arrival here from Shanghai via Hong Kong.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Dr. George F. Shrady of New-York City during one of his frequent "runs" to Ulster County related a pathetic little incident that came under his knowledge a year or so ago.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22.--Cyrus E. Brown has commenced a suit against Alphonso O. Munger of Boston to avoid carrying out a contract for the sale of the ground lease of the Brunswick, formerly the Clark House, Jan. 12.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 22.--The woman suffrage movement has always had many friends in this city, the home of Susan B. Anthony and of several other women prominent in the cause,...
ST. PETERSBURGH, Jan. 22.--Sinister reports that come from Bulgaria keep the Government on the alert for developments. Prince Ferdinand's abdication is a question of days.
Mme. Carnot is evidently the right woman in the right place. Her Christmas treats seem to consist chiefly of showing "good will to men."
CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--The officers of the West side Street Railway Company are investigating a serious "leakage." One conductor interested in the scheme to beat the company has confessed...

Henry M. Lester has placed a handsome memorial window on the southeast side of the New-Rochelle Presbyterian church. At its base is the inscription, "Erected to the Memory of the Huguenot Settlers of this town and Founders...

MONTREAL, Jan. 22.--The train which left the Grand Trunk station at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon by the Delaware and Hudson Railroad for New-York, met with an accident 10 minutes after leaving the station, by which one lady was killed and five other passengers injured.

VIENNA, Jan. 22.--The opening of the Reichsrath on the 30th inst. will be the beginning of a critical period for Count von Taafe's Ministry.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22.--The announcement of the dismissal of the Hon. William Ross, Collector of Customs at Halifax, for permitting the transshipment of the cargo of the American fishing schooner M.A. Batson has created a sensation throughout Canada.
John Greenwall, who was recently convicted for the second time of the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, was yesterday sentenced by Judge Moore in the Session Court, Brooklyn, to be hanged on March 12.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22.--The police have received information from Washington of the capture there of E.B. Gildia, whom they have been seeking for months, for robbing Mrs. S.J. Swift of $500 worth of...
The Castle Garden officials had as one of the immigrants who arrived yesterday a young man who they think is is specimen of the genuine Russian Nihilist.
ALBANY, Jan. 22.--The following figures are abstracted from the annual reports of fire insurance companies to the State Superintendent of Insurance:
Miss Harriet E. Coffin, the admirer of Actor Kyrle Bellew, was pronounced insane by Drs. Field, Fitch, and Douglas, at Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 22.--There are more sensational developments to follow last week's arrest of Cashier Henry F. Voigt of the Farmers and Mechanics' Bank, who is now in jail unable to procure $40,000 bail on the charge of defalcations amounting to about $150,000.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 22.--The Democratic caucus made no nomination last night, but it was not because Democrats could not agree on the question of a caucus, as their opponents pretended to believe.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22.--The petition of the Rutgers Sophomores for mercy for the members who had been suspended for participating in the recent cane rush has been denied by the Faculty, which sees no reason to change the decision.

The Montreal Winter Carnival, beginning Feb. 4 and lasting through the week, promises to be more spirited than ever. The first day the festivities will include the opening of tobogganing slides and of the ice palace in the evening.

Residents in the smaller towns along the Morris and Essex Division of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway have been complaining for some time that the accomodations afforded them by the railway company are of the most meagre description.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 22.--Miss Fanny Davenport, the actress, was unable to appear at the Grand Opera House to-night on account of a serious indisposition and no performance was given. The management is hopeful that she will have sufficiently recovered by to-morrow night to continue her engagement.

At the meeting of the American Football Association at Newark, N.J., the protest of the New-York club, the Thistles, against the admission of the drawn game with the Caledonians of Newark, N.J., was upheld and the match must be played over again on or before Feb. 2.
LITTLE SILVER, N. J., Jan. 22.--Mrs. Hannah Parker and Miss Deborah Lippincott are the only occupants of a small house situated between the Little Silver station and the village of Oceanport.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 22.--Martha Wilcox, a woman who did not live with her husband, was found this morning dead and frozen into the gutter beside the Old Colony Railroad in a lonely place a mile and a half from the station in this city. She was at Isaac Borden's yesterday and with him drank nearly two quarts of whisky. Borden has been arrested.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 22--In the Senate at 10:30 this morning Mr. Edwards, Democrat, offered a resolution that the Senate proceed to ballot for United States senator.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21.--The fight that is now being made by St. Louis to preserve its differential rate on corn has provoked the grain men of the Chicago Board of Trade to take up arms in defense of the rights of this city.

The Board of Aldermen took a hand yesterday in the controversy between the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company and citizens of the annexed district respecting the closing of parts of thorough fares in Melrose from One Hundred and Fifty-second to One Hundred and Fifty-sixth street to enable the railroad company to build a big car shop.
The second concert of the New-York String Quarter, which was given at Steinway Hall last evening, was a very great improvement over the first.

Charles L. Rubsamen, a wealthy retired banker, of Hoboken, blew out his brains at his home, 418 Garden-street, in that city, yesterday morning. He was engaged in business until about eight years ago. Since that time he had lived in handsome style with his wife and a large family of children.

President Richardson, of the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad company of Brooklyn, has addressed a circular to the employes of the company, which is to be distributed to them as they report for work this morning.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23.--The entries for the stake, to be run at the Spring meeting of the St. Louis Jockey Club will appear to-morrow. There are 15 stakes, including the St. Louis Derby, with $2,500 added. The stakes and purses aggregate $60,000 for 15 days' racing.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Mr. Chamberlain addressed a meeting at Birmingham to-night, and met with an enthusiastic reception. Mrs. Chamberlain occupied a seat on the platform. A letter was read from Mr. Bright's son, who wrote that his father's health was steadily improving and that his general condition was very much better than it was a month ago. Mr. Chamberlain, in the course of his remarks, referred to the rejected fisheries treaty.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 23.--Five persons accused of setting fire to the house of Mrs. Butler Banks over the heads of herself and little children, in Newberry County, have been arrested. Butler Banks, who shot James Banks, has not been caught yet, but his wife has been arrested as an accomplice after the fact.

The crowd that filled the Claremont-Avenue Rink, in Brooklyn, last night, at the annual boxing and wrestling tournament of the Varune Boat Club was as enthusiastic as it was big, but Police Captain McKelvey and six of his officers who were there to look out for ...

Tommy Russell played Little Lord Fauntleroy at the Broadway Theatre yesterday afternoon to an audience which packed the great house, and a portion of which, at least, was in full sympathy with him in every line spoken and every gesture and movement made.

There was published in one of yesterday morning's newspapers an advertisement signed "William Ellinger" and warning the public that "the person who lives at 120 West Fifty-thirdstreet and calls herself Mrs. Willlam Ellinger" was not his wife.

It is announced that an agreement has been made between the Westinghouse Electric Company and the United States Electric Lighting Company whereby the interests of the two companies shall hereafter be conducted for mutual benefit, both in the manufacture and ...

LAWRENCE, Mass., Jan 23.--One week ago no business man in Lawrence would have refused credit for almost any amount to John H. Prescott, a lumber dealer, who for a quarter of a century has been prominent in local business and official circles.

Thomas C. Platt and his admirers have been very active for a week on a search for the "trusted agent" sent by Gen. Harrison to this State to ascertain the real sentiment of the people toward Mr. Platt and Warner Miller. Some of the Patt admirers who gather nightly at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, and who have looked anxious ever since they began their search, ...
SALEM, Oregon, Jan. 23.--Both houses of the Legislature met in joint convention to-day, canvassed the vote cast yesterday for United States Senator, and declared J.N. Dolph elected.

Reference was made in THE TIMES Tuesday to the fact that a Wall-street news agency had raised a breeze by quoting President Bull of the Stock Exchange as a decided bear on the stock market. The Presidency of the Stock Exchange pays no salary.

The officers of George Washington Post, No. 103, G.A.R., were installed last evening at the Hotel, Brunswick as follows: Commander-- Gen. Martin T. McMahon; Senior Vice-Commander--Gen. W.D. Whipple; Junior ViceCommander--Gen. Fred T. Locke; Adjutant-- ...

DETROIT, Jan. 23.--The near approach of the special Protestant Episcopal Diocesan Convention to select a successor to the Bishopric made vacant by the death of Bishop Samuel S. Harris is causing considerable discussion in a quiet way over the question of candidates.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 23.--John D. Critchfield, a lawyer of Mount Vernon, began a suit in the courts here to-day against his mother-in-law for $100,000 damages. He claims that she deprived him of his wife's affections.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The race for the junior championship of the city and the Roger's stop watch prize took place this afternoon on a neighboring lake, under the auspices of the Newburg Skating Association. Entries were open to all who had never won races. Six only were made.
ALBANY, Jan. 23.--The Second Division of the Court of Appeals, composed of the seven Supreme Court Justices designated by Gov. Hill, is now ready for business.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 23.--A dispatch to the American from Elkton, Md., to-night, says that the Hon. Jacob Tome, the well-known millionaire, has given $500,000 for the creation and maintenance of the Tome Male and Female Seminary at Port Deposit, Md. The institution is for white children between the ages of 10 and 18, and everything is free.

The decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the patent case of the Bate Refrigerating Company against George B. Hammond Co., outlined in Tuesday's TIMES, attracted a great deal of attention among lawyers yesterday.

The people of Trenton and Elizabeth, N. J., have begun to make preparations to receive and entertain President Harrison on his way to this city to take part in the centennial celebration of the inauguration od George Washington as President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--Two boys, aged respectvely 6 and 7 years, sons of Mrs. Hensler a Newberry-avenue, came near losing their live this morning under the ruins of a snowhouse which they had built in the yard. The mild weather of Monday had made the snow heavy ...

The Charity Organization Society wishes to warn the public that several persons are collecting money and goods ostensibly for country churches but really for their own benefit, and that collectors for several spurious local charities are also fleecing the generously disposed.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--The Anarchists and their sympathizers in the city are greatly wrought up over a communication made to the stockholders of Waldheim Cemetory by its Superintendent, in which he says:

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 23.--The Knights of Labor have ordered a general look-out at the mines of the Oregon Improvement Company to force the company to disarm the Miners' Union. The Knights charge the company with furnishing rifles to the Miners' Union. The Knights are also arming themselves.
Life on the Stock Exchange yesterday was quite as free from riotous proceedings as usual. Prices stood still when they didn't run off a little.

The complications at present existing in the island of Samoa may, or may not, be considered in a serious aspect. In naval circles, however, the ordering of a squadron of war vessels to any particular point on a station is considered ominous of more than ordinary duty in store.
The frontispiece of the February number of Harpor is a portrait of John Ruskin, and presents to us an earnest and strong though a sad countenance.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 23.--In the suit brought by George T. Mellor, a loom fixer of this city, against the Merchants' Manufacturing Company to recover for the loss of an arm, the jury has found for the plaintiff in the sum of $3,441.

Among those who have Summer residences at Oakdale, Long Island, are William k. Vanderbilt and Christian Roberts. The spacious grounds surrounding the homes of these two millionaires adjoin each other and only a rustle fence divides them.

George G. Gibson, the son of an old sea Captain who formerly lived in Brooklyn, is locked up in Raymond-Street Jail, Brooklyn, on complaint of Prof. William R. Ware of Columbia College, who loaned Gibson $600 on a note.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The Rev. Sandford I. Ferguson of the New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference has been appointed Presiding Elder of the Poughkeepsie District is place of the Rev. Dr. Hare, who died recently.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Jan. 23.--The Orange Athletic Club's annual ball, usually the largest dancing party of the season at the gay NewJersey suburb, was held in the pretty clubhouse here to-night, and proved in some reacts ...

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23.--The Lake Carriers' As sociation, representing the shipping of the great lakes, which is considerably more than half the entire American merchant marine tonnage, is in annual session here.

The Executive Committee of the Workingmen's Municipal Reform League, at a meeting held Tuesday evening, indorsed the project of the Long Island Tunnel Company and condemned the action of the Board of Aldermen in referring the application of the corporation for a franchise to the Committee on Docks.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23.--A new steamboat company has been formed in this city under the name of the St. Louis, St. Paul and Minneapolis Packet Company. Who constitute the company has not yet been learned, but Andrew Delaney of St. Paul, an old and well-known river man, will be manager.

Henry Peters, son of the man who ruled the island of Petroffsky, in the Nova, at St. Petersburg for nearly 20 years by grace of a rather one-sided contract with the Russian Government, called at the office of W. Ropos Co., at 74 Wall-street, yesterday, having read in the newspapers that the firm wanted to see him.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Jan. 23.--Twenty-four freight cars standing on the track on the down grade at Ashburnham early this morning started toward this city, and all but four cars were thrown from the track.

ESCANABA, Mich., Jan. 23.--The funeral serv ces of the late Lieut.-Gov. Macdonald and all of his partner, William F. Cochrane, who were killed at Elm wood in a railroad accident last Saturday, were held this afternoon in Mr. Ma Donald's residence under Masonic auspices. The remains lay in state from 9 o'clock until o'clock, and were viewed by thousands of people.

It is so apparent that the permanent improvement of the red men and their adequate preparation for citizenship must be largely influenced by the instruction of the rising generation that the condition and progress of the schools for Indian youth become a matter of national importance.

Had Job ever sat as Judge at the trial of a case in which a thoroughly angry woman was a potent factor, he could not have exercised greater patience than did Judge O'Brien, yesterday, in Special Term of the Supreme Court. An angrier woman and a more patient judge have seldom before been seen in any trial in the Supreme Court of this State.
