WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Senator and Mrs. Hearst gave a ball to-night in honor of their guest, Miss Head of California. The interior decorations of the house were unusually beautiful and elaborate.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 23--Clara Louisa Kellogg was to have sung at the Euclid-Avenue Opera House the last three nights of this week. To-day Manager Hartz received the following remarkable telegram from Carl Strakosch, dated at Buffalo:

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 23.--The negro delega tion which will wait upon President-elect Har son will lack neither in number nor in consequence. If the word of John M. Langston is taken it will be the most important body of colored ...

BERLIN, Jan. 23.--The body of Mme. di Murska and her daughter were cremated at Gotha today. Mme, di Murska's Austrian husband and a dozen members of the Gotha Opera Company were the only mourners. The urn containing the ashes of the mother is inscribed: "These ashes are all that remain of a nighingale."

Between 200 and 300 messenger boys listened quietly and with some show of interest to a spirited address by Cleveland H. Dodge in Association Hall last night. There was no attempt at guying on the part of the boys, and, with two or three exceptions, no manifestations of a disorderly spirit.

The Veteran Firemen of this city had a great time of it yesterday afternoon and evening with their visitors, the Volunteer Firemen's Association of New London, Conn. The latter, under the cammand of Chief Engineer W.B. Thomas, arrived in the city on the 4 o'clock train.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 23.--John C. Cole, a coal merchant of Elizabethport, was presented last night with a handsome gold-headed cane by the people of the Second Ward of this city for his successful efforts in having the Elizabethport Glue Works closed by Chancellor McGill.

Sarah Lyman, a buxom German girl, who is about twice the size of her recreant lover, Julius Rinkert, appeared before Judge Ehrlich yesterday in the City Court. She wanted $10,000 from Mr. Rinkert for trilling with her affections.

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Rugor, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 84--Henry P. Stone et al., Executors, appellants, vs, Thomas B. Kenney, respondent.--Argued by J.M. Dunning for appeliants, Levi H. Brown for respondent.
SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 23.--Andrew Schoen, aged 50 years, a well-known merchant, committed suicide this morning by blowing out his brains with a revolver. Drink and business reverses led to the dead.

The audience at the Metropolitan last night was not the largest of the season, but its interest in Wagner's beautiful work, "Die Meistersinger" was manifested in close attention during the acts and in abundant applause at the ends of them.
When the vote was taken on Tuesday on the Republican Tariff bill every Democratic Senator present voted against it, and every absent one was paired with a supporter of the bill.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 23.--Senator Higgins came to Dover this evening, and held a reception in the rooms of the State Capital Republican Club, which was attended by nearly all the Republicans of the town. Afterward he was escorted to Burton's Hall, where he addressed a large audience.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 23.--Mrs. Amelie Rives-Chanler has offered a prize of $100 for the best American essay on child labor. The money has been placed in the hands of Prof. Richard T. Ely of this city, ...

Alfred G. Myers of the firm of Myers, Rutherford Co., who died in 1887, left $90,000 each for the benefit of his sisters-- Louise, who is in a lunatic asylum, and Matilda. John A. Rutherford, as managing Executor of Mr. Myers's estate, turned over to each of the sisters $1,450 as income from the total $180,000 for one year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 23.--The Northwestern Miller to-day says: "There were three less mills which made flour last week, and thought one large firm increased its product there was a falling off in the output as compared with the week before.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 23.--The 8 P.M. Southbound express on the Cincinnati Southern Road was boarded by robbers just beyond Ladlow last night. The train had scarcely got beyond the lights of Ludlow when a man, heavily masked, knocked at the rear door of the express car, and one of the passengers, thinking it was the conductor or brakeman, opened the door.

M.J. Gaffney Co., coal dealers at the foot of Grand-street, Brooklyn. Eastern District, failed yesterday with liabilities of $100,000. The firm was one of the largest in the city, and handled an average of 100,000 tons of coal a year. For some time the firm has been unable to meet its obligations, and a short time ago its account was thrown ...

OTTAWA, Jan. 23.--The Cabinet has appointed Inspector Hill Acting Collector of Customs at Halifax, Nova Scotia. The resignation of Mr. Ross, received last night, has been accepted. Mr. Ross will probably receive a retiring allowance, although the Government regards his action in permitting the transshipment of cargoes by an American vessel as unpardonable.

GILBOA, N.Y., Jan. 23.--This pretty little Schoharie County village has had several wild sensations during the past six months. The latest novelty that has set tongues to wagging is the birth of what a youngster here describes as "the bald-headed puppy dog calf over on the Stryker farm."

Mr. J.E. Bruce, one of the representative colored men of this city, called the attention of Senator Hoar to the statements of Mr. Mahone in regard to the selection of a negro for a place in Mr. Harrison's Cabinet, and received the following answer:

Yesterday was the twenty-eighth anniversary of the Women's Union Missionary Society, and the event was fittingly celebrated. In the morning 400 or 500 ladies and a half dozen of the sterner sex, who have been interested in the work of the society, gathered at the Broadway Tabernacle.

BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 23.--Other charges have developed against ex-Recorder H. D.B. Lefferts, who has fled from town to escape arrest on warrants for robbing the late George W. Reed of the Brooklyn Eagle and swindling a syndicate of capitalists who had taken stock in a company which was to manufacture a steam consuming boller.

At the end of the third day's effort to get a jury for the trial of ex-Alderman Thomas Cleary 231 talesmen had been called and none accepted. On the first day there were 23, on the second 109, and yesterday 99--42 in the morning and 57 in the afternoon.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23.--In accordance with a resolution previously adopted both houses met in joint session precisely at noon, Speaker Hudspeth in the chair. A resolution offered by Senator Edwards declaring John R. McPherson elected United States Senator, to succeed himself, for a term of six years, beginning March 4, 1889, was adopted.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 23.--Dispatches and rumors were current in St. Paul and Chicago this morning that the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Railway contemplated the removal of its general offices to Chicago at an early date.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 23.--The Legislature of Minne sota met in joint session at noon to-day, and after little preliminary parliamentary sparring, proceeded to ballot for United States Senator. On the first ballot Gen, W.D. Washburn received 107 votes and was declared elected.

NAHSVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23.--The Nashville Iron, Steel, and Charcoal Company, which for months has operated extensive works in the new town of West Nashville, four miles northwest of this city, to-day made an assignment for the benefit of its creditors.

Princess Martha Eugelitchoff read a paper yesterday afternoon at 50 West Forty-eighthstreet before a large company of ladies, who manifested the greatest reverence for the titled reader. The Princess, however, was extremely amiable and wholly-democratic in her manner.
The second installment of paintings and etchings from the collections of Benjamin Lewis of Brooklyn and A. Thill of New-Haven, sold at Lihon's Art Gallery, 845 Broadway, last ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The "walking delegate" is not so effective a scarecrow to-day in Congress as he was a few months ago. He appears to have been put away with the freetrade bugaboo, to be brought out again, perhaps, ...

PROVIDENDE, R.I., Jan. 23.--William Smith, aged about 32, a Tellor in the office City Treasurer, committed suicide last night in his room at the Narragansett Hotel shooting himself. City Treasurer Tripp says only a nominal sum is missing. Smith's sales was $1,200, and he was unmarried.

The Aldermen who voted to send the petition of the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company for leave to build a tunnel under the East River to the Committee on Docks, instead of to the Committee on Bridges and Tunnels, ...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The Hon. Roswell P. Flower and his brother, Anson R. Flower, of New-York have decided to build a magnificent church for the Trinity Episcopal parish in this city, their former home. The plane have been adopted and the church is to be completed by June, 1890. The cost, including glazing and furnishing will be $55,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 23.--Charles L. Colby, who for 10 years has been President of the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company, and who was also President of the Wisconsin Central Company, has resigned both offices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $1,015,000 registered 4 s at 100. All were accepted.
Dr. Charles Bliss met a sudden death at his Twenty-third-street residence yesterday morning. It was the result of a rather remarkable accident.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 23.--Judge Brewer, in a lengthy opinion, has indorsed the position maintained by the Iowa Railroad Commission in the cases of the State against the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company, namely, that the Iowa railroad law is a criminal statute, and that cases arising under it can not be removed to the Federal courts.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 23.--James A. McCool, at one time a well-known railroad man and one of Atlanta's most prominent citizens, comitted suicide to-day by hanging M. McCool was on the bond of Tax Collector Wilson, who was short in his accounts, ...

William Gillette reached New-York from Detroit on Tuesday and is now engaged in organizing a strong company for a special production which he is to make in March at the Hollis-Street Theatre, Boston, and afterward in this city. He maintains a mysterious silence regarding this venture, his only answer to all questions being that it is something entirely ...

John Lornie, a broker of Kirkcaldy, Scotland, has written to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for insurances on lives and granting annuities, asking that that company, which is Trustee under the Reading third preference mortgage, take such steps as will require the payment to the third preference bonbholders of full interest.

A telegram was received at the Navy Department this morning from Commodore Gillis, commanding the South Atlantic squadron, announcing the arrival of the Swatara at Montevideo on Tuesday from a cruise to the Straits of Magellan and the Falkland Islands. The steamers Alliance and Tallapoosa are also at Montevideo. The health of the squadron is reported excellent.

DETROIT, Jan. 23.--The creditors of the Electric Sugar Refining Company yesterday proceeded to decisive action against Howard. They sent an officer to Milan armed with an attachment for the purpose of levying upon the live stock shut up in his barns. The officer broke open the doors and levied upon everything in sight.

The Catholic temperance men of this vicinity have of late become active in their crusade against the saloons. A movement calculated to result in making future American citizens total abstainers has been inaugurated by the Provincial Council, which is composed of the Catholic temperance societies of this city, ...

Another new jockey club has come into existence, and with it another new race track. The jockey club is to be known as the NewJersey Jockey Club, and the track is to be built on a bit at land just purchased in Elizabeth, about midway between Elizabethport and the city of Elizabeth.

A small audience of Irish "liberators" of of the dynamite school met in a large room in the rear of a saloon at 326 East Twenty-firststreet last night to listen to a lecture upon "Weapons of War--Ancient and Modern," by Capt. J. Mooney.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 23.--T.D. Potter, a still hale and hearty citizen of Thomaston, has reached the age of 100 years. Mr. Potter is well aware that he bears his age rather buoyantly, and, when the fact is referred to, he invariably tells this story:

For the purpose of raising a permanent endowment for the Manhattan Dispensary and Hospital, Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-first-street, the Ladies' Association connected with it is to hold a fair for two weeks, beginning Monday, Feb. 4, and ending Feb. 18, at Pottier, Stymus Co.'s building, Fifth-avenue and Forty-second-street.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 23.--A student in the School of Pharmacy at the University is down with smallpox. He was vaccinated the day that he was exposed to the disease, and it is hoped that the case will not be serious.

There was a mass meeting of carpenters who belong to the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners last evening at Tummany Hall, and among the speakers were Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor; P.J. McGuire, Secretary of the federation and ...

HARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 23.--As far as the preliminary contest is concerned, the Democrats have won every point here. Yesterday the Republicans threatened another long deadlock in the Senate. They refused to allow that body to go into joint session to canvass the election returns, ...
BREMERHAVEN, Jan 23.--Naval reinforcements for the German fleet now in Samoan waters left here to-day on the North German Lloyd steamer Nuernberg.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 23.--President Miller of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad has been interviewed as to his views on the bill which has been introduced at Madison for the regulation of railway traffic.

A fire broke out at midnight last night on the third floor of the building 88 and 90 Walkerstreet. It is a brick building, 50 feet front and nearly 100 feet deep and seven storles high, ...

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--Contrary to expectation Mr. Ainsworth's Appropriation Committee did not hold a meeting this afternoon, and will not until something is heard from the experts who have been invited to investigate the ceiling.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 23.--Gen. Francis E. Spinner, ex-Treasurer of the United States, who receiving treatment for a cancer on his face. The General, under date of Jan. 19, in writing a friend in Amsterdam, says: "Your letter followed me here from Florida. I read it in parts at the time with difficulty.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 23.--A report has been current that the Canadian Pacific has purchased the right of way of the old road at Lewiston, and that it intends to erect a suspension bridge across Niagara River and connect with the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg.

The Pullman Palace Car Company yesterday acquired control of all the parlor car companies doing business in this country, with the one exception of the Wagner Company, whose operations are confined to the Vanderbilt railway lines.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The report that the Cunard liner Catalonia had failed to rescue Capt. Lunder of the wrecked barge John Bunyan on Monday when he was floating on a raft and making signs of distress elicits the following comment from Capt. Atkin of the Catalonia:

Some wicked student in the Medical College of the University of the City of New-York wrote across the blackboard in the clinic room yesterday afternoon: "Prof. Weisse will give a demonstration to-night in the theatre of the Carnegie Laboratory."

A meeting of telephone subscribers who favor the bill prepared by the Board of Trade and Transportation and introduced in the Legislature by Robert Ray Hamilton, providing for the reduction of telephone charges, will be held at the rooms of the board in the Bryant Building to-morrow afternoon at 1:30 o'clock.

BERLIN, Jan. 23.--The Deutsche Wochenblatt prints a Zanzibar letter which says that the blookade on the east coast of Africa has only fomented disorder, and has failed to check the slave traffic. The writer complains of a lack of energy on the part of the German Consul, and says that if Sir John Kirk returns to Zanzibar ...

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23.--The merchants of St. Louis held another meeting on 'Change to-day for the purpose of heading off Chicago, which city is alleged to have laid violent hands on the St. Louis corn market. President Cox presided. A petition was read from the grain dealers and exporters of St. Louis. It said:
The Aqueduct Commissioners decided yesterday that they need $1,000,000, and they called on the Controller to issue the bonds necessary to provide them with the money.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--A dispatch from NewYork printed here this morning stated that business in options on the Produce Exchange of that city had dwindled to a ridiculously smal volume, and that no grain was being exported because of manipulation by Chicago speculators who had kept the price of wheat above its actual value.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23.--Prof. Theodore Hunt of the English department at Princeton College announces to-night that he has just received from Thomas B. Wanamaker of Philadelphia the promise of a fund for the establishment of prize in the English department to be known as the "Thomas B. Wanamaker English Language Prize."

The ice has been broken and Kentucky and Tennessee breeders will send their thoroughbred yearlings to this city, the natural market, to be sold. Gen. William H. Jackson, proprietor of the famous Belle Meade Stock Farm, is the first to break away from the old custom, and the yearlings bred at that farm and ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 23.--The suit brought by the minority stockholders of the Savannah, Griffin and North Alabama Railroad Company against the Central Railroad of Georgia, which is owner of a majority of the capital stock of the Savannah, Griffin and North Alabama Railroad, ...

Samuel Davis, a barkeeper at 995 Eighthavenue, and known familiarly among poloticians in the Nineteenth Assembly District as "Our Sam," brought suit in the City Court yesterday against a neighboring barber, Charles Welterer, for libel, claiming $2,000 damages.

LONDON, Jan. 23.--Before the Parnell Commission to-day Dennis Tobin deposed that he was a member of the Kilconoly band of moonlighters. He said that when the members of the band were sworn the leader told them that, by order of the League, tenants who paid their rents were to be raided.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 23.--It is reported that the Minister of Finance is preparing a scheme or a fresh conversion of Russian funds. The Czar has decided to abolish the offices of Governor-General of the southern provinces, ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 23.--A number of the Prot stant ministry of the city have made an open declaration of war upon Emma Abbott, who is now playing a week's engagement here, the first date filled since her husband's death.

On May 1, 1888, the tenants of the old NEW-YORK TIMES Building were still in possession of their offices. Within less than one year THE TIMES has put up the finest and most beautiful newspaper building in New-York--or in the country, as for that matter.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 23.--At the meeting the Charleston Bible Society on Monday there was an animated discussion as to the re lations of Unitarians to the Bible cause. For many years they have had representatives on Board of Managers.

The funeral of the late Isaac Bell, Jr., ex-United States Minister to the Netherlands, took place yesterday morning from Trinity Church. The fine old building was clothed in Christmas garb, the chancel rail and clustered columns being still entwined with green and the corners and niches filled with generous fir trees.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 23.--Soon after 3 o'clock this afternoon fire broke out at the north end of the lower mule room of the Annawan Mill. The fire caught in a mule carriage at the north end of the lower mule room on the third floor and spread with almost lightning rapidity to the upper floors.

William Siller and a daughter of Paul Van der Esch, Superintedent of the Astoria Silk Mills, eloped from Steinways Village, Long Island, on Saturday, and were married the same evening in New-York by a Catholic priest.
PARIS, Jan. 23.--The Gaulois confirms the report that the Government has decided to repeal the decree of exile against the Due d'Aumale.
There is no rational basis for the assumption which some of our contemporaries have made that we have been subjected to a wanton insult in Samoa by officers of the German Navy.

Coroner Rooney and a jury began last night, in the County Court House, Brooklyn, an inquest into the death of Katie Cody on Jan. 16. The dead girl's sisters repeated the testimony given at the examination of Frank Dudgeon, charged with complicity in the death of the girl.

When the day closed at the Appraiser's Stores yesterday three more officials had been summarily dismissed from the Government's employ. Assistant Appraiser David C. Sturgis, the first of the three to receive his discharge, was the head of the Tobacco, Grocery, and Whisky Division.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 23.--There is no denying the fact that the ice companies are becoming very nervous over the outlook for ice. There is noticeable hurrying to and fro of bosses and agents and speculators into the interior along the Hudson looking for "refusals" of ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 23.--Senator Quay has succeeded at last, and he is really satisfied now. His man is going into the Cabinet, and Pennslvania's interests will be protected. Gen. Harrison and John Wanamaker fell in love with each other at first sight to-day.

There has been just published an atlas of the world by George F. Cram of 19 Park-place, which is an exceedingly valuable publication. It is known as "The Standard American Atlas," and is a volume of 370 pages.

The heavy fog which hung over this city yesterday morning, and the almost simultaneous arrival of three trains at the One Hundred and Fourth-street station of the Sixth-avenue elevated road, caused a double collision, which badly mixed up matters for a time and left several passengers with painful wounds.

OCEAN BEACH, N.J., Jan. 24.--At the annual borough election the following officers were chosen: Commissioners--Harry H. Yard, J.A. Buhler, H.H. Bennett, A. Fielder, W.E. Allen, J.S. Kuyler, and G.B. Kisner; Borough Collector--E.P. Philbrick; Borough Assessor-- ...

Philip Heinrich of 428 Pacific-street, Brooklyn, was held in $5,000 bonds by Recorder Smyth yesterday, charged with setting fire to his foundry, 195 William-street, which was partially destroyed by fire Nov. 24, 1888.

It is said that a copy of Cardinal Newman's "Grammar of Ascent" is to be presented to everybody who wishes to go up in the elevator of the new TIMES Building.

J.K. Brown, State Dairy Commissioner, has sent out notices to proprietors of boarding houses and places of public entertainment calling their attention to the New-York law against oleomargarine, and reminding them that its violation involves severe penalties.

Albert Meskill was tried in the Court of Sessions, Jersey City, yesterday, for assaulting Officer Murphy, Moskill pleaded that he had taken a three-cent glass of whisky and did not know what he was doing. The jury returned a verdict of guilty of assault.

DANVILLE, Va., Jan. 24.--The town of Martinsville, in Henry County, is excited over a series of mysterious burglaries which have taken place there within the last week. Several stores were broken into and small amounts of money stolen, but no effort was made to carry off other property.
The little actors and actresses of the stage gave a decidedly novel and thoroughly pleasing entertainment at the Bijou Theatre yesterday afternoon.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 24.--Early in the week all the Collectors of Customs in the maritime provinces were instructed not to issue any further licenses under the modus vivendi.

A little tempest occurred in the Assembly teapot this morning, which, for the moment, threatened to do violent injury to somebody's feelings, but fortunately it blew over without doing serious damage.

There was little life yesterday in the run of business in the wheat pit of the Produce Exchange. Quotations varied only slightly from those of the close of the day before, and generally there was less of the panicky feeling which prevailed on Wednesday. There was more or less nervousness, however.
HAVANA, Jan. 24.--Official announcement is made that the Society of "Los Manigos" has been dissolved, and that its bands or sets, (Juegos,) of which there were 30 in the association, have disbanded.

President Lewis of the Brooklyn City Railroad and the Executive Committe of District Assembly No. 75 met at the former's office last night and signed the agreement under which the road's employes are to work this year.

The Health Department needing two more meat inspectors the Board of Estimate and Apportionment set aside sufficient money to employ them, and yesterday the 29 applicants for the positions appeared at the office of the Civil Service Board in the Cooper Institute to pass the necessary examination.

The double collision on the west side elevated road yesterday seems to have been really an accident of the kind against which no foresight can guard. Certainly there is no evidence of carelessness on the part of anybody.

The Renton Brothers' Manufacturing Company brass goods, at 292 Pearl-street, whose factory is at Croton Falls, N.Y., was sold out by the Sheriff yesterday. Two judgments for $12,206 has been entered against the company in favor of Frederick N. Du Bois for borrowed money. The business was established in 1864 and was turned into a stock company in May, 1887, with a capital stock of $20,000.
We get every year from some official source the statement that real estate is overburdened with taxation and that personal property does not bear its proper share.

DETROIT, Jan. 24.--The J.J. Burns Company, (Limited,) which has just built the new railroad from Battle Creek to Gaston, Ind., and is building the road from Battle Creek to Bay City, today made an assignment of its affairs, in trust, to Hulbert Mechem of Battle Creek, the attorneys of the company.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 24.--A transaction has just been closed whereby the bonds of the Sioux City and Northern Railroad Company are placed.

Clubmen generally will be interested in the details of a civil suit for $25,000 damages for slander, involving the question of freedom of speech when applications for membership are up for consideration.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 24.--Mrs. Angela Mallory, widow of the Hon. Stephen Russell Mallory, Secretary of the Confederate States Navy, and mother of State Senator Stephen R. Mallory, fell from a street car to-day, breaking her left arm and sustaining other serious bruises. The lady is now 72 years old, and the shock to her nervous system must necessarily be of a grave nature. She is bearing up bravely under her sufferings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Consul Willard, at Guaymas, Mexico, has sent a dispatch to the State Department denying the report that a number of American citizens had been killed by Yagin Indians near Ortiz, 30 miles from Guaymas. He says that the Indians attacked a small force of Mexican soldiers and killed several of them, but that no foreigners were injured.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 24.--Members of "The Order of Financial Union" are greatly exercised over the stormy meeting last night of Department No. 23 of Philadelphia, when the society was pronounced a fraud. The headquarters of the order are in Paterson, where most of the chief officers reside.

J. Ira Newton, Joseph Dowling, James Stedman, and James F. Cosgrove, effeminate-looking young men, were arrested Wednesday charged with insulting women on Broadway, between Twentysixth and Twenty-seventh streets. A policeman saw them endeavoring to attract the attention of women passing by and arrested them. They were fined $10 each by Justice Patterson.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 24.--Charles Conklin, a notorious horse thief, was arrested here to-night by Chief of Police Grant. The authorities of Bergen County have been looking for Conklin for several weeks. They charged him with stealing a horse and buggy at Spring Valley. Conklin has served several terms in State prison. He will be turned over to the Bergen County officials.
Benjamin Field, a boy of 11 years, died yesterday at his home, 226 Monroe-street, Brooklyn, from some mysterious disease with which his physicians could not cope. An autopsy will be held to-day.
HARTFORD, Jan. 24.--Col. Jacob L. Greene, President of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of this city, made the following announcement this evening:

Henry J. Anderson, the Receiver of the Albion National Bank, was not so successful in his suit against George H. Chase and Thomas B. Atkins, brokers of this city, to recover money sent to the firm by the defaulting Cashier of the bank and claimed to be the bank's money, as he was against the firm of Kissam, Whitney Co.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The annual report of State Controller Edward Wemple, exhibiting the financial condition of the State for the fiscal year ending on Sept. 30, 1888, was submitted to the Legislature to-day.
HARTFORD, Jan. 24.--The two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the Connecticut Constitution was celebrated here today with appropriate exercises.

Inspector Byrnes is looking for Samuel Rothschild, a Hebrew, who came to this city from Hartford, Conn., and after shipping his effects home by express, vanished like a shadow. His mother lives at 255 Asylum-street, Hartford, and owns the Metropolitan Hotel Cafe in that city, which was managed by "Sam" Rothschild. He had been in charge for several years.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24.--The trial of Mr. William O'Brien on a charge of conspiracy began to-day at Carrick-on-Suir, County Tipperary. The Government had issued a proclamation forbidding any demonstration welcoming Mr. O'Brien, but despite this action 20,000 persons gathered around the Court House.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The Nickel Plate yards were tied up this morning on account of the switchmen refusing to work with Milton Cooper, who is said to have made himself obnoxious to the union in many ways.
PARIS, Jan. 24.--The newspaper La France says that the ordinary garrisons in and about Paris are being replaced by troops that are known to be devoted to the republic.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--The Post, referring to the banquet to Mr. Phelps, says: "It is not without a certain pride in the calm strength of English public sentiment that we find most ample recognition universally accorded to the representative of America and his honorable career in our midst."

The Pullman Palace Car Company took formal possession yesterday of the Union Parlor Car Company and the collateral branches, which give control of all the parlor car business in the United States except that of the Wagner system, confined to the Vanderbilt railways.

Rates on live hogs from Iowa points to Chicago are slightly higher than the dressed product, and this allows the packing industry in Iowa to flourish, while it had also led to the charge of discrimination against the roads by the Chicago packers.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--Owing to the opposition of Messrs. Sloan and Fassett it is extremely doubtful whether the bill that appropriates $125,000 to bring the entire National Guard of the State to the city of New-York on the 30th of next April on the occasion of the centennial celebration of Gen. Washington's inaguration will ever reach the Governor.

Yale's athletic graduates and undergraduates will have a royal good time at the dinner to be given them by the Alumni Association of this city on Feb. 16. Letters have been received from a number of old boating, baseball, and football champions, promising to meet the undergraduate champions and tell them the stories of their struggles to uphold the glory of the blue.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--Miss Jeannette Parker, the 20-year-old daughter of Engineer Parker of the Boston and Maine Railroad, fell down the elevator well in the Young Woman's Christian Association Building yesterday afternoon, a distance of five stories, and was instantly killed. Miss Parker was a sstudent at the Boston University and had boarded at the association ...

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, presiding, the following business was transacted: No. 134--Mary Irene Hoyt, appellant, vs. Samuel N. Hoyt et al., Executors, respondents.
A young lawyer who was engaged in defending a man before Recorder Smyth yesterday had a voice so shrill and penetrating that the Recorder's nerves were sadly jarred by it.

They are not saying very much publicly, but a secret meeting of the ...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 24.--The Twenty third National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic is to be held in this city the last week in August. The Common Council and cit izens have already organized to received and en tertain in a manner equal, at least, to any other ...

A man who said his name was Edward Lynch and that he lived in this city went to visit a friend living in a tenement at 238 North Fifth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday, and by mistake opened the door of Mrs. Soverina Savina's room.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The General Managers of the roads leading westward from Chicago met to-day to consider a proposition to establish a uniform time by all lines for the running of passenger trains between Chicago and the Missouri River.

Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday reserved decision on a motion of Congressman W. Bourke Cockran on behalf of Mrs. Mary McArthur to have a Receiver appointed for the firm of J. McArthur Co., broom manufacturers.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24.--The Grand Lodge of Masons ended a two days' session in this city this afternoon. The following officers were elected: Most Worshipful Grand Master-- Charles H. Mann, Haddonfield; Deputy Grand Master--George W. Fortmeyer, East Orange; Senior Grand Warden--James H. Durand, Rahway; Junior Grand Warden--Charles Belchor, ...

RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 24.--How the excessive fees asked by lawyers for legal services ear up estates has again been exemplified in Dutchess County. The will of the late M.D. Fanning, offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court, ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 24.--Eight years ago in a well-known city in Virginia a handsome young man loved a maiden fair. They were Southerners of good birth.

WATERTOWN, Jan. 24.--The great army of anglers who frequent the islands of the St. Lawrence River and Lake Ontario in search of black bass, muskallonge, and pickerel will be interested in a new movement just started by the net fishermen of this county.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 24.--Last year Stephen Collins, Supervisor of this town, appealed to the State Assessors from the equalization made by the Equalization Board of 1887. The appeal was sustained, and a verdict of $1,217 ...
James Christie turned on the gas when he went to bed in the Martin Hotel, 445 Hudsonstreet, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, and at 9 o'clock the porter found him dead.

The annual Winter session of the NewYork and Brooklyn Congregational Association was held last evening at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. J.G. Roberts of the Rochester-Avenue Church was re-elected Moderator and the Rev. William Caruthers of Richmond Hill, Long Island, Secretary.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 24.--Bernard Mansen of Philadelphia committed suicide by shooting here this morning. His sister, Mrs. Minnie Harris, lives in Newark, N.J.
A novel form of the "Southern question" has made its appearance in Indianapolis, and there are signs that this appearance will be renewed later and in still more formidable shape.

Mme. Modjeska is not the only star who is in active demand to act as support in strong companies. Mrs. D.P. Bowers has also been approached with liberal offers of salary for next season if she can be induced to abandon her career as a star temporarily.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24.--James Finnegan, second mate of the steamship Erin, which was abandoned at sea during a fearful storm off Cape Hatteras, arrived here to-day with five others of the crew. Capt. Hughes and the four passengers and the rest of the crew continued to Philadelphia and New-York from Norfolk, where they were landed yesterday. Second Mate Finnegan tells this story:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The President and Mrs. Cleveland gave their second state dinner to-night to the diplomatic corps, in whose honor the White House was profusely decorated with flowers and shrubbery.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--Mrs. Harrison, the wife of President-elect Harrison; her daughter, Mrs. McKee, her son-in-law, Mr. McKee, and John Wanamaker arrived at the Broad-Street Station in the Chicago Limited Express at 4:45 o'clock this afternoon.

Sara Jane Collins, the widow of Commodore Edward K. Collins, who is being sued by Edward K. Collins, as Executor of his father's estate, was released yesterday from her elevated position on the witness stand in Judge O'Brien's part of the Supreme Court, Special Term.
RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 24.--There are now 1,450 convicts in the penitentiary, costing the State annually $200,000. This is a heavy burden and the people are becoming restive and impatient under it.

PANAMA, Jan. 16.--Except the recent temporary stoppage of work at Culebra work on all the other sections of the canal continued as usual, and matters promptly assumed their customary pacific appearance.

Mr. Sidney Woollett's recitation of "Elaine" at the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon was heard with great pleasure by a numerous assemblage, the largest he has drawn since his present course of entertainments began.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Jan. 24.--The forward trucks of the engine on a special freight train, No. 26, bound north, broke last night just west of Hartford Bridge, the scene of the great disaster two years ago, derailing the engine and dumping eight cars down the embankment. The engineer and fireman jumped and saved their lives. Trains were but slightly delayed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--Chairman Abbott of the Western States Passenger Association and ViceChairman Daniels of the Central Traffic Association began yesterday an examination into the complaint made by the Kansas City local agents to the effect that the Wabash Railway has been paying commissions to brokers in Kansas City since Jan. 1, resulting in cut rates.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24.--A will of the late John S. Wells was admitted to probate two weeks ago, bearing date July 15, 1885. His attorney knew that a later will had been made, ...

Since the election Mr. HARRISON has been urged by many Territorial politicians to remove at the begining of his term certain persons now holding Federal offices in the Territories and to appoint residents of the Territories in their places.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 24.--The Directors of the St. Paul Distillery Company at their meeting today received a letter from a fire insurance company declining to take risks on the concern, as it has trouble with the Whisky Trust. The Di rectors expressed their determination to go on with production and to increase the volume of output, which has been growing steadily since the distillery was opened June 3.

The second of Mr. Thomas's matinee concerts took place at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The audience was very large, and its applause was most generous. The programme was bristling with novelties, and was accordingly heard with no small interest.

Although about 400 talesmen have been examined for the purpose of getting a jury to try ex-Alderman Thomas Cleary on the charge of accepting a bribe, the jury box is still empty. The proceedings yesterday were watched with evident interest by a large assemblage.

A man of 35, evidently a German, shot himself in the left side of the head, on the east side of Central Park, near Seventieth-street, last evening, and died while being taken to the Presbyterian Hos pital. He had two revolvers, 38 cents, and three five-cent postage stamps, but nothing to tell who he was or why he killed himself.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The meeting of Western railroad Presidents to consider the recent agreement made in New-York for the purpose of putting a stop to rate cutting and other disturbing practices by secondary executive officers was called to order in the Grand Pacific Hotel this morning at 10:30 o'clock, with closed doors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--Judge Horton is trying a case in which it is charged that a young woman was arrested and kept in a private detective's office until she consented to sign an affidavit exculpating the detective's client from certain alleged wrongdoings. In overruling a motion on behalf of the defense to dismiss the case Judge Horton took occasion to use some strong language in regard to private detective agencies and their methods.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--Gov. Hill was worsted again to-day. He has urged the appointment of Jospeh Eustace of Elmira, the successor of the late Edwin O. Perrin, as Clerk of the Court of Appeals. Deputy Clerk shankland was a can didate for the place.

An application was made to the Park Commissioners yesterday by Mr. E.E. Stearns of the Torry Botanical Society to have a part of one or more of the new parks devoted to the purposes of a botanical collection.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Jan. 24.--Returns from the smelting works give better results than were expected, making a total yield of the Ropes Mine for December in gold and silver $9,332 76. The expenses of operating the mine and mill were $4,600, transportation and other charges, $900, leaving a net profit of $3,832 76 on December work, being the first month's run on ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24.--There was a lively scene in the House to-day over the passage of the Hamilton bill, which places the Police and Fire Departments of that city in charge of a non-partisan board appointed by the Governor. Speaket Pro Tem. Albaugh was in the chair. The bill was not discussed, the previous question ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Representative Morrow of California is in receipt of a telegram from San Francisco informing him that a recount of the votes in the Fourth Congressional District increases his majority 62, making his majority 655 over his Democratic competitor, Mr. Ferrall.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--It is reported that the troubles of Baker's Theatre will shotly be set at rest. H.R. Jacobs, who controls so many theatres in the East and bought the lease of the Academy in this city from Daniel Shelby, will, it is said, add Baker's to his chain of houses.

A hat and overcoat were found near the stern of the ferryboat Manhattan Beach, which plies between Hunter's Point and Thirty-fourth street, at 10 o'clock last night. In the hat was found the address, "A. Lerbenroth, College Point." It is supposed that the owner of the clothing jumped overboard, but no one saw him jump.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--No one could have listened to the arguments made before the House Prisons Committee to-night without being impressed with the necessity of keeping employed the unfortunate men confined in the State prisons. Upon invitation of Chairman Savery, delegations representing the various penitentiaries in ...

The second Assembly was given at Delmonico's last night, and like the first, was a decided success. The ballroom was prettily decorated with simple bunches of bright flowers and a few palms. The guests were received by Mrs. William Astor, Mrs. J. Pierpont Morgan, Mrs. F.R. Jones, and Mrs. J. Wilmerding. A cotillion was danced to merry music by Lander. Supper was served downstairs in the restaurant, as usual.

A motion of Col. George Bliss, counsel for Col. W.W. Dudley, to vacate orders for the examination of his client before trial in the libel suits brought by him against THE NEW-YORK TIMES, the World, Commercial Advertiser, and ...

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The Trustees of Nyack Rural Cemetery, a beautiful burial place a mile west of this village, did a handsome thing this afternoon by presenting a large plot to the Masonic fraternity of Rockland County, in which any member of any lodge of Masons in the county will have the right of burial.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 24.--Another phase of the Fidelity Bank's tragic history came to light today in the filing of an answer by Mrs. Ammi Baldwin, widow of the Cashier of the Fidelity National Bank.

The interior of the Metropolian Opera House presented a brilliant appearance last night. It was the occasion of the annual reception and ball of the Old Guard. There was a very large assemblage and showy uniforms were as thick as sparks in a busy forge. There was an unusually large number of military guests from out of town.

The eleventh annual meeting of the Loan Relief Association, which, as its name implies, lends small sums of money and useful articles to the deserving poor, was held last evening at the residence of Mrs. Edwards Hall, 17 East Sixty-sixth-street.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 24.--In addition to 73 2-year-old colts and fillies of royal breeding, such noted performers as Clay Stockton, The ...

The steamer City of Para, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, brought in her forward cabin W. Ogg and W. Healey, formerly sailors on board the United States man-of-war Trenton. They were in charge of Lieut. A.C. Dillingham and two marines and were about to be sent to Albany to serve terms of imprisonment imposed by court-martial.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 24.--The weather to-day was cloudy but pleasant. The track was in bad condition, being muddy. Following were the events:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 24.--At a special meeting of the Nova Scotia Telephone Company yesterday it was decided to sell the company's interests in New-Brunswick to the Bell Company of Canada, by which company they are to be transferred to the New-Brunswick Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--Application for the incorporation of the Inquirer Publishing Company was filed this afternoon in the office of the Recorder of Deeds.
COLUMBIA, S.C. Jan. 24.--There are frequent stories of bold exploits by moonshiners in the mountains in the upper section of this State.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Jan. 24.--The Oklahoma boomers received another set-back in the Terri tory yesterday. About 600 families had during the past three weeks crossed the Canadian River and taken possession of some of the choice Oklahoma lands.

The Princeton Club of New-York held its annual meeting last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. The following officers were elected to serve for the coming year: President--Henry Van Dyke, D.D.; Vice-Presidents--Robert Stockton Green, ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The Board of Directors of the Board of Trade to-day passed a series of resolutions protesting against the introduction in the Legislatures of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kansas, and Colorado, of bills to exclude dressed beef, pork, and mutton from sale in those States.

The German steamship Savona, Capt. Ghuchenthal, which arrived yesterday from South American ports, experienced very severe weather on her way north. She left her last port, Maceio, Jan. 3. A storm from the south and south-southwest came up Jan. 21 and struck the vessel with tremendous violence.
BELVIDERE, N.J., Jan. 24.--John B. Grover, a wealthy butcher of Portland, Penn., was yesterday terribly gored and trampled on by a bull.
United States Senator Blair was the star attraction last night at the concert in aid of the Woman's National Industrial League at Chickering Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--A telegram received to-day by the Hydrographer, Navy Department, from Stornoway, in the Hebrides, off the northwest coast of Scotland, marks the completion of the long and erratic cruise of the derelict ...

Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild arrived in the city last evening from his home in Cazenovia and registered at the Buckingham. He was seen by a TIMES reporter, and cleared up the mystery which has enshrouded the actions of the Special Treasury Agents, Appraiser Stearns, and others engaged in prosecuting the investigation of the affairs at the Appraiser's stores.

A section of the Fire Department was summoned to the Parker House, at Broadway and Sixth-avenue, at 11:40 last night to extinguish a blaze in the Thirty-third-street L.A. careless employe in the kitchen tipped over a pan of grease, which caught fire, made a good deal of smoke, and created considerable excitement. The little fire was promptly put out without having caused much damage.

Thomas B. Barry, ex-member of the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor, and now T.V. Powderly's rival as head of a national labor organization, was in this city yesterday, and left hurriedly for East Saginaw to bury his child.

A fog enveloped this city for two hours yesterday morning and made navigation in the bays and harbor about as exciting as log-running on the Kennebec. LYNN, Mass., Jan. 24.--Police Officer Phillip Pitts of Saugus is at the hospital in a dying condition, having been fatally shot by a burglar near the Cliftondale railroad station at an early hour this morning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 24.--The consecration of the Right Rev. Boyd Vincent, Assistant Bishop-elect of the Southern Diocese of Ohio, will take place to-morrow at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. Mr. Vincent and friends have already arrived, also Bishop Spaulding of Colorado, the senior Bishop, and Bishop Knickerbocker of Indiana.
C.R. Robert, whose place at Oakdale, Long Island, adjoins that of William K. Vanderbilt, denies that he shot a big St. Bernard dog belonging to Mr. Vanderbilt as published yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24.--Henry Baxter, the student, and John Yent, the assistant janitor of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, this city, on trial at Towson, Md., to-day pleaded guilty of breaking open the vault at Bay View Asylum in December for the purpose of stealing bodies, and were sentenced to 30 days in jail.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 24.--Miss Elizabeth V. Clark, daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Daniel Clark, was married to John B. Covell, at Grace Church yesterday afternoon.

Voters who cast ballots for the Republican Presidential Electors at the last election, but whose names are not on the rolls of the Assembly district associations, will be enrolled to-day. By this is meant all such voters as live elsewhere in this city than the Eighth Assembly District.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 24.--The Democrats held another caucus this evening to agree, if possible, on a candidate for United States Senator. The fight so far has been conducted on a fair and friendly basis. The friends of Senator Kenna made an unprecedented concession ...

The ball of the Jersey City Fat Men's Club, held in Cooper Hall on Wednesday evening, ended in a disagreement between A.A. Newman, the proprietor of the hall, and the Committee of Arrangements. Mr. Newman consented to let the club have the use of the hall in return for the bar privileges. It was understood, the club men say, that a supper for the dancers should be provided.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24.--The Maryland Electoral College had an informal meeting here to-day to supply the omission of the Electors' names on the envelopes containing the three sets of certificates of Maryland's eight votes for President and Vice-President, Senator Ingalls, President of the Senate, having refused to receive the envelopes containing the votes unless the letters were so indorsed.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 24.--Judge Walling has adjourned until May next the trial of Frank Patterson of Asbury Park. Forty-three indictments for forgery have been hanging over Patterson for four years.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 24.--Fully two-thirds of the members of the Fire Department here have petitioned the Common Council for the removal of Chief T.O. Doane, and threaten wholesale resignation unless some one else is appointed in his place. They charge him with general incomeptency and disregard of the lives ...
A halting and drooping stock market ruled all day yesterday, while the one object of Wall-street consideration was the meeting of the new Western Railway Presidents' Association in Chicago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24.--Since the Presidential election Judge Thurman has remained closely at home, enjoying its comfort and the visits of numerous personal friends who have called to pay their respects. He has been out but little, an occasional visit to his office being ...
CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--Justice Thomas Bradwell has rendered an important decision in the replevin suit begun a week ago by Rhoades Ramsey, coal dealers, against the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railway.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--The Lord Mayor's banquet in honor of Minister Phelps tonight was the most remarkable gathering England has seen in many years. Indeed, so good an authority as Robert Browning said in private talk that he believed it to be the most notable assemblage Europe had ever seen.
CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Jan. 24.-- Public sentiment here is adverse to the proposed purchase by the United States Government of the territory of Lower California.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 24.--The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of the Bates Refrigerator Company against the Edison Electric Company created a flurry in the stock of the Westinghouse Company on the local Exchange to-day, it being believed by some that the decision affects suits pending between the two electric companies.

One of the most important undertakings any musical society in this city has ever undertaken is now well in hand under the auspices of the Arion Society. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 24.--The blockcutters' wages in both the large wall paper factories of this city will, at the beginning of next month, be reduced 10 per cent.

Judge Wheeler of the United States Circuit Court rendered a decision yesterday in the suit of Solon Humphreys and Edwin D. Morgan, as Trustees of the New-York and Pacific Car Trust Association, against the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railway Company upon a question involving a lease.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 24--At this season the town fire insurance companies of the interior of the State hold their annual meetings and make their financial exhibits for the year just past.

Funeral services were held at All Souls' Church, West Forty-eighth-street, yesterday morning, over the body of William Payson Mackaye, son of Steele Mackaye, who died on Tuesday last at the age of 20 years.

WAUKESHA, Wis., Jan. 24.--Simon Bolivar Needham has for months past prophesied the coming of a Messiah to this city. He even went so far as to fix the date, the 22d of January, and when yesterday a child was born unto Mrs. Carr, a widow and a member of his flock, there was great excitement among his followers.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25.--Howard D. Rees of the leather firm of Hans Rees's Sons, 17 Ferry street, New-York, killed himself at his home in Millburn by shooting.
WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 25.--Gen. Murray Myers has been ordered by the Governor to Clay County, the scene of the recent county seat war. A telegram from Lieut. Thorp, in charge of the militia there,...
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25.--Miss Emma C. Carleton of Minneapolis has been ordered to be sent to the insane asylum. Her case is a peculiarly sad one.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 25.--Chairman Williams of the House Committee on insurance has set aside Wednesday for the discussion of the bill relating to life endownment and casualty Insurance companies.

Dr. McGlynn has addressed a long open letter to Archbishop Corrigan in answer to the recent edict against attending the Anti-Poverty meetings.

The eight lines of Brooklyn surface railroads operated by "Deacon" Richardson's Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company were tied up a few minutes after 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and over 700 workmen were thrown out of employment.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 25.--The Rev. Dr. Tichenor, the Secretary of the Home Mission Board of the Southern Baptist Convention, left the city Wednesday night for Cuba with New-York exchange in his pocket for $20,000.

The Brooklyn police are investigating a daring highway robbery which took place under the glare of an electric light at Bedford-avenue and Hopper-street, in the Eastern District, at 4 o'clock Thursday morning. The victim was Eugene Cummiskey, who lives at Third-avenue and Thirtiethstreet, New-York.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 25.--For $10,500 F. C. Fowler of Moodus, Conn., has purchased of J. H. Blackford of Keene, Ky., the 6-year-old ch. s. Hinder Wilkes, with a 5-year-old record of 2:20 , by Red Wilkes, dam Lady Almont, by Almont.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The Surrogate of this county has made his decision in the ridiculous contest over the accounting of the will of the late lumber millionaire, James D. Weston, formerly of Tonawanda, and a member of the firm of A.W. Weston Son.

The terms of the Maximum Stakes of the American Jockey Club for 2-year-olds, entries for which close Feb. 1, having been indefinite as to weights in the original draft of the stakes, have been changed to read as follows: ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--The Railroad Trust is practically an accomplished fact, if the information obtainable concerning the second day's session to-day of the Presidents is reliable, and there is no reason to doubt that it is.
Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. have just given over 100 volumes to Union College library.

The Post Office has an employe who, in appearance, is almost appropriate servant of the Government. He is a fair copy of the conventional "Uncle Sam," and since his connection with the Federal Building has been dubbed with the national sobriquet.

The fifth day of the trial of Thomas Cleary, on the charge of accepting a bribe while a member of the Board of Aldermen of 1884, closed last night, and still not one of the 12 jury chairs is occupied.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 25.--The House of Representatives having rejected the Senate resolution forbidding C.M. Norwood, late Union Labor and Republican candidate for Governor, to contest Gov. Eagle's election unless he first gave bond to cover all costs, and limited the latter to $30,000, the investigation will proceed.
PARIS, Jan. 25.--A dispatch to the Temps from Zanzibar says: "An American sailing vessel, bound from Zanzibar to Madagascar, was fired on by a German vessel and one of her masts was broken."

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 25.--The pleasures and attractions of promenade week have passed, most of the visitors have gone, and Yale's students have again settled down to hard study. Interest in athletics has temporarily relaxed.
NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 25.--News comes from Cheshire that Mrs. Marcia Beers entered upon the second century of her existence last Monday.
A bold robbery was perpetrated by the "Whyo Gang," on the Bowery near Canalstreet, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Judge C.F. Brown of the Supreme Court recently appointed to the Second Division of the Court of Appeals of the State, was this evening tendered a complimentary dinner by Howard Thornton at the home of the latter on Grand-street.
When the Trenton was lying at Panama, prior to being ordered to the Samoan Islands, Lieut. Dillingham was sent down with a draft of men for her from the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25.--To-night Joseph A. Moore, the defaulting insurance agent, is locked up at his house in a state of physical and mental prostration--a self-confessed defaulter for an amount that is conceded to be more than a half million dollars and may reach much more.

There were no more removals at the Appraiser's stores yesterday and the Acting Appraiser spent but little time at his office. A conference lasting for several hours was held at the Custom House by Secretary Fairchild, Collector Magone, Acting Appraiser Stearns,...

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 25.--Col. W.H. Chilton, who has been for 15 years commercial editor of the Courier Journal, was to-day adjudged insane. His mind had been rapidly falling for two weeks. His condition was due to ill health and severe mental strain by close application to a narrow field of work. It is hoped that by rest from his customary labors he will be restored.
ZANZIBAR, Jan. 25.--An English missionary named Brooks and 16 of his followers were murdered on Saturday near Saadani by members of the coast tribes and natives of Zanzibar.

It took Auctioneer H.C. Merry about two hours yesterday to sell the theatrical wardrobe of J. Lestor Wallack at the Leavitt Art Rooms on Broadway. There were 87 catalogue lots, but nearly double that number of articles.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25.--The Rev. Boyd Vincent was consecrated Assistant Bishop of the Southern Diocese of Ohio in St. Paul's Church to-day. It has been half a century since a Bishop was consecrated here.

Mrs. Harrison, the wife of the Presidentelect, spent a busy day yesterday at the Gilsey House. In the forenoon she went for a drive in the Park, while the afternoon was given up to receiving calls, although she found time to take another short drive.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The Trustees and Board of Medical Directors of Vassar Brothers' Hospital having received a courteous letter from Mayor Rowley asking for information in relation to the management of the hospital, have sent a long reply.

The Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine have received a large number of sketches and plans for the proposed great edifice, in response to their general invitation to the architects of the world.

The inquiry into the controversy between the Spinola and Hagan factions in the Sixteenth Assembly District was not held in Tammany Hall last night. Some of the members of the committee of inquiry were not present, so it was adjourned until next Friday.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--The Baltimore Baseball Club has been asked to make an offer for Louisville's battery, Hecker and Cook, or else waive claim to them. Manager Davidson suggests that he would trade them for First Baseman Tucker and a cash bonus, but the Baltimore management would not listen to any proposition involving Tucker's transfer, and, having no use for Hecker and Cook, will probably relinquish all right to them.

The furniture warehouse of S. Epstein Son, at 99 Bowery, is in the hands of Deputy Sheriff Stevens. The failure has caused considerable comment, and the cause assigned is inability to collect outstanding accounts, which prevented the firm from meeting obligations about to mature.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 25.--The Secretary of War has officially notified the city of Frankfort, Ky., that the old wooden bridge across the Kentucky River at that point must be raised, as it is too low for boats to pass under. The bridge has stood for over 60 years.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Sitting just ahead of a TIMES reporter in a Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg car the other day were two elderly gentlemen who fell to talking about the weather.

The only thing to relieve the monotony of the brief session of the Assembly this morning was a little squabble over Mr. Ryan's bill appropriating $50,000 to improve the navigation of the Hudson River between Troy and Coxsackie.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25.--The last installment of entries to the Latonia Jockey Club Stakes was received to-day from California and the list is now complete and shows an array hitherto unequaled in quality or numbers.

Gov. Pennoyer has dismissed the Oregon Railroad Commission, consisting of ex-United States Senator Slater and Mr. Waggoner, upon the ground that a railroad commission is unnecessary, and that the State has no right to delegate its powers to a commission, anyway.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25.--Six oceangoing vessels with crews numbering all told 60 men have been long overdue at this port and have been given up for lost. The Austrian ship, the Lord Warden, new out 126 days, en route from Montevideo to Philadelphia, has been given up, and there is no longer any doubt but that she has gone to the bottom.
Judge William L. Learned of Albany is at the Victoria Hotel. Senator G.A. Deane of Copake, N.Y., is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

BOSTON, Jan. 25.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Justice Colt rendered an opinion adverse to Collector Saltonstall in the case brought against him by Daniel B. Claffin and others on the ground of overcharge of duties on goods described in the Custom House entries as cotton hose or stockings.

An attractive programme of private theatricals has been arranged for the annual entertainment for the benefit of St. Ann's Church to be given in Chickerling Hall next Tuesday evening.
RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 25.--Stephen Mylett of Rumson Neck went to New-York last Sunday and took with him his little boy, aged 4 years. Mylett left New-York on Wednesday.

Cyrille Carreau is getting signatures to a petition to the Legislature to have the law which gives the Board of Health power to compel landlords to abate nuisances caused by occupants of tenement houses changed so that proceedings in abatement be directed against the occupants.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Jan. 25.--The order of the Indian Commissioner warning lumbermen to cease logging operations on the Indian Reservation lands has created great excitement. The lumbermen announce that they will defy the Government. Trouble is feared and troops have been asked for to keep the peace.
AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 25.--The rejection of the Presidential Electoral return of Texas by Mr. Ingalls, President pro tem. of the Senate, created something of a commotion down here.
Cadet J.H.G. Lazelle, Fourth Class, Military Academy, has been granted leave of absence until June 20 next, when he will join the then Third Class.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25.--The Second Class of Naval Cadets, in a letter to Superintendent Sampson, deny their participation in the recent exploding of firecrackers in the cadets quarters.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 25.--The State of Georgia has just concluded negotiations with the State of South Carolina in which the possession of a dog was the point at issue. Judge Hopkins, who is the present Mayor of Thomasville, in...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The Tariff bill was received in the House this afternoon, but was not laid before that body. It will be submitted tomorrow by Speaker Carlisle, and unless an opposing motion should be made it will be referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

The nine boarders at the establishment of Mrs. Clark Stewart, 29 Cottage-place, were all taken sick yesterday soon after eating breakfast. Among them are three policemen who belong to the Fifth Precinct.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 25.--The alleged agreement 'between the Producers' Association and the Standard Oil Company had the effect of causing a flurry in oil on Change to-day.
ALBANY, Jan. 25.--There was not a quorum in the Senate this morning, and it was 11:30 o'clock before 17 Senators responded to their names.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 25.--The cup presented by Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan to Messrs. Owen and Metcalf of this city, late owners of the schooner Sachem, as the trophy for the Vineyard-to-Marblenead race for the season of 1887, is attracting a good deal of attention here from the fact that it is an old English trophy of the time of George IV.

The recent reports from Washington, to which we alluded yesterday, to the effect that an effort would be made to get a separate vote on the tobacco provisions of the Senate Tariff bill, and possibly to pass the whole bill, are gradually extending.
A terrible railway accident has occurred near this place, by which Princess Lieven, a member of a noble Russian family, narrowly escaped instant death.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--Dispatches were received at the State Department to-day from the United States Consul-General at Panama dated the 15th inst.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25.--The convention held at Fort Smith, Ark., yesterday, to discuss the question of establishing a Territorial Government over all the Indian Territory lying west of the State of Arkansas and opening it to settlement continued its session until midnight. Col. Robert A. Campbell, ex-Lieutenant-Governor of Missouri, was elected Chairman of the convention.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company issued yesterday a statement summarizing its affairs for the year of 1888. Gross earnings were $43,232,422, against $39,845,856 in 1887. Operating expenses increased from $30,694,000 in...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The fashionable world of Washington was well represented at the reception given to-night by Secretary and Mrs. Whitney.
The track at Clifton yesterday was very sloppy and deep in spots. The five races resulted as follows:
DANVILLE, Va., Jan. 25.--John Yancy, colored, who murdered Bob Oliver, also colored, in Caswell County, N.C. last April, was hanged at Yanceyville to-day.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Robert J. Masterton, one of the projectors of the bill for the Lombard Loan Company, which was introduced by Assembly man Demarest in the Legislature yesterday, was seen at his home in this place this evening.
VIENNA, Jan. 25.--The Fremdenblat denies the rumor that the Prince of Montenegro sent a note to the Czar proposing a union of the Balkan States.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Jan. 25.--At St. Peter's Church Wednesday morning Miss Jane Strawbridge Ledyard, daughter of George S. Ledyard, was married to Eliphalet remington of this place, the Rev. Mr. Neide, Rector of the church, officiating, assisted by the Rev. F.L. Norton, D.D., of Lynn, Mass.

The rooms of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation were crowded yesterday afternoon with telephone subscribers who indorse the board's bill, now at Albany, reducing telephone charges to $6 and $3 a month in the big cities and the smaller towns of the State.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The second chapter in Mayor Oliver's scheme to light this city by an electric light plant of its own was enacted at a mass meeting held here to-night. Central Hall was packed with over 2,000 taxpayers.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--A peculiar accident occurred to-day at the railway works at Crewe. An immense crane carrying a ladle containing seven tons of molten steel collapsed, and the ladle fell into a pit. Masses of the steel flew like bullets in every direction, and 20 men working in the vicinity of the pit were severely injured. The roof of the building was torn off.

The trial of a suit in which Mrs. Blanche L. Andrews seeks to recover $50,000 from the Executors of Seabury Brewster was begun yesterday before Judge Lawrence and a jury in the Supreme Court. Butler, Stillman Hubbard appeared for Mrs. Andrews and Townsend, Dyett Einstein for the Executors.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--The annual reports of fire insurance companies required by law to be filed with the State Superintendent of Insurance are nearly all in. From some of the latest received the following is abstracted:

Tucker; with Columbus, A.L. Mays and David Orr; with Louisville, W. B. Weaver, William Wolf, and D. Shannon;...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25.--To-day the Rev. Milton Merle Smith, Associate Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, resigned his charge and telegraphed his acceptance of the call made him by the Central Presbyterian Church of NewYork.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 25.--The liquor dealers of Allegheny County met here last evening and organized an association to oppose the prohibitory amendment in this State in the event of its submission to the people.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 25.--The wreck of the steamer Bristol was floated this morning and re moved from the head of the new deck, which she has blockaded for a month past to the south side of the old dock, where the machinery will be taken...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day sent to the Senate a response to the Plumb resolution calling for a detailed statement of all bond purchases made by the Government since March 4, 1885, and also all offers to sell bonds which have been rejected since that date. The following is a recapitulation of the Secretary's response:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--It looks as if the Baltimore and Ohio Road would soon solve the problem of rapid transit throughout Baltimore. At present its through trains to Philadelphia from Washington and Western points are ferried over the Patapsco River at Locust Point, which necessitates a delay.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 19.--The all-absorbing topic of discussion here at the present moment is the strange case of a Flemish mechanic, Stegaert, who was brought over here from New-York on a charge of murder committed at Gand, and whose second trial in that city has just been brought to a singular conclusion.

The Winter Carnival at Montreal always attracts large numbers of people from NewYork, Brooklyn, and Philadelphia. The West Shore Road has made extensive preparations to meet the traffic. Round-trip tickets will be sold Feb. 1 to 8, inclusive, good returning until Feb. 16, for $15.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--The Committee of Eighteen appointed four months ago to consider a plan for the revision of the contract on which the Central Traffic Association is founded met this morning.

William B. Neal, well along in years, seedy and sad-eyed, was before Recorder Smyth yesterday to plead guilty to forgery. He obtained about $50 worth of clothing on an order made by himself from a woman whose husband was in the Tombs.
DENVER, Jan. 25.--Information just received from Routt, Col., states that that portion of the State has been treated to a genuine earthquake. The shocks commenced on the afternoon of Jan. 15.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 25.--The Democratic caucus would have made a nomination last night, but adjourned at the request of several of the anti-Kenna men.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 25.--The J.J. Burns Co. assignment at Battle Creek begins to assume more important features as its facts become public. ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25.--One week ago a Winona grain dealer named Seefield, who is well known throughout the Northwest, suddenly disappeared, leaving creditors mourning the loss of some $300,000.

OTTAWA, Jan. 25.--Mr. W.D. Harrington, a wealthy Halifax grocer, will be appointed Collector of Customs at that port.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The Rev. Father McIncrow, Pastor of St. Mary's Catholic Church, has rebuked the married members of his parish for allowing their daughters to attend skating rinks at night.

The distinctive feature of the German Hospital fair to be held at the American Institute Building from Feb. 18 to Feb. 26 will be the art exhibition in charge of Mr. Louis Windmuller, a member of the Executive Committee of the hospital.
The street vendors who have been making big sales of various wire puzzles down town have generally got out of that line of trade and invested in playing cards and poker chips, dice, and dice boxes.
The terrible weather experienced by the steamship Amalfi, which arrived yesterday from Hamburg, came very near proving fatal to two of her crew and one of her passengers.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 25.--In Senator Hoar's letter to John E. Bruce, colored, of New-York, published in THE TIMES yesterday, Mr. Hoar says he does not believe Mahone said what is reported about the negroes. The interview appeared exclusively in the Charleston Daily World, and the reporter who got it, Fred Miller, will make affidavit that Mahone said exactly what was reported.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 25.--The fire here last night was not as destructive as it seemed it would be at one time. It originated in the drug store of B. Lemly, from the explosion of a coaloil lamp. The drug store was a total loss.

The derelict-schooner W.L. White, which crossed the ocean without a navigator and entered port at Stornoway, on the northern coast of Scotland last Wednesday, was built in Rockland, Me., in 1884. Her length was 164 4-10 feet, breadth 34 9-10 feet, and depth of hold 15 feet. Her gross tonnage was 659, and her net tonnage 626.

The Belgian steamer Olbers, Capt. Gregory, which arrived yesterday from Rio Janeiro, reports that at 3:30 P.M., Jan. 23, in latitude 36 8' north, and longitude, 70 38' west a disabled steamer was sighted with distress signals up.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25.--Murat Halstead swooped down upon Gen. Harrison to-day and carried him captive for a long walk in the outskirts of the city. Gen. Harrison is 5 feet 5 inches in height, while Mr. Halstead is 6 feet 2 inches and portly for his height, which was made to seem even more lofty by his enormous overcoat and tall silk hat.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--In the United States District Court Judge Morris has dismisses without costs the libel suit of Robert McGuinn, a colored minister, against the owners and Captain of the steamer Mason L. Weems for damages for the treatment on board to which McGuinn was subjected because of his color.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--Mrs. Gertrude S. Talcott of Cass County, Dakota, began an action here to-day asking that Joseph Elder, David McKinley, and William Applegate be enjoined from collecting a note for $2,000 given by her to cover alleged losses in dealings in grain on the Board of Trade. Besides the note Mrs. Talcott put up $1,131 in cash for margins.

Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday took the papers on a motion made by ex-Judge Dittenhoefer in behalf of Dion Boucicault, to which there was no opposition, to punish Henry E. Walton for contempt of court.

The fifth annual report of the Civil Service Commission of Brooklyn was sent to Mayor Chapin yesterday. The commission states that since the establishment of the present regulations in 1884 their substance has not been altered.
A story was circulated yesterday that Recorder Smyth had declared war against Mayor Grant and that he proposed to oppose him inside and outside of Tammany Hall.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The strike of the switchmen on the Nickel Plate in this city promises to prove more serious than was at first thought.

Paolo Giorza's fourth mass will be sung for the first time in this country, under the personal direction of the composer, at the Church of St. Agnes, Forty-third-street, near Lexington-avenue, to-morrow morninf at 11 o'clock.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 25.--The editorial estimate of the News and Courier that the cotton crop would reach 7,500,000 bales has caused a flutter in futures. Numerous inquiries have been received here from New-York and other markets and cablegrams from Liverpool asking upon what facts the estimate was based.

An extraordinary degree of interest was displayed in the enrollment of Republicans, or alleged Republicans, yesterday. It was an interest excited by the desire of many men to prove their alliance with the successful side, and by the ambition of certain persons to overthrow present leaders in various districts.

The committee of marketmen having in charge the arrangements for the opening of the new West Washington Market held a meeting at 100 Vesey-street yesterday afternoon and discussed the final details of the parade and the programme of the ceremonies.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 25.--The Railroad and Warehouse Commission has addressed a circular to the managers of the railroads within the State on the subject of uniform distance tariff and the matter of reducing the terminal commodity and other tariffs in force on the different lines for the transportation of grain, coal, lumber, live stock, and dressed meats.
