ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan 25.--The Rathbun House corridors were well filled yesterday afternoon and evening on the occasion of the meeting of the Central Baseball League.

Arthur Plympton, 38 years old, the wellknown dry goods merchant of Boston, Mass., was taken to Bellevue Hospital by friends last evening while suffering from nervous prostration. He was very violent while in the hospital, and was assigned to Ward 27, under the care of Dr. Parrish.
Jay Line Adams, an old and well-known business man of this city, died very suddenly on Thursday evening at his residence, 110 East Seventy-eighthstreet.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--As Mr. Phelps has not been recalled and has not resigned he is not entitled to an audience with the Queen. Nevertheless the Queen has invited Mr. and Mrs. Phelps to dine with her on Monday, and to remain at the palace over night. To-day Mrs. Phelps gave her last reception here. There was a large attendance.

Alderman Patrick Divver thought last Summer that he would make a good Sheriff. He sought but did not get the Tammany Hall nomination to the office. Now he thinks he would be a good Excise Commissioner.

There were some notable features about the nineteenth annual dinner of the Burns Society of this city at Sutherland's, in Libertystreet, last evening. One of these was the menu. Under the head of soup came cock-aleekie and Scotch hare.

A bill of interest to taxpayers, as well as to Trustees, guardians, administrators, and the beneficiaries of trust estates, has been drawn by Corporation Counsel Beekman, and, at his request, approved by the Controller, has been introduced into the Legislature by Assemblyman Hornidge.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 25.--The first annual convention of the Young Men's Christian Association of the First District of New-Jersey, embracing the associations located in Middlesex, Somerset, Union, and part of Monmouth Counties, assembled here to-day, and will be in session until Sunday evening.
Steamship Amalfl, (Ger.,) Kraeft, Hamburg 20 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Funch, Edye Co. Arrived at the Bar at 6 A.M.
One of the largest audiences of the season gathered in the Metropolitan Opera House last evening at the second performance of Halevy's "Jewess."

CHARLESTOWN, Mass., Jan. 25.--An unsuccessful attempt, evidently by professional cracksmen, was made to break the Connecticut River National Bank last night, and it apparently failed only through lack of time to remove unexpected obstructions.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 25.--Chief of Police Brackett to-day formally announced that there would be no more "glove contests" or prize fights in the city under his administration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 25.--It has been a long time since there has been so great activity in athletics as is now shown at Harvard. Any one who says or thinks that all the work is done by the candidates for the baseball nine is mistaken. Harvard is devoting a great deal of attention to all branches of college sport.

DUBLIN, Jan. 25.--When the trial of Mr. William O'Brien was resumed to-day at Carrick-onSuir, Mr. O'Brien was absent. The trial, however, proceeded in his absence, and he was convicted and sentenced to four months' imprisonment without hard labor. The police have as yet discovered no clue to Mr. O'Brien's whereabouts.
HAVANA, Jan. 25.--The third game in the chess tournament here was begun yesterday and continued eight hours. After midnight play was suspended to be resumed to-day.

ASHLAND, Wis., Jan. 25.--Orders have been received by Indian Agent Gregory from Commissioner Oberly which have put a stop to the cutting and hauling of Indian pine timber contracts not yet approved by the department.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--An English syndicate is endeavoring to form a trust among the Albany brewing firms. The greatest reticence on the subject prevails.
JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 25.--A murder was committed here last night. Mrs. Mary H. Latimer, a widow, living with her son, R. Irving Latimer, a druggist, was shot twice in the head after retiring.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--While skylarking in a saloon in Calvert-street to-night, Edward Gordon, the barkeeper, was accidentally shot in the left breast and fatally wounded by Peter J. Campbell, a member of the Maryland Legislature from this city. Campbell gave himself up to the police.

More than 100 of the Alumni of Amherst College met last night at Delmonico's to dine in honor of their Alma Mater and sing and say her praises with enthusiasm. Before sitting down to the dinner they held a short business meeting and elected the officers who will have charge of their association for a year.

The owner of the hat, coat, and cane found on the ferryboat Manhattan Beach Thursday, was Adolph Liebenroth, a wealthy citizen of College Point, Long Island, and a member of the firm of Liebenroth, Vonauw Co., 52 Franklin-street, New-York.

Angelo Diloco, who knocked down and robbed Carl Neidhert of 1,359 First-avenue of his watch, chain, and locket at Second-avenue and Seventy-fourth-street, Jan. 1, was taken before Recorder Smyth, in Part I. of General Sessions, for sentence yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Joshua Overton, a farmer, who lived near Theresa, Jefferson County, hanged himself in his barn last evening. A succession of financial and physical afflictions caused the suicide.

PARIS, Jan. 25.--Two reports will be presented at the meeting of the Panama Canal shareholders announced for to-morrow. One is signed by the temporary Administrators, and will detail the negotiations which have resulted in the formation of the new company.

A jury before Coroner Schultze yesterday in the case of William C. Morris, a fresco painter of Salt Lake City, who accidentally turned on the gas in his room at 12 East Twenty-third-street on New Year's Eve and who died from its inhalation at the New-York Hospital Jan. 5, brought in a rather peculiar verdict.
In the American Museum of Natural History there are four specimens of the Labrador duck. Two are adult males, one an adult female, and one a young male.
JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Jan. 25.--Sheriff Hay and posse went to Bull Creek early yesterday morning, and succeeded at last in arresting old Harrison Hogan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate: Robert M. Branch, Postmaster at Florence, Mass.; Russell D. Woodman, Appraiser of Merchandise for the port of Portland, Me.; Benjamin F. Chadbourne, Assistant Appraiser of Merchandise for the port of Portland, Me.

DETROIT, Jan. 26.--Despairing of bringing the rebellious Poles under the leadership of Father Kolasinski back into the fold by gentle methods, Bishop Foley yesterday issued a circular warning them that further attendance upon the service of the deposed priest meant excommunication.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--The Grand Opera House was closed to-night for the second time this week. Fanny Davenport is the attraction, and the management announced "the continued illness of Miss Davenport" as the cause.

A guest at the Sturtevant House has just had a protracted spree wound up for him in a most peculiar and embarrassing manner. The gentleman is E.B. Pickardt of St. Paul, a wealthy young man, extensively engaged in the storage and warehouse business. He came to NewYork recently and has been having a glorious time.

The Portuguese have been daring sailors from the earliest periods of their history, and this characteristic is predominant in the race at the present day. The results of political strife and intrigue have left Portugal in a condition sufficiently weak to warrant her seeking England's protectorate.

Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, wife of the President-elect, is still at the Gilsey House. She spent a more quiet day yesterday than on Friday, although she went driving twice and received a number of callers. The latter, however, were not as numerous as those of the preceding day. Last evening she dined with friends in the city.

BERLIN, Jan. 26.--The East Africa bill came up for debate in the Reichstag to-day. The chamber was crowded, and much eagerness was manifested to hear the discussion.

VIENNA, Jan. 26.--Emperor Francis Joseph gave a dinner at the palace to-night on the occasion of the eve of Emperor William's birthday. The Prince of Reuss, German Ambassador here Count Kalnoky, Count von Taafe, and other leading diplomats were present.

The Rev. Cure Chagnon has gone to Quebec to see Cardinal Taschereau, carrying with him statistics showing that the French Canadian Catholics in the New-England States outnumbered the Catholics of all other nationalities in those States by 5,000. BRUSSELS, Jan. 26.--It is officially announced that King Leopold has created, under the Presidency of Prince Ligne and Gen. Baron Jolly, an African Society of the Red Cross.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 26.--The big oyster steamer Early Bird, owned by Cook Hilton of Five-Mile River, was set on fire by an incendiary early this morning and totally destroyed. The vessel was on the ways, undergoing repairs, and it is the impression of the owners that the deed was done through malice.

One of the most remarkable characters Cincinnati ever saw died yesterday. It was Dr. Joseph Garretson of West Eighth-street. For 62 years of his life he never drank a cup of coffee nor sipped a little tea.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Jan. 26.--Garrett Swisher, a well-known character living at Vienna, was this morning found drowned in Penwell Pond. Yesterday he took a load of produce to Washington, and driving home late at night after drinking very freely he drove his team in the pond.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26.--A small fire on the stage of the Olympic Theatre created a panic at the matinee this afternoon and a great loss of life was narrowly averted. The attraction was "Erminie," and at the end of the first act the fire blazed out in view of the audience.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 26.--The North End Club has just completed at a cost of $60,000 its new clubhouse, which is the best equipped and handsomest in this city. The building is three stories high and is built of brownstone, with granite trimmings.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 26.--Jacob Tome's gift of $500,000 for a free seminary and manual training school to Port Deposit will be increased by an endowment of at least $2,000,000, and probably $3,000,000. Port Deposit is a town with about 2,200 population on the Susquehanna River.

PARIS, Jan. 26.--A meeting of holders of Panama Canal shares was held to-day. M. de Lesseps was present and met with a hearty reception, out no offers of financial assistance to the canal company were made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The total amount of bonds purchased to date under the circular of April 17 is $108,917,800, of which $51,396,650 were four per cents, and $57,521,150 were four and one-half per cents. CINCINNATI, Jan. 26.--Charles A. Stevenson, husband of Kate Claxton, the actress, was in the Police Court this morning on a charge of assault and battery brought by Benjamin Wessel. Capt. William Badger, Sixth Infantry, was yesterday placed on the retired list of the army, having been found incapacitated for active duty by a Retiring Board. His retirement will cause the promotion to be Captain of First Lieut. John Carland, the oldest First Lieutenant of Infantry in the army, who has nearly reached the age of retirement.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 26.--The tour of the Clara Louise Kellogg Opera Company closed to-night. Manager Strakosch says it is useless for the company to go any further.

A gentleman from Dakota arrived in Florida a few days since, and in conversation with a prominent citizen of Orlando said there were more deaths last Winter in his immediate section from cold weather than there were in the whole State of Florida last Summer from yellow fever.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Dispatches from Yankton, Chamberlin, and Sioux Falls, Dakota, report a furious snow and wind storm prevailing since yesterday morning and the temperature falling very rapidly. At Sioux Falls the mercury dropped from 45 above at 9 A.M., to zero at 11 P.M.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--The General Managers and General Passenger Agents of the Western, Northwestern, and South western railroads have submitted a plan which, if they live up to it, will make it impossible for any ticket broker to do business. It was discussed at a meeting held here to-day, at which 20 of the 21 interested roads were represented. The one unrepresented, the Chicago, Burlington and Northern, is known to be in accord with the agreement.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 26.--The Mercantile Banking Company, a small concern without a State bank charter, but which has been doing a collection and loan business under a Superior Court charter, was put in the hands of a temporary Receiver to-night. J.R. Tolleson is at the head of the concern.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--A dispatch from Brisbane, Queensland, says that Mr. Armstrong, the Government labor agent in New Guinea, was inveigled ashore by natives on the Island of Manoba and put to death, his head being split open with a tomahawk. The head of the unfortunate man was sent to the chiefs on the mainland.

CARTHAGE, Ill., Jan. 26.--A wolf hunt, participated in by 500 men and boys, took place yesterday. Timber and prarie wolves have become very numerous this Winter. They have made inroads upon small domestic animals and fowls. An exciting day's sport was had and three wolves were captured. Several dogs were severely injured in fights with the wolves.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 26.--The cold wave is expected to reach here to-night. At 7 o'clock this evening the mercury was 10 above, and the Signal Service officer says it will go below zero before morning. The fail in temperature has been very pronounced, especially at Sioux Falls, Dakota, where the mercury dropped 70 in 10 hours--from 60 above to 10 below. There has been only a light snowfall, scarcely worth mentioning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--There is no doubt whatever that Congress will adopt the proposition of Mr. Sherman and Mr. Herbert to appropriate a liberal sum of money to enable the Administration to occupy a coaling station at Pango-Pango Harbor and to protect American interests in Samoa.
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 26.--The Junior Literary Society is a new organization at Yale which has taken upon itself the duty of cultivating and increasing the literary spirit of the college.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 27.--The West End has a new addition to its fleet of boats in the shape of a pretty sailing canoe. It is one of the finest in America, and carried off championship honors in the annual regatta at Perth Amboy, several Northern illustrated periodicals publishing her picture in that connection.
BIDDEFORD, Me., Jan. 27.--The worst snowstorm of the season began this morning. A strong wind has blown all day and the snow is drifted badly. To-night snow is still falling.

The Faculty of Cornell take a rational and advanced view of college athletics, and the interviews with President ADAMS and a number of the Professors published in yesterday's TIMES will meet with cordial approval, not only from the Alumni of Cornell and other universities, but from sensible undergraduates as well.

BERLIN, Jan. 27.--The city was gay with bunting to-day in honor of the Emperor's birthday. Special services were held in the churches, and numerous banquets and other entertainments were given to celebrate the occasion.

The total amount of dividend and interest payment in Boston in February is $4,045,757, against $4,213,320 last August. The passing of the Atchison dividend takes $975,000 out, but this is largely made up by increases and principal payments.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--There was no demand for discount during the past week. The reduction of the official rate been followed by a marked movement downward. Yesterday's rates were only 2 to 1. It is expected that the Bank of England will immediately reduce the rates still further.

A.R. Cazauran, the well-known playwright and writer, died yesterday noon at the Hotel Dam, after a long illness. He had been in poor health for two years. His sickness afterward developed into a drepsical affection. For the past six months he was confined to his room, and at times lay very low.

Gen. BOULANGER'S plurality in the election at Paris yesterday was 81,550; his majority over all other candidates was 54,432. The vote was an extremely full one for France, where for a number of years the "abstentions" have been considerable.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 27.--During a fight with four tramps on the outskirts of the city to-night, Police Officer Ellis J. Ellis was shot in two places in the abdomen. He will probably die. The entire police force has been scattered over the city and surrounding country in search of the men who shot Ellis.
The Union League Club of the Twentysixth Ward of Brooklyn has grown so rapidly since its organization, less than two years ago, that its members are preparing to build a costly clubhouse.
During the past week amateur athletes have been devoting much time to a discussion of the handicapping system, which worked rather unfairly at the Athletic Union games at Madison-Square Garden.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 27.--Rain has fallen heavily nearly all day along the Hudson River. In portions of the Catskill Mountains snow fell. Roads are in very bad condition to-night. In this city when the rain first began falling it froze on the sidewalks, making all out of doors a veritable sheet of glass, treacherous in the extreme.

One hundred and five collieries are now open in India, which, among them, raised nearly 1,400,000 tons of coal in 1886. It is not so very long since the chief Indian Government geologist said that he was prepared to eat all the coal that was ever found in India.

A large proportion of the Executive Committee and of the lady managers of the German Hospital Fair, which is to be held at the American Institute from Feb. 18 to 26, inclusive, met at the Liederkranz Club yesterday afternoon to discuss ways and means and report progress.

Kentucky is responsible for the present disagreeable weather which is prevalent in nearly every State east of the Mississippi. Early yesterday morning the wind, the rain, and the snow were dispatched from that State to make mankind uncomfortable.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 27.--The Scranton and Forest City Railroad Company, under which title the Ontario and Western Company is building the southern end of its proposed branch from Hancock, N.Y., to the Lackawanna coal fields, is having a very hard time in securing a right of way.

Like the Emperor Justinian, Mr. John Elsey of Duncan-avenue, Jersey City, is having trouble with the factions of his church. Like that great lawmaker, Mr. Elsey relies upon his material power to gain the respect which is his due, and, still more like the ruler of the East, Mr. Elsey knows that silence is golden, particularly while there is a fight abroad.

James Madigan of 354 Madison-street, who was found in the hallway at 307 Monroestreet with a bad stab wound in the left breast, made a contradictory ante-mortem statement early yesterday morning at Gouverneur Hospital.
A gendarme was buried alive the other day in a village near Grenoble. The man had become intoxicated on potato brandy, and fell into a profound sleep.

The gunners who are accustomed to hunt wild ducks on the Great South Bay are wondering whether it will be necessary for the birds to go south at all this Winter. Wild fowl will remain on the waters near the city until the bays freeze over and they are unable to get food.

The chief feature of the Naval Appropriation bill now before the House for action is its liberal provision for constructing the new vessels. This will bring the total amount carried by the bill above that of the current fiscal year.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 27.--The remains of Congressman James N. Burnes were interred at Mount Mora Cemetery in this city, after appropriate ceremonies at Ayr Lawn, his country home, at 4 o'clock this afternoon.
Thirty-five years ago the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was established, and the anniversary was celebrated in many of the churches in that city last night.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 27.--There is indisputable evidence in the hands of the Democratic managers which snows that agents of the Republican Party have attempted to bribe four members of the Legislature. It is sufficient to establish a moral certainty of guilt if it does not convict the bribers and lead to the detection of the men behind them.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27.--John H. Tucker, age 21, to-night attempted to murder his father by shooting him in the house at 146 Madisonstreet, but was unsucessful. He was arrested. He made a similar attempt last night. Tucker has just finished a term of imprisonment for stealing.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 27.--In South Carolina, as in nearly all the other States of the Union, what is called "the old-soldier element" is one of the most powerful of political factors.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Jan. 27.--The White Caps continue to make their threats, and in some instances are taking steps to carry them out. It was considered by some that the talk of White Caps being around was only a joke, ...

Henry S. Ives and Partner George H. Stayner spent yesterday in their rather princely prison on the third floor of the Sinclair House. Saturday had passed without their procuring the bail of $250,000 set by Judge O'Brien in the civil suit brought by the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company to recover $2,500,000.

The officers of the Etruria were very uneasy men during the steamship's last trip. The Chief Engineer was said to have been particularly displeased.

Here is one of the latest stories of the great von Biilow. He was walking one day in Berlin when he met a man with whom he had formerly been on somewhat intimate terms, but whose acquaintance he was desirous of dropping.

The Rev. Dr. Taylor of the Broadway Tabernacle preached last evening on the subject of medical missions, with special reference to the International Medical Missionary Society of 118 East Forty-fifth-street.

The office seeker does not always select the place for which he is best fitted. Mr. M.D. HELM of Washington, D.C., and Muncie, Ind., has picked out the office of Public Printer, and, although he has had some experience in the printing business, it occurs to us that he should turn his attention to some other department of the public service.

ROME, Jan. 27.--A demonstration was made by the Radicals to-day to celebrate the anniversary of the battle of Digione. The proceedings were orderly until one of the speakers alluded in offensive terms to King Humbert. This led to a conflict with the police, several of whom were injured. Fifteen persons were arrested.

The past year has been a remarkably profitable one for all fire insurance companies of the State, the earnings of several being 25 per cent. above all losses and expenses. Every company has been able to carry a handsome sum to the surplus account, in addition to dividends divided.
The first sealed handicap cross-country race in America will be held over a six-mile course on Long Island by the Prospect Harriers on Saturday, Feb. 16, at 5 P.M.
Thanksgiving services were held in the Bedford-Avenue Refermed Church, Brooklyn, yesterday on account of the lifting of a debt of $50,000 which had hampered the church for the past 20 years.
The steamer La Bretagne, which arrived yesterday from Havre, made her trip in very quick time, beautiful weather having been encountered nearly all the way over.

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--If New-York loses a Cabinet position it will be due entirely to the pervisity, obtuseness, and selfishness of Mr. Thomas C. Platt. The Cabinet bee did not enter his head till after he heard that Gen. Harrison was looking with favor upon Mr. Warner Miller as the successor of Mr. Fairchild.
LONDON, Jan. 28.--The steamship Leerdam, (Dutch.) Capt. Stenger, from New-York Jan. 13 for Amsterdam, passed the Lizard yesterday.
An absurd instance of the length to which the policy of protection is carried out by French douaniers was told the other day by M. Maspero to some friends.
During a drunken row on Saturday night in the rooms of Peter Callahan at 19 Statestreet, Brooklyn, Callahan beat and kicked John O'Day so severely that O'Day died at 8 o'clock last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission has promulgated an opinion on the subject of passenger tariffs and rate wars prepared by Chairman Cooley.

Of every eight loaves of bread which the Londoner eats seven are made of foreign wheat --two being Russian--and only one of homegrown grain. During last year London received a total of 2,745,891 quarters of wheat, and of flour a further quantity (reckoned as quarters) of 2,356,883 quarters, or a grand total of 5,102,774 quarters.

ELMIRA, Jan. 27.--It is stated in this city tonight that Alexander C. Eustace, Gov. Hill's lieutenant and personal Elmira friend, will within the next two weeks be nominated for Superintendent of the Insurance Department, in place of Robert A. Maxwell.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28.--The Chicago Gas Trust is in court again. It was brought up before Judge Baker this morning on the demurrer of the trust to the petition for quo warranto filed in the name of people on the relation of Francis B. Peabody, the object of the proceeding being to secure the dissolution of the big monopoly. George Hunt, AttorneyGeneral of Illinois opened the arguments, appearing in behalf of the people.

The publication of the long-promised statement of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company attracted lots of attention in Wall-street yesterday, but only that group of gentlemen whose business it is to be satisfied with everything sound pleasure in it.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 28.--In joint convention to-day the Legislature elected George L. Beal of Norway State Treasurer. He received 112 out of 115 votes cast.
PARIS, Jan. 28--In consequence of the victory of Gen. Boulanger yesterday the Ministry tendered their resignations this morning, but President Carnet declined to accept them.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--The marriage ties of James Henry, Jr., and his wife, Annie Henry, were to-day unfastened by a jury in Judge Bregy's court. Mr. Henry is a member of the cotton manufacturing firm of Thomas Henry Son. Mrs. Henry is an actress.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 28.--To-day's races were run over a very heavy track. The weather was clear, windy, and cold. Following are the results:

Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court yesterday, reserved decision on a motion made by John E. Parsons for a stay of the judgment against the North River Sugar Refining Company, pending an appeal. This, if granted, would make the appointment of Mr. Gray as Receiver, to all intents and purposes, null and void.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--The McCaull Opera Company began its regular Winter engagement at the Chestnut-Street Opera House to-night and gave its first performance of Von Suppe's opera "Fatinitza," with a castincluding Marion ...

The great and constantly-increasing number of equestrians that this city boasts will be delighted to know that before long the bridle path in Central Park, which now stops at Mount St. Vincent, will be extended to the upper end of the Park at One Hundred and Tenth-street and Eighth-avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bonds: Four and one-half per cent. bonds to the amount of $102,300 at 109.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 28.--Police Officer Ellis J. Ellis, one of the most trustworthy, brave, and efficient men on the Scranton force, died at noon to-day of injuries received in a desperate encounter with a gang of tramps on the outskirts of the city last evening. An eager search for the murderous tramps is going on in the surrounding woods.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 28.--C.W. Barry, the veteran actor, stricken with paralysis on the Grand Opera House stage last night, died this morning. The remains will be taken to NewYork. Mr. Barry was formerly well-known for his rendition of old-men paris in stock companies, but recently he had been playing in sensational pieces. He was the author of "Escaped from Sing Sing," which he wrote for Dominick Murray, and in which he himself appeared.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28.--The sessions of the Legislature to-night were short. In the Senate a bill to pay Grand Jurors the same as petit jurors was defeated and killed-- 10 to 11.

Ex-Alderman Conkling has made charges of incapacity against Street-Cleaning Commissioner James S. Coleman, and has asked Mayor Grant to investigate them.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 28.--Four convicts escaped from the Onondaga Penitentiary late last night by prying up the floor of the shop where they were incarcerated as smallpox suspects.

WOLFBOROUGH, N.H., Jan. 28.--Mrs. Nancy Edgarly, a life-long resident of this town, died Saturday at the age of 104 years 5 months and 28 days. She retained all her faculties and strength to a remarkable degree. Since her last birthday she gradually weakened in body and mind, becoming entirely dependent during the last six months.

MONTREAL, Jan. 28.--Medical men are curiously interested here over a pamphlet published by Dr. J.A. Crevier, a French Canadian practitioner, in 1866, entitled "Etude sur le Cholera Asiatique," which is revised by La Patric and indorsed as authentic by the French author, Louis Frechette.

It is understood in military circles that the nominations of those non-commissioned officers who passed the last examination for commissions in the army will be sent in this week to the Senate.

Judge Beach destroyed the symmetry of the United States Illuminating Company's complaint in its suit against the Board of Electrical Control, on trial before him, by deciding yesterday morning that the only question to be considered was whether or not the board had removed or interfered with the company's poles and wires.

BOSTON, Jan. 28.--The schooner yacht Gitana, owned by Commodore Weed of the Eastern Yacht Club, was to sail to-day for a cruise in the Mediterranean, but an accident which befell her in getting under way will delay her departure for several days.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 28.--Last night a white woman named Mrs. Elizabeth Brown, a respected lady of Danville, Va., left Durham, where she had been to sell a piece of property, and started to return to Danville.

RAHWAY, Jan. 28.--The Post Office here was broken into Sunday night, the safe smashed, and about $400 in money and stamps was stolen.
OTTAWA, Jan. 28.--Five miles of track belonging to the St. Croix and Penobscot Railway, a road which runs from Calais, Me., to Princeton, Me., has been seized by Canadian customs officials.

Capt. D.F. Tezier of the United States revenue cutter Manhattan received orders yesterday morning from Collector Magone to board the Mallory Line steamer Carondelet and make inquiries concerning her cargo. The United States was given a verdict in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in a suit brought by A.D. Julliard Co. to recover duty paid upon several importations of wool tops. When the wool arrived the Custom House inspectors rated it not as ordinarily wool, but as scoured wool, and charged 60 cents duty instead of 30 cents.
The effect of the press upon stage art was pretty thoroughly discussed last night at the Brunswick Hotel, when Dion Boucicault and William Winter read papers before the Goethe Society.
GRAHAM, Texas, Jan. 28.--Boone Marlow, who murdered Sheriff Wallace of Young County Dec. 18 last, was killed last Thursday in the Indian Territory by Martin Beavers and John Derrickson.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 28.--William Tate, a wealthy farmer of Hamblen County, has given $20,000 out of his private fortune to be distributed among disabled Confederate soldiers of the First and Second Congressional Districts. He was a private in the Confederate Army.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 28.--Judge Jackson of the United States Circuit Court to-day rendered a decision in the case of Winters and others against Receiver Armstrong of the Fidelity National Bank, in which the question of the validity of the second issue of $1,000,000 stock was at issue.
OTTAWA, Jan. 28.--There is little prospect of the Government resuming the issue of fishing licences to American vessels under the conditions of the modus vivendi.

LONDON, Jan. 28.--The settlement opened to-day on the London Stock Exchange. Money was abundant. Contangoes were easy at 2 to 4 per cent. for foreign securities and 3 to 4 per cent. for American railway securities.

ATLANTA, Ca., Jan. 28.--J.R. Tolleson, President, and James M. Richards, Cashier of the Mercantile Banking Company, were sent to jail to-day by Judge Marshall J. Clarke for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--The President has commuted the sentence of Banker Fish so that he will be released from confinement in May. He has had the case long before him for consideration and has listened to many arguments in Fish's behalf.

William Dieterle, proprietor of the Montreal Black Goods Store, at Montreal, assigned yesterday at the instance of Stewart McDonald of Glasgow, with liabilities aggregating $54,000. Mr. S.C. Fatt has been approached provisional guardian, and a meeting of creditors has been called.
MONTREAL, Jan. 28.--A young Parisian named Raoul Delmas, employed in the audit office of the Canadian Pacific Railway, has mysteriously disappeared.

At Scottish Rite Hall, Madison-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, services were held yesterday over the dead body of Mary H. Fiske--journalist, dramatist, and author. Utterly lacking those outward signs of mourning which characterize funeral services, yet the obsequies of Mary H. Fiske were none the less solemn and impressive.

BERLIN, Jan. 28.--The committee of the Reichstag to which was referred the East Africa bill, has approved of the measure, after striking out the clause placing the East Africa Company under the control of Capt. Weismann.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 28.--There is considerable gossip to-day over the resignation of the Rev. Mr. Brown as Pastor of the Second Reformed Church in this city. Interviews with some of the Consistory show that dissatisfaction existed in the church over his coming, and it has ...
The track at Clifton was in bad shape yesterday and dangerous. Two horses fell during the races, but luckily without serious consequences.

A defective grate caused a fire in one of the apartments of Grace Church rectory, occupied by the Rev. Dr. Huntington, a few minutes before midnight last night. An alarm was sent out and the fire was extinguished after about $20 damage had been done.

Arrangements for the continuous pool tournament for the championship of the United States and a purse of $1,000 have almost been completed. Hardman Hall, Fifth-avenue, and Nineteenth-street, has been engaged by the committee, and Monday, Feb. 25, will be the opening night.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 28.--The sensation of the day has been the expose in regard to the bribery cases. Intimations of these have from time to time been made, and Republicans have discredited them.
LONDON, Jan. 28.--London doctor eloped on Friday last from Nice with the 17-year-old daughter of a resident of New-York State. The young lady is a blond and very pretty.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan-28.--James B. Green today instituted in the Circuit Court of this city a suit for $40,000 against the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company.

The official naval board, consisting of Commander Goodrich as President and Lieuts. Seaton Schroeder and Bradley A. Fiske, yesterday considered the results of Saturday's official test of the dynamite guns for the Vesuvius.

The Kitty Cody inquest was concluded last night by Coroner Roeney in the Brooklyn Court House. Detective Reynolds and Capt. Kenny gave testimony implicating Frank Dudgeon, who is charged with complicity in the crime which resulted in Miss Cody's death.
SUAKIN, Jan. 28.--A merchant who has arrived here from Khartoum asserts that the dervishes captured Emin Pasha, who, however, escaped.
ALBANY, Jan. 28--The session of the Legislature to-night was uneventful. Many of the New-York members were absent, in attendance at the Police Captains' dinner in the metropolis.

The parties to the Stewart will contest heard little that was new and less that was important in yesterday's proceedings, during which ex-Judge J. Lawrence Smith continued his testimony under cross-examination. In the morning inquiry was confined mainly to the identification of notes and letters from Mrs. Smith to Mrs. Stewart in which was occasional "Love to the Judge."

Detective Vahent of the Charles-street police station is endeavoring to verify a confession of murder by Fritz Roehl, 16 years old, which was made on Tuesday, when he was arrested for attempting to rob his employer, Jacob Thurmann, who has a restaurant at 96 Gansevoort-street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28.--The meeting of Presidents of the Western railroads to-day suceeded in removing all stumbling blocks hitherto encountered by the "gentlemen's agreement." Tonight there seemed to be little or nothing to prevent a speedy organization of the proposed Inter-State Railway Association.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28.--Mr. T.S. Tinsley, a prominent architect and inventor of Kansas City, is reported to have discovered a method of producing sterilized air. The value of the discovery is stated that all surgical operations can be performed by its use without danger of subsequent inflammation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day delivered an opinion in the case of William H. Robertson, Collector of the Port of New-York, plaintiff in error, against the Excutors of Charles L. Perkins.

The matinee performance of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" at the Broadway Theatre yesterday attracted one of the largest audiences which has been brought together to see Mrs. Burnett's play.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 28.--The joint legislative committee now considering the subject of pools and trusts has been steadily at work for some time, and the indications are that a report will soon be made.

Little Fannie Moore was buried yesterday. The causes which led to her death were sad in the extreme and aggravating beyond measure. She was absolutely frightened to death by an unknown scoundrel. Fannie was a very pretty child and not yet 11 years of age, though she had the appearance of a girl of 14. She lived with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Moore, of 317 East Twelfth-street.

Joe H. Stewart, for the Board of Directors of the National Confederate Soldiers' Home, at Austin, Texas, has issued an appeal to the patriotic and charitable men and women of the country for contributors in aid of the institution.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28.--Manager J.H. McVicker's suit against Mrs. Langtry for $10,000 damages, for failure to play at his theatre some months ago, when she claimed to be sick, came up for trial before Judge Gresham to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28.--Judge Cooley and Col. Morrison of the Inter-State Commerce Commission were in Chicago to-day on their way to St. Paul, where they will confer on various matters with the Minnesota State Railroad Commissioners.

Mr. George O.T. Weiss, a German music teacher of some 15 years' residence in this city, is the composer of a mass that is to be performed for the first time next Sunday at 11:15 A.M. in St. Teresa's Church, Rutgers and Henry streets. Archbishop Corrigan, to whom the mass is dedicated, has written a pleasant autograph letter in acknowledgement thereof.

In answer to Senator Chandler's resolution relative to the allowance of claims of naval officers and men on receiving ships for extra pay the Secretary of the Treasury sent to the Senate yesterday a communication on the subject from the Fourth Auditor.

The frost king enjoyed himself yesterday, painting noses red and nipping ears until they glowed and tingled painfully. His advent was preceded by a light fall of rain, followed in remarkably quick time by a shower of feathery snowflakes. The changes in temperature were rung at such short intervals that the general aspect of the city underwent a complete transformation during the night.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 6.--Mrs. Alexander Wicks, 70 years old, reached this city today on her way to Bridgeport, Conn., where her two sons live.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 28.--It was discovered to-day that smallpox had broken out in the Onondaga Poorhouse, situated four miles from Syracuse. Seven of the inmates are sick with the disease and fully a hundred others have been exposed. The State Board of Health has ordered the institution to be quarantined. The smallpox has entierly disappeared from Syracuse.

The cars on nearly all of the street railroads in this city will stop running this morning. The local assemblies of the various roads whose employes belong to the Knights of Labor have been holding meetings for the past six days, and have taken a vote as to whether they should tie up or not. It was yesterday announced that the vote for a tie-up was unanimous.

Detective Eibe F. Hey died Sunday morning at his home, 38 Charlton-street. For 27 years past he had been connected with the Police Department, and for the last 10 years had been at the new Twenty-eighth Precinct.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education Bernard McFarland of 186 West Fourth-street presented charges against E.J. Tinsdale one of the School Trustees of the Ninth Ward, accusing him of conduct tending to discredit his office as School Theatre and the system.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 28.--The United States Government has entered suit in the United States Circuit Court for the forfeiture of the bonds of the late United States Marshal of this district, Reuben B. Pleasants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--Mrs. Cleveland held a reception after 8 o'clock this evening to a large party of specially-invited guests.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 28.--Fire was discovered is the Grand Opera House at 2 o'clock this morning. It started in the basement, and was soon beyond control, although the whole Fire Department was early on the spot. At 3:30 A. M. the building was a total ruin.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 28.--Bob Cook, Yale's famous oarsmen and coach, was in this city Saturday afternoon and saw the crew row. He inspected the tank and was pleased with Janitor Cooper's improvements. George Adee and ex-Capt. Stevenson were also at the college, and a consultation on boating matters was held in Capt. Woodruff's room.
The entertainment offered at Koster Birl's was varied and attractive last night for those fond of specialty performances.

Fifty or more produce commission merchants, grocers, and farmers met at the Retail Grocers' Union, 213 East Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon by invitation of the Market Committee, and tried hard to reconcile their ...

The Railroad Committee of the Connecticut Legislature, which will resume the hearing to-day concerning the Housatonic Road's improvements, will submit the objection raised by the Consolidated Road last week to a disinterested Judge for decision.

The course of lectures now being delivered in seven of the public schools every Monday and Thursday evenings are attracting much attention. They are for workingmen and working women, and include talks on physiology, astrology, natural science, chemistry, political science, law, and other subjects. The lecturers include Profs. Roberts, Bickmore ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--The Supreme Court to-day handed down a long opinion affirming the decisions of the Court of Common Pleas of this city in the case of Knight, Bayard Hinchman against the Philadelphia and ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--Mrs. Harriet Burrow, who pleaded guilty last week to murdering her husband, William Burrow, was to-day brought up from prison to the new Court House to have the degree of her crime fixed by Judge Hare.

The Irish Parliamentary Fund Association met last evening in the Hoffman House. Mr. Eugene Kelly presided and announced that Archbishop Corrigan had sent him a check for $100 to be applied to the purposes of the association.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 29.--At a largely attended public meeting held yesterday afternoon in the Board of Trade rooms it was announced that the small outstanding debt of the Subtropical Exposition had been funded, and that the exposition would be opened, as announced, on Feb. 20.

Amateur theatricals at Chickering Hall last night in aid of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church for Deaf-Mutes were given a special zest by one feature that the large audience were prepared for and by another that was unexpected. The first was the appearance of Mrs. Daniel Palne Griswold to assist the amateurs.
Mrs. Harrison and Mrs. McKee yesterday went out for a drive in Central Park, called on Mrs. Gen. Grant and her daughter, Mrs. Sartoris, ...
LONDON, Jan. 29.--The steamship Martello, (Br.,) Capt. Abbott, from New-York Jan. 16 for Hall, passed the Lizard to-day.

BOSTON, Jan. 29.--A special cablegram was said to have been received this noon by the Chadwick Lead Works of this city stating that the great European copper syndicate has refused to buy any more copper, and that the market is quite demoralized. This is interpreted as practically the breaking up of the syndidate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--The expectation that the Senate would be in executive session all of this afternoon led to the postponement by the President of the transmission to that body of the communication he has prepared on the Samoan question. It was a subject of discussion at the Cabinet meeting to-day.
The Executive Committee of the National District Assembly were in session all day at Fritz Wendel's Hall, Ninth-avenue and Fortyfourth-street. But little could be learned of their proceedings.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 29.--James Owen O'Connor, tragedian, , to-day sent letters to newspaper offices along the Hudson Valley reading as follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29.--Joseph A. Moore, whose shortage in the sum of $500,000, as the financial agent of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company in this city, was reported last week, has joined the caravan which moves to the cool shades of Canada.
BOSTON, Jan. 29.--The Directors of the Home Market Club held a meeting to-day, at which a resolution was adopted "that the course of the ...

Yesterday marked the Feast of St. Francis de Sales in the Catholic Church. The day was generally celebrated. At the Ursuline Convent, East One Hundred and Fiftieth-street, the celebration was of unusual interest, for at its ...
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 29.--John A. Campbell was expelled from the Merchants' Exchange today because of crooked dealings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted 4 per cent. registered bonds to the amount of $266,000 at 109.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 29.--The United States Senatorship question was virtually settled in the Legislature to-day, James H. Berry being chosen to succeed himself for a term of six years.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 29.--The high brick wall of the Opera House, which was burned Monday morning, fell at 11:30 A.M. to-day upon a frame building standing in the next lot and occupied by Chamberlain Co. as a book store.

Detective Sergeant Rogers had an exciting adventure at Fourth-avenue and Twentythird-street yesterday afternoon. He was passing the corner alone when he saw a gang of roughs, evidently strikers, attack one of the cars of the Twenty-third-street line going west.

The effect of the strike on the attendance at the theatres last night was marked. There was not a place of amusement in the city that did not suffer, with the possible exception of Daly's Theatre, which was filled on account of its being a subscription night.
PARIS, Jan. 29.--Gen. Boulanger, in a letter, thanks the electors of the Department of the Seine. He says:

As the District Attorney has joined the counsel for the defense in the Cleary case in asking for a change of venue, we take it that we have seen the last of the "boodle" trials in New-York. We regard it also as ominous of the speedy abandonment of ...

The steamship Oranje-Nassau, which arrived yesterday directly from Port an Prince, Hayti, brought an account of the campaign during this month which contradicts the news from the Hippolyte side which arrived on the steamship Wensleydale Saturday night. According to yesterday's advices the cause of ...
A dispatch received yesterday from Buffalo stated that the Hotel Bartholdi, Broadway and Twenty-third-street, had been leased to R. H. Stafford, proprietor of the Mansion House, Buffalo.
Young Hamilton Fish is developing into a reformer of the purest and highest class, and if he continues in the path he has laid out he will hold a commendable position at the close of the session.

John D. Watson was convicted of obtaining money under false pretenses and sentenced to four years in State prison on June 11 of last year, but his counsel obtained a stay of execution from the Supreme Court and he was held in the Tombs.

The strike on "Deacon" Richardson's system of horse railways in Brooklyn assumed yesterday the most serious aspect it has had since the trouble began. There was a determined opposition by the malcontents to the police and the result was exceedingly encouraging to the former.

Miss Rehan's acting of Peggy Thrift in "The Country Girl" was found to be as droll and satisfying as ever last night when the Wycherley-Garrick comedy was put forward at Daly's Theatre for the seventh subscription performance.

The application of the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company for permission to build a tunnel under the East River and across the city under Forty-second-street was yesterday peremptorily denied by the Aldermen. The action of the board was based on a report of its Committee on Docks adverse to the tunnel scheme.
In the Roman Catholic churches of this city an interesting ceremony will be witnessed next Saturday, when the Feast of St. Blase takes place.

Yesterday's proceedings in the Stewart will case did not add materially to the stock of information with which the record is loaded, but the day was quite a lively one. Ex-Surrogate Rollins and Leslie W. Russell went into ...
Some two years ago the Harlem River Bridge Commission decided to name the magnificent span in course of construction between Washington and Fordham Heights the Manhattan Bridge.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 29.--The situation here has been simplified to a great degree by the caucus nomination of United States Sennator Kenna to succeed himself.

Engineer Thomas McFarland of Glasgow, Scotland, and Sixth Engineer James Dewar of Liverpool, injured in the explosion on board the steamship Republic, died yesterday' making three dead in all. None of the others who were injured are likely to die.
LONDON, Jan. 29.--Mr. Edward Stanhope, Secretary of State for War, addressed a meeting of his constituents in the Horncastle Division of Lancashire last evening.

The Railroad Commissioners had a talk with "Deacon" Richardson in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday and decided that they had no authority to adjust differences between railroad companies and their employes.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The Grant Lodge of the Ancient Order of United Workmen of this State will hold its sixteenth annual session at Syracuse next week, Feb. 5, 6, 7, and 8.
The employes of H. O'Neill Co. will give their annual ball at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House on Friday evening, Feb. 1. Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band will furnish the music.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 29.--Van Sickle Son, the largest firm of masons in the city, have discharged all their men and have engaged non-union workmen.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 29.--John K. Aldrich, who was arrested in Windsor a few days ago, was to-day held for extradition to the United States on the charge of robbery. He is an expert swindler, and Detective Matt Pinkerton relates several instances of his performances.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 29.--Capt. John B. Rife of Middletown, brother of Congressmanelect Rife, was thrown from his carriage in South Harrisburg this evening and almost instantly killed. He was a Captain in the regular army for a number of years and was a prominent citizen.
A fine military display was made last night in the Hanson-place armory, Brooklyn, by the Thirteenth Regiment, for the edification ...

The "tie-up," which took most of the people in this city by surprise, was not unexpected by Superintendent Murray. He had been looking forward to a strike of the NewYork car drivers and conductors in sympathy with the strikers in Brooklyn, and when it came it found him to a certain extent prepared for the fight.

Jacob R. Shipherd, at one time President of the Peruvian Company, in which capacity he originated a scandal involving the then Secretary of State, James G. Blaine, sat in Supreme Court, Chambers, as defendant yesterday in a suit brought against him by his son-in-law, Charles W. Lyman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Senator and Mrs. Cockrell gave the second of their two enjoyable card receptions to-night. The house was prettily decorated with smilax and growing plants.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29.--This has been the dullest day for some time in Indianapolis. Very few visitors troubled Gen. Harrison to-day.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 29.--To-day the members of the Chamber of Commerce closed their transactions in the present quarters, preparatory to removal to their new palace at the southwest corner of Fourth and Vine streets.
The House Committee on Naval Affairs yesterday decided to report favorably a bill providing that the pay of Ensigns in the navy shall be as follows:

OTTAWA, Jan. 29.--The trade and navigation returns for the year ending June last have been issued by the Customs Department. Imports into Canada reached $110,000,000 the duty thereon being $22,200,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 29.--W.J. Whipper, (colored,) who ran on the Republican ticket in Beaufort County at the last election for Probate Judge, has been lodged in jail for contempt of court. The Republicans contested the election for county offices before the Elector Commissioners and were defeated. They then appealed to the Circuit Court. Judge Aldrich decided the case against them, and ordered them ...
The chief officers of the city and of the county received numerous formal notices and complaints from the railroad companies and from the strikers as well yesterday.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 29.--Two hundred delegates to the annual State Convention of the Empire Order of Mutual Aid assembled at the new Osborne House to-day.

When New-York awoke yesterday morning it found itself almost wholly deprived of horse-car transportation. The employes of all the surface roads, with the exception of the Third-avenue, the Fourteenth-street, the Christopher and West Tenth-street, the Twenty-thirdstreet and the Bleecker-street lines, had gone on a general strike.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29.--The funeral of Thomas Gillen, the catcher of the Detroit Club, who died on Saturday last, took place from the residence of his parents, 1,232 Federal-street, ...

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 29.--The commission appointed by Gov. Dillingham, consisting of ex-Gov. J. Gregory Smith, Gen. J.G. McCullough, Gen. L. Kingsley of Rutland, Gen. P.P. Pitkin of Montpelier, the Hon. L.K. Fuller...
BISMARCK, Dakota, Jan. 29.--Gov. Church does not feel disposes to yield, and the Legislature threatens to hold out. The little unpleasantness grows out of nothing more nor ...

Ignatz Reinitz, the tobacco merchant of 140 Maiden-lane, who left town last Friday heavily in debt, is supposed by some of his creditors to have gone to Canada, although it is said he told some friends that he was going to ...
Coroner Rooney held an inquest last night into the death of Henry W. Adams, the unfortunate man whose dead body was found in front of the Ninth-avenue stables on Saturday night, ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Democratic Senators are growing restless under the deliberate action of the Republicans in hanging up President Cleveland's nominations, and the matter was talked over by them at some length in a caucus held this morning.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29.--Miss Julia R. Stockton and Richard C. St. John were married by the Rev. Mr. Baker of Princeton at Trinity Church this morning.
The ferry boat Brooklyn of the HamiltonAvenue Ferry line while on her 8 o'clock trip from Brooklyn last evening ran into and overturned a small steam launch just off Governor's Island.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The special election to fill the office of State Senator for this district, made vacant by the death of the Hon. Henry R. Low, took place to-day in Orange and Sullivan Counties. The weather was fine and the vote polled was large for a special election.

The stock market braced up somewhat yesterday and closed with an encouraging snap in it. Some stocks that have been dormant these many weeks suddenly waked up and went up smartly, while the more active old stagers shared in the buoyancy far enough to make all the bull prospects big with anticipated happiness.
LONDON, Jan. 29.--The Century Club to-night gave a dinner to Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister. Lord Coleridge was Chairman.
A contest has been begun over the will of John Frederic Eilers, a wealthy varnish manufacturer of this city, who left an estate valued at about $100,000.

BUFFALO, Jan. 29.--C.J. Hamlin has been asked by Washington parties to sell Chimes, his famous young stallion, and has replied that he will sell for $50,000. Chimes was bred by Leland Stanford, was foaled April 4, 1884, has a 2-year-old record of 2.33 was sired by Electioneer, and is a full brother to St. Bell.
A new baseball league was formed in Jersey City last night, to be known as the Atlantic Association.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 29.--L.B. Pickhardt, who was robbed of his clothing at the Sturtevant House in New-York Saturday morning, upon being interrogated claimed St. Paul as his place of residence.

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 29.--Gen. James Longstreet of Georgia arrived in this city to-day. He was met at the station by Gen. Mahone, whose guest he is, and the two were driven directly to Mahone's residence. The object of the visit is supposed to be of a political nature.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 29.--The Baltimore Sun will say to-morrow in a special dispatch from Washington:

Acting upon the suggestions made to them by Controller Myers, the Pilot Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, voted to notify to Pim, Forwood Co., agents for the Atlas Line, that the steamship Atlas, sunk in the North River, must be removed at once.

No cars were run yesterday on something like twenty street-car lines, all but three or four in the city. The man who appears to be mainly responsible for this result of inconvenience to the public and of loss to the men who have struck work makes complaint against the officers of two lines.
BOSTON, Jan. 29.--A cablegram received from the European Union of Aftronomers announces the discovery of an asteroid at the Nice Observatory.

The Senate held its longest session of the Winter to-day, and yet the people's business was not materially advanced. However, half a dozen Senators indulged in lofty flights of oratory which will look very well on the legislative record, and will prove to their unsophisticated and questioning constituents that the approaches to the State Treasury are faithfully guarded.

The sale of boxes for the Purim Ball, which is to be held on Thursday evening, Feb. 28, at the Metropolitan Opera House, was held last night in the vestry rooms of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth-avenue and Forty-third-street.
Adolph Sambalino, charged with forgery by David Spero, the Broadway feather merchant, was found guilty of forgery in the second degree in Recorder Smyth's Court yesterday.

The Court of Appeals handed down a decision yesterday in the case of Thomas D. Ottman, Executor of Robert R. McIlvaine, against the Mayor of the city. "Dr. McIlvaine," explained Assistant Corporation Counsel George L. Sterling, "died July 28, 1881, and left his library to the Mayor, the President ...
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The apple market still continues in a deplorable state. What is to be done is the question staring every farmer, buyer, and commission man in the face.

Senator CULLOM, who accompanied Senator ALLISON in the important interview at Gen. HARRISON'S house on Sunday, is known as a warm friend of Mr. BLAINE, and is naturally very well pleased that that illustrious gentleman shall take his old place in the Cabinet.

When Justice Patterson took his seat in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning he found a crowded court room and all of the lawyers engaged in the Cleary bribery case arrayed in front of the bench.
MITCHELL, Ind., Jan. 29.--Jullen C. McClure, a prominent citizen of Jackson County, has disappeared, and it is reported that he is short in his accounts as guardian of minor heirs $23,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The following decisions were to-day handed down in the Court of Appeals: The People, appellants, vs. William Harmon, respondent; The People vs. Mary Harmon; The People respondents, vs. Hugh O'Neill, appellant,-- Judgement affirmed.
Miss Helen Dauvray, who is well known in New-York as a star actress, has decided to return to the stage after an absence of more than a year from the footlights.

Reform, and especially tariff reform, was the theme discussed in the big hall of Delmonico's last night at the first annual dinner of the Reform Club, whose members had turned out in goodly force to make the occasion a success. The hall was decorated with national standards, and in the balcony a band furnished music.

The brunt of the fight was borne by the Sixth-Avenue Company, against which the instigators of the strike make the loudest complaint because of its determination to acknowledge no labor organization among its employes.

William Mahl, as Assignee of a claim of the Citizen's National Bank of Louisville, Ky., has obtained an attachment from Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court against the Mercantile Banking Company of Atlanta, Ga., for $16,253, balance due on collections. A Receiver was appointed for the latter company on Saturday at Atlanta.
At the fourth annual meeting yesterday of the jewelers' Board of Trade it was decided to appoint a committee of three to act with a committee of the New-York Jewelers' Association to secure ...
BOSTON, Jan. 29.--The adversaries of President Phillips of the Fitchburg Railroad made things interesting, at the sacrifice of harmony, at the meeting of the stockholders of that road to-day.

There is considerable excitement in the dry goods district owing to the slashing of prices by Chicago jobbers. Marshall Field Co. caused a sensation Jan. 23 by issuing a circular offering 1,000 cases of Amoskeag and York ginghams ...

ALBANY, Jan. 29.--Eleven Republican Senators answered a response for a caucus in the Senate Library this evening. Judge Robertson, Messrs. Erwin, Vedder, Coggeshall, Raines, Vau Cott, Deane, Hawkins, and O'Connor were present.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29.--There was a sensational scene in Judge Normile's court to-day. Ed Kelly, alias Slattery, charged with highway robbery, and a desperate character, had just consented to his attorney, Joseph Furlong, accepting a 10-year term in the penitentiary for his crime.

WALNUT SPRINGS, Texas, Jan. 29.--Early this morning W.H. Greer, a hired man at the house of Charlie H. Balch, one mile from town, heard two pistol shots. He went to Balch's room and found both him and his wife lying on the bed dead.
ROCKPORT, Ind., Jan. 29.--The Rockport and Cannelton accommodation train was thrown from the track and turned over yesterday between Lincoln City and Chrissey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Representative Dunn from the Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries to-day presented the results of the investigation by the committee into the furseal fisheries of Alaska, with special reference as to whether the contract giving the Alaska Commercial Company the right to take fur seals had been violated.
The fourth anniversary of the Young Men's Institute was held last night in the main hall of their building at 222 Bowery, which was crowded to overflowing.

A motion for a permanent injunction to prevent the selling of the paintings in the Governor's Room in the City Hall under a Sheriff's levy will be argued before Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers, Friday.
BERLIN, Jan. 29.--In the Reichstag to-day the East Africa bill passed the second reading after a short debate, in which only Progressist and Socialist members opposed the measure.

LONDON, Jan. 29.--William O'Brien was arrested at Manchester to-day while addressing a meeting. A rumor had been freely circulated that Mr. O'Brien would baulk his pursuers and appear at the meeting. This report brought out a large audience.
The Coquelin-Hading company will not open in Havana on Thursday night, as announced. Fate has decreed otherwise, and at least one night, and possibly two, will be lost in Havana.

James Duer died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday morning, and is the third victim of the explosion on board the White Star steamship Republic at her dock on Sunday. Coroner Schultze took a quantity of testimony in the case on board the steamship yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29.--Mr. W.K. Vanderbilt's yacht Alva arrived here this morning from Wilmington, Del., to take on provisions. It is reported that she will be joined here by Mr. Vanderbilt and family and proceed on a trip to the West Indies.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 23.--Dr. William Hagadorn, a practicing physician for the past 15 years in the village of Gilboa, Schoharie County, has been arrested and given a hearing before a Court of ...
A telegram from Pensacola, Fla., to the New-Orleans Picayune dated Jan. 24 says:

Samuel Riker of Eighth-street and Christopher Kirwan of East Fifth-street, Long Island City, are reported to be dying from the effects of wounds received on Sunday morning last in a fight in the ballroom of Held's Schuetzen Park.
The eleventh annual reception of Palestine Commandery, Knights Templar, occurred at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. The spectacle was brilliant in the extreme.

BUTTE, Montana, Jan. 29.--It has just leaked out that a big syndicate has been formed to get control of and work the immense coal deposits of the Rocky Fork Coal Company. Villard, Haggin, Frederick Billings, Hauser, Oakes, and others form the syndicate, whose capital is placed at $2,000,000.
About 150 members of the Alumni Association of the University of the City of NewYork sat down to the annual dinner last evening at the Hotel Brunswick.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29.--The annual report of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College for the year ending Sept. 27, 1888, was made yesterday to the Board of Overseers.

ALBANY, Jan. 29.--Friends of Thomas E. Platt assert that they have information to the effect that Gen. Harrison has invited Platt to enter his Cabinet as Postmaster-General and that Mr. Platt has sent his letter of acceptance, ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 29.--For $6,000 Dwyer Brothers of Brooklyn, N.Y., have sold the black stallion Pontiac, 8 years old, by Pero Gomez, dam imported Agenoria, by Adventurer, to M. Young, Brothers at the Lorillard sale for $17,500. During his turf career he has won 11 races.

Philip Zeh, Jr., a young Brooklyn florist, spent 12 hours on last Wednesday night locked up in a vault in the graveyard. He was working at the plat of S.P. Dewey during the day and at 5:30 P.M. entered the Dewey vault.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Senator Allison has returned from his brief visit to Gen. Harrison's home and, simultaneously with his arrival, gossip among the politicians and legislators has it that he really declined to accept a place in the next President's Cabinet.

WEST UNION, West Va., Jan. 29.--For two years past John True, aged 60 years, has been confined in the county jail at this point on the charge of murder, most of the time being the only occupant of the prison.

PESTH, Jan. 29.--After three weeks of stormy debates the Hungarian Diet has passed the Military bill by a majority of 126 votes. A large number of students who were opposed to the measure, and who favored the creation of a national army, blocked the approaches to the Chamber during the closing debate.
APPALACHICOLA, Fla., Jan. 29.--The mail steamer Sam sank opposite this city to-day. No lives were lost.

The Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange held a meeting yesterday afternoon. The sub-committee reported on the bill before the Legislature to reduce the legal rate of interest to 5 per cent. The sub-committee reported adversely to the bill, and the report was thereupon indorsed by the full committee.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29.--Yale's Senior Class to-night elected the following-named officers: Class Cup Committee--Sherrill, Sherman, and Peck; Promenade Committee--Underhill, Lucas, Atkins, Frencke, Brewster, McMahon, ...

"The first step in the effort to provide for the conservation of the forests on the national domain," says Garden and Forest in today's issue, "should be the withdrawal from sale of all forest lands belonging to the Nation.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 29.--Ira E. Tabor, a wealthy farmer residing near here, was murdered yesterday afternoon by a neighbor named Joseph Chapleau.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 29.--Robert Soutler, son of James T. Soutler, died in New-York City in 1873.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 29.--The weather was clear and cool, and the track heavy to-day. Following were the events:
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29.--In the Assembly today the bill for the adoption of the Australian system of voting was taken from the table and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

FORT DODGE, Iowa, Jan. 29.--The violation of the prohibitory law in this city has caused Gov. Larrabee to interest himself in its enforcement. Sheriff Adams has received the following letter from the Governor:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--Frank De Wolfe Smith, the Young New-Yorker who put a bullet into his left side at Fifteenth and Pine streets yesterday morning, may not die. He has some means and is well known in amateur musical society.

The State Board of Arbitration and Mediation spent most of the day yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. The members felt very sore over the reception that Commissioner Donovan had received from President Curtiss of the Sixth-Avenue Railroad.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 30.--Dr. Oliver Wendell Helmen has presented his medical library to the Boston Medical Library Association.

LONDON, Jan. 30.--The Contemporary Review publishes an article entitled "The Bismarck Dynasty," which bears no signature, but which contains internal evidence of having emanated from a high authority. It is probable that the article will create a sensation.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 30.--The ice on Orange Lake is in good condition and the race for the Van Nostrand Cup will probably take place tomorrow. The cup is now held by Commodore Higginson, who owns three yachts of the eleven forming the fleet.

Ives and Stayner went back to Ludiew-Street Jail after business hours yesterday, and at 11 o'clock last night a Deputy Warden said that they were as contented as possible under the circumstances and that no one had dropped around during ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The next batch of news from Samoa will probably contain an account of a German attack upon the islanders who took part in the recent attack upon the German forces at Matafagatile, in which 52 men were killed and wounded.

The Rev. Newland Maynard was last night sworn in as Chaplain of the Ninth Regiment by Col. William Seward, Jr., in the presence of the command and a large gathering of interested spectators at the armory, 221 West Twenty-sixth-street.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 30.--What practically amounts to a decision was a ruling in the Supreme Court in the case of the State of Minnesota ex rel. the Railroad and Warehouse Commissioners of the State Railroad Commission of Minnesota, relator, vs. the Minneapolis Eastern Railway ...

LONDON, Jan. 30.--The steamship Polynesia, (Ger.,) Capt. Kuhne, from New-York Jan. 17, for Hamburg, passed the Lizard at 11 P.M. to-day. The steamship Buffalo, (Br.,) Capt. Malet, from New-York Jan. 19 for Hull, passed Portland Bill to-day.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--The Assembly Judiciary Committee gave its first hearing on the Saxton Electoral Reform bill this afternoon. The speakers all advocated the general principles set forth in the bill, simply suggesting changes and criticising certain of its provisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--Senator Allison, always an agreeably reticent man, is having his good humor and his ability to make diplomatic and immaterial answers sorely tried in trying to answer the inquiry whether he is to be the Secretary of the Treasury under Gen. Harrison without saying anything.

A number of the pupils of the National Conservatory of Music appeared in concert and extracts from operas at the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon in the presence of a number of friends, who applauded them with the generous enthusiasm common on such occasions. Such an exhibition serves a good purpose in giving the pupils a little experience of ...

WASHINGTON, Jan, 30.--Mr. Hiscock and Mr. Harris are members of a sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance to consider the advisability of approving the House bill passed last Summer to forbid the further use in the Bureau of Engraving and Printing of steam-plate printing presses.

The case of Edward P. Myerson, the theatrical advance agent, who was charged by his former employer, Charles L. Davis, with the larceny of a small diamond pin and ring about July last, and who was ...

All arrangements for the dinner to be given by the Yale Alumni in honor of the athletic victories of that university in the past few years are now complete. The banquet will be eaten at Delmonico's Feb. 16, and the applicants for seats are ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate: Postmasters.--Samuel McQuaid, Holyoke, Mass.; Frank K. Bonney, Medfield, Mass.; Herman Snyder, South Norwalk, Conn.; James U. Squier, Stefford Springs, Conn.; Albort Holle, Frostburg, Md.; ...
CHICAGO, Jan. 30.--Mrs. Meckie Rawson, the wife of the millionaire banker who in open court shot his lawyer nearly to death, was acquitted in short order this evening.

DETROIT, Jan. 30.--The Supreme Court of this State this morning granted orders on the Circuit Judge of Washtenaw County to show cause why the attachment writs heretofore issued by him against the property of Mrs. Olive E. Friend ...

LONDON, Jan. 30.--Archduke Rudolph, heir apparent to the throne of AustriaHungary, was found dead in bed this morning, and it is still a matter of uncertainty here how he died.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 30.--Gen. Harrison has received from Mr. Blaine his acceptance of the Secretaryship of State, and he said this afternoon that he would give the document to the press in a few days.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Jan. 30.--The Supreme Court of New-Mexico to-day gave the decision in the Maxwell land grant case, affirming the title to that property and dismissing the bill of the Government to set aside the patent.
Almost at day break the crowd began to collect around the Belt Line stables, and at 8 o'clock the corners for several blocks on each side of Fifty-fourth-street were crowded.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 30.--Smith M. Weed and party of New-York and Plattsburg friends arrived by special train to-day at the Ampersand for a few day's Winter outing.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30.--Trade and Traffic publishes this week some highly interesting, statistics that are not easily obtainable, and which the public are seldom given an opportunity to scan.

The parishioners of the Polish Lithuanian Roman Catholic Church on North Tenth-street, Williamsburg, have petitioned Bishop Loughlin for the removal of their Pastor, the Rev. Father M. Yodyzsus, who went to Brooklyn from Pennsylvania six months ago.
The Commissioner of Police in Brooklyn, Mr. BELL, is an educated gentleman of excellent reputation, of considerable experience in public life, and a veteran of the war for the Union.

Henry Karl thought he could drive across the Northern Railroad at Tarrytown Heights in a wagon yesterday afternoon before a train which was due came along, but it struck the vehicle, and Karl was thrown out and so severely injured that he was taken to the Ninety-ninth-Street Hospital.

The funeral of Mr. Hugo Fritsch, the Austrian Consul, at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, yesterday was attended by many notable persons, among whom was Count Chenneville of the Austrian Legation at Washington.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 30.--Mrs. Georgiana Beekman, aged 65 years, was found lying dead on the floor in her house, at Mount Hope, this morning. She had not been seen by her neighbors since Saturday, and to-day they forced an entrance into the house. At first foul play was suspected, but the Coroner's inquest showed that apoplexy was the cause of death.

Ex-Judge J. Lawrence Smith continued as a witness in the Stewart will case yesterday. The direct examination was devoted to showing the cordiality of the relations between the Smith and Stewart families for about 40 years.
The ball of the New-York Saengerunde last evening filled the Lexington-Avenue Opera House with a throng of merry masqueraders.

Chauncey F. Black of York, Penn., President of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, in answer to an invitation from John Z. White of Chicago, Secretary of the American Tariff Reform League, to attend its convention on Feb. 19, 20, and 21, has addressed a long communication in reply.

John Behlen, whose wife, Emma S. Behler, is suing for divorce, and who disappeared a few days ago, has not yet been heard from. Mrs. Behlen's motion for alimony and counsel fees was on the Supreme Court, Chambers, calendar for argument yesterday, and went by default. Mr. Behlen's friends fear he has committed suicide, as he was much depressed by the suit.
What would the condition of New-York be to-day if there were no elevated railroads? Those who remember the state of things before the elevated railroads were built can answer this question.

HARTFORD, Jan. 30.--President Greene of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company has been absent from the city during the day, but will be back to-morrow. He will then submit a statement to the policy holders concerning the method and extent of Moore's defalcation. It is emphatically denied by the company that the amount will exceed the original figures of $500,000.

George S. Hart, President of the First and Second Avenue Companies, has determined to start a car on Second-avenue about 9 o'clock this morning, and, if no trouble results, the company will try to run on schedule time, or as near it as possible.

LONDON, Jan. 30.--The Manchester Guardian says that Lord Salisbury, yielding to great pressure, will withdraw the English vessels from the blockade on the East African coast as soon as Germany commences to operate on shore.
BUFFALO, Jan. 30.--Buffalonians road with much interest the news that Francis H. Tows of New-York had left a bequest of $100,000 to Maria L. Tifft of this city, widow of John V. Tifft.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 30.--The details of the assassination of the Hon. John M. Clayton, brother of Gen. Powell Clayton, at Plummerville, 40 miles west of this point, last night reached here this evening.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--M. Floquet, in receiving the bureau of the Extreme Left to-day, said that he had considered the advisability of resigning, but had abandoned the idea, deciding to face the intrigues and attacks of his opponents.
