Among the passengers sailing on the White Star steamer Republic for Queenstown and Liverpool yesterday were J.T. Bostwick, John Darling, Rober D. Fowler, T.B. Houston, Samuel S. Long, Dr. Villaraza, and Francesco Valdez.
Arrest proceedings are being taken against Berry Wall for contempt of court. Mr. Wall owed a Fifth-avenue tailor $386.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30.--The Presidents of the Western railroads, after being in session just one week, completed their work of revising the great agreement which is to form the basis of the Inter-State Railway Association, and adjourned this evening, subject to the call of the Chair.
Walter Smith, elevator boy at the Osborne Flats, Fifty-seventh-street and Seventh-avenue, fell down the shaft last night and was killed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30.--The Young distillery at Gary, Ill., owned by Francis M. Young, was burned to the ground early this morning. One man, Jack Keefe, employed about the establishment, lost his life in the flames.
John M. Hill, manager of the Bartholdi Hotel, said last night that the arrangements for the future conduct of that house and not yet been definitely made.

An interesting picture was presented in the hall of the Italian school in Leonard-street, an institution that is enjoying remarkable prosperity under the charge of the Children's Aid Society, last night.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Jan. 30.-- Much opposition is displayed in the press to the introduction of water gas as proposed by an American company under a recent concession, and medical publications contain articles against this gas. The Council of Public Health is reported to be almost unanimously opposed to water gas.

The cars of the Third-Avenue line were kept running all day yesterday on schedule time. Nearly every car was guarded by a policeman and the volume of traffic was perceptibly increased over that of ordinary times, though it was hardly as heavy as that of Tuesday. Many attempts were made to induce the employes to leave their cars, but this the men stoutly refused to do.

The last of Mr. Locke Richardson's excellent Thursday afternoon entertainments at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Wilson Industrial School will be given to-day, when Mr. Richardson will recite "The Merchant of Venice."

The grand banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick was the scene of festivity and mirth last night, the occasion being the sixth annual banquet of the Ale Brewers' Association of the States of New-York and New-Jersey.

A special meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday for the purpose of considering the report of the Special Committee upon Reform in the School System. Some general business was first transacted.

It is a lesson in architecture.
The Forty-second and Grand Street Ferry line put two cars out of the stable, each of which made two trips before 4 o'clock, when operations were stopped for the day.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--Another ferry company has been incorporated to operate on the East River. It is the Tenth and Twenty-third Street Ferry Company, and its capital is $1,000,000.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 30.--The Rev. A.C. Dixon, Pastor of Immanuel Baptist Church, this city, has received a call to the Fifth-Avenue Baptist Church of New-York.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 30.--The recent break in the ranks of the Salvation Army of America has resulted in the creation of two factions of the army in Nyack, and this place now rejoices in two rival meetings nightly where the devil can be fought in true hallelujah style by rival commanders and their followers.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 30.--The papers last evening contained a dispatch from London, England, outlining the elopement of Dr. Sellon of London, a married man, 40 years of age, and Miss Ida Wilcox of Minneapolis.
A joint committee of the trunk lines and Central Traffic Association roads met yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office to discuss the old and troublesome questions of dressed-beef rates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30.--Active work is being done at the Mare Island Navy Yard in getting ready for sea the United States men-ofwar Mohican and Monongahela. Commandant George E. Belknap says that the Monongahela and Mohican will probably be put to sea about the middle of next week.

Superintendent Murray was at Police Headquarters before daybreak yesterday, and, with Inspectors Byrnes, Steers, Williams, and Coulin, made arrangements to protect the surface lines.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan, 30.--William F. Dewey, aged 33, a clerk in the First National Bank of New-York City, died here suddenly of apoplexy this morning.
Mrs. Benjamin Harrison is still at the Gilsey House. She took an outing yesterday, both morning and afternoon, and received a few callers. In the evening she went to the theatre with some friends.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 30.--A St. Paul paper this morning printed an article stating that Senator Washburn was seriously ill. This was the pith of a half column of matter.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 30.--The resolution providing for the submission to the people of a constitutional amendment prohibiting the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquors in the State passed the Senate to-day by a vote of 32 to 2.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 30.--The Riverside Athletic Club held its first Winter games in the Belleville-Avenue Rink to-night. A large crowd encouraged the young men to do their best. The events were well chosen and brought out a large number of competitors, including a delegation from this city.

NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 30.--What remained of the oldest saw mill in the country has been torn down, and upon its site is building a new grist mill, the property of E.E. Billings.

George M. Boyd, lithographer at 207 Fultonstreet, made an assignment yesterday to Samuel Lowenstein, giving three preferences for $3,035. He has been in business about eight years, and made a specially of cigar labels. He has had two partners, but has been alone for the last five years. His plant represented an investment of $30,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted 4 per cent, registered bonds to the amount of $192,000 at 109.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30.--In the State Trades Convention to-day the address of President Haller was read. It favored strongly a more general circulation of trades union literature, advised that mass meetings be held on Washington's Birthday, the Fourth of July, and Labor Day, and urged speedy legislation in the matter of convict labor. The speech was altogether in line with the recommendations of the convention.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 30.--The recent speech of Congressman Butterworth on the labor question has created a mild sensation among his political friends, and it is now generally conceded that it the brilliant Cincinnati statesman over had the call for the Gubernatorial nomination he has thrown away his opportunity.

BOSTON, Jan. 30.--The Board of Overseers of Harvard College held the most important meeting of the term in this city to-day. WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The annual charity ball, given to-night at the National Rifles' Armory for the benefit of the Children's Hospital, has, like its brilliant predecessors, proved the event of the season. The hall was elaborately decorated with flags of all nations around ...

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 30.--The situation is not a promising one for Senator Kenna. Two ballots were taken in the joint assembly to-day. Every Democrat was present and voting, but Kenna received only 42 votes on each ballot.

The death of the Inspector-General of the Army increases the list of vacancies now existing to 21. To fill these there are 11 non-commissioned officers who passed the examination at Fortress Monree for commissions in the army.
The fifty-first annual ball of the Emerald Society was held at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last evening. The great room was handsomely decorated for the occasion.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 30.--In the election held in the Thirteenth District yesterday, to fill the vacancy canned by the death of Senator Low, the latest returns show that Peter Ward (Dem.) is elected by 166 majority. Ward carried Orange County by 202 majority, B.B. Odell (Rep.) receiving 36 majority in Sullivan County.

Van Cortlandt Lake was yesterday the scene of two of the most important events of the season. The Mitchel Medal match for the champion rink of American curlers was contested by 19 rinks, the first ties being played in the morning and the second in the afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 30.--At New-Iberia, at midnight, the body of Jim Rosemond, one of the colored men ordered out of town by the Regulators, was found swinging over the bridge that crosses Bayon Techeux. He bore a bad name and was classed as a cattle thief. He was charged with trying to rally the negroes to resent the killing of Wakefield. Who the lynchers are is kept a profound secret.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30.--Coffee jobbers are very happy at the increase in Baltimore's coffee trade. They say they will soon have back more than New-York took away from them four years ago. Within the next 30 days 73,600 bags will be landed here.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30.--Canada's Winter carnival has assumed shape, though in the conception of the plan and details of the arrangement there were many difficulties to be overcome. Now the ice palace raises its walls of transparency to a height of a hundred feet.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 30.--Matthew S. Quay particularly desired the re-election last Fall of Congressman Charles N. Brumm of the Schuylkill District. Schuylkill County is naturally Democratic, but Brumm was elected in 1886 on a fusion of the Labor Party, which is strong in the county, with the Republicans.

Byron H. Bird, a drug clerk who has until very lately been employed in a Brooklyn store, committed suicide at the Hotel Everett, in Park-row, Saturday night, by drinking prussic acid. He was a sufferer from the morphine habit and had been drinking heavily of late, and was undoubtedly suffering from melancholia at the time of his suicide.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 31.--Col. H. Coulter Cabell, a prominent retired lawyer, was found dead in bed to-day. He was father of J. Alston Cabell, Assistant Surgeon Julian M. Cabell, United States Army; Lieut. H.C. Cabell, United States Army, and Clarence Cabell, now studying as Leipsic, Germany.

The annual dinner of the Williams College Alumni Association of New-York and vicinity was held last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. Music at the dinner was furnished by an Alumni glee club and by the New-York Mandolin Club.

W.J. Henderson delivered his third lecture on musical history before the students of the New-York College of Music, 163 East Seventieth-street, last evening. The subject was "Opera from Handel to Verdi."

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday signed the order of judgment against Benjamin A. Gaitan, in the suit brought against him by the United States of Colombia. Davis, an actor, developed interest before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday. The court room was crowded by theatrical people and their friends. Davis was cross-examined at some length by Mr. Hummel.

In Newhouse, Kilkenny County, Ireland, June 8, 1859, died John Hayden, gentleman. Mr. Hayden was prepared for death, having made his will Aug. 11, 1856. It ably upheld his reputation for occentricity. Now, over a quarter of a century afterward, it is providing employment for courts and lawyers.

The Sixth-Avenue Road managers are well pleased. Forty cars were run, seven trips each, beginning at 8:15 in the morning and ending at 5 in the afternoon, and the boast was made at 3 o'clock that the receipts were very nearly as great as before the strike.

The committee of life insurance men which has been trying to find a way to avoid the evils of the rebate system, met Wednesday at the Murray Hill Hotel and drew up a sketch of an agreement, which amounts to the first section of the agreement proposed to the companies last Fall.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Jan. 31.--Some time ago William H. Bradley, who was 27 years of age and whose family attended St. Paul's Roman Catholic church of this city, joined Orusader's Castle, Knights of the Golden Eagle.

A deed of trust for the benefit of creditors has been executed by William M. Ewart and John P. Wightman, with George H. Baker consenting, to W. Benton Crisp, Trustee. They are engaged in the canned goods business in Baltimore, Mr. Baker is a special partner.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 31.--The Mormon invasion of the South has become an investment. Their army of Elders or missionaries has grown from 3 or 4 to a command of 114 in the past few years.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 31.--At the closing session of the annual convention of the National Furniture Manufacturers' Association a proposal by one of the members to organize a furniture trust was voted down by a large marjority.
Mayor Grant was an interested and active participant yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration, of whose board he is a member ex officio.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 31.--Henry Hines, who was tried for the murder of his stepfather, George Fitch, at Bolivar, Madison County, to-day pleaded guilty to murder in the second degree, and was sentenced to Auburn Prison for life.
DUBLIN, Jan. 31.--Mr. William O'Brien was to-day lodged in the Clonmel jail to undergo the sentence of four months' imprisonment imposed on him at Carrick-on-Suir for offences under the Crimes act.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31.--The Assembly met this morning and adjourned until Monday night, without transacting any business.

ALBANY, Jan. 31.--It looks as if the Excise Commission bill is destined to be beaten. Chairman Curtis has given out to his friends that the bill cannot possibly pass the House, and if it should, it certainly would be defeated in the Senate.

The will of ex-Congressman John W. Lawrence of Flushing, who died a few weeks ago at the age of 83, was admitted to probate by Surrogate Weller yesterday at Jamaica, Long Island. The estate is valued at over $1,000,000. Three hundred thousand dollars is specifically bequeathed to children and grandchildren, the residue to be shared equally among the testator's children.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1.--The new agreement of the Western States Passenger Association went into effect to-day without a hitch.

The annual ball of the employes of H. O'Neill Co., under the auspices of the H. O'Neill Co. Mutual Benefit Association, took place last evening at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House. Over 1,500 tickets had been sold, and it was estimated last evening that between $800 and $900 had been realized for the benefit of the association's fund.

PARIS, Ky., Feb. 1.--Clay Woodford of the Runnymede Stock Farm, have purchased from the Dwyers the crack colt Sir Dixon. The price paid was $10,000. Sir Dixon is by Billet out of Jaconet, the latter being a full sister to the great Iroquois, the only American horse that ever won the English Derby.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 1.--The outlook in rowing at Cornell University is very bright. About two dozen candidates are in active training, in charge of Commodore Psotta, who holds the amatuer championship of America in single sculls, and Mr. Nelligan, the university athletic trainer.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 1.--The Supreme Court this morning affirmed the decision of Judge Adams, holding the Citizens' Bank stockholders liable for about $15,000 only.

TORONTO, Feb. 1.--The hardware firm of Rialey Kerrigan has suspended payment. The firm claims a surplus of $30,000.

The Brazilian Vice-Consul in this city, Gustave H. Gossler, has been for a month searching for three men who are supposed to have been preparing to flood Brazil with counterfeit money, and a week ago he locates them in Brooklyn.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 1.--A bill making the election laws of the State much more rigid and seeking to prevent fraudulent voting of all kinds will be presented before long in the Senate. Senator Fritz of Milwaukee is giving the subject very careful consideration.
BRUSSLS, Feb. 1.--It is asserted that the Italian Government will create a State bank with a large capital, which will absorb other financial establishments under State control.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 1.--In the star catalogue case the cross-examination of Dr. Peters was concluded at 10 o'clock this morning. He did not vary from his claim that Mr. Borst was in his pay, and that the catalogue was constructed under his supervision.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 1.--W.J. McGarigle, exWarden of the County Hospital of Chicago, has written to the Russell House asking for a suite of rooms. He will arrive next week to spend a month at the capital. The ex-Warden, so his friends here say, is hopeful of returning to Chicago.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Feb. 1.--"I will tell you the real inside motive that prompted the order of Commissioner Oberly stopping logging on Indian reservations, if you won't use my name," said a lumberman of this city who operates on one of the reservations, and who was observed to be worrying but very little about the order.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1.--In the Circuit Court to-day Charles Enen Johnson of Philadelphia asked for an injunction to restrain John B. Jeffrey from suing him on notes and drafts aggregating $12,000.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 1.--The weather is colder to-night and the mercury is falling. The ice in the Hudson is fast from a point two miles south of Stuyvesant to Albany. At Stuyvesant and Schodack this afternoon iceboats were gliding about the river.
AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 1.--A bill was reported to-day in the Senate from the Judiciary Committee prohibiting the sale or gift of tobacco in any form to minors under 16 years of age.

A gentlemanly middle-aged man is at the New-York Hospital in an insane condition. He was found wandering about the Sixteenth Precinct, and the police had him taken to the hospital. He is dressed in dark clothing of fine material, a derby hat, and lace shoes, and has an iron-gray beard. Nothing in his possession indicated his identity.

She will be fitted and rigged on the principle of the Ocean King, the model ocean tug on the Atlantic coast.

DETROIT, Feb. 1.--A pardon was received at the Detroit House of Correction last evening from the President for Frank Youne, who was received Dec. 15, 1884, from Montana, under sentence of life for murder.
ALBANY, Feb. 1.--Thirty "White Caps" on Thursday visited a man named Ostrander, in Polyman's, this county. Ostrander and his nephew fired upon the crowd, wounding one "White Cap." The mob then left.

Along the line of the Fourth-avenue road yesterday forenoon there was little disturbance. Some one threw a heavy iron bolt through an airhole of the tunnel on the roof of a car about 11 o'clock, but no damage resulted.
Some of the manufacturers of woolen goods have been looking at the wool and woolens duties in the Allison bill. They do not like the schedule, and they are beginning to say so.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1.--The merchants of this city are making a hard fight to secure the Mexican trade. They have organized and will establish trading agencies in all the leading centres of the sister republic.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Feb. 1.--The tobacco growers of Madison, Jefferson, Leon, and Gadsden Counties will hold a convention in this city on the 6th inst. MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 1.--In the Circuit Court today Louis Hendersen, colored of St. Elmo, in this county, recovered a judgment of $736 against the Western Union Telegraph Company for failure to deliver within a reasonable time a telegram sent by Henderson to a physician at lived beyond the half-mile limit within which the company contracts to deliver telegrams.

The fact that two of the rescued were women made the task more difficult.

BUFFALO, Feb. 1.--The suspension bridge at Niagara Falls, which was blown down on the morning of Jan. 10, will be fully restored by May 15. The necessary iron work is already under may, and as soon as the weather moderates work over the gorge will begin. It will cost $60,000 to restore the bridge.

DUBLIN, Feb. 1.--The Freeman's Journal states that Lord Salisbury is negotiating with Lord Hartington with a view to the latter becoming Prime Minister. Smith, Government leader in the House of Commons, will be elevated to the peerage.

The fire was discovered in a closet on the second floor, and is supposed to have been caused by the carelessness of workmen or by spontaneous combustion.

Mr. Frank Curtiss, President of the Sixthavenue company, received an anonymous letter yesterday threatening his life. The letter was mailed at Station G at 1:30 P.M. yesterday.

HAMMOND, Ind., Feb. 1.--Dr. Burnett, a so-called Indian doctor and astrologer, was arrested yesterday charged with "voodooing" Paul Malsch, a hardworking German farmer, whom the doctor had terrorized into giving up considerable property. The doctor, it is alleged, had a couple of accomplices personating witches, and by their machinations so upset Malsch's nerves that the poor farmer is now bedridden.

ALBANY, Feb. 3.--The Bogota Electric Light Company was incorporated yesterday with a capital of $100,000. The operations are to be carried on in Bogota, United States of Colombia, with principal office in New-York City. The Trustees are A. Langenbach, Francis Betancourt, and Rafael Fi dearl.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 3.--At Dayton, Tenn., to-day, John Overstreet and Jim Montgomery engaged in a dispute, during which the lie was given by each. Montgomery seized Overstreet by the throat and knocked him down.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 3.--Trouble has broken out afresh in the Sophomore Class at Rutgers College, and the difficulty has split the class asunder, half of the members refusing to sit with the other half for class pictures and ...
A man has just died in Cabarrus County who once risked his life to save his Colonel, the Hon. William Henry Harrison Cowles.
The second anniversary of the Compania Transatlantica Espaniola was celebrated yesterday on board the trim steamship Habana, at her dock, Pier 21 North River.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3.--The export of cotton goods from Canada to China is an industry not a year old, and yet it has assumed large proportions, the total amount already exported being nearly 15,000 bales, with another shipment of eight carloads now on the way.

Orders were issued Saturday from the Treasury Department to place the United States revenue cutter Grant in commission at the beginning of the present week, and at the same time Capt. L.H. Stodder, the commanding officer, was directed to muster in 33 additional seamen for service. Orders have also been issued assigning to duty on the Grant Lieuts. ...

Mr. and Mrs. Steinway are interested in ascertaining, if possible, the identity of a stray and unauthorized German nobleman, who declares that he is a relative of theirs, but concerning whom they know nothing save that he has occasioned them considerable annoyance.

HALIFAX, Feb. 3.--The United States is such a large country--with so many varied interests-- and her people are so absorbed in the great problems which pertain to the working out of her vast system of government that they have little time or disposition to concern themselves much in the affairs of her smaller neighbors at the north.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--The deathbed confession of Eila Schwartz, wife of the brakeman now serving a long sentence in Joliet for complicity in the great Rock Island train robbery and the murder of Express Messenger Kellogg Nichols, is made public to-day.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 3.--Word was received to-day from Pocahontas of the suicide near that place of Mrs. Mary Shipley, wife of Milt Shipley, a prosperous planter.

Only a few years ago when the then too numerous haddock was pulled in it was only to be contemptuously thrown overboard again, for he was not good for salting and drying, though considered excellent eating when cooked fresh. Now the supply of haddock is small, quantities are put up as "finnan haddies," and for a little fish of this variety you must pay 20 cents.
The sunshine and warmth of yesterday morning drew out a congregation that filled every pew and every extra chair in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church.
RANDOLPH, West Va., Feb. 3.--Thomas Foy, aged 18, was lodged in jail here to day charged with murdering his half sister, aged 8.

The first electric crane ever built in the United States has just been introduced in the foundry of E.P. Allis Co. It is a ponderous affair, weighing 30 tons, and is capable of lifting and carrying to any part of the foundry, with case, a weight of 25 tons.

Yesterday was the sixth day of the streetcar strike in New-York. It was the first Sunday since the advent of the trouble and for that reason it was feared the ruffianly element would be unusually demonstrative.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 3.--Prominent citizens and taxpayers from all parts of Union County met on Saturday at the Elizabeth Court House to discuss a general road bill to be submitted to the Legislature.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 3.--At 2:48 this morning fire broke out in the seven-story coal elevator and pockets of the Providence Coal Company on Dorrance-street wharf.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 3.--Before James B. Livingston of Rhinebeck died he owned a large amount of property, included in which was the Rhinebeck Gazette. After his death the paper passed into the hands of Editor Rhodes.
The opening paper in the Century for February, the account of the artist Gerome, will searcely disappoint any expectations that may have been for med of it.
LONDON, Feb. 3.--There was a good demand for discount during the past week at 2 to 1 . Money was plentiful. On the Stock Exchange business was animated.

Some interesting statements about the inception, growth, and advantages of the Australian ballot system were made to a representative of this newspaper yesterday by Mr. John H. Wigmore, a young lawyer of Boston. Mr. Wigmore is probably as well informed on this subject as any man in America.

Scribner this month has not a dull article and some of its features are of very excellent quality. Few illustrated articles could be more interesting than the one of Thomas Sergeant Perry on the Graeco-Egyptian portraits recently found in the Fayoum country.

We would like to do justice to a book on which a great amount of industry has been lavished if only we could find the usefulnees of it. We grant that there are many arithmetical puzzles which are amusing, beginning with the well-known story of the King who was desirous of rewarding the inventor of chess.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 3.--The Briggs Building at the corner of Main-street and the Pawcatuck, Westerly, was burned out at an early hour this morning. The building was a frame structure and was built out over the river on piles.

New-York had occasion to enjoy itself again yesterday with a strayed Spring day which did everything for the enjoyment of the pleasure seekers save to clothe the trees and cause the flowers to blossom in the parks.

St. Brigid's Church, in Avenue B, was consecrated yesterday, having, after a struggle of nearly 40 years, freed itself of debt. The services began at 7 A.M. and continued almost without interruption until 1:30 P.M., and there were vesper services besides.
Dr. Edward McGlynn was welcomed by an exceedingly large number of members of the Anti-Poverty Society in the big hall of the Cooper Union last night.

LONDON, Feb. 4.--The Standard's Berlin correspondent says: "In spite of unmistakable friction with the Americans, nobody here fears that there is any danger of the Samoan affair leading to a war between the two nations.

Some 10 years ago a woman named Lucie Lafrance came from a country district to Montreal to earn her living as a seamstress. About three years later she was informed by a letter from a friend that the only relative left to her, a sister, had just died.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 3.--The Rev. Dr. George E. Reed, Pastor of the Trinity Methodist Church of this city, is now at work upon his letter of acceptance as President of Dickinson College of Carlisle, Penn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--Managers and theatregoers can look back upon the last week at the Chicago playhouses with satisfaction. It has been a prosperous week at all the leading houses with possibly one exception, and the entertainment offered has been good enough to warrant the prosperity.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--J.H. Breslin, proprietor of the Gilsey House, and R.H. Southgate, proprietor of the Hotel Brunswick, both of NewYork City, are in Chicago, to sign papers for the management of the new Auditorium Hotel.
BOSTON, Feb. 3.--James Golden last week purchased for John Shepard the famous bay gelding Arab, and Mr. Shepard now thinks he has what he has always wanted, the fastest pair of horses in the world.

The annual convention of District Lodge, No. 1, Independent Order Free Sons of Israel was called to order yesterday in Arlington Hall, 21 St. Mark's-place, a large number of members of the organization being present.
MONTREAL, Feb. 3.--Perfect carnival weather prevails, and everything is in readiness for the opening to-morrow. The ice palace is finished and is ready to be flooded for a skating rink.

The beautiful window in the facade of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, on Fifth-avenue, memorial of the Rev. Dr. Robert Shaw Howland, was unveiled yesterday forenoon. Dr. Howland was the founder and first Rector of the parish. He died Feb. 1, 1887.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 3.--The latest development in the Hawes murder case is the capture by two Age-Herald reporters of a man supposed to have been an eye witness of the murders. The reporters got on the man's trail and followed him 2,000 miles, finally capturing him in Middleton, Tenn.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 3.--The Wilkesbarre Record will announce to-morrow morning that a crisis in the anthracite-coal trade is threatened.

Robson and Crane made their farewell appearance in Boston as joint stars at the Hollis-Street Theatre on Saturday night, and the occasion was made quite a celebration by the Boston admirers of the two comedians.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 3.--The State Medical Society will meet here on Tuesday and continue in session three days. Tuesday evening the President, D.S. B. Ward of this city, will tender the members a reception. On Wednesday night the annual dinner will be held.

LONDON, Feb. 3.--A great wind and snowstorm prevailed to-day on the English and Irish coasts. The Cunard steamer Servia, which arrived at Queenstown to-day, was unable to transfer her mails, the tender sent out to receive them being forced to run back to the inner harbor for shelter. Several buildings at Queenstown were unroofed by the wind.

ALBANY, Feb. 3.--Fire insurance companies incorporated under the laws of this State have all filed their annual reports to the Superintendent of Insurance. The reports of companies of other States which transact business in NewYork are coming in rapidly. Following are some of the latest reports:

BOSTON, Feb. 3.--Boston society was very much interested in the dispatch from St. Paul announcing the elopement of Oakes Ames, a cousin of Gov. Ames, with a pretty assistant Postmistress of Anthony Park.

Fabius Feraud, a designer in tapisserie, of 80 Clinton-place, was held for trial yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court for forging the indorsement of Louis Clemencet of Hoboken, his father-in-law and former partner, to a check for $90 on the Fifth-Avenue Bank.

ERIE, Penn., Feb. 3.--Two years ago a number of capitalists organized the Presque Isle Gas Company for the purpose of testing the rock stratum known as the Trenton formation for gas. They contracted for a well 4,000 feet in depth, and the drill was set to work.

The question of Paul Cinquevalli's return to this country next season as a member of Rich and Harris's Howard Athenaeum Specialty Company would have been settled last week if Cinquevalli and his managers were the only ones to be consulted.
A special benefit performance in aid of the Actors' Fund is being arranged by Augustin Daly mnd A.M. Palmer, to be given in Daly's Theatre on the afternoon of Thursday, Feb. 14.

The pleasant, sunny weather of this Winter has given the amateur photographers an unusual chance for outdoor work, which they have not failed to take advantage of.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3.--Edward L. Stewart, Administrator of the estate of Charlotte Smith, began two equity suits in May against Della T. S. Parnell, the mother of Charles Stewart Parnell. Foreign attachments were at the same time issued against Mrs. Parnell's property at Tenth and Pryor streets. Mr. Stewart and ...

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3.--There is much more politics than business in the legislative halls at Trenton this year. As only one bill, the Sunset Election Repeal, which was signed by the Governor on the 28th, has gotten through both houses, notwithstanding they have been, nominally, in session two weeks, the conclusion reached is that the members are not overworked.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 3.--A new and promising vein of copper ore was struck on Saturday in the copper mine of the Bristol Copper and Silver Mining Company.

PHILADELHIA, Feb. 3.--Annie Klaus, a pretty girl, the daughter of a well-known shoe dealer, was found on a lot at Hope-street and Montgomery-avenue last night with a bullet in her brain. She died without gaining consciousness. The body was not identified until 2 o'clock this morning, but before daylight the murderer had been run down and had killed himself, after having tried to kill his wife.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3.--The Sparrowspoint Railroad, connecting Steelton, the Pennsylvania Steel Company's new manufacturing town, with Baltimore, has been completed, and trains will be run to Union Station next week.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 3.--News of a horrible murder, supposed to have been occasioned by bad feeling engendered by the recent crimes on the borders of Logan and Lincoln Counties, has just been received.

People whose means compel them to be ever watchful have "viewed with alarm," more or less, the continued mild weather of this Winter, fearful that when the Summer months come the iceman will be more of a magnate than ever, and that only the wealthy will be able to indulge in what has become a necessity rather than a luxury--ice for domestic purposes.

Probably nobody is better able to-day to throw light on the Samoan troubles than those who were there in authority during the regime of United States Commissioner Steinberger, from which time dates the origin of the difficulties which have culminated in the aggressive actions on the part of the German naval authorities.

The concert given at the Broadway Theatre last night in aid of the charity fund of the New York Press Club was a market success in every particular. The house was crowded to the doors, people standing in quintuple rows behind the orchestra seats.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Feb. 3.--George Heidel, a young farmer residing about nine miles below this city, lost his life Friday in a most singular manner. Adjoining his farm was that of William Tompkins, a negro, who for several days past has been engaged in clearing up new ground, cutting ...

HARTFORD, Feb. 3.--The late George D. Sargent of this city in his will set aside a sum of money for the erection of a statue in the City Park, fronting the State Capitol, of the late Gov. Richard D. Hubbard, who was one of Hartford's most public-spirited citizens.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 3.--The Bennett and Moulton Opera Company, which concluded a week's engagement at the Wieting Opera House last night, left for Williamsport, Penn., to-day minus its prima donna, Marie Greenwood, and its baritone, J.B. Richards, both of whom have severed their connection with the company.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 3.--A terrible railway accident occurred to-day near Groenendaal. A train bound from Brussels for Namur struck a pillar of a bridge near that place, causing the bridge to collapse. The train was carried down with it and completely wrecked.

The question of the charges made by the Socialists against certain delegates that they had been bribed by the brewers to use their influence to lift the boycott from pool beer came up at the meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday, and more testimony was received, after which the accused began their defense.
--A new translation of the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen has been undertaken by the American Minister to Denmark, Rasmus B. Anderson. It will be published in London.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 3.--A serious accident occurred in North Denver this afternoon on the Berkeley motor line. The car started down the long and high grade, but before going any distance became unmanageable and dashed down the hill at the rate of 40 miles an hour.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 3.--About 4 o'clock this afternoon a switch engine carrying 10 men delivered a car of stock at the stock yard of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company and started on the return trip to town at the rate of 15 miles per hour.

VIENNA, Feb. 3.--The sensational news leaked out to-day that a beautiful young Baroness committed suicide by taking poison at Meyerling at the same time that the Crown Prince took his life. The two acts were committed almost simultaneously.

More evidence was put into the Stewart will case yesterday to show that Mrs. Stewart made the assignment of her husband's business to Judge Hilton believing that he would conduct the business as a trust for her benefit.
Officer Grant of the Auburn Insane Asylum took four men to Bollevue Hospital yesterday and requested that their mental condition be inquired into.

At Frye's billiard parlor last evening Charles Erickson, "the California wonder," and Charles H. Manning played a match game of continuous pool as a preliminary to the selection of a contestant for the regular, championship continuous tournament to be held in Hardman's Hall Feb. 26.

The session of the House lasted just half an hour, and an adjournment was then taken to permit the members to hear the Senators deliver memorial speeches to Judge Low. Mr. Sullivan of New-York introduced a bill to abolish news stands on the elevated railroads.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4.--The friends of the International Copyright bill were much disappointed to-day by the failure of their carefully-prepared programme for securing a day for the consideration of that important and sound measure.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 4.--To-day Judge Monroe rendered a decision in the suit of Conery and others against the New-Orleans Water Works In favor of the plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4.--Secretary Bayard received to-day from Count von Arco Valley, the German Minister, the proposition of the Imperial Government referred to by the President in his message to Congrees on Jan. 30 as having been sent from Berlin on Jan. 20.

A meeting of the Washington Centennial Celebration Sub-Committee on Army, Col. S. Van Rensseiaer Cruger, Chairman, was held yesterday in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, at which it was resolved that the military parade should take place Tuesday, April 30, and the industrial parade Wednesday, May 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4.--Senator Evarts from the Committee on Privileges and Elections made a report to-day of the results of the investigation into the alleged election outrages in Washington County, Texas.

The history of yesterday's business in the House does not speak very well for that body. It appears that there would have been no effective opposition to a suspension of the rules in order to pass the will for international copyright.

QUEBEC, Feb. 4.--The Provincial Government at last session passed an act to convert the debt of the province and inserted a clause making such conversion compulsory, but at the same time gave a pledge that this clause would not be put in operation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 4.--There is great excitement at Sandy Creek, Oswego County, over the finding of natural gas at the experimental well sunk by the Sandy Creek Oil and Gas Company on Saturday last.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 4.--Ex-Gov. H.B. Harrison, as committee for the Superior Court, has made his findings in the celebrated case of Charles D. Yale against Simpson, Hall, Miller Co., the hearing of which has extended over a period of two years.
SLATER, Mo., Feb. 4.--A live stock train, when within 30 feet of a bridge 40 miles east of this place on the Chicago and Alton Road, jumped the track to-day and was almost wholly wrecked.
The East River Savings Bank has brought suit in the Supreme Court to have Pythagoras Hall, in Canal-street sold to satisfy a mortgage of $35,000.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4.--The extraordinary series of barn burnings along Mason and Dixon's line in York County, Penn., and Carroll County, Md., continues. Yesterday the barn of Mrs. William Arnold was burned, and the fire was undoubtedly incendiary.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 4.--Seldon Barker of Ellington committed suicide to-day by hanging. He was 60 years old and his debts troubled him. The tragedy took place on the farm where Mrs. Frank Crosby was murdered a few years ago.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Feb. 4.--The individual operators have joined with the large companies in curtailing the output of coal in this vicinity, and in consequence there is but one mine in operation. The five suspended collieries employed almost 3,000 hands, and shipped yearly over 800,000 tons. The operators are a unit in their determination to maintain prices.

Affairs have quieted down to a wonderful extent in Brooklyn. Cars began to run about 7 0'clook in the morning on the Fifth-avenue and Boerum-place and Fifth-avenue and South Ferry lines, and 32 cars were run during the day, making 160 trips, against 45 trips on Saturday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 4.--Gen. Powell Clayton and Judge Clayton, brothers of the Hon. John M. Clayton, who was assassinated on the night of Jan. 29, have issued a statement to the public reciting the circumstances leading up to and culminating in the assassination of their brother. All agree, they say, that this was a political assassination and they then give the causes which created the trouble.
LONDON, Feb. 4.--The council of the National Liberal Federation will hold a special meeting to consider the subject of Mr. William O'Brien's treatment by the prison officials at Clonmel.

Mary Hewins Fiske, one of the most original, prolific, and entertaining newspaper writers of her time, died at her home, 72 West Ninety-third-street, yesterday morning. She had been ill about a week, and was a victim of pneumonia, complicated with other diseases.

NANTUCKET, Feb. 4.--Surrounded by a foaming waste of tumbling billows lashed by a howling gale, the air thick with blinding snow and sleet, the brave sailors on the Nantucket South Shoal Lightship are obliged to pass many days and nights.
Judge Barrett was engaged yesterday at Special Term with the suit of several dissatisfied stockholders of the Texas Land Company, Limited, against the Directors, headed by William Walter Phelps.

The answer of the Mercantile Trust Company, the Missouri Pacific Railroad, the Union Trust Company, Jay Gould and others, in the suit brought by the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad Company to settle the construction of a consolidated mortgage, entered upon through a lease of the plaintiff's road, was filed in the United States Circuit Court yesterday.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 4.--The Democrats carried every point in the joint Assembly to canvass the returns of the election. Every resolution prepared in the Democratic conferences went through by a strict party vote.
Daniel E. Finn, the pugnacious ex-Assemblyman, was smoked out yesterday in the investigation by the Commissioners of Accounts of the grievances of old West Washington Market men.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, Feb. 4.--Gen. A.B. Ward, the distinguished Republican speaker, has vanished from the city. His history is gradually being unraveled, and it turns out that he is a brilliant fraud and adventurer of the first water. He asserted to politicians here that his "O.K." would be required for all offices in Dakota.

Pleasant auspices attended the opening last evening of the St. Bartholomew's Mission, 158 East Forty-second-street, and the long rows of settees were filled with the many well-wishers of success who had come.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 4.--Montclair's rink building, where the noiseless rubber of the bicycle has supplanted the ratting wheels of the roller skate, was transformed this evening, and Montclair had its second annual charity ball.
There was plenty of bustle and activity at the office of the Westminster Kennel Club, at 44 Broadway, yesterday.
SITKA, Jan. 9.--For the fiscal year ending June 30, 1888, Congress appropriated $45,000 for the support of schools in Alaska. The appropriation this year is only $40,000.

The Modjeska route for next season, which had been solidly booked up by Messrs. Nixon Zimmerman, is already in demand by outside managers, and there will be no difficulty in filling all the time which was reserved for this favorite actress at the different theatres throughout the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4.--"Fatinitza" continues to prove very attractive to theatregoers here. The opening of the second week of Col. McCauli's superb prodcution of this opera drew another large audience to the Chestnut-Street Opera House to-night.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 4.--There has been a further improvement in the condition of the King of Holland.

HARTFORD, Feb. 4.--Owing to the continued illness of Senator Graham, Chairman of the Railroad Committee, the Housatonio Railroad hearing, which was assigned for Tuesday, will probably be postponed for a week.

The popularity of the balls given by the Patriarchs increases as each season's dates are arranged. Last night the second dance of the 50. Venerable in name, was given at Delmonico's, and never before has there been such a demand for invitations. As a result the ballroom and adjacent reception rooms were crowded. Over 425 persons were present.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4.--Mr. Darwin G. Feano to-day assumed the managing editorship of the Philadelphia Times, succeeding Mr. Charles H. Houstic, who retires to accept the position of managing editor of the Inquirer. Mr. Fenno has been city editor of the Times for several years past.

An old-fashioned fire engine, "Old Black Hawk, No. 14," and a score of buckets and ladders were taken to the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday, and the big place was decorated for the annual ball of the Volunteer Firemen's Association last night.

The Architectural League of New-York had a very pleasant time yesterday. In the afternoon about 40 of its members, at Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt's invitation, visited her house at 640 Fifth-avenue. From 4 to 6 o'clock the first floor of the house was at the visitors' disposal.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Feb. 4.--The thermometer at Saranac Lake, the coldest town in New-York State, registered 38 below zero this morning. Here it was 28 and at Champlain 33 , and in the Mohawk Valley the temperature was 22 below. In Vermont the mercury ranged from 24 to 40 and in Maine it fell to 40 , and in Ontario, Canada, it ranged from 24 to 37 below zero.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted 4 per cents to the amount of $211,000 at 109.

The bank of J.N. Knapp in Marquette, Mich., closed its doors yesterday morning. The liabilities are from $30,000 to $50,000. The bank commenced business a year ago. Slow collections are given as the cause of this suspension. It is thought the depositors will not lose anything.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 4.--White Caps have been writing threatening letters to residents of this city and of surrounding towns for some weeks, but these notices have universally been regarded as in fun.
A boisterous reception was given at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening to a new three-act farce by Mr. George Jessop with the unfelicitous title of "22, Second Floor."

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 4.--While James Reagan and John McCormick, arm in arm and so intoxicated that they could scarcely stand, were crossing the Shore Line Road at "Poorman's Crossing" this afternoon they were struck by the 3:15 accommodation train and instantly killed. Both were employed at Redfield's Quarry, and both leave families at Fair Haven.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4.--Dispatches from Pennsylvania to-day told of a Soft Coal Trust being formed, at the head of which is Vice-Presidentelect Levi P. Morton and a number of other Eastern capitalists. A number of leading soft coal dealers here were asked if such a trust could extent its influence to this part of the country.
DETROIT, Feb. 4.--The product of the Calumet and Hecla copper mine for January was 2,599 tons, the Atlantic, 223 tons, and the Quincy, 240 tons.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 4.--Indiana will soon have as stringent a law against trusts as any State in the Union. To-day the Senate passed by a vote of 43 th 2 a bill which was introduced by Senator Barrett, Democrat, of Fort Wayne, one of the most prominent lawyers in the State.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 4.--Mrs. Annie E. Nash of Waterbury, in this county, is to bring divorce proceedings against the first of her two husbands, William Nash, who is now of that city. It is a sort of an Enoch Ardeu case.

Messrs, Simon Sterne and Charles F. Reach, Jr., yesterday filed their brief with the Inter-State Commerce Commission on behalf of the plaintiffs in the noted carload lot cases against the trunk lines in reply to the brief for the railroads. As this ends the argument, the matter is now in the hands of the commission for decision.
Ancillary letters testamentary were issued yesterday by Probate Clerk Tinney to Grace Townsend Turnbull on the estate of her son, Townsend ...

The steamship La Normandie, which arrived yesterday from Havre, was detained in Quarantine for fumigation and inspection on account to two cases of smallpox which had made their appearance among the members of the crew.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 4.--The experts, Joyce and Fanning, appointed by the County Commissioners to examine the books and accounts of the absconding embezzler, John K. Sullivan, late County clerk, began their work this morning. Sullivan's exact whereabouts are a matter of much speculation.
For the first time in many days there was something like a real bull movement in wheat on the Produce Exchange yesterday. It came very quickly and very late in the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4.--Lawyer S. Spencer Chapman to-day filed in court the statement of Mrs. Mary Fleming, who recently began a breach of promise suit against ex-United States Senator John J. Patterson of South Carolina, but who is now residing at Mifflintown, in this State.

The Baptist Pastors yesterday at their usual Monday conference listened to some remarks on "How the World Affects the Church" by St. Clair McKelway of Brooklyn. An attempt was made early yesterday morning to set fire to the St. James Hotel, at West End, Jersey City. A good many years ago the building was put up by the Giles Wales Watch Company for the accommodation of the families of the chiefs of their factory, which was erected on adjoining grounds.

A large number of Germans filled the Church of Our Saviour, at Monroe-place and Pierrepont-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon when the funeral services were preached over the body of Frederick W. Steins, who had occupied a place in the choir of this church for 30 years.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Feb. 4.--The special committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders of Monmouth County, recently appointed to investigate the accounts of Gen. Charles Haight, Prosecutor of the Pleas, met at this place to-day. Gen. Haight was charged with withholding ...
BALTIMORE, Feb. 4.--James K. Harley, an artist, aged 60, said to be, by his first wife, related to Senator and Gen. Sherman, commited suicide here today.

PARIS, Feb. 4.--The dissolution of the old Panama Canal Company has been decreed on the petition of persons acting in accord with M. de Lesseps. The court appointed M. Brunet official liquidator.

Commissioner Donovan of the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration called yesterday at the headquarters of the Executive Board of the strikers and had another conference with Master Workman Magee, who urged that the State Board should hold an investigation of the strike and the causes that led to it.

The entertainment at Koster Bial's this week does not lack novelty. Ferguson and Mack are a familiar team of Irish comedians, and their drolleries well pleased the patrons of the concert hall last night.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 4.--High wind at 2 o'clock this afternoon blew down the large section of the east wall of the Max Meyer brick building on the corner of Farnum and Eleventh streets, which was recently gutted by fire.
Te ruins of the old West Washington Market are alive with rats that, after gorging for years upon the offal thrown from the stalis, have attained an enormous size.
To-night's session of the Senate was entirely devoted, with the exception of the introduction of half a dozen unimportant bills, to the exercises in memory of the late Senator Henry R. Low.

MONTREAL, Feb. 4.--The Montreal carnival opened this morning with the most promising prospects. The morning came in clear and sharp with 14 negative degrees of frost, and at 10 o'clock the carnival was in full progress.
ST. PAUL, Minn, Feb. 4.--A letter from pierre, Dakota gives full details of the death in that city about a week ago of a young boy who had been treated by Christian scientists.

ISHPEMING, Mich, Feb. 4.--Policeman Archie yesterday arrested a member of the Salvation Army. The man was rescued by friends. The Chief of Police, reinforced by the police and a posse of citizens, then made other arrests, but all the prisoners but one were rescued before reaching the jail.

Frank R. Lawrence, counsel for the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company in its suit for $2,500,000 against Henry S. Ives and George H. Stayner, received a summons yesterday to appear this morning at ...

The Ladies' Association of the Manhattan Dispensary, which has been plotting and planning for some time how to increase the funds of the hospital, last evening made a successful attack upon the charitable purses of certain society people and intends to keep up its campaign for a fortnight or so longer.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Feb. 4.--The movement developed some time ago to adjourn the Legislature till after the 4th of March broke out afresh this morning, and it soon became manifest that there was a large majority in both houses who favored the adjournment, if it could he had legally.

PALATINE, Ill., Feb. 4.--William Frost, aged 45 years, is dying from hydrophobia. He was bitten in the face by a rabid dog six weeks ago, the wound bleeding freely. He had the sore cauterized and afterward reported to the madstone treatment.
HARTFORD, Feb. 4.--The needs of Trinity College in this city, resulting from the constant and remarkable increase in the demands upon its educational facilities, will seen be made ...

The project of taking the entire block of land bounded by Centre, Elm, Franklin, and White streets for the purpose of building thereon a new criminal courts building was favorably considered by the Sinking Fund Commissioners in the Mayor's office yesterday.

The 6:30 Troy ttnd Montreal express that left the Grand Central Station last evening had added to its unusual length of ten coaches Erastus Wiman's special car Arlington, with a large party aboard, under Mr. Wiman's care.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 4.--Tobacco growers from Kentucky and Ohio to the number of 300 met in convention here this afternoon and passed a reduction resolution which makes it obligatory on all tobacco growers in the two States to raise only 55 per cent. as much in 1889 as the crop of 1888 amounted to. Many members of the convention favored not raising any tobacco this year.
The Columbia College Trustees held their regular monthly meeting yesterday afternoon at the college, and, in the absence of Hamilton Fish, Dr. Morgan Dix presided.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 4.--There was a lively debate to-day in the Senate on the motion of Senator Drummond, Montreal, to adopt an address to the Governor-General in reply to the speech from the throne.

The chief feature of the street car strike in this city yesterday was that three of the lines which have hitherto done little more than wait for events to shape themselves ran cars over part of their lines.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 4.--At daylight this morning the thermometer ranged at various points throughout this region from zero down to 13 below, the latter figures being indicated, at places in the Delaware River Valley.

It was rumored yesterday in theatrical circles that Frank W. Sanger and T. Henry French had resolved to submit their dispute over the proprietorship of the American and Canadian rights to "Little Lord Fauntleroy" to the courts for adjudication, but upon inquiry the report is shown to be premature.

Judge Lawrence opened the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday for the purpose of trying Dr. and Mrs. William Reynolds for presenting a false claim to the London Assurance Association nearly two years ago.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4.--The Senate took possession of the Assembly Chamber this evening. Gov. Green mounted the Speaker's dais and presided. Werts took a seat by his side. A large portrait of the late Gov. Joel Parker was carried ...

The Century Association, which has for years occupied the clubhouse at 109 East Fifteenth-street, has at last concluded to move further up town. At its meeting Saturday evening it placed in the hands of a committee, consisting of the Board of Managers and five others, the business of buying a new site.

At the Lyceum Theatre, Friday afternoon, Feb. 15, at 2:30, a company of amateurs will present the two-act drama "Ernestine" and Buckstone's comedy, "The Dead shot," for the benefit of the Fresh-Air Home as Summit, N.J. Messrs. Edward Fales Coward, Valentine.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 4.--The Rev., Carter Helin Jones, Pastor of the First Baptist Church of Elizabeth, who has largely increased the membership during his pastorate of three years, tendered his resignation yesterday morning, to the great surprise of the congregation. The resignation takes effect April 1. Mr. Jones has accepted a call to a church in Knoxville Tenn.

The handsome residence of Mr. Henry C. Nevins, the wealthy dry goods commission dealer, at 3 East Fifty-third-street, was badly wrecked by fire yesterday morning. The house is of brick with brownstone trimmings, on the north side of Fifty-third-street just east of Fifth-avenue.

A number of single-tax men who think a clubhouse would conduce to the prosperity and growth of single-tax principles some time ago organized themselves into a committee to carry their ideas into effect.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 4.--"It can't be true," repeatedly moans Rachael Smith. She is the betrothed of Deminick Marion, the fireman who was crushed to death by falling walls at the big fire on Saturday morning, and grief has made her crazy.

ELMIRA, Feb. 4.--William B. Lane, for several months doing business in the hosiery and fancy goods trade at 114 Main-street has fled, having previously and under cover of night shipped all the goods in the store to New-York.

The Fifth-Avenue Baptist Church was filled with people last evening who witnessed the marriage of Mr. A. Alfred Tappen and Miss Ella C. Jones, daughter of Mr. J Paul Jones. The bride wore a gown of ivory satin and point lace, with decolete corsage and long train.
Agnes Garrie, 12 years old, and her mother, Mrs. Catharine Garrie, were terribly hurned yesterday morning in their apartments in the attio of the three-story dwelling 532 Greenwich-street.

The Secretary of War has issued a series of rules and regulations for the establishment and government of post canteens in the army. It is provided that canteens may be established at military posts where there are no post traders for supplying the troops at moderate prices with such articles as may ...

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 4.--The schooner C.R. Oliver of Mattews County, Va, was sunk in the squall in Chesapeake Bay Thursday night. She had on board Thomas Williams, the owner of the vessel, and his brother, Washington Williams, besides the crew--Thomsas Hurst and Robert Diggs, all of matthews County. Nothing has been heard from the men, and they are believed to have been lost.

At all the recent meetings of the holders of Panama Canal securities everybody seemed willing to forego dividends and interest until the canal should be finished, and to support M. DE LESSEPS heartily in his plans for a reorganization of the company.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 4.--President Gates of Rutgers College emphatically denies the report that Thomas Bell, a member of the Freshman Class, was severaly hazed Saturday night by Sophomores, White Caps, or any other parties. He says the story was utterly without foundation. The Fredontan, which started the report, has contradicted it and apologised.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 4.--The Legislature today passed a resolution allowing C.M. Norwood to withdraw his petition of contest for the office of Governor without prejudice to himself or the General Assembly of the State of Arkansas.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 4.--C.H. Wheeler, who ran two backet shops in this city, "skipped" the town at an early hour this morning, leaving a score of customers, whose losses range from hundreds to thousands of dollars. Wheeler is a young man.
The new Board of Managers of the Coffee Exchange met yesterday and appointed the standing committees of the Exchange. Louis Seligsberg was appointed Secretary.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 4.--The weather was cloudy and mild, and the attendance at the races was good. The track was heavy. Following were the events:
The Irish Parliamentary Fund Association met last night at the Hoffman House to collect money for the Parnell defense fund.

Eight or nine years, ago Joseph B. Braman, a Boston lawyer, notary public, and Commissioner for various States and Territories, finding himself in need of the smart, responsible clerk, appointed as such his wife in accordance with her own suggestion.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4.--The experiment of billing live stock shipments by weight instead of by the carload, which went into effect Jan. 1, is not meeting with the great success that was predicted for it.

OTTAWA, Feb. 4.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Patterson, member of Parliament for Essex, introduced a bill to admit United States vessels to wrecking, towing, and coasting privileges in Canadian waters.

Yesterday's stock market enjoyed a halt. There was bad news from Chicago, and, thought the market did not break, quotations lost a good deal of their buoyancy, and for a good part of the day the Stock Exchange tickers practically stood still.

Extensive preparations for an excursion to Washington have been made by a committee of the Young People'e Baptist Union of Brooklyn. The party will leave the New-Jersey Central Railroad ...

From the accounts lately coming from abroad there seems to be a decided tendency to out down the weights in naval armaments, supplying in lieu guns of smaller calibre and possessing higher velocities. In the British service this appears the most marked, and, if accounts prove true, there will not be many more 100ton Armstrongs turned out for naval vessels.

PETERSBURG, Va., Feb. 4.--Albert Hicks, aged about 60 years, a former citizen of New-York, but for two years past a farmer in Prince George County, committed suicide near the reservoir in this city to-day by shooting himself through the head.

HARTFORD, Feb. 4.--The indictment of the Indianapolis defaulter, Moore, is supplemented by a statament from President Greene of the Connecticut Mutual Life, which will be received with great interest by the policy holders of the company.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 5.--John Walsh, a Central Railroad brakeman, was struck by a train to-day at Bergen Point and fatally injured. He thoughtlessly jumped from his own train on the other track in front of the Somerville express, which hurled him 30 feet in the air. His skull was fractured, and he died after being taken to the Elizabeth Hospital. Walsh was married, and he leaves a wife and three children at Bergen Point.

The first step toward establishing a Museum of Fine Arts in Brooklyn was taken last night and an earnest and enthusiastic step it was. The hall of the institute at 200 Washington-street was nearly filled by assemblage that admirably represented the culture, the wealth, and the enterprise of the City of Churches.

Dr. Milton J. Roberts showed the photographical section of the American Institute last night how flash-light pictures can be easily taken with electrical apparatus, and told of the coming use of the process in medicine and surgery.

Garrett Brinkerhoff, a wealthy old gentleman residing in Communipaw, N.J., was mulcted in $20,000 damages by a Brooklyn Sheriff's jury yesterday. The award was made to John J. Meehan, a furniture dealer, in whose store at 494 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, old Mr. Brinkerhoff first met Mrs. Meehan.

At a meeting of the New-York Academy of Anthropology held yesterday afternoon in Room 22 of the Cooper Union a paper was read by Dr. F.B. Lawson of Brooklyn on "The Inorganic Elements of the Human Body and their Value in Health and Disease."

The annual report of the Elizabeth Public Library and Reading Room, at 21 Broad-street, just issued, tells of increasing success for that institution.

A spotted horse made a short, sharp, and painful leap for fame in Printing House-square and Centre-street soon after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The animal was attached to a grocer's wagon owned by Mr. K. Moss of Brooklyn.

The great strike of the car drivers and conductors of New-York, that has lasted just eight days, is off, and all the men who can get employment will return to work early this morning. It was officially declared off by District Assembly No. 226 at about 11:30 o'clock last evening.

The masquerade ball of the New-York Maennerchor at Terrace Garden last night had all the elements of success. The hall was elaborately and tastefully decorated, and the floor, boxes, and gallery were crowded long before the great event of the occasion.

Behind the brownstone front of the Fellowcraft Club's house, 32 West Twenty-eighthstreet, there was feasting and mirth and speechmaking last evening. The occasion was one of the Fellowcraft's dinners, and the members of the club and their friends who were present decided that it was by far the most successful yet given.

The substantial and ordinarily active stocks were dull, and even drooping, yesterday, but the specialties were active and buoyant enough to atone for this unhappiness. The Granger stocks, on the strength of Judge Brewer's Iowa decision, showed weakness, and there was reiteration from Chicago of the obstacles in the path of the projected Inter-State Railway Association.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 5.--Sir George Smith Baden-Powell, member of Parliament for Kirkdale Division of Liverpool, England, passed through yesterday on his way to the Pacific coast.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5.--The Central Traffic Association Committee, of which D.S. Gray of the Pennsylvania Road is Chairman, will meet here to-morrow, to decide upon a reviced form of agreement, and to prepare a report to submit to the meeting of managers on Thursday.

George Engels, who was arrested for stealing a diamond stud from William McNiff's jewelry store on Grand-street, Williamsburg, on Monday, was arraigned before Justice Nacher yesterday, and was identified by five jewelers from whom he had stolen articles. He waived examination and was held for the Grand Jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5.--The board of naval officers detailed to examine the United States gunboat Yorktown, both as to her speed qualifications and general fitness for acceptance into the United States Navy, convened to-day at the offices of William Cramp Sons and effected an organization.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Feb. 5.--This afternoon a Sheriff levied an attachment upon the property of Bartlett Brothers, the largest contractors and builders in the western part of the State, to satisfy a claim for $1,600 of M.D. A.W. Hodges of this town. Bartlett Brothers' liabilities are $65,000; resources not known.

The latest exhibition of the willingness of Gov. Hill to use the National Guard for the purpose of furthering his personal and political ambitions is shown in the proposition that he shall accompany the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn on its suggested trip to Chicago and Minneapolis in August next.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 5.--The sixteenth annual session of the New-York State Grange was begun this morning in the assembly room of the Leland Hotel. The session to-day was secret.

The first death resulting from the rioting of the strikers occurred yesterday on the Boulevard, near Sixty-first-street. A noisy crowd of men and boys had been lounging in the vicinity for some time. RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 5.--Harry Miner, the NewYork theatrical manager, has bought the Leggett cottage on the south bank of the North Shrewsbury.

The German Republican County Committee met last night in its quarters, 12 St. Mark'splace, which they have engaged permanently, and reorganized for 1889. The meeting was one of the largest held in years, 117 out of 120 delegates being present. Jacob Kessler presided over the temporary organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 5.--The eighty-third annual reunion of the State Medical Society commenced to-day, Dr. S.B. Ward of Albany President. The attendance is unusually large. Papers on the treatment and prevention of diphtheria and tpphoid fever were discussed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 5.--The Grand Lodge of the State of New-York of the Ancient Order of United Workmen assembled in the Empire House in this city to-day, the occasion being its sixteenth annual session. Grand Master Jabez H. Morton presided.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 5.--Prof. Daniel C. Eaton of the scientific department of Yale University has presented to the Legislature strong objections to the granting of a charter to a newlyorganized company in this city for the running of street cars by electricity conducted through overhead wires.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Feb. 5.--Mr. Clemens and Charles L. Webster of the firm of C.L. Webster Co. of New-York City are fighting for a judgment of $31,000 which they recently obtained here against D.L. Roots of Burlington, and his sureties, Henry Nan and L. Dee.

LONDON, Feb. 5.--Despite their promises that the question regarding the Parnell letters should be brought to an issue at once, the Times's lawyers to-day began to introduce the American section of their testimony with the statement that it would all be exhausted before the other things are taken up.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 5.--Tons and tons of ice were cut on streams, ponds, and lakes in the Hudson River and inland tier of counties to-day. In the Catskill and Shawangunk mountain ranges hundreds of men are employed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5.--Mr. P.D. Armour, the great dealer in dressed beet, was to-day shown an Associated Press dispatch from New-York telling of the meeting there last night of local butchers for the purpose of taking steps to secure State legislation to prevent the shipment of Western dressed beef into that State.

Warrants for the arrest of Coroner Frank Hall of Queens County and Mrs. Mary Harriman of 124 Flatbush-avenue, Brooklyn, in whose house Kitty Cody died on Jan. 15, were issued yesterday by District Attorney Ridgway. Dr. Hall and Mrs. Harriman are charged with complicity with Frank P. Dudgeon in the death of the girl.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 5.--The committee of local capitalists which went to New-York to meet the Directors of the Wyoming Improvement Company and settle the details of building the Pacific Short Line from Sioux City to Ogden, Utah, have returned.

William Kershaw is an Englishman and a carpet weaver. He was an old-time leader of District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor. When Higgins Co.'s employes went out on strike he led them, and later manifested his ardor by brutally assaulting Thomas Campbell, the foreman of Higgins's factory. A warrant was issued for his arrest, and yesterday he was captured and arrested while doing duty as a non union driver on an Eighth-avenue car.
RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 5.--Interest increases in the Republican Club of Shrewsbury Township. At the meeting held here last night 20 new members were elected and 29 were proposed for membership.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett's new play, which he is to produce next season, was written by Mr. William Young, the author of "Pendragon," and is entitled "Ganelon." The story is historical, and the scene is laid in the Island of Corsica in the early part of the ninth century.

News of the most exciting conflict yet waged in the Haytian rebellion came to this port yesterday by the steamer Harold, Capt. James Hutton, which arrived from the blockaded northern ports of St. Marc and Port de Paix.

The Custom House Civil Service Commission is having an experience which is duplicated by nothing in its history. For once, at least, it seems to be unable to get enough candidates to compete for a Government office. The rush for public places seems to have weakened wonderfully, and the officials are greatly puzzled.
The Thomas Concert at Chickering Hall last evening was the most commendable of the series thus far. The programme was composed of interesting material and the performance was admirable throughout.

John O'Neil, who was convicted of robbery in the first degree March 28, 1888, and sentenced to 12 years aad 9 months in State prison, was released yesterday on his own recognisance, the Supreme Court, General Term, having set aside the conviction Jan. 22.

The range in restaurant prices from Delmonico's down is wide, but a new establishment on the Bowery has about reached "bed rock." The proprietor cautions persons entering the place not to worry about whether he makes money or not and assures them that by feeding many he gains a sufficient profit.

The diary of ex-Judge Smith, reflecting the discoveries and opinions of himself and his family in relation to Judge Hilton's management of Mrs. Stewart's affairs, became again a subject of inquiry in the Stewart will case yesterday without eliciting much that was new.
BERLIN, Feb. 5.--Prince Bismarck to-day gave an audience to Judge Lambert Tree, the American Minister to Russia. The staff of Capt. Wissmann has been completed. It numbers 60 persons.

BERLIN, Feb. 5.--In the Reichstag to-day, on the third reading of the budget, Herr Munckel, a Progressist, raised the Geffeken affair, contending that the publication of the indictment against Geffeken at the instance of Prince Bismarck was quite incompatible with the laws of the empire.

Frederick Hartmann, a German 42 years old, residing at Stapleton, Staten Island, was charged before Police Justice Vaughn, at the Edgewater Court yesterday, with having on Sunday night assaulted and turned his aged father into the street.

About 1,000 journeymen tailors attended a mass meeting called by the Journeymen Tailors' Union in Clarendon Hall last night. The abolition of the system of working at home instead of in a shop provided by the merchant tailors was much discussed.

PARIS, Feb. 5.--A special meeting of the Cabinet was held to-night at the Ministry of the Interior, Premier Floquet presiding. It is reported that the Ministers decided to take active measures for the repression of the Boulangists.

The Secretary of the Navy has designated the following-named officers a board to conduct the official examination and trials of the cruiser Charleston, now being built at San Francisco: Commodore George E. Belknap, Commander Henry Glass, ...

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 5.--Mr. H. Kernaghan, who is contesting the seat of Col. C.E. Hooker from this district in the next Congress, fired the first gun in the contest to-day by commencing to take testimony before Oilver Clifton, Clerk of the Supreme Court. Col. Hooker's majority in the district was over 8,000, but Kernaghan thinks he can show fraud, intimidation, and other irregularities to overcome this and give him the seat.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 5.--Over 200 farmers filled the large room in the Court House today to participate in the George Clarke land sale. The list included 28 farms in the towns of Millan and Pine Plains. Much of the land is in a poor state of cultivation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 5.--An important bill was introduced in the Senate this afternoon providing for the consolidation of the debt of Kartford and the issue of bonds amounting to $1,350,000 to meet outstanding obligations.

The attempt of Police Commissioner Bell of Brooklyn to compel the owners of boilers in that city to submit to periodical inspections by the city boiler inspector terminated yesterday in a test suit, brought by Charles S. Higgins Co.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 5.--Henry G. Davis, President of the West Virginia Central Railway Company, gave an elaborate dinner in this city to-night to the members of the Seaboard Soft Coal Association. President Mayer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad supplied the Philadelphia ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 5.--A premature explosion of dynamite occurred near Salt Point on the Poughkeepsie connecting railroad this afternoon. Workmen were endeavoring to get off a blast with a battery.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5.--The suit of the United States against Henry Curtner and others has been decided by Judge Sawyer in favor of the complainant, Justice Field concurring.

It looked for a time yesterday as if Produce Exchange quotations would give May wheat a place above the dollar mark. There was a bullish feeling early because Chicago felt that way too, and at the opening May stood at 99 3/8 cents.

It is doubtful if in the history of NewYork society there is recorded an event so successful in regard to the magnificence of the costumes, the lavish display of wealth, the assembling of such exclusive sets within more beautiful surroundings than characterized the ball given at the Academy of Design last night.

MONTREAL, Feb. 5.--The second day of the carnival was attended by a heavy fall of snow which told somewhat against the success of the events. In the morning the Victoria Rink was opened with music and skating and also the Dominion Rink. The ice was too heavy for trotting and the races were postponed.

A concert by the Courtney Ladies' Quartet is a sort of big family party. The hallful of people know one another and know Mr. and Mrs. william Courtney and the entire company personally, and they are delighted with everything that is done. This was true of the concert given in Steinway Hall last evening.

Three of "Deacon" Richardson's Brooklyn surface reads were operated yesterday with comparatively little trouble, and a large number of men seeking employment applied at the railroad company's office. The names of all who applied before 4 o'clock were taken down, ...

Henry Webber, a butcher of 499 Market-street, Newark, N.J., visited this city on Sunday. In the evening he started for home, but has not since been seen or heard from. He had $200 in money with him. The police are looking for him.

When the steamers Noordland and Servia met in collision Jan. 30, 1886, in the North River an admiralty suit was brought to ascertain which was in fault, each vessel claiming negligence on the part of the other. The Noordland was found at blame in the United States District Court by Judge Brown. The case was appealed and yesterday Judge Wallace of the Circuit Court affirmed the decree of the court below.
