NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5.--E.S. Dixwell of Cambridge, Mass., has presented to the NewHaven Historical Society valuable papers which once belonged to his ancestor John Dixwell, one of the three New-Haven regicides of Charles I. The other two were Walley and Goffe, and the three names are prominent in New-Haven history.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 5.--Thomas McDowell of this city has sold the bay gelding Argyle, 4 years old, by Strathmore, dam by imported Knight of St. George, to J.C. Twyman of Lexington for $1,200.

PARIS, Feb. 5.--It is semi-officially announced that, Great Britian having recognized Legitime as President of Hayti, France will do likewise. M. Goblet, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has instructed M. Laforesterie, the Haytian Envoy ...

The new play at Daly's Theatre last evening received a cordial greeting from the usual large and brilliant audience. It is a fouract comedy of modern manners, exceptionally bright and witty in its text, slow in action, and slight in plot. There is not a hint of farce in "An International Match."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 5.--Particulars have been received of the killing of the Sizemores near Manchester, Ky. A year ago Simon Garrison, a respectable lumberman, and Robert Sizemore, of bad character, exchanged shots, and Sizemore was wounded. Last Friday as one of Garrison's sons was passing along the road by the Sizemore home he was shot through the face but not dangerously wounded.

Mayor Grant yesterday returned to the Board of Aldermen, without his approval, the resolution appointing a standing committee of five to appear, as occasion might require, before the Legislature for the purpose of advocating certain legislation affecting the interests of the city.

All ladies will be interested in the news that Lady Eva Quinn has turned tiger killer, and laid five tigers low in Upper India. One of our representatives, says the Pall Mall Gazette, ...

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 5.--The tomato growers of Monmouth County held a meeting at the Globe Hotel yesterday. It was decided that the growers should not receive less than $8 per ton from the canners for their product.

The thirty-sixth annual meeting of the Huntingdon and Broad Top Mountain Railroad and Coal Company was held in Philadelphia yesterday. The report for 1888 shows: Gross receipts, $516,000; expenses, $225,807; net earnings, $290,192, an increase ...

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 5.--The contest over the famous will of Frozee Lee, the Plainfield miser, was resumed to-day at Elizabeth, in the Union County Orphans' Court. Lee, it will be remembered, bequeathed his fortune, estimated at $250,000, to the Baptist Church at Scotch Plains.

Frederick Truedell, 17 years old, and Joseph E. Barbour, 18 years old, who say that they are hotel bell boys, were arrested yesterday on suspicion of having been concerned in a number of house robberies. It is charged that they have been in the habit of hiring furnished rooms and disappearing ...

There was another surprise in store yesterday for the officials at the Appraiser's stores. Late in the afternoon communications were sent to two employes by Appraiser Stearns notifying them that their services were no longer required.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 5.--The people of the sea-washed village of stonington, have been amused by an unprecedented judicial scene, which occurred Saturday last. For some time past temperance advocates have been busying ...

The eighth annual reception of the Joel Parker Association was held in Newark, N.J., last night. Five hundred prominent politicians and their wives attended. Among those present were: Gov. Robert S. Green, ex-Gov. Abbett, and United States Senator McPherson.

ALBANY, Feb. 5.--A contest between intellectual giants will take place before the Court of Appeals to-morrow to test the constitutionality of the Arcade Railway charter. Thus far the company has won in the lower courts, and its existence depends upon the decision of the last court of resort.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 5.--Mrs. Courtlandt de Peyster Field and Miss Hamersley of NewYork City gave a Bible reading this afternoon at Cloverly, the residence of Mrs. Mary Westbrook Van Deusen of this city. Ladies from all along the Hudson River were present.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 5.--For some weeks cerebro spinal meningitis has been making disastrous headway among the horses in this section.
ALBANY, Feb. 5.--From reports of the following savings banks for the past year these abstracts and comparisons are made:

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 5.--The Democrats received a decided set-back to-day in their efforts to prevent the reading of the vote on Governor by counties. It has been settled that there will be no publication or declaration of this vote, and without either Goff cannot have a shadow of a claim to the Gubernatorial chair, except such as he established through a contest.

VIENNA, Feb. 5.--This city was to-day entirely given over to mourning. All places of business were closed and the shops throughout the city put up their shutters early in the forenoon. Many streets, usually bright and animated, wore a deserted look, the life of the town being concentrated around the spot where the obsequies of the Crown Prince were held.

The House continued yesterday to discuss the conference report upon the Nicaragua Canal bill, but a vote was not reached. The curious opposition that had been shown before the passage of the bill was renewed.

Shortly after 7:30 o'clock last night, Leon Osiel's Japanese goods store, 843 Broadway, which has an L running to 59 East Thirteenth-street, was found to be on fire. Among other things the Isthmus of Panama is noted for the white ant, a harmless sort of a chap enough when he is all alone, but a very different sort of fellow when he is in a trust composed of several hundred millions of his brothers, sisters, and other relations.

PARIS, Feb. 5.--Panama Canal shares closed on the Bourse to-day at 68.75, a fall of 2.50. On the Petite Bourse the shares were largely offered, which caused a further fall. The last quotation was 61.25.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 5.--Express rates on shipments from Milwaukee to the East, which have been ruling very low for a few weeks, were restored to-day, and rates on shipments received here from the East will be restored Saturday.

With a well-filled stage and a good-sized audience in the body of the room the Charity Organization Society of the City of New-York met in Association Hall, in East Twenty-thirdstreet, last night for its eighth annual public meeting. Robert W. De Forest, President of the society, was Chairman.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5.--In the Senate this afternoon the bill abolishing Superintendents of Schools in cities of less than 30,000 population was indefinitely postponed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5.--Jonathan Ingersoll has been out of the city since Saturday. His wife says that he went to New-York. There is good reason to believe that a warrant has been issued for his arrest.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 5.--John Price, 26 years of age, was shot and severely wounded on Monday night by a careless marksman at Elizabeth. He is employed by the Central Railroad to summon the wreck gang when required.

Gustave Adolph Freiderichs, an editor of the Pittsburg Volksblatt, came to New-York three weeks ago to be treated for Bright's disease, and he hired a room at 123 Forsythstreet. As he was a member of Abraham Lincoln Company No. 2, of the Manhattan Schuetzenbund, he was treated by its doctor.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5.--A madman last night stabbad an inoffensive peanut vendor here, who, from the injuries received, died to-day. "I see blood, blood on the moon," excitedly exclaimed Lee Willey, a young man who came here from Gloucester Point, Gloucester County, ...
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5.--Levi Ury and Erski ne Mansfield, prominent cigar manufacturers of this city, were arrested to-day on warrants sworn out by a committee of the Cigarmakers' International Union.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Feb. 5.--Word has been received from Eufala, Indian Territory, that Belle Starr was killed there Sunday night. Belle was the wife of Cole Younger, and Jim Starr, her second husband, was shot down by the side of Belle less than two years ago.

At the regular meeting of the Long Island City Board of Aldermen last evening Mayor Gleason sent in his annual message. It is rather lengthy and decidedly interesting. It is the Mayor's third annual message, and the recommendations are many. Speaking of the city's financial condition he says:
Judge Lawrence, when the Court of Oyer and Terminer was opened yesterday morning, announced that he had decided to allow the trial of Dr. and Mrs. William M. Reynolds separately.

At a well-attended meeting of the Historical Society last night, under the Chairmanship of President John A. King, an interesting paper on "New-York City in the Year 1789" was read by Mr. Thomas E.V. Smith.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5.--News has been received here of a dreadful accident at Pine Lake, Fulton County. The reports are in definite, but as far as can be learned the disaster resulted in the drowning of 17 men. The victims were driving teams engaged in hauling logs across the ice, when the ice broke and the men and horses were all lost.

Ex-Senator WARNER MILLER is at present engaged in an effort to prevent the passage of any law at this session of the Legislature which shall accomplish anything in the way of a further restriction of the liquor traffic.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Feb. 5.--The most severe storm of the season has been raging here since yesterday. It abated somewhat to-day, but this evening it is storming worse than before, with the wind blowing hard and the temperature falling.
Mrs. Cleveland, who is expected to arrive in the city this morning from Washington, will be accompanied by Col. Lamont, and will occupy apartments at the Victoria Hotel.
The Commissioners of Accounts continued yesterday in the Stewart Buildiug the hearing on the charges that money had been paid for obtaining stands in the new West Washington Market.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 5.--A year of so after the close of the rebellion a number of schools, independent of the regular common schools of the State, but supported by the State, were established in Pennsylvania for the care and education of the orphans of soldiers and sailors ...

Filmon Condet, who manufactures a patent refrigerator fastener, has been a prominent member of the Law and Order League in Newark, N.J. He resigned a few days ago. Yesterday it was learned that he had been threatened with a boycott by brewers, who largely use his patent, unless he severed his connection with the league. Brewer Ballantine is said to have insisted on the reignation.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 5.--Justice McMahon to-day gave judgment in the case of Edward Fletcher of Kankakee, Ill., releasing the prisoner from custody. Fletcher was held on a writ of capias in a suit brought against him by William Rice to recover $20,000 damages for allenating the affections of Rice's wife.

MONTREAL, Feb. 5.--Mr.Walter H. Smith, President of the Astro Meteorological Association, has been making special observations on the planet Venus with the aid of a reflecting telescope, and reports rapid changes in the shape and outlines of the horns, due to the planet's rotation brining mountain ranges to the edge of the disk.

The twenty-third annual ball of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique for the benefit of the widows and orphans' fund was held last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. About 5,000 people were present, and the floor was filled to its utmost capacity.
Very nearly from the time the ball was first talked of several of the ladies concerned in it concluded to give dinners to such of their friends as were going to it.

ALBANY, Feb. 5.--Mr. Hamilton has decided to stand sponsor to the Cable bill, and it will come before the House to-morrow. DETROIT, Feb. 5.--The Auditor of the recent J.J. Burns Company, (Limited,) the railroad building company which failed a few days ago at Battle Creek, gives the following assets and liabilities from the inventory and schedule of the railway company:

Live Oak, No. 44, Exempt Association, gave its annual ball in Walhalla Hall, last night, and about 600 veteran firemen, with their families and friends attended it. They danced through a programme upon which there were 25 numbers, and had a first-rate time of it generally.

It was evident by 11:30 o'clock that unless the ball was formally opened very early there would be no dancing possible. So the merrymakers assembled about the Reception Committee and urged the quadrilles to be called. They were to be, after the march of the artists, the events of the night.
The Liederkranz Society last evening promptly accepted the resignation of Oscar B. Weber, leader of the progressive element in the organization, as a member of the Musical Committee.

Thomas Sheehan, who invented the process of covering the exterior of iron with steel, died yesterday in the Hudson County Almshouse at the age of 77 years. He sold his patent many years ago for a moderate sum and went across the ocean. There he married.

This will be the last season that Louis James and Marie Wainwright will star together. At a late hour last night they decided to separate professionally, and each to head a separate combination next year for very much ...

Judge Lawrence, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, discharged Walter W. Toby, who was brought before him on a writ of habeas corpus. Toby was arrested in Boston for petit larceny with two companions and convicted.

Bidding was so brisk yesterday when the sale of property belonging to the estate of Lorillard Spencer look place at the Real Estate Exchange that the whole sale is regarded as one of the most active ever held there. Naturally good prices were realized.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following decisions were handed down:
BOSTON, Feb. 5.--The House of Representatives this afternoon adopted the proposed constitutional prohibitory amendment by a vote of 161 to 69.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--When the Agricultural Appropriation bill is taken up in the House an interesting debate may be expected on the clause inserted at the suggestion of Mr. Burnett of Massachusetts, proposing to correct the present clumsy and wasteful system of distributing ...

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 5.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon two boilers in the engine room of the State Hospital for the Insane exploded, completely wrecking the engine house, killing two patients, and injuring the two engineers, who will in all probability die before morning.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Feb. 5.--The Post Office at this place was entered by burglars last night. The safe was blown open and several hundred dollars in money were stolen, including the contents of registered packages on hand, the amount of which cannot at present be ascertained. No other mail was tampered with.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5.--The Liberal members of Parliament held a caucus to-day and decided to continue their present policy in favor of unrestricted reciprocity with the United States. A resolution to this effect will be introduced in the House shortly.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 5.--This morning Daniel Sickles, a farmer about 60 years old, who resided near Dayton, while driving with a horse and light wagon, attempted to cross the track at Grigg's crossing, about two miles west of Monmouth Junction. His wagon was struck by train No. 62 and smashed, and he was almost instantly killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5.--Vice-President elect Levi P. Morton came over from New-York this afternoon to attend a dinner given in his honor by A.J. Drexel. Mr. Morton, in his usual unpretentious style, took an ordinary coach attached to the express which leaves NewYork at 3 o'clock. It was 5:12 when the train dashed into the Broad-street station.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 5.--The New-Jersey Telephone Company to-day obtained and injunction from the Supreme Court restraining Henry Winters, the belligerent property owner of Plainfield, from again interfering with their poles.
A series of resolutions asking for a new armory for the Ninth Regiment has been sent to each member of the Sinking Fund Board and the Armory Board by a committee of veterans of the regiment.

LONDON, Feb. 6.--Advices from Burmah announce that Mandalay has recently been visited by two immense conflagrations. In the first, the flames destroyed 632 houses, a bazaar, and a Buddhist monastery. In the second 500 houses were burned. Both conflagrations were of accidental origin.
Although Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn bought the handsome residence of Jockey McLaughlin a short time ago for $23,000 it is doubtful if he will get possession of the property.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5.--The County Grand Jury this afternoon returned an indictment against Joseph A. Moore, charging him with embezzlement, and there is reason to believe that another indictment will be returned against him for forgery, the alleged crime having been committed in a real estate transaction ...

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Feb. 5.--Information was received to-night that this morning 12 teams, each with a driver and load of logs, broke through the ice while attempting to cross Canada Lake in Fulton County. Nearly all the animals and men were drowned. No details can be learned. The location of the accident is 50 miles from Amsterdam. The men had just commenced logging.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 5.--To-day in the Senate, when the calendar was taken up, the first objection was made by Senator Brown, who, when Senator Bowen's bill regulating arrests and police powers was read, asked for some reason why such a bill should be passed. Senator Bowen replied:

BOSTON, Feb. 5.--By an almost strict party vote the Massachusetts Legislature to-day passed the order to submit a prohibitory amendment to the people for their rejection or adoption. The vote in the House was 161 to 69, more than the necessary two-thirds required. A great crowd was present to hear the debate.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5.--A number of Chicago gentlemen some time ago ordered a silver service to be presented to the Untied States for use on the new cruiser Chicago. The service has been completed and is now on exhibition at the storeroom of the manufacturers.

A big old safe in which were kept the records of the United States Circuit Court of this district was removed from the Post Office Building yesterday, and a new one substituted. The old safe was purchased in 1857, and was used by the court when ...

It is a remarkable fact, observes the London Truth, and one that does not say much for Prince Albert's prescience or sagacity, that the three statesmen of the Queen's reign whom he most disliked and distrusted were Lord Palmerston, Lord Beaconsfield, and Mr. Gladstone.

The Westchester County Grand Jury yesterday brought in an indictment against Thomas Waldon for bigamy. The complainant to Marietta Stocum of Mount Vernon. She claims that they were married by a Southern minister named J.A. Tarbeck, and that now Waldon has been married again in Greenwich, Conn., to a young woman.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Feb. 5.--At a meeting today of the creditors of V.E. Fuller and H.H. Fuller, who have a large dairy and live stock interest, V.E. Fuller refused to make an assignment unless the creditors agreed to pay his employes in full, some of whom have large amounts in back pay due them.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 5.--The Board of Supervisors to-day ordered an election to be held in this (Hinds) county on Tuesday next, under the local-option law, to decide whether or not whisky shall be sold in the county for the next two years.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 5.--Every intellient boy and girl in Charleston, and a great many grown people, have read Edgar Poe's story of "The Gold Bug."

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 5.--Franz Schwartz, a dealer in brewers' supplies at New-York City, was arrested this morning on a capias sworn out by Paul Weidner, a dealer in brewers' supplies, of this city. The capias is the initial step in a suit which Weidner brings against the New-Yorker for $25,000 damages.

The Manhattan Lumber Company, at Eleventhavenue and Twenty-fourth-street, is in the hands of the Sheriff, and the sale is set down for to-day. Judgment has been entered against it in favor of the Tradesmen's National Bank for $19,457 on eight promissory notes.

The frost king enjoyed himself yesterday, painting noses red and nipping ears until they glowed and tingled painfully. He advent was preceded by a light fall of rain, followed in remarkably quick time by a shower of feathery snowflakes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6.--The trial of Charles T. Orbann against the Philadelphia Traction Company for personal injuries received terminated to-day in a verdict for the plaintiff for $20,000. Orbann was a newsboy, and while selling papers at Third and Market streets either was pushed or fell from a traction car and had his leg cut off.

Inspectors of the enrolment of Republicans met last night in many of the Assembly districts to hear from the persons whose standing as Republicans has been challenged, reasons why their names should not be stricken from the rolls.

Two young girls, Josephine Despres, 17 years old and Annie McCauley, 14 years old, employed by Mrs. T.G. Farnham, who keeps and embroidery and tancy goods store at 10 West Fourteenth-street, were locked up in the store by mistake last night. They succeeded in attracting the attention of Patrolman McGonigal and were released about 9 o'clock in the evening by him and Patrolman Leeson.

The Merchant Tailors' National Exchange of the United States continued its convention in Mason Templeic yesterday. The attendance in the forenoon was large, but that of the afternoon session was light, the attractions of the town evidently proving too great for many of the delegates.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6.--There is no change in the Cabinet situation to-night. Gen. Harrison has not yet selected a Secretary of the Treasury in place of Allison, though all the prominent politicians here believe that he will soon offer the place to Col. John C. New.
Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court yesterday, reserved decision on a motion made by John E. Parsons for a stay of the judgment against the North River Sugar Refining Company, pending an appeal.

Nearly 2,000 people attended the annual reception of the Atalanta Boat Club at Terrace Garden last night. The organization is the oldest of the kind in the city, and its receptions have grown from year to year till they have fairly outgrown Terrace Garden.

The fact that Theodore Babcock is acting as Secretary of the Civil Service Board at the Custem House has stirred up some commotion there, and some officials hold that he has not been legally appointed to the post, and that he cannot legally certify candidates for appointment.

DETROIT, Feb. 6.--The special convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Michigan assembled in this city to-day. There was a very full attendance of both the clergy and laity, the object being the selection of a successor to the late Bishop Samuel S. Harris.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--The Pitkin Vaughn Printing Company to-day entered up a judgment for $1,546.47 in the Superior Court against Charles A. Gardner. The defendant is a comedian, who has appeared in a play entitled "Karl, the Peddler."

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6.--The Hon. James Russell Lowell, ex-United States Minister to the Court of St. James, was given a dinner here to-night at the Mount Vernon Hotel by Reverdy Johnson, Jr. The other guests invited to meet Mr. Lowell were President D.C. Gilman of Johns Hopkins University, Francis White, William W. Spence, and J.H. Given.

Charles G. Rochat, a jeweler on Montgomery-street, near Washington-street, in Jersey City, assisted at a burglary of his own establishment. A day or two ago a genteel-looking stranger dropped in at his store, and, representing that he was agent for the York Safe and Lock Company of York, Penn., talked with him about buying a safe of that make.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6.--This morning the third day of the carnival opened with a tremendous storm. Snow was falling heavily, with the thermometer below zero and a cutting wind was blowing from the west. The streets piled up rapidly with snow, and in the morning few people were about.

County Clerk Henry Meream of Broome County has given notice to District Attorney Fellowes of the receipt of the indictment and papers in the case of ex-Alderman Thomas Cleary, which was transferred to that county on a change of venue.

A British man-of-war has been dispatched to Ching-Kiang-Foo to protect the lives and property of British subjects.

Joe H. Stewart, for the Board of Directers of the National Confederate Soldiers' Home, at Austin, Texas, has issued an appeal to the patriotic and charitable men and women of the country for contributions in aid of the institution.

PARIS, Texas, Feb. 6.--The disintegration of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system has apparently begun. The same policy is to be pursued that was followed in the Wabash wreck, the lopping off of branches.
LONDON, Feb. 6.--The steamship Brooklyn City, (Br.,) Capt. Filt, from New-York Jan. 24 for Bristol, passed Brow Head to-day.

Dadley Avery of the Stat militia and 17 others of that parish for whipping Joe Modeste and compelling Wakefield, Richardson, and others to leave the parish. They were placed under $1,000 bonds each to appear for trial.

DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 6.--Eight days ago three men called at the county jail to see Andy Finn, under arrest for highway robbery. They carried an extra overcoat, false whiskers, Finn donned them, coolly walked out with his confederates, and took the train for Wisconsin. The story has just leaked out.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--A man named Walter S. Bradley to-day shot and killed his wife and then committed suicide at the Hotel Cortlandt at the corner of Wabash-avenue and Adams-street. Bradley was a member of an old and respectable family in this city.
The course of lectures now being delivered in seven of the public schools every Monday and Thursday evenings are attracting much attention.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 6.--The Window Glass Trust has fallen through. One of the manufacturers said to-day that the discussion on the subject just before the Washington meeting developed the fact that is was an impossibility.
Second Lieut. John T. Barbour, Seventh Infantry, has been granted two months' extension of leave, and Capt. W.P. Hall, Fifth infantry, one month's extension.

LONDON, Feb. 7.--The death is announced at Rome of Cardinal Ledochowski, formerly Primate of Poland and Archbishop of Posen. He was imprisoned by Prince Bismarck, but was released on his promise to reside abroad.

Although the $2,000,000 capital stock of the American Pig Iron Storage Company has been subscribed for by wealthy iron dealers, railroad men, and bankers, the project of throwing pigiron warrants on the market does not meet with the approval of all of the iron manufacturers.

DETROIT, Feb. 6.--The articles of incorporation of the Michigan Gas Company were filed to-day in the office of the Secretary of State at Lansing. The capital stock is $1,000,000, which is the limit of capitalization in this State.
DETROIT, Feb. 6.--Sigmond Goodman, for many years a leading clothier of Port Huron, has made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to Frank Whipple, a Port Huron attorney.

Mr. George Riddle's dramatic entertainment, already announced in this column, will be given at the Lyceum Theatre to-morrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. Mr. Riddle has not appeared on the theatrical stage since he made a venture with a drama in verse by Mr. Edgar Fawcett in Boston about two years ago.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 6.--Columbus was thrown into a fever of excitement this morning when it became known that W.W. Bussey, Teller of the Eagle and Phoenix Savings Bank, has absconded. A general rush on the bank was made, but the demands were met by borrowing from other banks in the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6.--A meeting of representatives of soft coal companies was held today at the office of the Seaboard Steam Coal Association for the purpose of arranging a schedule of prices and compieting a pool for the restriction of production. President Mayor of the Baltimore and Ohio was present. It was understood that soft coal prices were fixed, but that the formation of a pool was still unsettled.
Assistant District Attorney Dos Passos opened for the prosecution yesterday, in the trial of Dr. William M. Reynolds, in the Court of Oyer sud Terminer, before Judge Lawrence.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6.--The bill for the adoption of the Australian system of voting had a lengthy hearing before Mr. Heppenheimer's committee this afternoon. The Assembly Chamber was filled with interested auditors, and the addresses deferred the opening of the afternoon session of the House half an hour.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6.--The second of the two cast steel 6-inch guns authorized by the act of Congress of March 3, 1887, will be tested at the Naval Ordnance Proving Grounds to-morrow.

LONDON, Feb. 6.--The British bark Large Bay, bound for Auckland, was towed to Spithead today in a sinking condition. She reports that on Monday night last she was in collision with an unknown four-masted steamer off Beachy Head and that the steamer was sunk with all on board.

George E. Frazer, a madical student, residing in the boarding house of Mrs. Packer at 349 West Fiftieth-street, was found dead in his room yesterday, having in his hand a hypodermic syring. Whether his death was the result of an injection more powerful than he intended, or made with the purpose of ending his life, re mains to be determined by a Coroner's inquest.

At a stockholders' meeting of the Toledo and Ohio Central Railroad Company at the general offices at Toledo yesterday it was voted to increase the common capital stock of the company to the amount of $257,000 for the purpose of settling the claims of the income bondholders of the Ohio Central Railroad Company to the amount of $642,900.

The United States was given a verdict in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in a suit brought by A.D. Juilliard Co. to recover duty paid upon several importations of wool tops. When the wool arrived the Custom House inspectors rated it not as ordinary wool.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 6.--An important meeting of Presidents and General Managers of all lines running into Pueblo was held this afternoon in this city.

Mr. George O.T. LONDON, Feb. 6.--Mr. Parnell was present at the session of the Parnell Commission to-day. He held a lively conversation with Mr. Michael Davitt.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 6.--Judge William J. Wallace of the United States District Court has issued and order removing James A. Murray of Buffalo from the office of United States Commissioner, and has directed that copies of the order be served upon United States District Attorney Lockwood and Congressman Glover of St. Louis, Mo.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 6.--It is stated on good authority that Memphis is to have another trunk line. The Illinois Central has been figuring on a Memphis connection for some time.
The matinee performance of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" at the Broadway Theatre yesterday attracted one of the largest audiences which has been brought together to see Mrs. Burnett's play.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 6.--The Sloux City subscribers to the $400,000 guarantee fund, subscribed for the purpose of aiding the building of the line from this place to Ogden, Utah, known as the Pacific Short Line, will be called upon this week for 25 per cent. of the amount subscribed.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 6.--A profound sensation has been created here by the issue of a summons against Lawrence Herchmer, Commissioner of the Canadian Northwest Mounted Police, on the charge of smuggling liquor into the Northwest Territories.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--The Committee on Reorganization of the Central Traffic Association met to-day to prepare a report to be presented to the meeting of managers to-morrow.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 6.--The Grashdanin says that Count Tolstoi, Minister of the Interior, will soon resign. MADRID, Feb. 6.--Gen. Salamanoa has been appointed Captain-General of Cuba in place of Gen. Marin, who has resigned.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 6.--The Cotton Oil Trust case was resumed to-day before Judge Rightor. Mr. Raoul Valton and Mr. Charles McGinnees testified. Attorney-General Rogers being in Now-Iberia Mr. E. Howard McCaleb conducted the case for the State.

The members of the Anawanda Junior Pleasure Club had an enjoyable time at their second annual ball at Nillson Hall Tuesday evening. The club is a young east side organization, with rooms at 326 East Twenty-firststreet, and is composed mostly of the members of the J.J. Scanlon Post, Sons of Veterans, fife and drum corps.

The three-masted schooner Allie R. Chester, Capt. Ingersoil, while bound from Charleston, S.C., with phosphates to Barren Island, was struck by a squall on Jan. 20 and driven ashore on the Diamond Shoals, II miles off Cape Hatteras. Just before she struck, First Mate Willis was washed overboard and lost.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 6.--The Rev. Thomas Hesiln, Pastor of St. Michael's Church in this city, has been appointed Bishop of Natchez. The news was received with a degree of surprise, since in was expected that the Rev. F. Maerschardt, Vicar of Natchez, would be promoted.
A half hundred enthusiastic young men of the Independent Democratic Ballot Reform Club met at 533 Eighth-avenue last evening to discuss the Saxton Electoral Reform bill.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 6.--The sixteenth annual meeting of the New-York State Grange continued its session in this city to-day. Mayor William B. Kirk in a brief speech welcomed the membors to Syracuse, assuring them that their organization must command the approval of all intelligent people.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 6.--Another insult to the American flag has been offered, this time by the Portuguese. The information has just reached this place, although the incident occurred the 1st of October, 1888.

Cooper, Hewitt Co. have become involved in a dispute with the Secretary of the Navy over the quality of about 300 tons of iron furnished by the firm to C.J. Townsend, a Government contractor.

Hill really intended to have his public appearance here as the guest of Secratary Whitney regarded as an initial step in his race for the Presidential nomination of 1892 and its value is to be estimated by the character of the impression created it was almost a flat failure.

Sawyer of New-Hampshire that he would not appoint Senator Chandler to serve in the Senate for the interim from the 4th of March to the 19th of June, at which date the Legislature will most to elect a Senator for the remainder of the term of six years, ending March 4, 1895.
Two committees of the American Industrial and Shipping League met at the rooms of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 7.--Walter J. Gibson, a prominent business man, shot and killed himself in the Wagner bathrooms, on Washingtonstreet, about 2 o'clock this morning.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7.--The report that Count Tolstoi was about to resign the portfolio of Minister of the Interior is officially denied. It is stated that the Minister's scheme to reform the local government will probably receive the sanction of the Czar.
Amos Lawrence Hopkins has quiet the service of Jay Gould. For years he has been one of Mr. Gould's closest business associates. He has been intrusted with interests of vast magnitude.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7.--At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the St. Louis Jockey Club today $10,000 was appropriated for a guarantee purse for 2:30 trotters, to be trotted for at the Fall meeting, 1889. This is the largest purse ever offered by a Western association.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 7.--The meeting of the Western Freight Association at Chicago next Tuesday will be of unusual interest. Inter-State rates will be forced down in consequence of the reduction of Iowa rates.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 7.--In the Star Catalogue case to-day Prof. Root of Hamilton College testified that he visited the observatory frequently in 1884-5, and saw Mr. Borst at work on sheets which resembled the catalogue manuscripts. GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 7.--The story of the drowning of 17 men and as many teams at Pine Lake, in this county, was a hoax. Information received yesterday to the effect that Secretary Endicott of the War Department was about to enforce the removal of the wreck of the Atlas within 30 days, called forth a letter from Pim, Forwood Co., agents of the Atlas Line, in which they repeated their statement that the work of removal is being carried on as fast as possible.

The Dock Commission has at last been able to obtain a full meeting of its board and to pass, by the requisite unanimous vote, a resolution placing in the hands of the Chief Engineer of the Dock Department the business of sweeping away the collection of unsighsly sheds known as the old West Washington Market.

Cards are out for Miss Bradford's wedding on Thursday next. The affair will be a quiet one. The bridesmaide are to be the Misses Nine Erving, Nine Betts, A. Winthrop, Constance Curtis, and Miss Wilson. The latter is the fiancee of Mr. Van Cortlandt. The ushers will be the Messrs. Fairiaz, Van Rensseiner, and Edward Key of Baltimore.

The most popular costume of the Liederkranz ball last night was that of Romeo. It mattered not how fat or how lean the man was, he disported his Venetian tights and doublet with an effervescent appreciation of his manly beauty that aroused comment if it did not awaken admiration.

President Aaron Raymond of the North and East River Railroad Company, by which title the Fulton-street cross-town electric railroad company is known, said yesterday that in all likelihood cars would be running over that line between Fulton Ferry and the Cortlandt and Chambers Streets Ferries on or before April 1.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 7.--The outrage perpetrated on the American whaler, Mary Frazer of Edgartown, by the Portuguese officials of Fayal, is of peculiar interest to the whaling communities of this vicinity, and especially to those merchants having whaling ships engaged in the North Atlantic fisheries.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 7.--A case was operated upon at the Sisters' Hospital this week which most strikingly illustrates that probably fatal folly of that modern humbug, Christian science.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 7.--Not long ago the remains of a man were disinterred near Matteawan, some persons believing he had been poisoned.

Daniel E. Finn, ex-Assemblyman--who is a great reader, as well as a slugger, powerful when not expected to slug, and a good sprinter when slugging is likely to be done with him as its object--did not appear before the Commissionors of Accounts yesterday.

Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday adjourned the hearing on the motion for a change of venue in the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton suit against Henry S. Ives and George H. Stayner until 2 o'clock today.

There are still only small opportunities given to anything in the New-York stock market except the specialties. Their activity and their buoyancy, however, are far beyond anything that Wall-street has known in many a day. Things that have been most neglected for months past are the most conspicuous now. Stocks that have invited most sneers are at present the strongest.

There were no police guards on the Belt Line cars yesterday. More old drivers and a few of the old conductors were taken back on this road, and the full complements of cars were run on both the east and west branches.

The handsome home of the Jersey City Athletic Club, at Clifton and Crescent avenues, Jersey City, was ablaze with light and redolent of flowers from cellar to dome last night at the tenth annual reception of that flourishing organization, and some 400 members and guests admired the fine decorations.

Judge Frazier, father of the young medical student, George E. Frazier, who died from an overdose of atrophia at his rooms in 349 West Fiftieth-street Wednesday afternoon, arrived in the city from Caldwell, Ohio, last ...
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 7.--Henry Womack, living near Social Circle, was bitten by a rabid cat about one month ago. He died to-day after undergoing all the horrors incidential to hydrophobia.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 7.--The weather was bright and pleasant and the track good, though not fast. Following were the events:
A jury in the Supreme Court, before Judge Ingraham, yesterday gave the law firm of Seaman Conger a verdict for $300 as compensation for drawing up the will of Henry Welsh, a wealthy grocer.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7.--John W. Norton, the actor and manager, filed suit to-day for divorces from his wife, Emma S. Norton. He charges desertion and immoral conduct, and makes Henry W. Moore, exmanaging editor of the Post-Dispatch, co-respondent. The defendants are in New-York City.

ALBANY, Feb. 7.--Gen. Newton Martin Curtis, St. Lawrence's gigantic warrior, was forced to beat a retreat this morning. He had introduced his new Excise bill and was distributing printed copies of it to members of the press when he was beset by one-half the members of the Assembly and his only refuge was in flight.
BALTMORE, Feb. 7.--Cardinal Gibbons has returned to Baltimore from Richmond, where he presided at a meeting held to choose three clergymen from whom the Pope will appoint a Bishop of Richmond.

TRENTON, Feb. 7.--The politicians who have been planning a new charter for Newark and Jersey City have discovered that an agreement is not likely, and it is said that the politicians of each city have partially made up their minds to "go it alone."
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7.--At a revival meeting in the Central Methodist Church to-night the Rev. Dr. Iglehart told the story of a remarkable conversion.
Miss Fanny Lahy, niece of Edward Kemp, was married last evening to Alfred Huidekoper Thorp at the Buckingham Hotel by the Rev. Father Brown of St. Mary's.
Some of the new and hitherto inexperienced street-car drivers are finding their situations all but easy and profitable. So long as they were accompanied by teachers, who told ...

The somewhat famous report of Mr. T.A. BYRNE, which was presented to the Senate last month, has been printed and distributed through the ordinary channels. It is entitled "Report of Frauds in Sugar at New-York and Philadelphia, by Special Employe J. AUBREY BYRNE."

Rear-Admiral Chandler, commanding the Asiatic squadron, reports under date of Shanghai, Jan. 5, the location of vessels of that squadron as follows; Marion and Omaha at Shanghai, Monocacy at Yokohama, Paios at Tien-Tsin.

BERLIN, Feb. 7.--In the Reichstag to-day, during the discussion of the budget, a resolution was moved by Herr Mirbach on behalf of the advocates of bi-metallism, calling upon the Federal Governments to concert with England for the re-establishment of a silver standard.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 7.--The citizens of Walker County, Ga., a few miles from this city, are very much excited over the existence of a genuine wild man who haunts the mountain region of the county.
The sale of seats for the special matinee to be given in Daly's Theatre next Thursday afternoon in aid of the Actors' Fund will begin ...
Anthony Comstock and a squad of policemen from Police Headquarters late last night raided seven gambling houses situated at 190, ...
SUTHERLAND, Fla., Feb. 7.--The new Hotel Sutherland here was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning, the guests and help narrowly escaping with their lives in their night clothes.

Charles Frohman leaves New-York to-day for Cleveland, Ohio, where be goes to sign, in connection with the Miller Brothers of Columbus, a five years' lease of the new Park-Theatre of Cleveland.
The Ninth Ward Pioneer Corps and a gay party of their friends that numbered 1,000 had an enjoyable time of it last night in Ferrero's Assembly Rooms, Tammany Hall.
LONDON, Feb. 8.--A dispatch from Rome to the Daily News, relative to the late Crown Prince Rudolph, says: "The first telegram received at the Vatican simply announced the death of Rudolph.

LONDON, Feb. 7.--It has been ascertained beyond doubt that the steamer which was sunk in collision with the British bark Largo Bay off Beachy Head on Monday night was the Glencoe, belonging to theGlen Line of Glasgow.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 7.--The New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad will extend its coal-shipping facilities, and as a step in this direction it has begun the erection near Two Bridges Station, N.J., of a mammoth system of coal chutes, covered by a building 1,000 feet long and having a storage capacity of 200,000 tons.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 7.--Senator Aldrich's merits for the Secretaryship of the Treasury were laid before Gen. Harrison to-day by John Hopewell, Jr., of Boston, a large woolen manufacturer and a leading member of the Home Market Club.
The news that the Secretary of War had awarded the Pneumatic Dynamite Gun Company the contract for seven guns for coast defense was little else than was expected by the officers of the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted registered 4 per cent. bonds to the amount of $290,000 at 109.

In his sermon at the Church of the Holy communion last Sunday evening the Rector, the Rev. Henry Mottet, D.D., said: "I cannot use any names, but I have it upon very good authority that a New-York gentlemen intends soon to surprise this city or Chicago with the gift of $20,000,000 for a great university. He has discussed his intention with friends of mine."
District Attorney Fellows was informed yesterday by Gen. Tracy and Richard S. Newcombe, counsel for ex-Alderman Arthur J. McQuade, that they would move for a change ...
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7.--The Thurlow steel gun was tested this afternoon at the naval proving grounds, opposite Annapolis, and stood the Governmental test.

LONDON, Feb. 8.--The Standard's Berlin correspondent says: It is understood that England will consent to the proposed Samoa conference. It is not likely, however, that the conference will it for some time yet. Various accounts of the Apia fight assert that Klein fired the first shot and incited the Samoans to attack.
Mrs. William Astor gave the fourth of a series of cotillions last evening at her residence, 350 Fifth-avenue.

BOSTON, Feb. 7.--When Oliver Wendell Holmes; a few days ago, formally transferred his medical library to the Boston Medical Library Association he had already placed on record his attestation of its value to him. It was at the dedication of the present building and hall of the association not very long ago that he said:

The Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island, the pioneer church club of this city, celebrated its twentieth anniversary in Delmonico's last evening. The ladies of the union were prestent in large numbers and enjoyed the elaborate menu which was spread.

A large number of the prominent members of the medical profession filled the seats in the large hall of the Academy of Medicine last evening to listen to the inaugural address of the society's now President, Dr. Alfred L. Loomis.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7.--The Missouri River Com mission held a secret session here yesterday and laid out work for the coming year. Vigorous operations will commence as soon as the weather becomes favorable for work.
The American Tariff-Reform League will meet in national convention in the city of Chicago on Tuesday. Wednesday, and Thursday, Feb. 19, 20, and 21.
People whose eyes were directed toward the southern heavens at sunset last night beheld a most wonderful and beautiful phenomenon.
The Chamber of Commerce again busied itself yesterday with the question of the proper location for the new customs buildings which are to be erected in this city.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 7.--Capt. James E. Waller, private secretary to Gov. Lee, was found in his office at the State Capitol building this morning with a bullet hole in the right side of his head. A pistol lay on the floor, Capt. Waller was 32 years of age and a native of Stafford County.

WOOD'S HOLE, Mass., Feb. 7.--Deputy Sheriff Alfred Crocker of Barnstable to-day attached all the personal and real estate of the Pacific Guano Works, at Wood's Hole, for $30,000, in the interest of the Lynn Institute for Savings of Lynn, Mass. Keepers were placed in charge.
Nothing was done yesterday in the case of the seized Mallory Line steamer Carondelet. She is still in the custody of Deputy United States Marshall George H. Holmes and several assistants.

Last year, on the recommendation of the Governor, the Legislature provided for a commission to make a careful revision of the excise laws of this State and either consolidate them in one act or, if that proved impracticable, report a measure embodying a new system of excise regulation.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Feb. 7.--Mrs. Sallie Vandergrift, the wife of Moses Vandergrift, Road Supervisor of Bensalem Township, has eloped with William Rue, a vagrant farmhand, aged 25. Rue was hired last October on account of his wretched condition and given employment as a matter of charity, and at once Mrs. Vandergrift was attracted to him.
The work of the Plan and Scope Committee of the Centennial of Washington's Inauguration to nearing completion.

The annual reunion of the Theta Delta Chi Fraternity under the auspices of the NewYork Graduate Association will take place at Siezhortner's, 32 Lafayette-place, at 6 P.M., Wednesday, Feb. 20. A large attendance of old and prominent members is expected. Intended participants are requested to communicate with Charles D. Marvin, 18 Wall-street, Secretary, before that date.

The Lieutenant-Governor of this State is a pushing and energetic man of business, but heretofore he has not been known as a political philosopher. Neither, to be sure, has he been known as an agriculturist, but it was both as a publicist and a farmer that he delivered on Wednesday the annual address to the State Grange.

LONDON, Fab. 7.--The sweeping character of Dr. Le Caron's testimony against the Clan-na-Gael, which was completed to-day before the Parnell Commission, has excited much interest, but it comes more from the sensational career of the man himself than the intrinsic weight of his story.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 7.--Mrs. Elizabeth Stryker, 89 years old, was found dead in her bed at her home in Spotswood, N.J., this morning. She was cutting a new set of teeth in her old age, and in consequence of that had been feeling ill for several days.

Adequate space for a botanical garden in one of the new parks having been assured by the Park Commissioners Jan. 24, under conditions calculated to make the garden conform in its scope and character with the importance of the city and the value of the grounds to be de voted to the garden, the Botanic Garden Committee ...

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 7.--The Legislatures of Kansas and Missouri seem determined to kill the Chicago dressed-beef combine. A few weeks ago bills inimical to the alleged combine were introduced in both Legislatures.
The Rev. R.B. Johnson was Pastor of the Methodist church in Essex, but he fell from grace and was expelled last April from pulpit and church.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 7.--The Democrats to-day completed the work of canvassing the returns of the election.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 7.--Two yachts of the Carthage Landing Ice Yacht Association were put on the ice to-day and raced over the low point flats during the afternoon. Ice yachts were also started at Dutchess Junction on the flats there. The ice here is fast and increasing in thickness every hour.
The Consolidated Electric Light Company filed its answer in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in the suit brought against it by the Edison Electric Light Company for infringement of patents.

OSWEGO, Feb. 7.--The storm here has abated, but the railroads are having a hard time. All the trains on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad were abandoned last night and one passenger train was all night in the snow between Oswego and Pulaski. Trains were started east and west this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--At the meeting of the managers of the lines in the territory of the Central Traffic Association to-day the Committee on Revision submitted the proposed articles of reorganization.

The new Fourteenth Ward Industrial School of the Children's Aid Society, at 256 and 258 Mott-street, was formally opened last night, when several hundred people, who are interested in the work of the organization met in the hall-like room on the second floor of the building which stands as a fitting monument to Mrs. John Jacob Astor's memory.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.--Ambrose T. Secor, formerly bookkeeper and cashier of the American District Telegraph Company, pleaded guilty to-day to the embezzlement of funds of the company and was sentenced to three years' imprisonment. The amount involved is said to be about $17,000.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 7.--A.H. Jackman of Nyack, the great shoe manufacturer, has decided to turn over his interests to the Hudson River Shoe Manufacturing Company of this city and to become one of the officers of the latter company.
HARTFORD, Feb. 7.--One hundred and twenty labor organization in this State are taking a secret vote concerning the Reform Ballot bill, which they will support before the Legislature.

The Rev. Henry Y. Satterlee of Calvary Episcopal Church had not received official notification of his election to the Bishoprie of the State of Michigan yesterday, and possibly will not till next week.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 7.--The whole of the foreign community of Chin-Kiang-Foo, with the exception of a dozen customs and consular officials, have arrived here safely.
The announcement has been made that it is almost a certainly that the opening of the Union-Square Theatre will take place Thursday, Feb. 28.
Mrs. Libby Mckellar of 190 Waverleyplace was so afraid of house thieves that she concealed her valuable gold watch and chain in her rag bag.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 7.--George B.A. Busche, who has been on trial for several days on three indictments for embezzlement in having swindled his employer, Isaac D. Blauvelt, a carriage builder, was yesterday found guilty on all three indictments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--The investigation into the methods and management of the office of the Supervising Architect of the Treasury was resumed this morning by the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds.
ALBANY, Feb. 7.--The State Medical Society to-day elected the following officers: President --Daniel Lewis of New-York; Vice-President-- ...
The annual election of the New-York Yacht Club which took place last evening at the club, 67 Madison-avenue, resulted in changes in the offices of Vice-Comadore and Secretary.
The hearing in the case of Coxe Brothers Co. of Drifton, Penn., against the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company was begun before the Inter-State Commerce Commission at Washington yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 7.--George S. Oldfield, President; H.C. Percy, Cashier; H.B. Nichols and H.L. Page, Directors, were indicted to-day by the Grand Jury for making false statements to the State Auditor in October last as to the condition of the Home Savings Bank of this city, which falled last November. Bail was given in all the cases except that of H.C. Percy, who is absent from the city.
QUEBEC, Feb. 8.--The report of the Government Commission appointed to investigate the management of the lunatic asylums of the province has been submitted.
J.A. Beasley, a member of the banking firm of A.W. Beasley Co. at 37 Wall-street, was walking down Montague-street, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning when he staggered and fell.
The watchcase makers complain that the task system has been forced upon them, and that the work that they formerly accomplished in six days they are now required to do in five days.

A transaction in tea, which is said to be the biggest operation in that staple ever taking place in this country, and perhaps never exceeded abroad, was announced yesterday. Joseph J. O'Donohue Sons have bought 55,000 packages of Pingsuey teas.

DUBLIN, Feb. 8.--The Court of Queen's Bench has granted a writ of habeas corpus for Mr. William O'Brien in order that he may be arraigned in the Killarney Court on Tuesday next on the charge of inciting tenants to adopt the plan of campaign.

WHEELING, West Va., Feb. 8.--About a month ago a mad dog appeared in the valley of Fishing Creek, Wetzel County, and there are now at least 20 dogs in the central part of the county known to be mad.

Mrs. Langtry will soon withdraw "Macbeth" from the stage at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre. The tragedy will be acted on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday evenings next week, and thereafter "As You Like It" will be given at every performance. The comedy is also in the bill this afternoon.
BOSTON, Feb. 8.--A.D. Ford and Mrs. R.A. Bates of Watertown were arrested to-day, charged with setting fire to a brick block in Watertown to obtain $1,200 insurance on furniture.

PARIS, Feb. 8.--The Journal des Debats publishes an article expressing approval of the action of the authorities in ordering an inquiry regarding the issue of an order of the day by Col. Senart, commander of the Ninetieth Regiment of Infantry, commenting in severe terms upon the German passport regulations.
John C. New arrived here yesterday afternoon and was on view as a possible Secretary of the Treasury in the Gilsey House cafe last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8.--There was a joyous gathering this evening at the little home of John Redmond, a blacksmith, at 2,610 State-street. A lost child had been found, and a father driven insane by the loss of his daughter was restored to his mind.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 8.--The glee club, assisted by the banjo and guitar club, gave a concert in Sunderland, Mass., on Tuesday evening.

The friends of Edgar U. Upton, who is missing, have asked Inspector Byrnes to offer a reward of $250 for any information relating to his whereabouts.
Elias H. Dormaul, a hat manufacturer, of the firm of Funai Dormaul, 88 Prince-street, accidentally shot himself in the head yesterday afternoon while cleaning a revolver.

The Third-Avenue Railroad cable case was not the only success scored by the Corporation Counsel in the Court of Appeals yesterday. In the appeal of the Sisters of the Poor of St. Francis against the Mayor of New-York, appellee, an interpretation was given to the statutes relating to the taxation of property which establishes a precedent and is of interest to real estate owners and dealers.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The week has made glad the heart of those who have been longing for some of the good old-time weather. Monday morning was the coldest this Winter, the thermometer registering 32 below zero at the Signal Service station. Wednesday the record was 1 above and on Thursday 12 below.
JAMAICA, Long Island, Feb. 8.--The will of Abrham Hewlett, who died suddenly at his residence at Woodsburg, Lond Island, in December last, was admitted to probate to-day.

Disputes arise between the harbor pilots and those of the Sound boats as to the right of way in the North and East Rivers, and as a rule the pilots of the larger force their way whether the smaller craft like it or not, or whether passengers in the smaller boats are frightened or not.

The Amateur Athletic Union's polevaulting contest which was postponed from the regular games held at Madison-square Garden, Jan. 19, was finished at the gymnasium of the New-York Athletic Club last night.

The minstrel entertainment of the Columbia College Baseball Association last evening proved very successful. The cozy theatre of the Berkeley Lyceum was filled with well-wishers of the blue and while.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 8.--A novel shipment was made from here to-day. It was a machine for the manufacture of ice, and it required 13 cars to carry it.
DES MOINES, Feb. 8.--The Supreme Court has passed upon what would seem to be the very last question that can be raised concerning the enforcement of the prohibitory law.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8.--The New-Jersey Society for African Colonization held its annual meeting at Princeton to-day, the Rev. James P. Wilson, D.D., of Newark, presiding.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 8.--The trial of "Red-Nosed" Mike, now in progress, is one of the most exciting events which ever has happened here. McFadden, the contractor, testified to finding the dead bodies of McClure and Flannigan on the morning of the murder.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 8.--A new phase of the factional fight among the Republicans of the State developed to-day, and in an unexpected form.
The summons and complaint in Frank W. Sanger's suit against T. Henry French were served yesterday, through his counsel, Mr. Henry Thompson of the firm of Vanderpoel, Cuming Goodwin.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Feb. 4.--The schooner Nellie A. Drury of Thomaston, Me., Capt. Wilson, from Baltimore for Cardenas, with a cargo of coal and cooperage materials, went ashore near Settlement Point, Banama, on Jan. 29.
The editors of the Columbia Spectator reinaugurated last night the custom of having an annual reunion of the editors and ex-editors of Columbian papers.

The Consolidated Gas Company's main in East Seventy-fifth-street sprang aleak Thursday night and the escaping gas found an outlet along the connecting pipe into the building at 241. This is a brick tenement house of five stories, including the cellar, and is owned by William Sartorus.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 8.--Several important bills were introduced in the Legislature yesterday, one of which is probably the fruit of the temperance discussion before the House Committee during the last two days.

The fourth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society, which took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon was one of the most interesting entertainments given by the organization this reason.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 8.--Many prominent horsemen have already arrived in the city to attend the great breeders' sale of trotting stock, which begins here next Monday.

BOSTON, Feb. 8.--The wrestling match at the Howard Athenaeum this afternoon between Duncan C. Ross and Capt. J.C. Daly for $2,000 a side and the championship of the world was won by Ross.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--Mrs. Daniel Lamont this afternoon gave the first of her two afternoon tea parties, which was well attended by the social world in which the hostess is so deservedly a favorite. NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 8.--The Oil Trust got ananother black eye to-day. Judge Monroe in the Circuit Court handed down a decision in the case of the State of Louisiana against the McGinnis Oil and Soap Works, overruling the exception filed by defendants.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The annual Junior promenade took place to-night in the armory of the Cornell University. It was the greatest social event of the season. This year's ball outshone all others.
FORTRESS MONROE, Feb. 8.--Senator Beck arrived here to-day much improved in health. He expects to remain about a month.

ZANZIBAR, Feb. 10.--News has been received from Lake Nyassa to Dec. 19. Lugard was still holding Karongas with a greatly reduced garrison, including six Europeans, the remainder having left owing to ill health.
The Rev. Herman C. Berg was installed as Pastor last evening at the Bedford Reformed Church, corner of Bedford-avenue and Madisonstreet, Brooklyn.
A miscreant who has not yet been discovered made an attempt early yesterday morning to set fire to the tenement house 7 Hester-street, which is occupied by 16 families.

Mr. WILLIAM D. FOULKE, President of the Civil Service Reform Association of Indiana, supported Mr. HARRISON and the Republican Party in the recent canvass on the ground that from their success more was to be hoped for the progress of civil service reform than from that of their opponents.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--Mr. Charles Spurgeon has sent a letter to his congregation saying that he will soon see them again, and that his limb is improving, though he cannot use it yet. His long absence, he says, shows the vitality of the church, which he declares will remain a power for good when he has departed.

It is alleged that at Antioch a Greek priest made so furious an assault on one of his congregation was had become Protestant as to kill him. The English Consul has received instructions to watch the prosecution and see that it is fairly conducted.--Constantinople Dispatch to London Daily News.

One of the happiest congregations in this city yesterday was that of the Riverside Baptist Church. Ten years ago the society was organized, and during all that time has been without a home.
The steamship Caroline Miller, which arrived yesterday from Cape Haytien, left that port only one day later than the Ozama, whose advices were published Saturday.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Feb. 10.--In a message to the House of Representatives Gov. Church yesterday attacked his predecessor bitterly, and the Legislature returned the attack with equal warmth and then postponed their formal answer till Monday to get it in better shape.

The Prospect Harriers will hold their first sealed handicap cross-country race over their course on Long Island on Saturday. The start will be made at 5 o'clock from the Manhattan Clubhouse, Sixty-fifth-street and Fourthavenue, Brooklyn. Entries will be open until Tuesday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 10.--Caesar Frazer and Ned Criss, both colored, were arrested this morning for the murder of E.H. Holdenburg, Frazer made a full confession of his own guilt. Criss asserts his innocence.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 10.--The movement in favor of asking Senator Kenna to withdraw from the candidacy, for the time being at least, has received a decided impetus. On the first ballot to-morrow at least five Democrats besides Dorr will leave him.

PARIS, Jan. 24.--"Pour embeter le gouvernement" is a phrase repeated just now again and again from the salon to the street. It is needless to add that it is used only by the Boulangists; or, better, by those who mean to utilize his name and their vote just to spite the Government.

The richest man in Berlin rejoices in an annual income of 2,760,000 marks, ( 238,000.) There are, besides this Croesus, 162 millionaires in thalers (at three mark) and 926 millionaires in marks. It is a pity that the millionaires in pence could not be added to these statistics.-- Pall Mall Gazette.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 10.--The late strength in wheat has had some effect in encouraging trade in flour. There were many buyers willing to take flour yesterday without asking any concessions.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton of All Souis' Church, in West Forty-eighth-street, preached to an unusually large congregation yesterday morning on the subject, "Deeds of the Dreamers." He said that every aspiration was an inspiration.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 10.--The Free Press for a consideration of $30,000, has absorbed its only competitor, the Morning Call.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--Discount was quiet during the past week at 2 to 2 . English railway securities were largely bought at an average advance of 1 per cent.

The seven hundred and odd men who tied up "Deacon'' Richardson's Brooklyn railroads over two weeks ago are very much interested in trying to discover what has become of the money subscribed for their support during their idleness.

Ingalls of the Chesapeake and Ohio and of the road that has just changed hands, was not a surprise to railroad investors here.

A movement to unite the Catholic temperance societies of New-York, Brooklyn, and New-Jersey is being talked of. The object of the union is to raise funds with which to erect a statue of Father Mathew in Central Park.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--Snow continues to fall throughout the South of England and in Wales. On the coasts heavy gales prevail, and a number of shipping disasters are reported. Telegraphic communication is greatly interrupted.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., Feb. 10.--The neutrals of the Class of '91 of Rutgers College, the members of which are at war over the class election, have combined.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10.--Official advices from Mare Island Navy Yard state that the United States man-of-war Mohican has left for Panama. She did not register at this port and passed out so quietly that she was not seen by lookouts at the entrance to San Francisco Bay.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Feb. 10.--Local operators report an improvement in the anthracite coal trade, and 2,000 men will resume work to-morrow morning in this district.

CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 10.--The strange case of Mrs. Emma Althouse, whose very recent awakening from a sleep of over 20 days has caused considerable newspaper comment, had a more than equally strange counterpart right here in Tennessee, the difference being that, while Mrs. Althouse slept days, the Tennessee woman slumbered years, and grew from a child of 10 to a woman of 32 while she slept.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Feb. 10.--Mr. Albert Bandle of this city mailed to-night an acceptance of Dr. Carver's challenge to shoot a match at 100 live birds in Cincinnati on March 16 for $250 a side under Hurlingham rules. Mr. Bandle's letter contained a draft for $250 to cover a like deposit already made by Dr. Carver.

Large quantities of ice are being cut by New-Jersey companies at Landing Station, Lake Hepatcong, N.J. The ice is of exceptionally good quality and about nine inches thick. DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 11.--While descending to a coal mine at Mitchellville to-day the rope parted and the cage, containing three men, fell 95 feet. George Harper was killed, his son slightly injured, and a man named Reynolds probably fatally hurt.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 11.--The Hon. Jehu Baker, Representative from the Eighteenth Illinois District, to-night wrote a letter to the Republican committee of the district withdrawing from the contest instituted in the district. This gives the district to Forman, Democrat. A recount of the votes of the whole district was recently made and showed a net gain of 15 for Forman over the official returns.

In the last twenty-five years wonderful changes have been wrought in Japan.
