The Lincoln Club of Jersey City held its annual banquet at Taylor's Hotel last evening. Major Panghern presided and 125 gentlemen sat down at the tables. Responses to the toasts were made by Gen. Hawley of Connecticut, the Rev. Carlos Martyn of New-York, John A. Blair of Jersey City, John Y. Foster of Newark, and the Rev. John R. Thompson of Brooklyn.

It does not take a vast deal of cause to set some of the people of the great east side to rejoicing. A hand organ, with its accompanying monkey, will fill the youth of half a ward with glee. A wandering band struck up a waltz the other night in front of Ludlow-Street Jail and ...

Miss Fannie Blackstone Freeman was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Louis Livingston Seaman of this city at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth-avenue, near Fortyfifth-street. The ceremony, which took place at 4 o'clock, was performed by the Rev. D. Parker Morgan, Rector of the church.

In all the discussion concerning Mr. HARRISON'S Cabinet there has been nothing more curious than the references to the Hon. WARNER MILLER, ex-Senator of the United States from the State of New-York and candidate of the Republican Party for the office of Governor last Fall.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 12.--An epidemic of the most virulent character has broken out among the Chippeway Indians in the Cold Lake district, north of Fort Pitt, where the great massacre took place in 1885.

There is much bickering among Tammany Hall's followers in the Twelfth Assembly District. Its cause, so some say, is that exAssemblyman Louis Cohen has attempted to take advantage of Coroner Daniel Hanly's lack of executive ability.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The testimony in the case of Coxe Brothers Co. against the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company was concluded to-day and an adjournment taken until March 1 next, when counsel will make their arguments.
LONDON, Feb.12.--Lord Hartington has issued a circular calling upon his supporters to attend the reopening of Parliament. The Prince of Wales started to-day for Cannes. He goes by way of Paris.

The cabled information of the marriage of Mrs. George L. Lorillard to the Count Casa de Agreda in Cornwall, England, Monday last, has aroused much interest here, especially in turf circles. Mrs. Lorillard was not only the widow of "Gentleman George" Lorillard, the ...
What might readily have been a section of the State Camp of Instruction at Peekskill was set up in the armory of the Twelfth Regiment, Infantry, at Ninth-avenue and Sixtysecond-street last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12.--Two masked men broke into the house of John Arterburn, a Nabob, in Monroe County, a few nights ago, and took $740 in cash and notes to the value of several thousand dollars.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12.--Roger Walcott, Esq., one of the Harvard Board of Overseers, addressed the students last night at a college conference meeting. No reports of his remarks were allowed.

LONDON, Feb. 12.--Le Caron finally left the box to-day in the Parnell inquiry, after 23 hours of close examination, with his story practically unshaken. It is true that, as against Parnell and others here in Parliament, it amounts to next to nothing; but it had been expected that the cross-inquiry would damage his general credibility more than it has done.

James Dickey owns a farm in Fannin County. For years the Dickey family has cultivated it, getting what could be raised on its rocky soil. Mr. Dickey has worked it from his boyhood. He won't work it any longer, for a few months since a Chicago firm that is looking ...

PESTH, Feb. 12.--The debate on the Army bill will begin in the lower house of the Diet on Thursday next. The agitation against the measure, which ceased during the overpowering public emotion arising from the death of Rudolph, has arisen again with sudden intensity.

The new County Committee of the County Democracy met for the first time last evening in Cooper Union. It consists of 480 members, and all of them who were at the meeting were as enthusiastic as if they had not met with disaster recently.

District Attorney Fellows, in the extraordinary session of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Daniels, moved yesterday that a day be set for the trial of Thomas B. Kerr, the former Treasurer of the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad.

George Putnam Smith as Referee began, at 115 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, the work of getting at the facts in the Pythagoras Hall controversy between the Quinn and antiQuinn factions. Technically the proceeding is one to cause the dissolution of the New-York Protective Association, the petitioners being ...

Some more of the policicians who have procured stands in the new West Washington Market, to the exclusion of men who had worked for years to build up business in the old market, appeared before the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12.--The following characteristic letter, written by John C. Calhoun in 1847 and found in the scrapbook of one of the old-time Democratic leaders, Samuel Medary, will be of interest at the present time.

A vague belief exists that our savings banks, particularly those situated in the large cities, hold fabulous sums of unclaimed moneys, the ownership of which has reverted to them by reason of neglect of depositors to make demand therefor within the period of 20 years.

The American Shooting Association was organized in this city yesterday, with C.W. Dimick of Boston as its President; J.A.H. Dressel, VicePresident; Elliot Smith, Secretary, and Solomon Turck, Treasurer.

ERIE, Penn., Feb. 12.--The United States Revenue steamer Perry, one of the largest and finest vessels in the Revenue Cutter Service, has at last been rescued from her perilous position, and, save a two-thousand-dollar injury to her hull and upper works, is in a sound condition.

The second day of the 48-hour female bicycle contest opened yesterday with a light attendance, not more than 1,800 being present altogether throughout the day and evening. The contestants went on the track at precisely 3 o'clock, looking comparatively fresh after their hard ride of the preceding day.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 12.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Westinghouse Electric Company was held to-day. The election of Directors was, however, postponed for 60 days, in view of the fact that important negotiations are pending with reference to the company's business in England, where large orders have ...

Whatever may be its views on the tariff, the Republican Club is a respecter of the American flag, for the Stars and Stripes were everywhere in the big ballroom of Delmonico's last night. It was festooned over the many mirrors from the front of the music gallery, back of the guest table, and its colors appeared in shields ...

ROME, Feb. 12.--The Pope, in his allocution, after declaring that the negotiations between Russia and the Vatican are progressing satisfactorily and will soon be concluded, deals at length with the position of the church in the modern world.

An ex-conductor of the Fourth-avenue car line said yesterday that the laboring men employed on the tracks of the Fourth-Avenue Railroad have had their wages reduced from $2 to $1.60 per day by order of Chauncey M. Depew and that the wages of all the other employes on the road will be also reduced to enable the company to make up for the losses it sustained during the tie-up.

Superintendent Murray sent yesterday to the Board of Police the following report: GENTLEMEN: I have the honor to submit the following report of the operations of the police force during the recent surface railroad strikes, and to make certain recommendations in connection therewith which the exigencies of the service would seem to require.

"Lincoln Day" was celebrated with due festivity and oratory by the Brooklyn Republican League last night, when the members of that body and their guests comfortably filled the hall of the assembly rooms of the Academy of Music of that city.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 12.--The belief that the visitors to Washington on March 4 will exceed the number of those at any previous inauguration finds substantial expression in the efforts made by the railway companies to provide adequate facilities for their movement.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 12.--On Jan. 30 the suit of Pferdmenges, Preytre Co. against the Government, commonly known as the Patna rice case, for the reimbursement of three-quarters ...
At the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, last night, a large number of people listened very attentively to Miss Morgan and her harp.

The way in which the allegation that an attempt had been made to bribe a member of its Appropriations Committee was treated by the Assembly yesterday did not indicate the right kind of sensitiveness in regard to the honor of that body and the integrity of its committees.

Ex-Judge J. Lawrence Smith was well enough yesterday to resume his testimony in the Stewart will ease. The cross-examiners still had him in hand. They carried him back and forth over old ground, and he became a little impatient early in the day. That was the condition of mind in which the lawyers evidently wanted him, and he contiuned to be an interesting witness.
Cardinal Gibbons, on behalf of the Archbishops and Bishops of the Catholic Church in the United States, has written a letter to Pope Leo XIII, condoling with him on his situation ...

FREEHOLD, N.J., Feb. 12.--The liquor dealers of Monmouth County are alarmed over the prospect of the county voting "dry" at the special election ordered for May 21 next, and there are rumors afloat that a big corruption fund to to be raised and freely used to defeat the dry ticket on that occasion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12.--May Wheat went booming today, advancing 4 5/8c. over yesterday's closing figures. It was a wild and ungovernable market from the start and the volume of trade was immense. The bulls had things pretty much their own way, the shorts rushing in to cover their contracts, and prices were bound to go up.

DUBLIN, Feb. 12.--In Donegal to-day Mr. James O'Kelly, member of Parliament for North Roscommon, was sentenced to six months' imprisonment for inciting tenants to adopt the plan of campaign. Mr. O'Kelly entered an appeal.

Coroner Levy was called upon yesterday to investigate the death of Mrs. Mary Sullivan, a widow 45 years of age, who was housekeeper for Mrs. Mary Farrel of 1,450 Second-avenue. Mrs. Sullivan paid a visit to her daughters, who live near by, on Monday, and on her way home bought some fish and cooked and ate them.

LONG BRANCH, Feb. 12.--Richard, J. Dobbins of Philadelphia, who is one of the largest property owners here, has sold the Searborough, the Queen Anne style hotel at Ocean and South Bath avenues, to Richard Mears, the proprietor ....
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12.--The Lincoln banquet, under the auspices of the Ohio League of Republican Clubs, occurred to-night.

SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 12.--The village of Sing Sing is lighted up to-night with electricity for the first time. The prison is brilliantly lighted up in the same manner, the electric lights having superseded the gas heretofore in use.
The Committee on Legislation of the Real Estate Exchange held a long and busy session yesterday afternoon.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 12.--News has been received here of the killing of Charlie Stein, a renegade, in Oklahoma, Saturday, by James Williams, Matt Coke, and John Swain, law-abiding citizens. Stein had killed Deputy United States Marshal John McAllister a few days ago at Eufaula. A party pur sued him without a warrant. He fired at them and they returned the fire, killing him instantly.

When John Y. McKane was expelled from the Kings County Democratic General Committee he brought suit to compel his reinstatement, but was met by a demurrer based on an argument that the court had no jurisdiction.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 12.--A private dispatch received to-day from a newspaper correspondent who has pretty thoroughly canvassed the situation says that Senator Taylor's railroad bill will be showed under in the Senate and can be counted now as killed.

A handsome spirit thermometer, 18 inches long, mounted upon a gorgeous, great card bearing a colored fac simile of Aruheim's tailoring establishment, is a recent device employed by that enterprising house for disseminating news of the good things sold therein. It is doubtful if there has ever been a larger or more interested audience at any meeting of the New-York Society of Anthropology than appeared yesterday in the small hall of Cooper Institute. It had become known that Dr. Henry S. Drayton would speak concerning thought transference and the communication of ideas independent of the senses.
PARIS, Feb. 12.--The committee which the Senate has appointed to consider the Scrutin d'Arrondissement bill consists entirely of members in favor of that system of election.

Hitherto machines for felling trees have been driven by steam power, but this is sometimes inconvenient, especially in thick woods, and electric power has recently been adopted in the Galician forests.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 12.--Mrs. Rachel Willis shot and killed herself at her home here this morning.

Over 100 preliminary notices in condemnation procedings have recently been served open property owners, principally in the lower part of the city, by Shipman, Barlow, Laroeque Choate, counsel for the City Railway Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 12.--The Czar's approval of Count Tolstoi's measures of reform extends only to the first section, which provides for the appointment of rural cheifs of districts to control the affairs of the peasantry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--Mr. Chandler's great desire to keep Representative John R. Thomas's name out of the Naval Appropriation bill has been gratified by the Senate, but the war vessel designed by Mr. Thomas is to be built and the credit for its design is to be given to the Illinois Congressman.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Jockey Club last Monday afternoon, Philip J. Dwyer, W.L. Scott, M.F. Dwyer, L.C. Behman, James Shevlin, Richard Hyde, John McCarty, John Delmar, and A.C. Washington were elected Directors. Of the 5,000 shares 4,028 were voted. Mr. Philip J. Dwyer left here for Florida Monday night to remain until the middle of March.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 12.--The General Term at Brooklyn to-day reversed the verdict in the John M. Pollock case, sentenced by the late Judge John G. Wilkin to five years in State prison for grand larceny. Pollock was junior member of the bankrupt banking firm of John R. Willsie Son of this city. Arthur V. Willsie, the senior member, is in jail awaiting trial.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12.--The new gunboat Yorktown left Cramp's shipyard this morning and steamed down the Delaware River for her final trial in the ocean to-morrow.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 12.--About the only event of importance to-day was the arrival of Congressman John R. Thomas's boom. It did not make a great deal of noise, for it came by mail. Gen. Harrison quietly inspected it in his library.

The subscription sale of seats for the Coquelin-Hading engagement at Palmer's, beginning next week, commenced at the box office of the theatre yesterday morning. A large number of the best seats had been ordered for the season by mail, so that the choice offered to purchasers was limited.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12.--A dispatch from Meriden says that there was a heavy run on the Meriden Savings Bank yesterday, a rumor having been circulated that its financial condition was not good. About $10,000 was paid out, all demands being readily met. There is no reason to believe that the bank is unsafe, but President Coe is in Washington and the other officials will say nothing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The President and Mrs. Cleveland were entertained at dinner this evening by Postmaster-General and Mrs. Dickinson. The table presented a beautiful appearance, with its floral decorations and exquisite appointments of cut glass, silver, and gold. In the centre an oblong bed of ferns was studded with red and yellow tulips.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12.--Another great theatrical partnership was formed to-night on the receipt by Mr. W.J. Florence of a telegram from Joseph Jefferson.
Suburban gardeners tell us that London fogs, with the accompanying hoar frosts, are increasing from year to year, both in frequency and in density.

Col. R.R. Hazzard, who returned from a seven months' sojourn in England, Monday, by the Umbria, gave a TIMES reporter yesterday some details of an extensive rapid-transit railroad scheme which he had organized for the Londoners, and which, he declared, was in a fair way of practical beginning in April.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 12.--The work of building the trestle for the Jersey approach of the Baltimore and Ohio bridge began to-day at Elizabethport and Roselle, the latter point being where the Baltimore and Ohio joins the Jersey Central.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12.--Highwaymen have been exceedingly bold in their operations in this city of late. Their attention has principally been devoted to ladies returning home from shopping, several having been "held up" on side streets and robbed, within a few weeks.

PARIS, Feb. 1.--For some days past a mild excitement has pervaded Europe. It was caused by a rumor--of which no doubt, the cable has apprised you--that Pope Leo XIII, had determined to make the Carthusian monks relinquish the monopoly of the liqueur whose process of manufacture is a secret with them.

W.M. Browne Co., wool dealers, 114 Federalstreet, Boston, have failed. The liabilities are said to be about $90,000; of which $58,000 or thereabout are for merchandise. The assets are reported as rather light. A detailed statement of the firm's affairs will soon be laid before the creditors. The members of the firm are Richard D. Peters and Henry R. Browne, both of Boston.

The merriest of all the Daly plays. "A Night Off; or, a Page from Balzac," was given last evening for the ninth performance of the subscription series. The fun of this piece defies description; nothing more diverting than the odd sequence of incidents in its third act has ever been presented ...

BERLIN, Feb. 12.--Prince Bismarck's attack of neuralgia is complicated with rheumatism, renal disorder, want of appetite, and insomnia. He continues to work against the advice of his doctors. His visits to the Chancellerie are marked with frequent outbursts of passion and other evidences of extreme irritability.

A few days ago there was reported in the Senate an amendment to one of the regular appropriation bills giving $100,000 to be used in protecting the interests of the United States on the Isthmus of Panama.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 12.--Gen. Louis Wagner, Inspector of the Soldiers' Orphans' Schools of Pennsylvania, passed through the city to-day en route to Erie, to attend the Grand Army of the Republic encampment.

MONTREAL, Feb. 12.--A young Frenchman named Emile Victor Michea, belonging to Valence, France, was arrested by High Constable Bassonnette yesterday charged with having forged in France a title deed, on which he raised $1,000.

TOKIO, Feb. 12.--The new Constitution was promulgated from the throne by the Mikado on Monday. The Constitution establishes a House of Peers, the members of which are to be partly hereditary, partly elective, and partly nominated ...

The Tammany Hall Committee of Twentyfour met last night and inspected the names of the persons--10 from each Assembly district-- chosen by the former Purroy Democrats to represent them in the Tammany Hall General Committee.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Feb. 12.--Jehu Baker, who defeated Col. William R. Morrison in the Congressional election two years ago, has given up his contest in the Eighteenth Illinois District against W.S. Forman, Democrat.
The State Commissioners of Fisheries met at their headquarters, in the Potter Building, yesterday afternoon, and considered applications for supplies.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 12.--In the House of Commons yesterday Mr. Choquette asked whether the Government has directly or indirectly received from any person or company an invitation to be presented to this House to visit the principal cities of the United States.

Great interest is felt by the Baptists of the country in the proposed establishing of a Baptist University in Chicago by some of the wealthy members of the denomination throughout the country.

Gen. Wingate having declined to serve another year as President of the National Rifle Association a committee has been appointed to select a suitable candidate for the office.
Philip Ohl, age 23, entry clerk in the wholesale silk and button house of W.H. Riley Co., 21 Mercer-street, was a prisoner in Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

Adam R. Dill, a colored engineer employed by S. Rothschild Brother, 307 Canal-street, this city, died in a horse car on Pavonia-avenue, Jersey City, while returning from work last night. Heart disease was the cause of death.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 12.--The members of the Yale crew of '88, the football and baseball men, officers of the athletic organizations, Harmar, Sherrill, and Shearman, and all members of the athletic teams which have won championships, will attend the banquet at Delmonico's next Saturday night.
OTTAWA, Feb. 12.--The Hon. Peter Mitchell in the debate on supply in the House of Commons to-day, expressed himself strongly against the increased appropriations for military purposes.

EAST BRADY, Penn., Feb. 12.--A loaded coal car dashed down the incline at Galusha A. Grow's mines, above town, yesterday, instantly killing Edward M. Baker, a miner. Robert E. Criswell, the weighmaster, had a leg and arm broken and received other injuries that may prove fatal. The tipple house and track were totally demolished.

HAVANA, Feb. 12.--Yesterday's chess game between Steinitz and Tchigorin, which was the eleventh game of the series, and which was won by Tchigorin, was opened with the Evans gambit. Thirty-one moves were made. The game lasted an hour and a half, of which time Tchigorin occupied only 20 minutes in making his moves.

Fire Marshal Mitchell spent several hours yesterday in investigating the causes of the Hesterstreet fire of last Sunday morning and became sattisfied that the fire was of incendiary origin. No thought that probably not more than a pound of powder was used, but this could create considerable damage in the way of spreading the flames, though it could not do much toward blowing up the building. It is believed that the miscreant has been located.
Eight new members were elected at the meeting of the society of Amateur Photographers last night at their rooms on West Thirtysixth-street, near Broadway.

The will of Cornelius H. Delamater was filed with Probate Clerk Tinney for probate yesterday. Under it his widow, Mrs. Ruth O. Delamater, receives all the property absolutely. By a codicil the son, William Delamater, receives the testator's interest in all patents and in his contract with the Rider Engine Company, and it is provided that the partnership formed with him shall not be disturbed by the father's death.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12.--The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company's Terminal bill, as modified by the Mayor, was taken up for consideration this afternoon by the Railroad Committee of Councils in Select Council Chamber. Interested spectators crowded the room.

Mrs. Ballington Booth's recent success in interesting prominent church and society people of this city in the work of the Salvation Army has encouraged her to organize a new series of meetings among the higher classes here. The first meeting of the new series will be held in the Berkeley Lyceum either Feb. 18 or one month later.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12.--Hinds County, which has been "dry" under the local option law for the past two years, voted again to-day under the same law, and returns received from the principal voting places indicate that the county has voted "For the sale" by from 300 to 500 majority.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 12.--L.K. St. Clair, a merchant of Wilkinsburg, this county, lies dying at his home to-night from two bullet wounds received at the hands of burglars early this morning. St. Clair has a gentleman's furnishing store and sleeps in a room just back of it. About 2 o'clock A.M. he was awakened by hearing a noise.
There is quite a rally of Montenegrins at St. Petersburg just now. Besides the Princesses their father Prince Nicolas and Bozo Petrovitch are on their way to visit the Czar.

WATER VALLEY, Miss., Feb. 13.--William Harris had a narrow escape from lynching this morning. He was arrested last night for the murder of James Jenkins, whom he is accused also of robbing.

A war appears to be imminent in transatlantic freights. At the White Star Company's office it is claimed that the complications are due to the action of the Inman Line in changing its sailing day from Saturday to Wednesday, beginning with the sailing of the City of Chicago from this port Feb. 27, the same day the White Star steamer sails.

Seats for the special matinee at Daly's Theatre in aid of the Actors' Fund have sold very rapidly, and it is quite certain that Mr. Daly will turn over a very substantial contribution to the treasury of the fund.

The following-named gentlemen will act as pall bearers at the funeral of Dr. John C. Dalton in St. Bartholomew's Church this morning: George Bliss, Dr. James W. McLane, Cornelius Vanderbilt, James A. Roosevelt, Joseph H. Choate, Dr. T.M. Markoe, Dr. T. Gaillard Thomas, and Dr. Charles McBurney.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 13.--One of the new departures at Johns Hopkins University is the formation of an association for ethical culture. The move is a new one in student circles and the President and Trustees do not look upon it with much favor.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 13.--Gen. and Mrs. Harrison gave their parting reception to-day previous to their departure for Washington. In the afternoon they received about 500 of their friends and neighbors and in the evening the Republican members of the Legislature.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 13.--Judge Cooley of the Inter-State Commerce Commission passed through the city to-day en route to Chicago. He said the commission had divided in order to hold sessions in Chicago and Baltimore.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., Feb. 13.--A second attack has been made on the will of Christopher Meyer, the millionaire, Otis W. Randall of Newark, guardian of Howard Meyer, the lunatic son of the testator, has appealed from the decision of the Middlesex County Surrogate admitting the will to probate.

BERLIN, Feb. 13.--Capt. Wissmann starts tomorrow night for East Africa. Some of the members of his staff have already started. The steamers purchased for the expedition for coast and river service will arrive at Zanzibar about the end of the present month.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 13.--W.H. Reading, a wealthy Cuban, this afternoon bought of John Madden, Lexington, one of the most remarkable fillies Kentucky ever produced, she being none other than the great Bosque Bonita, 4 years old, by Macey's Hambletonian. The price paid was $10,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13.--Yesterday's big advance in wheat was followed this morning by a natural reaction. Plenty of wheat came upon the market at the opening, and the May option started in at $1 09, a decline of 3/8 cent, and during the day ranged from $1 07 to $1 09 .

The cyclorams of the "Battle of Gettysburg" has attracted 150,000 persons since the great work of Philippoteaux was placed on exhibition Dec. 24, 1887.

An attachment has been issued against the Manhattan Clock Company of 58 Warren-street, NewYork, for $4,216 in favor of M.S. Frost, the President, who advanced the capital to carry on the business. PARIS, Feb. 13.--The Senate to-day, by a vote of 228 to 52, advocated the bills providing for the re-establishment of the scrutin d'arrondissement system of election.

Thomas H. Davis, manager of "The Stowaway," booked at the Star Theatre for next week, as a Yankee with red hair, who prides himself on the color of his locks. Manager Davis is bound that the red-haired girls shall not monopolize attention as magnets for white horses.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13.--This morning's fire in the Southern Hotel started on the fourth floor. The guests were hastily summoned from their rooms and came rushing through the hallways, panicstricken.

Louis Bixby, 22 years old, a tailor, residing at 166 Division-street, has been "keeping company" with Sarah Minxcatsky, aged 19 years, of 143 Delancey-street, for the last five months. He visited her frequently, and last night he made his usual call about 8:30.

TORONTO, Feb. 13.--Detective Davis this afternoon brought to Police Headquarters a young men supposed to be William E. Jones, exCashier of the Continental Oil Company at Denver, Col., who absconded with a large amount of the company's funds nearly a year ago.

PESTH, Feb. 13.--Emperor Francis Joseph today received the Presidents of both houses of the Hungarian Diet, who presented him with resolutions of condolence passed by their respective houses. In reply to the remarks of the President of the upper house the Emperor said:

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Feb. 13.--The case of Louis Huller continues the reigning topic. He is still in custody, but is allowed a large room and exceptional comforts, and is in good spirits and confident of coming out of his difficulties triumphantly.

OMOA, Jan. 12.--The snug little harbor of Omoa is sheltered from the north winds by a long sand spit, a miniature Sandy Hook, covered with beautiful mangrove trees, which in any other country but lazy Central America would be laid out as a park.
The feature of the bicycle race at Madison-Square Garden yesterday was the persistency with which Misses Stanley and Oakes worried Miss Armaindo off the track each time she appeared.

The Board of Directors of the Maritime Association of the Port of New-York yesterday appointed a Committee, consisting of Charles P. Sumner, Vernon H. Brown, William P. Clyde, Frederick G. Hennessy, and H.T. Hughes, to represent the association at Albany in opposing the Graham Pilotage bill.

The Executive Committee of the trunk lines met at the office of Commissioner Fink yesterday, about all the lines having representatives present except the Grand Trunk and the New-York, Ontario and Western.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 13.--Representative D.F. Morgan will introduce in the House to-morrow a bill to suppress trusts and combinations of all kinds.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 13.--Full returns from the local option election in Hinds County yesterday, show it to have been very close. The Returning Board have made official count from 14 boxes, which give a "wet" majority of 16. The remaining six are contested by the Prohibitionists, and if counted will increase the "wet" majority to about 200.

DETROIT, Feb. 13.--Eight churches belonging to the Detroit Presbytery of the United Presbyterian Church formally withdrew from that organization to-day and at once transferred their connection to the regular Presbyterian body. The movement was headed by the churches in this city and Port Huron, the only two in the old Presbytery that are prosperous and self-sustaining.
The steamship Faraday, which is engaged in laying the cable from Coatzacoalcas, Mexico, to Galveston, is now lying in the outer roadstead, having come here from New-Orleans, where she went for coal.

John J. Seagrist, a Brooklyn saloon keeper, who was tried in Justice Massey's court yesterday for keeping his saloon open on Sunday, was in luck. Two policemen testified to going into the place, finding Seagrist behind the bar in his shirt sleeves, two men lying in a corner, and two others throwing dice at the bar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13.--Instructions have been issued to have all the stores on board the United States steamship Monongahela by Friday. She is expected to leave direct for Samoa Monday or Tuesday of next week.

The little unpleasantness between M. Coquelin, the French comedian, and Mme. Jane Hading, the leading actress of his supporting company, has been stretched into much more important dimensions by an incident connected with the tour to California.

ALBANY, Feb. 13.--Ever since the dinner of the Holland Society in New-York City early in January the members of the society here have been uneasy. As a result of much discussion on the matter a local dinner was arranged, to be given as a supplementary affair to that of the mother society held in New-York.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 13.--When Mrs. P. Bauer of this city returned home from making calls at 4:30 this afternoon she found her pretty sister, Jennie Englebert, aged 26, sitting at a table with a bullet hole in her head.

Gen. Henry A. Barnum, the Marshal of the New-York State section of the inaugural procession in Washington, yesterday appointed Capt. Winfield M. Clark as his chief of staff and Moses G. Byers as his quartermaster.
LONDON, Feb. 13.--The hearing in the case of Patrick Molloy, who is charged with having testified falsely before the Parnell Commission, was resumed in the Bow-Street Police Court today.

I cannot say whether the death of the lamented Reichsbund which, unbound by any chain, used to accompany its master on his walks through the Thiergarten, has anything to do with an official announcement which has just been published in Germany.

The subscription sale of season tickets for the Coquelin-Hading performances at Palmer's, beginning next week, closed at the box office of the theatre yesterday. The sale is announced to be much larger than the subscription to the first season last Fall.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 13.--Andrew Carnegie said to-day that the indications were that natural gas would not last. This, he thought, was what Pittsburg was most concerned about, rather than any possible rivalry from the South.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 13.--Mr. Donison, a strong Government supporter, moved in the House of Commons to-day for the appointment of a select committee to inquire into the desirability of the Government acquiring all the telegraph lines in Canada.

The Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday passed a resolution approving the bill to increase the number of State Assessors to five and to secure one of them for the county paying the largest amount of taxes.

It is now reported, on what is usually considered very good authority in theatrical circles, that Mr. Barrett has in contemplation the production at the Broadway Theatre next season of "Antony and Cleopatra," with Mr. Booth as Antony and Mme. Modjeska as Cleopatra.
The Trustees selected to manage the operations of the system of manual training introduced into the city of Hoboken by the Industrial Education Association have just made their annual report.

Grammer School No. 9, in Eighty-firststreet, near the Hudson River, was visited yesterday by the Committee on School Hygiene. The building was erected in 1829. An extension has been added, but the old building is still in use.

The toast list for the Yale athletic dinner for Saturday evening is complete. Among the speakers are Chauncey M. Depew, Isaac H. Bromley, the Rev. Joseph H. Twitchell, Prof. E.L. Richards, and W.A. Stiles. The applications for seats have been so numerous that the committee in charge has requested all persons who hold tickets and do not expect to attend to immediately return them to the Treasurer, Otto T. Barnard, 65 Duane-street.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13.--The discovery has been made here that the control of the barbed wire patents is not vested in any American firm or corporation, because the device of barbed wire was patented in France to Louis Janin on April 19, 1865.

HAVANA, Feb. 13.--The twelfth game in the chess contest here was begun with the Zukertort opening. It lasted seven hours and a half and was won by Steinitz.

The Park Commissioners were informed yesterday that if they would move it to a site in one of the parks Mr. P.A. Karey would present them with the cottage on Fordham Hill where Edgar Allan Poe lived a long time and wrote some of his most striking poems.

HULMVILLE, Penn., Feb. 13.--Nancy and Sallie Severus, two maiden sisters, who have lived at Hulmville all their lives, are dead. Nancy died on Monday, age 91 years, and Sallie did yesterday, age 89 years. They will be buried to-morrow together.

ALBANY, Feb. 13.--The Jagger Iron Works, situated in the town of Bethlehem, just over the city line, were sold to P.J. McArdie to-day for $30,100. The works cost $500,000 20 years ago, and are assessed for $60,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 13.--The Dominion Government, it is stated to-night, has adopted a scheme to counteract the growth of the annexation sentiment in Canada. Sir John Macdonald, so the story goes, has been in communication with the imperial authorities to bring about the visit to Canada next Summer of a member of the royal family.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13.--Another one of the serious coasting accidents for which the steep hills of Ithaca are famous occurred last night. CHICAGO, Feb. 13.--Dr. Harriet C.B. Alexander, one of the new physicians at the County Insane Asylum, has discovered several cases of scurvy among the inmates. The disease originated from an insufficient vegetable diet. This neglect has been remedied, and while new cases have recently appeared it is thought there is little danger of its further spread.

HARTFORD, Feb. 13.--The objection raised by counsel for the Consolidated Road that the Housatonic Company is without standing before the Railroad Committee, surveys and estimates of cost for its proposed extensions not having been produced, was overruled this afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 13.--The Committee of Five Hundred, lately organized for the purpose of enforcing the laws against violation of the Sabbath and securing legislation reforming the present system of impaneling juries for the trial of offenders against the Sunday laws, held a large meeting last night.

Tammany men are working hard to induce Mayor Grant to appoint one of their number an Aqueduct Commissioner to take the place now held by Gen. James C. Duane, the President of the commission. It is not likely that they will succeed, at least before May 1.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 13.--The Rev. Father John J. Keogan, Rector of St. John's Church, Goshen, has been invited by Archbishop Corrigan to take charge to the newly-created parish between One Hundred and Tenth and One Hundred and Twenty-third streets and Fifth and Ninth avenues, New-York. Father Keogan was ordained at Troy Seminary in 1872, and was assistant four years at St. Patrick's Church, Newburg, since which he has been stationed at Goshen.

John Fleming testified yesterday in the inquiry by the Commissioners of Accounts into the West Washington Market matter that he has a stand in the new market. Col. James Mooney commended him for it and he got it, although he had no stand in the old market.

LANCASTER, Penn., Feb. 13.--A congress for the organization of a national trotting association for half-mile tracks is in session here to-day, 30 fair associations in Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, and Maryland being represented. The new organization will be independent of the existing associations. Frank Mortimer of Perry County, Penn., was chosen Acting President, and E.S. Edwards, Secretary.
Mr. Sidney Woollett will close his series of poetic recitals at the Madison-Square Theatre this afternoon. The programme will include "Enoch Arden" and other poems.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 13.--There has been a falling off in some of the Pittsburg iron and steel mills since Feb. 1. on account of low prices. Carnegie Brothers Co. are buying all the muck iron they can get.

A Middletown (N.Y.) paper claims credit for announcing that John D. Rockefeller has given $20,000,000 to found a Baptist theological seminary. Mr. Rockefeller himself refused to see reporters last night, but an authorized spokesman of his said there was not a word of truth in the story. Whatever might be his intentions of giving, he would say nothing about it until it was done.

The Granger stocks had another bad day yesterday. Though showing small activity, they went down easily. The specialties, upon the other hand, displayed quite the same buoyant spirit that has given them recent control of the market.
On the anniversary of the death of Seligman Solomon memorial services were held yesterday at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and Tenthavenue.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13.--William Hafner was to-day appointed Receiver of the Chicago Consolidated Bottling Company. This means that the "soda water trust" has collapsed.

The five-story factory building, 603 to 607 West 36th-street, known as the Dodge Building, was gutted from the second floor to the roof early yesterday morning, by a fire which started on the third floor.

HARTFORD, Feb. 13.--An effort will be made during the current session of the Legislature to secure a modification or repeal of the tramp law in this State, which has been on the statute book since 1879. Under the law 85 tramps have been sentenced to State prison.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13.--It is now generally conceded by even the warmest advocates of his nomination that Gen. Bushnell will not under any circumstances be a candidate for Governor on the Republican ticket.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 13.--The ice harvesters are at work at all points on the river north of this city. By noon to-morrow 8,000 men and boys, and 3,000 horses, will be harvesting the crystal cakes. From Athens to Albany the ice is 12 inches thick, and of good quality.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 13.--A lively legal controversy has sprung up here between the Elizabethport Cordage Company and ex-Mayor Seth B. Ryder over Little Smith-street. The Cordage Company wants to close the street in order to extend its works.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 13.--The Democratic members of the Legislature will hold a conference to-morrow night that is expected to decide the Senatorial situation. It will settle whether there can be an election at this session or not.

Thomas Conor, 40 years old, of 342 East Sixty-third-street, was yesterday found guilty in the Court of General Sessions of robbing Samuel Pratt of 306 West One Hundred and Seventy-ninth-street of a watch, diamond pin, and $5 in money on Jan 24.

MONTEZUMA, Ga., Feb. 13.--The steamer Montezuma, which navigates Flint River, between Montezuma and Warwick, in Worth County, sank at 7 o'clock last night, about 12 miles below Monetzuma. She left her dock here at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, with a full cargo of guano and merchandise, for Flint River Landing.

HARTFORD, Feb. 13.--The petition for legislative clemency by John L. Swift of this city, who is under sentence of death for murdering his wife here, July 7, 1887, will be stoutly resisted. The Supreme Court of Errors has denied Swift's appeal for a new trial.

An effort will be made by the National Skating Association to hold its fourth annual amateur championship meeting on Washington's Birthday in the vicinity of Newsburg. It is proposed to skate the 220-yard and 5-mile races in the morning and the 1-mile and 10-mile races in the afternoon.
DUBLIN, Feb. 13.--Mr. O'Brien, who is now in Trallee Jail, is very weak. He has been ordered better food.

The first result of Thomas C. Platt's visit to Washington and conference with James G. Blaine was the authoritative announcement by him yesterday of the fact that Mr. Blaine has accepted the Secretaryship of State.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 13.--Dr. C.B. Adams is at the head of a very strong movement for the establishment of a homeopathic hospital in this city. A bill was introduced in the Legislature yesterday providing a charter for the institution and appropriating $75,000 as an endowment fund.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 13.--Col. Ruth Goshen, Barnum's big giant, died at his home at Clide, near Middlebush, yesterday afternoon. He had been ill for months of a complications of diseases, which culminated at length is dropsy, and it was from that disease that he died.

The recent filibustering in the House of Representatives illustrates a condition of things that is very little appreciated. It is the result of the development of a bad theory which was established in reconstruction days.

Information concerning manuscripts that exist in America, written in the Oriental languages, is being sought by a committee representing the American Oriental Society. Circulars have been sent to librarians and eminent scholars throughout the country, asking their co-operation in this search.
Nearly a hundred years of useful service has been performed by the New-York Dispensary. This venerable and philanthropic institution was founded in 1790.

A suit of importance to importers, though not involving a large amount in itself, was decided in favor of the plaintiffs, Luckenmeyer Schaffer, yesterday by Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court. The firm imported some cashmere dress goods in which there was a trace of cotton.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 13.--A handsome new hall and library, costing at least $25,000, is to be built in this town to replace the Englewood Athenaeum, which was burned two years ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13.--President Hughitt has issued a call for a meeting of the Presidents of all the Western roads interested in the proposed Inter-State Railway Association to be held at the Grand Pacific Hotel next Tuesday morning.

CHURCH'S FERRY, Dakota, Feb. 14.--Considerable excitement exists regarding the half-breed situation at St. John. It seems that vigorous attempts are being made on the part of the Rollette County officials to collect taxes from such half-breeds as are alleged to be regularly taxable.

PESTH, Feb. 14.--During the debate on the Army bill in the lower house of the Hungarian Diet to-day Herr Ugron accused the Ministry, of using the influence of the Crown to exercise presents in favor of the measure. The remarks of Herr Ugron caused a tumult in the chamber.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14.--The United States gunboat Yorktown has proved a complete success. She has developed on her speed test an excess of 650 horse power over the contract requirements.
Three of the five stories which make up the brick building on the corner of Park-place and Greenwich-street, numbered on Park-place 71 and 73, were burned out by fire yesterday morning at 11 o'clock.

It is now quite plain that there will be no tariff legislation at the present session. The Metropolitan Trio Club gave its second concert of chamber music at Steinway Hall last evening in the presence of a large and appreciative audience.

The fourth of Theodore Thomas's delightful matinees took place at Chickering Hall yesterday. The audience was large and unquestionably well pleased, as it ought to have been by so excellent an entertainment.

There is plenty of good music to be heard today. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society gives a public rehearsal in the afternoon, and at the Metropolitan Opera House the Symphony Society gives one. BEATRICK, Neb., Feb. 14.--Everybody here is talking about the heroism or Mrs. C.W. Jackson, who saved her little boy from drowning in the Blue River yesterday.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 14.--The local-option election in this county resulted in favor of the anti-Prohibitionists by a majority of 35, Several boxes which gave wet majorities were thrown out, which if counted, would have given the antis a majority of over 300. The Prohibitionists are disappointed, but accept their defeat gracefully.

There has been no fighting, and Tamasese and Mataafa remain in their strongholds. The British Consul has warned British subjects not to supply natives with arms and to maintain strict neutrality.

RED JACKET, Mich., Feb 14.--All the shafts of the Calumet and Hecla Mine have been salted down to keep fresh air from the mine, as flames have again gained possession of the sixteenth level. There was no loss of life, as there was amble time to warn all men in danger.

LONDON, Feb. 15.--A Liberal paper having referred to evictions on the Hawarden estate, Mr. W.E. Gladstone explains that the tenants in question were getting hopelessly in arrears with their rent, and denies that any harshness or cruelty was shown toward them.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 14.--Assistant General Superintendent N.D. Root of the Northern Pacific Railroad, who was recently injured at Tacoma, Washington Territory, died late this afternoon of his injuries.

HAVANA, Feb. 9.--In 1888 the lumber imported from the United States into Havana amounted to 16,390,722 cubic feet--8,453,948 feet white pine, and 7,936,774 feet yellow pine. During the same year the railroads crossing the province of Matanzas carried 3,196,104 arrobas of sugar cane.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 14.--Baltimore narrowly escaped a scarcity of stamps, as the combination look on the stamp sale in the Post Office refused to work properly yesterday morning.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 14.--Application was to-day made for a charter for an electric railroad from this city to the famous battle field of Chickamauga. It will be 10 miles long, will be operated by electricity as a motive power, and will cost $200,000. Among the incorporators are three Massachusetts capitalists.

The Carondelet, with her cargo so fraught with unpleasant anticipations for the Southern Haytians, left port yesterday and sailed for Newport News, where she will finish coaling for her voyage to Hayti. Capt. Evans was too sick to go in charge of her and Capt. Conner took his place. There was added to the cargo already on board 130 boxes of Remington rifles from the steamship Westernland, first intended for Antwerp.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14.--Luke Emerson, the American who fired into a crowd in London, England, yesterday and killed a man, is a young stockdealer whose home is in Bowling Green, Mo. His parents are wealthy and he is well known in this city, where he did a large business in the purchase and sale of horses. He was somewhat addicted to liquor and always went armed.

The Book Committee of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church continued its labors yesterday. Agent-elect the Rev. Dr. Homer Eaton was warmly welcomed in an address by Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, and he met with a cordial reception by the Bishops and members present.

SAN DIEGO, Texas, Feb. 14.--James E.W. Herrera, a wealthy Spaniard, who came here recently from Northern Texas, died last night from the effects of poison administered by unknown parties. Sufficient evidence has been obtained to show that he did not commit suicide. The authorities are investigating the murder.

John Erhardt, John Grimes, and Owen Hanrady boarded a Staten Island Rapid Transit train yesterday and proceeded to raise a riot. They were intoxicated, and in the free fight which followed with the trainmen, they contrived to break many of the car windows and to thoroughly terrorize the passengers, among whom were many ladies. One of the latter was badly cut by flying glass.

Action taken at the Patent Office a few days ago with respect to an application made by EMILE BERLINER for a patent covering a device to be used in a telephonic transmitter has excited considerable interest in Boston.

Our past experiences ought to teach us that the supreme maxim in regard to the investment of the deposits of savings banks should be "absolute safety."

LONDON, Feb. 18.--A dispatch from Munich says that King Otto of Bavaria has been proved without a doubt to be hopelesly insane. The King had recently shown such marked signs of improvement in his mental condition that some hope of his ultimate recovery was entertained.

HARTFORD, Feb 18.--Within the annals of Connecticut it is doubtful if there has been such an accident, attended with so many terrible details, as that which occurred in this city today. The gloom of the storm is a fitting accompaniment to the horror of the catastrophe.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 18.--Allen B. Eggleston, Tax Collector of the town of German, has been indicted by the Grand Jury of Chenango County for embezzling moneys received for taxes, and has been put under $1,000 bail to appear at the next Oyer and Terminer for trial.

BARNETT, Ga., Feb. 18.--About five miles from this place two Mormon Elders were caught on Saturday night. The leader got 120 lashes and the other 85 lashes. They were then allowed to leave the community.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 18.--Col. C.C. Langdon, Secretary of State, is critically ill at the Exchange Hotel and is not expected to live through the night. He is past 80, and has long been a prominent figure in Southern politics.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 18.--The twenty-third course of "Mechanics' Lectures" at the Sheffield Scientific School will commence on Friday evening, Feb. 22, in North Sheffield Hall, ...

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 18.--In executive session this evening the Senate confirmed the following appointments made by the Governor:

Capt J.F. Fessenden. Fifth Artillery, has been ordered to temporary duty at Washington; Capt. Robert W. Shufeldt, Assistant Surgeon, to examination for retirement; Second Lieut. Alfred Hasbrouck, Jr., Fourteenth Infantry, to accompany a detachment of recruits to the West and then to join his company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--The more or less positive assurances from Indianapolis that Mr. Windom is to be Gen. Harrison's Secretary of the Treasury and to be credited to Minnesota are not overpleasant to many of the national legislators and political Cabinet makers here.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 18.--The King of Holland has had a relapse. His condition is critical.

The boys' department of the Twentythird-street branch of the Young Men's Christian Association celebrated its first anniversary last evening at Association Hall.

The Adams Express Company, as the result of a dispute with the Philadelphia and Reading Company over the terms of its traffic contract, has taken its business off of the Reading lines, transferring it to the Pennsylvania Road. The Adams people say this will work them no inconvenience.
A report that Postmaster Pearson was suffering from cancer in the stomach was denied by his friends yesterday.

The Parade Committee of the Washington Centennial Celebration has been notified that the Maryland National Guard will be represented April 30 by at least one regiment and ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18.--Sixty-four horses passed under the hammer at W.T. Woodward's combination sale in this city to-day. They brought a total of $25,110, being an average of $392.
The Directors of the Illinois Central Railroad held a meeting yesterday at which, according to an official statement, they did "nothing of public interest."

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 18.--Ice was gathered at points along the Hudson River to-day in a driving snow and rain storm.
