An important meeting of the National Cross-Country Association drew together last night, at the Grand Union Hotel, ...
Fifty Custom House clerks were put through an examinations for promotion yesterday. They are getting $1,000 a year and the places open to them pay $1,200 each.
LONDON, Feb. 18.--Mr. Herbert Gladstone has written a letter defending the evictions on his father's estate at Hawarden.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--The tariff-reform convention which will begin in this city to-morrow evening promises to be one of the most important economic gatherings ever held in this country.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 18.--Andrew B. Humphrey, Secretary of the Republican League of the United States, arrived in Baltimore to-day and found the arrangements made by the local clubs ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--The National Association of Electricians and Electrical Apparatus Manufacturers will convene in this city to-morrow. There will be a varied exhibition of electrical inventions in the exposition building.
The Republican Club at its meeting last night adopted a resolution to the effect that the Excise Commission bill presented to the Legislature was not calculated to reduce the evils of ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--The President has granted pardons in the following cases: Anthony Owens, convicted in Tennesee of attempting to pass a counterfeit United States ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 18.--The cotton palace which is to be an accessory to the festivities in the carnival season of this year was formally opened this evening. Mayor Shakespeare, Gov. F.T. Nicholls, Judge C.E. Fenner ...
DUBLIN, Feb. 18.--Mr. William O'Brien was arraigned at Tralee to-day on the last summons issued against him for offenses under the Crimes act.
Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday reserved decision on a motion made by J. Aspinwall Hodge to compel Julien T. Davies ...
AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 18.--The Savannah River has risen since yesterday noon to the height of 33 feet, but to the great relief of the community is now at a standstill.

PARIS, Feb. 18.--M. Meline, recognizing the impossibility of forming a Cabinet on the basis of a concentration of the several Republican groups, has abandoned the attempt. It is expected that President Carnot will appeal to M. Rouvier to form a Ministry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--The Chinese colony in this city is greatly excited over the departure of Sing Von, the trusted cashier of See Son Co., Chinese merchants, with $1,500, of which $1,000 belonged to the firm and the remainder to individual Celestials who had used See Son Co.'s safe as a place for their savings.

The Republican situation with reference to an extra session is becoming more complicated than it was three weeks ago when Senators ALLISON and CULLOM thought that they had arranged for one beyond question in Mr. HARRISON'S library.
A quorum of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees manged to get together yesterday and had quite a lively meeting. Mayor Grant made his first appearance as an ex officio Trustee.
Madison-Square Garden presented a busy scene yesterday in the preparation for the dog show which is to begin there this morning.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 18.--The sensation of the day is the resignation of the four Democratic members of the Legislature from this county who, it is charged, were holding their seats from the fact that six poll books were stolen at the ...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 18.--The fate of Oklahoma is watched in Southern and Southwestern Kansas with a great deal of interest. If the Territory of Oklahoma is created by the present Congress, there will be a heavy movement in that direction during the next three or four months.
TYLER, Texas, Feb. 18.--Receivers Bonner and Finley of the International and Great Northern Road to-night issued a circular stating that they had accepted the trust.

Robert W. Woolley, an expert accountant, in the employ of Charles F. Brown of 94 Wall-street, was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday charged with forging his employer's name to a check for $440. This was cashed at the Third National Bank, but when returned to Mr. Brown he declared is a forgery. Woolley refused to plead until he had consulted a lawyer, He was held for future examination.

ALBANY, Feb. 19.--With objects to protest and assist German Roman Catholic emigrants, maintain a Roman Catholic chapel, , in NewYork, the Lee Home for German Catholic Emigrants is incorporated. The Trustees are the Right Rev. Winard M. Wigger of South Orange, N.J., Herman Huber, William Schiekel, Peter Klein, and Joseph Schaefer of New-York City.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 19.--The mail carrier and the office boy were the most assiduous callers on Gen. John W. Noble to-day. The one delivered a basketful of congratulations from friends at a distance, and the other introduced a hundred or more friends at hand.

At the meeting of the Board of Education, to-day, a petition from the citizens of the Ninth Ward will be received, asking that recent alterations in the arrangements of Grammar School Building No. 3, at Hudson and Grove streets, be ratified.

The thus far unfortunate San Dominican steamer Conserva was seized Monday night by United States Marshal Stafford. Yesterday morning she was towed to the Atlantic Dock, in Brooklyn, and left in the hands of the officers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19.--The schooner Tahiti, arriving here from Tahiti, brings word that the greatest ecitement prevails there in consequence of news brought of trouble at Samoa. This has been heightened by the operations of the French toward Bola Bola, Muaheine, and Rairates, which form the leeward islands of the Society group.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 19.--The ice on the Central Hudson is like a sheet of glass in point of smoothness. Rondout Marlborough, Hyde Park, New-Hamburg, Low Point, and other yachtsmen have arranged to sail a series of races to-morrow. Fast time it is expected will be made.

The programme of the Coquelin-Hading performances next week, the last of the engagement at Palmer's, was yesterday arranged by Mr. Abbey. It will include nine performances, two extra matinees being arranged for, one on Wednesday for the benefit of Mr. Durand, the business manager, and one on Friday for the benefit of Mme. Patry.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 19.--The bodies of the Rev. Dr. Perrin and wife were removed from the ruins of the Park Central Hotel during the day. Insurance Commissioner Fyler of Torrington, who was frequently with Dr. Perrin while in this city, knew the location of his room in the hotel.

UTICA, Feb. 19.--George D. Egert, aged 61, and for about 30 years roadmaster for the Utica and Black River Railroad Company, committed suitice by hanging this morning in a woodshed in the rear of his residence in this city. He leaves a widow and one daughter.

The Joint Committee on Railroads gave another hearing this afternoon to the Hamilton Cable bill. The only speakers were Corporation Counsel Beekman and Gen. James M. Varnum. The latter appeared in opposition to the bill as the counsel for the property owners about Gramercy Park.

At 12 o'clock to-day the new trunk line agreement goes into effect. It was accepted yesterday afternoon by the Presidents of the roads, who met at the office of Commissioner Fink to pass upon the revision which he had prepared, with the assistance of suggestions from the Executive Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 19.--In the Parliamentary election in the Eastern Division of Perthshire today, Mr. Kinloch, the Gladstonian candidate, received 4,005 votes, and Mr. Boase, Unionist, 2,189. In the last election the Gladstonian candidate received 3,504 and the Unionist 2,195.

DETROIT, Feb. 19.--In the two cases of Olive E. Friend against the Washtenaw Circuit Judge, the Supreme Court to-day denied the motions for a mandamus to compel the latter to dissolve the attachment issued against the goods and chattels of the complainant.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19.--There was an extensive and expensive fire in this city this morning. Rudolph Blankenburg Co.'s large importing house, 13 Bank-street, and extending through to 18 and 20 Strwarberry-street, was completely destroyed.

The rupture to the relations which have existed between the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company and the Adams Express Company is a result of several complications. When the Adams people bought out the Reading's express business, about two years ago, a five-year contract was made, under which the Adams was to control all the express business...

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--If tariff reform had won a magnificent victory at the polls in November instead of suffering a reverse, the enthusiasm of its friends who met here to-day in convention could scarcely have been greater.

It is fitting that in a series of public lectures provided by a Society for Promoting Good Citizenship there should be one relating to possible large reduction of the death rate by the enforcement of sanitary laws.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Fifty one-thousanddollar bonds of Ulster County, interest 3 per sent., payable annually, bonds payable March 1, 1900, were sold here to the highest bidder this afternoon.

TRENTON, Feb. 19.--The conference that had been arranged between Senator McPherson and other Democratic leaders on the liquor question did not take place yesterday, and the caucus had to go on to-day without their help.

There was a large attendance last evening at the fair in aid of the German Hospital that is being held at the American Institute. The receipts from Monday evening amounted to $8,766, and Mrs. F. Schneider, the lady President, received $350 in cash donations. Miss Meta Volkmann raised $3,245 through advertisements in the Fair Journal.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday received and approved the report of its Law Committee in favor of amending the law permitting stands for the sale of fruit, c., within stoop lines. The law does not permit the standholders to pay rent to the owners or occupants of premises in front of which their stands are placed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The following statemeet in regard to the Samoan question was prepared of the Department of State and furnished for publication to-day:

Peter F. Meyer has faced many interesting crowds of bidders from his stand in the Real Estate Exchange, but never until yesterday did he enjoy the experience of selling property at the rate of $1,000,000 an hour. That is what he did for two hours with the estate of Joshua Jones.

PARIS, Feb. 19.--In spite of continued negotiations the settlement of the Cabinet crisis appears as distant as ever. The failure of M. Meline indicates the absolute impossibility of forming a Cabinet on Ferryist or Opportunist lines.

The Centennial Sub-Committee in charge of the church services commemorative of the inauguration of George Washington as first President in to-day regretting the face that no printed records or account of the religious ceremonies which took place on that momentous occasion are extant.

The funeral of Miss M. Louise Comstock was held yesterday morning at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Chapel, Thirty-ninth-street and Seventh-avenue. The Rev. Thomas H. Sill, Rector, officiated, assisted by the Rev. J.R.L. Nisbett of Richmond Hill, Long Island, and the...

Several of the Eastern stockholders of the Hector Gold Mining Company of California have organized for the purpose of resisting an assessment of 15 cents a share on the stock, and for otherwise protecting their interests.

An open letter from Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn to Chairman Crosby of the Cities Committee of the Assembly was made public yesterday. The letter to directed against the objections made by ex-Mayor Low to the "local improvement" bills at present in the hands of the Legislature.

DOVER, Del., Feb. 19.--The State Treasurer and Auditor dead-lock was ended this afternoon by the House sending in the names of the present incumbents, William Herbert and James H. Boyce, whose nominations were at once confirmed by the Senate.

The Stars and Stripes will cover the interior walls of Terrace Garden Saturday night, at the reception and ball of Manhattan Lodge, I.O.B.B., which will not only be a lodge affair, but will in a small way foreshadow the centennial celebration of Washington's inauguration.

The Emigration Commissioners yesterday re-elected as their President Charles N. Taintor. The question of the baggage contract, which has been so long under consideration, was decided by allowing Bernard Biglin, the present holder of the contract, an opportunity to continue his present service at a reduced rate.

P.T. Barnum, the veteran showman, appeared as complainant yesterday in the Yorkville Police Court against a female swindle who gave the name of Maggie Morgan, and said she lived at 218 East Eighteenth-street.

The attempt to make Mr. ANDREWS, the Superintendent of Public Buildings, the scapegoat for the swindling of the State in the construction of the ceiling of the Assembly Chamber will be warmly supported by those politicians who are anxious to screen the real culprits.
There was a family gathering in the Twelfth Regiment Armory last night which was attended by every officer and soldier in Col. Barber's command, beside many invited guests.

DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 19.--Advices from Washington say that the Government has decided against the Stinson claim, involving 14 quarter sections of land at Old and West Superior, Wis., worth about $2,000,000. It was charged and sustained that Stinson, 20 years ago, had the land taken up by his employes and later made over to him, a prearranged fraud.

The stockholders of the New-Jersey Jockey Club met yesterday afternoon at the office of the club. 58 Broad-street, Elizabeth, and elected the following officers for the current year: President-- Michael F. Dwyer; Directors--M.F. Dwyer, John Kelly, Philip J. Dwyer, and F.C. O'Reilly; Secretary--H.D. McIntyre; Treasurer--J.J. Fogarty; Superintendent--Benjamin Brush. About 200 men are at work grading the track.

PESTH, Feb. 19.--The Pester Lloyd professes to have secret knowledge of the source from whence Gen. Boulanger derives his election funds. It says the Pan-Slavists staked their hopes on Gen. Boulanger and the political success...
BERLIN, Feb. 19.--The Official Gazette publishes an imperial ordinance regulating the prize jurisdiction in connection with the Zanzibar blockade.

LONDON, Feb. 19.--The court room was crowded to-day when the Parnell Commission resumed its sitting. Messrs. Henry Labou chere. John Morley, the Right Hon. George Shaw Lefevre, and other prominent persons were present.
CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 19.--The work on the new cruisers Concord and Bennington is being pushed steadily forward and it is expected that both vessels will be launched before July next.

The tenth and last of the subscription performances at Daly's Theatre, which have afforded rare enjoyment to cultivated playgoers during the Winter, was given last night, and was in some respects the most interesting of them all.

Ohio, the mother of Presidential candidates, became too big for her outskirts last night and filled up Delmonico's with her big society in this city that it might properly enjoy its fourth annual banquet.
Business came to a standstill for about an hour on the Stock Exchange yesterday aft ernoon while the brokers had fun with a mule.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The Acting Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bonds: Registered 4 s, $450,000, $100,000, $5,000, and $100 all at 109 1/8.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19.--The proceedings before the Appropriations Committee of the House to-day in the matter of the ceiling investigation were such as to convince the most unconcerned spectator that if the truth and the whole truth of this scandal is ever brought out it must be transferred to some other committee.

There will be a meeting of members of the Produce Exchange in the call room of that institution to-morrow afternoon at 2:15 o'clock for the purpose of taking action with reference to the bill now before the State Legislature to repeal the McEvoy Elevator act of last year.

PANAMA, Feb. 19, via Galveston.--Two thousand five hundred men were discharged from the canal works at Tavernilla on the 16th. The contractors continue to curtall the work on all the sections. There is a strong military force on tho line of the canal to maintain order.

QUEBEC, Feb. 19.--The Ultramontanes have been displaying a most aggressive spirit lately and time and time again they have forced the Liberals in the Provincial Legislature to suit their legislation to the ideas of the Church of Rome.
CARLISLE, Penn., Feb. 19.--Theodore Carnman (Democrat) was to-day re-elected Mayor of this city by a reduced majority.

At the annual meeting of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company yesterday Jay Gould retired from the Board of Directors, Henry A.C. Taylor being elected his successor. The change is made at Mr. Gould's own suggestion. He wrote this letter a month age to President Samuel Sloan:
The statement by one of Mr. HARRISON'S recent visitors that no authentic announcement of the names of the members of the Cabinet will be made until after the inauguration is undoubtedly correct.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 19.--One of the leading millers makes the following estimate of wheat in sight, and says that the millers here have fully as much wheat bought for future delivery as is here figured out. The estimate is given for what it is worth and merely to show how the bulls here look at the situation:

ELIZABETH, Feb. 19.--Engineers for the Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday staked out the new station to be erected at the junction of East Broad street with Pennsylvania Railroad-avenue. The station will, it is said, be the finest in New-Jersey outside of the one at Jersey City. The Pennsylvania Company will soon remove the North Elizabeth Station to Laura-street, in close proximity to the new race course.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 19.--At the charter election to day the Republicans elected the Overseer of the Poor, the Assessor, three Aldermen out of six, nine Supervisors out of eleven, and three School Commissioners out of six. The Common Council last year stood eight Republicans and three Democrats. The new Council will stand six Republicans to five Democrats.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19.--The difference of opinion between the Annapolis and the naval authorities as to the opening of King Georgestreet will probably, under the inspection it is now receiving, be narrowed to a very small point.

It is likely that the West Washington Market inquiry will not go on to-day. Another obstacle has been put in its way. De Lancey Nicoll has refused to act as special counsel for the Commissioners of Accounts unless Controller Myers will do something that he has refused to do hitherto.

The Press Club will give its annual dinner at Delmonico's Wednesday evening next. Among the speakers will be Gov. Hill, Gov. Greene of New-Jersey, the Hon. Chauncey M. Depew, Mayor Grant, Mayor Cleveland of Jersey City, the Hon. Roswell P. Flower, Col. Taylor of the Boston Globe, Gen. Agnus of the Baltimore American, Col. Elliott F. Shepard, Henry George, and many others. No tickets will be issued after Monday next.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--In the State Senate to-day a bill was introduced fixing the rate on telegraphic messages between points in this State at 15 cents for 10 words or less, and 1 cent for each additional word for distances of 350 miles or lees, and at 20 cents for 10 words and 2 cents each for additional words for distances greater than 350 miles.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 19.--The market Record says: "Minneapolis millers say they have bought more wheat for May than there is wheat in Minneapolis, Duluth, St. Paul, and country elevators. They believe wheat will be short next Summer and have bought the future because they want the property.

Senator VEDDER'S bill for the taxation of liquor sales was ordered to a third reading in the Senate yesterday by a party vote. The fact that there was a party division upon it is enough in itself to indicate that there is no hope of its becoming a law, and it is only an obstruction in the way of proper excise legislation.
NEWBURG, Feb. 19.--The Coroner's jury in the coasting accident at Matteawan, in which Fred Langman died from injuries received, have censured Chester Palmer and his father...

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 19.--The annual session of the Ancient Order of United Workmen, Grand Lodge, embracing the States of Maryland, Virginia, New-Jersey, and Delaware, began here this afternoon. About 110 delegates, representing 104 lodges with a membership of 3,129, are present.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19.--Intelligence was received here to-day of the suicide of the Hon. Jesse Calhoun, a prominent planter of Pike County. The cause was shame over the arrest of his son in Texas for murder.

NEWBUBG, N.Y., Feb. 19.--The divorce case of George Massie of New-York against Eliza J. Massie was tried here to-day before Judge Barnard. Four persons named as co-respondents were among the witnesses, as were also three children of the couple, aged respectively 12, 7, and 5 years.

FULDA, Minn., Feb. 19.--The facts of the life and death of Annie L. Swindell, the teacher in the Donaldson District, are somewhat mysterious. Miss Swindell was engaged last Fall as a nurse by Mrs. McCready of Slayton.

The trnuk line Presidents yesterday considered the charges as to the manipulations of rates on traffic from Western points via Peoria and other competitive junctions, and the action of the Peoria Board of Trade boycotting the inspection of billing.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 19.--The Democrats frittered away another apportunity to agree on a United States Senator to-night. A conference was held, and, as usual, the out-andout Kenna men prevented it from taking any decisive action.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19.--When the case of Mr. William O'Brien was resumed at Tralee to-day Mr. O'Brien refused to allow Mr. Healey, his counsel, to apologize for the language the latter had used to Col. Turner during the progress of the case yesterday.
ELIZABETH, Feb. 19.--While taking in clothes from a line Mrs. Joseph Osmun fell from a thirdstory window of her home, at 169 Third-street, today. She was fatally injured by the fall.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 19.--The State Prohibition Convention was called to order at the Opera House this morning by Mr. John Fulton, President of the State Constitutional Amendment Association. Upon motion of Representative Dravo of Alleghany County Gen. Harry White...

Thomas B. Peddie, who died a few days ago, gave during his life $115,000 to the Peddie Memorial First Baptist Church of Newark. By his will it was learned yesterday he directed that his estate should contribute the money necessary to finish the church. This additional donation will amount to $35,000 or $40,000.

The thirteenth annual bench show of dogs, given under the auspices of the Westminster Kennel Club, was opened yesterday morning in Madison-Square Garden with the largest exhibition that has yet been given here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--The Chicago, Bulington and Quincy has reduced its train service in the State of Iowa to the extent of 8,000 miles a month, and is preparing to make an additional reduction to the same extent.
The work of examining candidates for the jury to try Thomas B. Kerr, the alleged briber, went on all day yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Daniels.

COXSACKIE, N.Y., Feb. 19.--This has been a busy day for the ice companies and their employes along the central and upper Hudson, the tonnage of ice cut and housed having been large. From reports received this afternoon from 36 points there seems to be no doubt but that a full harvest of very fair ice will be gathered between Rhinebeck and Albany before Saturday.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 19.--An electrical street railway is projected for Elizabeth and will run through the western and northwestern parts of the city. An application for a franchise will be made at the next meeting of the City Council.

ST. HYACINTHE, Quebec, Feb. 19.--A collision occurred on the Grand Trunk Railway last night two miles from St. Hyacinthe Station, between the Point Levi express train due here at 6:50 o'clock and a local train from Montreal.
HARTFORD, Feb. 19.--The cross-examination of Col. Stevenson of the Housatonic Road was resumed before the Railroad Committee this afternoon.

Fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the house of James H. Pitteuger at 734 Park-place, near Kingston-avenue, Brooklyn. The building contained a quantity of costly furniture and a number of valuable oil paintings.

By the will of Mrs. Amelia Kerr, widow of Henry A. Kerr, filed for probate yesterday, many charities and institutions will receive substantial bequests. The will was executed April 4, 1884, and has two codicils executed in 1885 and l887. Walter Carter of this city and George H. Danforth of Madison, N.Y., are made Executors.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 19.--A.P. Wright Son bought in Chicago to-day for Buffalo millers 600,000 bushels of No. 1 Northern hard wheat at a price 5 cents above Chicago May. This is said to be the largest cash transaction in grain on record, involving about $700,000.
For several days past the resolution-makers of Tammany Hall have been hard at work. The result of their labors was shown at the meeting of the Committee on Organization last night.

A petition is being circulated in Sing Sing in favor of the Assembly Bill No. 240 which provides for the location of a new State prison and for the removal of the prison at present in Sing Sing. It is said, however, that the merchants of Sing Sing are not as much in favor of the removal as those persons who merely reside there while having business interests elsewhere.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 19.--There is no trustworthy news to-day about the personnel of the Cabinet. Gen. Harrison keeps himself more and more to himself, and nobody gets anything from him.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19.--A big pile of ties was planed on the Louisville and Nashville Road near Walton, Ky., on Friday night to wreck the Cannon Ball train, due here that night, but the train was going at such a high rate of speed that the shock broke the tie which was to lock the pile together and the train passed in safety.

The Commissioners of Charities-and Correction have directed Warden Dunphy of Hart's Island to provide means in future to have separate graves for the Roman Catholic dead in order that they may be buried in consecrated ground. Heretofore one common grave was used for all.

The Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange transacted some important business at yesterday's meetings. Of special interest to taxpayers and investors was the report of the special committee appointed to examine and report upon the Larmon Personal Tax bill ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The President and Mrs. Cleveland were entertained at dinner tonight by Secretary and Mrs. Vilas. The centre piece was an ellipses of asparagus vine studded with long-stemmed Puritan roses.

Hawkins, Tenth Infantry, to be Lieutenant-Colonel Twentythird Infantry; Capt. Edward W. Whittemore, Fiftenth Infantry, to be Major Tenth Infantry; Alfred Hedberg, late Captain Fifteenth Infantry, to be Captain Fifteenth Infantry, (act of Congress approved April 16, 1888.)

READING, Penn., Feb. 19.--It was learned here this afternoon that an intimation was recently made to the members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers in the employ of the Reading Railroad Company that it was desired by the company that they should either quit the brotherhood or the company.

PETERSBURG, Va., Feb. 19.--Gov. Fitzhugh Lee and Mayor Ellyson of Richmond addressed the business men of Petersburg under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce to-night in advocacy of the payment of State taxes in money instead of coupons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The Republican Senators have at last decided what to do with the Chandler and various other resolutions concerning so-called "election outrages" in the South.

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 19, via Galveston.--M. Fernandez, the Mexican Minister to France, is expected to arrive here to-day. His successor will be named shortly.

Yesterday's stock market stood still. There was interest in nothing except speculations as to what was possible or probable as an outcome of the chicago meeting of Western railway Presidents. Brokers matched quarters on othe Stock Exchange in lieu of the excitement of trading in stocks.
On the fifth day of the trial of Thomas B. Kerr, yesterday, 44 talesmen were examined as to their fitness to serve on the jury, but none were accepted.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 20.--Ex-Judge Luzern B. Morris, Referee for the Superior Court, to-day heard the evidence in the suit of Rutherford Trowbridge for a divorce from his wife. Alice Anderson Trowbridge.

Judging from recent developments the Giants are to be homeless. When the fence of the Polo Grounds was taken down, many supposed that the scheme was a political "strike," and in consequence but little attention was paid to the move.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 20.--City Engineer Caldwell will to-morrow survey and lay out a half-mile course on Muchattoes Lake for the skating races of the National Association on Friday.

LONDON, Feb. 20.--Mr. Gladstone arrived in London to-day. He was welcomed by a great throng of people, and a delegation from the Italian colony presented him with an address. In replying to the address, Mr. Gladstone said that he had "left beautiful Italy in body but not in spirit."
A Broadway bric-a-brac dealer yesterday opened an exhibition and began the private sale of rare and historical jewels and antiques, part of the estate of a collector.

LONDON, Feb. 20.--The race for the Sandown Grand Prize (a handicap hurdle race) was run at Sandown Park to-day and was won by Mr. C. Hibbert's 5-year-old b.c. Castilian by three-quarters of a length. Mr. C.H. Jolliffe's 5-year-old Scottish Minstrel was second, and Lord Dudley's aged Kilworth third. The last betting was 5 to 2 against Castilian, 7 to 1 against Scottish Minstrel, and 10 to 1 against Kilwerth. There were 11 starters.

LONDON, Feb. 20.--Much anxiety is felt at Algiers regarding the safety of Mr. Starr, agent for P.T. Barnum. Mr. Starr left Tangier alone some time ago for the purpose of scouring the desert, which swarms with dangerous fanatics. He is now a week overdue. Mr. Barnum has given instructions to send out a search party immediately.

The earnings of the Southern Pacific Railroad for 1888 were $48,850,000; expenditures, including interest on bonds, $44,901,000, leaving a surplus of $3,949,000, from which amount deducting the guaranteed rental of the Central Pacific of $1,360,000, leaves a balance of $2,589,000, or about 2 per cent, interest on the outstanding stock of $100,000,000. The balance of profit in 1887 was $1,367,000.

HAVANA, Feb. 20.--The fourteenth game in the Steinitz-Tschigorin chess contest, which was played today, was won by Steinitz. It began with the Zukertort opening, and lasted three hours and twenty minutes. Thirty-five moves were made.

At an early hour Tuesday morning a man was found arranging faggots and saturating them with oil on the second flour of the Dobtandecker Block at Erie, Penn. The alarm was given and the incendiary fled. There are no funds available for such work, and it will not be ordered until the Deficiency bill becomes a law.

NEWBURG, Feb. 20.--Judge Bartlett this morning granted a bill of separation to Mary E. Pountney from her husband, William Pountney. The defendant is a wealthy manufacturer at Port Jervis, and they have three grown-up children. The ground for separation was cruelty.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 20.--The Advisory Committee of the American Shooting Association completed their code of american rules for trap shooting at live birds and inanimate targets yesterday, and most of them returned to thier homes. The report will be presented to the Directors of the association in New-York early next week.

A dispatch from Hugh A. Dinsmore, American Consul General at Seoul, the capital of Corea, says: "A terrible famine prevails in the southern portion of Corea. People are reduced to the last extemity and many are starving. The need of assistance is urgent and relief funds should be cabled." Mrs. Dinsmore will promptly devote to the relief of the sufferers any funds which may be forwarded her.

At a meeting of the Board of Trustees of the New-Amsterdam Eye and Ear Hospital the executive surgeon reported that the number of new patients had increased to 558 and 1,926 visits had been made by them to the dispensary. The big Democratic social clubs are in rivalry respecting the celebration of Washington's Birthday. The New-Amsterdam Club having decided to have a reception to-night, the Tammany Hall Sagamore Club decided to have one likewise. Then the Harlem Democratic Club, from which the Sagamore is an offshoot, determined to have a smoking concert. So the Democratic politicians will have a busy time moving from one clubhouse to another.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 21.--C. Leon Trueman was killed this morning by falling with an elevator in W.E. Jones's printing office. He got on with a form of type, the rope broke, and the elevator car fell about 75 feet crushing Trueman's skull. He was a brother of W. Cabell Trueman, editor and owner of the Critic newspaper.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21.--The anthracite coal companies have practically determined to further restrict their output by shutting down two days each week. The Reading and the other coal companies have agreed to join the movement.

The Centennial Celebration Sub-Committee on States, of which Col. William G. Hamilton is Chairman, has arranged that the United States steamer Dolphin shall be the official boat in the reception of President Harrison on Monday, April 29.

The Hudson River off Sing Sing and Tarrytown yesterday presented a very animated appearance. There were large stretches of smooth ice upon which, off the former place, a number of iceboats were scudding before a brisk wind.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 21.--The Rev. James Gibson, a prominent Baptist minister of York County, was drowned yesterday while returning to his home from a pastoral visit to one of his charges in the country. Ahont 8 o'clock in the morning, when he arrived at the bank of sugar Creek, he found the stream very much swollen and the bridge washed away.

The funeral of Mrs. Margaret Kemp, who died on Tuesday at the ripe age of 96 years, will be held at her home, 51 West Forty-seventh-street, to-morrow afternoon. Friends are invited to attend before 1 o'clock.

One hundred Roman Catholic priests and laymen with well-filled wallets and ruddy cheeks started from Hoboken yesterday on a new crusade to the Holy Land. Brochy, won over the eight mile course in 17:30. The Blizzard, Capt. Newbold, was second in 21:30, and the snowball, Capt. Rogers, was third in 31:00.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 22.--While leveling the ground to build a sea wall at East River, a little village on the shore 20 miles east of NewHaven, Emory Morse of Wallingford unearthed the crumbling skeleton of an Indian which he believes is that of the famous sachem whose fate in battle gave name to the pretty shore retreat, Sachem's Head.

The dog show in Madison-Square Garden came to an end last night, after its most successful day, in point of patronage. Throngs of visitors poured in and out of the Garden, until the box office and turnstile men were anxious to lie down and sleep.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 22.--Mrs. Nellie Goodwill, a widow whose age is progressing into the thirties, has begun suit in the Circuit Court against Maxwell M. Fisher for $50,000, charging breach of promise of marriage. Fisher, who is an aged millionaire, has been boarding with Mrs. Goodwill since his separation from his wife last Summer. Fisher says he may have had matrimonial aspirations, but Mrs. Goodwill is not concerned therein, never was, and never will be.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 22.--Tunnel No. 17 on the Cincinnati Southern Road, near Sunburnt, Tenn., is on fire, and in a property sense it is the greatest catastrophe any railroad ever suffered. The officers of the road place the loss at from $450,000 to $600,000.

NEW-HAVEN Feb. 22.--President Snipe of the Yale Boat Club, after consultation with an attorney, has concluded that the tank used by the Yale crew is not an infringement on the patent of George W. Briggs of Chicago as claimed by him.

Charles Teitent, 19 years of age, who lived in Third-avenue, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth streets, was struck yesterday afternoon by a train while walking on the track, near Woodlawn station, and instantly killed. James Welles of 303 East Seventieth-street, who was with him, escaped death, but his injuries are very severe. He was taken to the Manhattan Hospital.

A very pretty and enjoyable concert was given last evening in the Berkeley Lyceum, 21 West Forty-fourth-street, by the Brown University Glee and Banjo Clubs. Fully 400 persons enjoyed the music and nearly every number was heartily encored.

There was an annoying if not destructive accident on the Sixth-avenue branch of the elevated railroad early last evening. A five-car train, drawn by Engine No. 217, was within its own length of the west station at Park-place when the engineer was forced to come to a full stop, leaving the train stretched around the curve into Murry-street.

The Federal Club gave a reception last evening to the veterans of 1840, known as the old Tippecanoe Club, in celebration of their presenting to the club the banners carried by them in the campaigns of 1840 and 1888.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Feb. 22.--The lot of the Oklahoma boomers is not a happy one. During the last 10 days all the boomers who were ejected some time ago have gone back into the forbidden Territory and have been joined by numerous others attracted thither by the recent discovery of ore, supposed to be largely gold-bearing.

The House of Rest for Consumptives at Tremon, has issued its nineteenth annual report, which shows that 162 patients were treated during the year. Of these only two paid for their support. Two were discharged cured and 21 improved in health. As usual, the death rate was high, 57 having died at the house.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 22.--To-day the Genesee Valley Club house was formally opened. TOYAH, Texas, Feb. 22.--The general merchandise store of W.F. Youngblood was robbed of $2,000 by two masked men last night. Three customers and two clerks were in the store.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 22.--The wrestling match at the Howard Athenaeum to-day between Duncan C. Ross and J.C. Daly, mixed styles, for $250 a side, was won by Ross. Five bouts were necessary, Ross having won two falls in catch as catch can, and Daly throwing Ross twice in collar and elbow. The fifth bout, side hold with harness, was won by Ross, to whom the stakes and the match were awarded.

Kate Burke, 27 years old, of 251 East One Hundred and Twentieth-street, who is accused by her husband with taking laudanum with suicidal intent on Wednesday, was arraigned before Justice Murray at the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning. The woman said that she only took a small quantity of the poison in order to frighten her husband, who had quarreled with her. She was discharged with a reprimand.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 22.--Gabriel Dumont is at Gretna, on the boundary line, and has sent word to his little and band of sympathizers here that he intends visiting Winnipeg in a few days. Dumont was Riel's Lieutenant in the Northwest rebellion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--President Cleveland signed the bill for the admission of the States of North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, and Washington at 11 o'clock this morning, and immediately sent word to Mr. Springer by letter.
As a holiday Washington's Birthday was in this city a comfortable sort of success, without anything startling or extraordinary to mark it.

Many friends of the Young Men's Institute of America, No. 100, enjoyed its first annual entertainment in Chickering Hall last evening and wondered at the rapid strides forward that the organization had taken since its formation.
Mrs. Julia L. Dudley, the wife of Oscar A. Dudley, a druggist, committed suicide yesterday at her home 2,134 Seventh-avenue, by shooting herself in the head.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22.--The statement that the Reading Railroad Company will use the Baltimore and Ohio station at Chestnut and Twentyfourth streets, in Philadelphia, for its passenger trains in two or three weeks is admitted to be correct.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22.--The Cornell Freshmen had a high time at the Ithaca Hotel last evening. For a week the hotel has been practically owned by the Freshmen, and their preparations were elaborate and careful.

The dinner of the Southern Society at the Brunswick Hotel last night was an ovation to the South by Northern men of Southern birth and affiliations. It was a great outburst of love for Dixie.

The reception given by the New-Amsterdam Club last night in celebration of Washington's Birthday was one of the biggest and jolliest of the festivals evergiven by that County Democracy organization.

Henry Cordes and his wife Emma, Indian half-breeds living at 192 Bleecker-street, became involved in a domestic quarrel about 12 night. During the quarrel the woman struck her husband on the head with an earthen platter fracturing his skull. She was arrested and locked up in the Mercer-Street Police Station. They were consignments of William Corbett, S.J. Rose, Count Valusin. Hancosk Johnson, and C.A. Durfee. The sale is to take place in New-York on March 7 and 8. The shipment numbers about 90 colts and fillies.

Joseph Tutio, an Italian laborer living at 65 Mulberry-street, while in the yard of his home yesterday was accosted by a stranger who wanted him to purchase a revolver which he exhibited. While Tutio was looking at the pistol, which was in the hands of the stranger, it was discharged and the bullet from the weapen lodged in Tutio's shoulder, inflicting a severe wound. He was taken to the Chambersstreet Hospital. The stranger ran away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24.--The centennial ceremonies of Georgetown, just closed, draw attention to the preparations that have begun for the observance of the centenary of the Catholic hierarchy in the United States. That event will occur in November, but the programme has already been considered and covers ceremonies which will open in Baltimore and end in this city, extending over a period of four days.

NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 24.--At a meeting of the First Baptist Church this evening it was voted unanimously to extend a call to the Rev. O.J. White of Jersey City, N.J., to become Pastor. A society meeting will be held Tuesday evening to indorse the action of the church to-night.

Thomas Schultz, an old toy manufacturer of East New-York, who was arrested saturday on suspicion of being concerned in his wife's death, was released yesterday.

The committee of five, to whom the Liederkranz Society referred its charges against the police, held a meeting yesterday afternoon and considered the half-dozen written complaints ...

TULARE, Cal., Feb. 24.--On the receipt of intelligence last night of a train robbery at Pixley, a special car was at once ordered to carry officers to the scene of the robbery, and in a short time about 10 officers were on the ground where the tragedy had taken place.

The Lower Bay yesterday was dotted with floating ice. Navigation was somewhat impeded, and the Staten Island ferryboats experienced much difficulty in entering their slips. The boats, at times, were compelled to go at half speed. Some of the wheel buckets were broken by the pounding of the ice.

The 10,000 persons who attended the concert at the German Hospital Fair last night gave every manifestation of pleasure. Sieboldt's orchestra played the "Rienzi" overture, the andante from Beethoven's C minor symphony, and, among other compositions, a festival march dedicated to the fair by Fred Brandels.

That the interest in amateur photography is increasing is shown by the number of new societies being formed all over the country. Every week word is received of the formation of clubs, and nearly all the old ones report constant additions in membership. The grade of work increases in like ratio. There is every prospect that there will be more pictures taken this Summer than ever before.

"Bobbing" for eels is the favorite Winter pastime of Mr. Jules Carker, who lives between Ridgefield and Fair View, N.J., and breaks the ice that has formed on the streams of the brackish water courses that have their source in the Hackensack River and flow sluggishly across the low-lying salt meadows.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24.--Representative Springer of Illinois, to whose persistent efforts is partly due the final passage of the bill admitting North and South Dakota, Washington, and Montana into the Union, expects to see NewMexico also enabled to become a State before the close of the session.
Minister Preston of Hayti yesterday expressed his opinion in a very forcible manner concerning the firm of Jimenes, Haustedt Co. of 5 South William-street.
Mr. Henry George appeared before the Manhattan Single-Tax Club, at their rooms, 8 St. Mark's-place, last evening and faced an audience of not less than 200 persons.

The return in the inquest held to ascertain the cause of death of Lilla A. Hoyle of Webster has been made by Judge Jillson. It is as follows: "She came to her death as the result of the uulawful act of some person other than herself."

CHICAGO, Feb. 24.--Jacob Schaefer, the billlardist, said to-day that he will not cover the forfeit which George Slosson has posted in the office of the Spirit of the Times. Schaefer complains that be is not willing to reduce his chances of winning by playing a short game.
LONDON, Feb. 24.--The Cunard Line Steamship Aurania, Capt. Hains, from Liverpool, sid. from Queenstown for New-York to-day.

Guy Williams, an 8-year-old boy, died at his home on Lemon-street, Newark, a day or two ago, as the result of a peculiar accident. While at school he broke the frame of his slate and held a fragment of the wood in his mouth while he tried to repair the damage.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 24.--The removal of Dr. Thomas Aby, Quarantine Officer at the mouth of the Mississippi, by Gov. Nichols, has caused a vast amount of trouble and bad feeling in New-Orleans.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24.--The first section of a freight train on the Pennsylvania Railroad had stopped at the east end of the Raritan River bridge tn this city, at 2 o'clock this morning. when the second section ran into it.

If old Jack Frost had perched his regal personality on the pinnacle of the Central Park obelisk yesterday and east his eyes over the beautiful public domain he must have been satisfied that he is not such a universally-despised individual as cold-weather dyspeptics would make out.

Herrmann the prestidigitateur writes to THE TIMES that he will, at the close of his present season, be glad to meet the B.M. Lawrence who is such a stanch adherent of Spiritualism and duplicate on the spot, by mundane means, any "manifestation" or "phenomenon" that any medium can produce.
A middle-aged, handsome man, well dressed, was found lying in a hallway at 34 Kent-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday morning, with his skull fractured.

PARIS, Feb. 24.--Late last night the workingmen's delegates issued a manifesto calling upon workingmen to refrain from attempting to hold a demonstration to-day, and thus avoid a massacre.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24.--One action taken by the Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias at its recent session here is likely to lead to a lively cut in rates among secret societies, and perhaps to a subsequent rate war.

The annual Washington's Birthday reception at the Asylum of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, Eleventh-avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-first-street, yesterday, called out the usual throng of enthusiastic visitors.
TRENTON, Feb. 24.--It is likely that there will be a warm discussion in the Senats's exec utive session over the confirmation of E.O. Chapman as State School Superintendent.

R. Blankenburg Co.'s safe was taken out early in the morning. Its contents, which were in first-rate condition, included the ledgers, purchase books, and stock books, the most important books in enabling a statement to be made with the insurance companies. This safe was one of Herring's patent.--Philadelphia Public Ledger.
New-York Yacht Club members were last evening discussing a cablegram about the sale of the Scotch cutter Thistle and the announcement that she was to be sent abroad.

Edward W. Woodruff, held in Newark in connection with the Ives and Stayner indictments, will come to New-York to-day and surrender himself for trial. He declined to say anything yesterday except that he wished to spend Washington's Brithday and Sunday near his friends and would now come to New-York.

The Federate Council of the different Protestant Episcopal dioceses of New-York, which holds an important session to-morrow in this city, was established in 1872 to provide for joint action with reference to legislation for the incorporation of churches.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 24.--The promising 5 year old stallion Abdallah Prince died last week of colic at the stables of Mr. Gilbert Green, his owner, near this city. Abdallah Prince was by Bachman's Kentuckly Prince, and was, therefore, half brother to Guy, 2:12 ; Spofford, 2:18. and other speedy horses. His dam was by Virgo's Hambletonian, another famous sire. Mr. Green had recently refused an offer of $4,000 for his horse.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 24.--Public sentiment has lately changed a great deal in favor of the Bald Knobbers who were to have been hanged at Ozark last Friday, but who were respited 60 days with the prospect of receiving a commutation of their sentence to life imprisonment.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 24.--Ernest L. Inman, late manager of the Inman Line of ocean steamers, was in the city to-day. He represents a wealthy British syndicate which has recently purchased the Santa Catalina property, a tract of 200,000 acres in the State of Durango, Mexico.
ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 24.--Finn Brothers of Grayling, Mich., working on prospects north of the Michigan Mine, yesterday struck gold 10 feet from the surface.

Some members of the Jersey City Financial Union are preparing to begin proceedings against the heads of the order at Paterson. They charge that they have unlawfully used the reserve funds of the union. An injunction restraining the chief officers from disposing of $14,000 now on deposit in one of the national banks in Paterson has already been secured.

The bark Petunia, Capt. Nichols, which arrived yesterday from Aracaju with a cargo of sugar, reported that she had been in collision with the Edward Cooper, Pilot Boat No. 20, off Barnegat, on the morning of the 23d.
A complimentary dinner was given to Vice-President-elect Levi P. Morton last evening by Mr. John F. Plummer, at his residence, 24 East Fifty-sixth-street.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Feb. 25.--At Winfield, Henry County, this State, yesterday morning, the dwelling of Thomas Innis was destroyed and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Torbitt, 60 years old, and Innis's 11-year-old daughter were burned to death.

LONDON, Feb. 25.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Sexton gave notice that he would introduce a bill to amend the law relating to contempt of court. This announcement was received with cheers.

The city officials of Brooklyn met at the City Hall yesterday to take some action in regard to the death of Controller Livingston. Mayor Chapin presided, and Corporation Counsel Jenks was made Secretary.

The Young Men's Democratic Club decided at the Hoffman House last night to recommend the passage by the Legislature of the Saxton Ballot Reform bill if it is amended as proposed by a committee of the club.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 25.--Twenty-five citizens of this place have just embraced Mormonism from Elder Smith. They will leave here Monday next to join a large party at Chattanooga and take the emigrant train for the West. Smith has worked among the poorer classes for over a year and has met with much success. .

HAVANA, Feb. 25.--In the Steinitz-Tschlgorin chess contest Steinitz won the sixteeth-game. It was begun with the Zukertort gambit and lasted six hours. The seventeenth game, which was begun with the Evans gambit and lasted four hours, resulted in a draw. It was agreed that the match be considered as ended, with Steinitz as winner.
With bright eyes, renewed vigor, and a nimbler tongue than he had before he went to Saratoga on Saturday, Mayor Grant took his seat yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control.

BOSTON, Feb. 25.--Joseph Bent, a life convict in the State prison, who has already served 25 years for the killing of a fellow-sailor on an American whaling vessel in 1864, was discharged to-day, his pardon having been granted by President Cleveland. Bent, whose real name is Joseph Bento, is a Portuguese, 79 years old, and left this afternoon for New-Bedford where he expects to find some of his countrymen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 25.--After several days of delays and waiting for either wind, boats, or ice, the great ice yacht race for the Ice Yacht Challenge Pennant of America came off shortly after noon to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 25.--Ruth, daughter of the Rev. George Herbert Patterson of South Portsmouth, died last night after suffering from unmistakable symptoms of hydrophobia. The child was bitten by a dog last September.

It is officially announced that through train service between Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, and this city over the lines of the Baltimore and Ohio and Reading Roads will be inaugurated on March 10.

Victor Hugo's romantic drama, "Ruy Blas," was performed at Palmer's Theatre last evening to the gratification of a large and attentive audience. Coquelin was in the cast at Don Cesar de Bazan, the reckless nobleman who has lost everything but his honor.

Steen of 241 East Seventy-ninthstreet has issued an invitation to Prof. Herrmann to make good his offer to duplicate at sight any manifestation, or so-called spirit phenomenon, that will be produced in his presence. Steen says he agrees to forfeit $500 if Herrmann will reproduce or explain three tests by himself or Mrs. Steen.

The will of Eugene Copley of Antwerp, Jefferson County, N.Y., bequeaths all of his estate, amounting to $100,000, excepting $10,000, which is reserved for his mother, to Ives Seminary, a Methodist Institution at Antwerp, on condition that the name of the seminary be changed to Copley Seminary. MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 27.--An interesting incident of the commemoration of Washington's Birthday in this quarter was the founding at Port Jervis by about 50 prominent gentlemen assembled there of the Minisink Valley Historical Society.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27.--Four of the Yale literary editors were elected to-day: Crosby, Sage, Cotton, and Hurd. There is a contest between Opdyke and Beckford for the fifth place, which will be decided to-morrow.
A dispatch from Philadelphia yesterday quoted Peter A.B. Widener, the horse and cable railroad magnate as follows:
LONDON, Feb. 27.--An immense crowd was present in the court room this morning when the session of the Parnell Commission opened. Much excitement was manifested. Mr. Parnell arrived at an early hour.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27.--Senator Baker of Cumberland County is the first Democrat to represent that county in the Senate for many years. The county is generally republican by 1,200 majority. This county is also strongly prohibitionist.
The third annual orchid exhibition was opened at the Eden Musce yesterday, and was well attended despite the extreme inclemency of the weather.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Feb. 27.--Clafford Carroll of this city, last year of the International League Club of Buffalo, and for a number of years of the teams of Providence and Washington, was married this evening to Miss Addie Wood, a handsome Quaker maiden of this city. Carroll has bought a fine farm with his savings and has retired from the world of sports.

A Washington dispatch printed in yesterday's TIMES telling of Secretary Fairchild's action in the matter of frauds practiced in this city in the appraisement of Sumatra tobacco caused considerable talk among the trade yesterday.

With the exception of the loan exhibition of paintings, statuary, and fine tapestries, all there was of the great fair in aid of the German Hospital at the American Institute Building was brought to a close last night.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 27.--Another Italian murder, atrocious in all its details, has followed, if not resulted, from the mysterious murder of Vincenzo Ottumva some weeks ago.

A committee representing the several associations of steam engineers of this city called on Mayor Grant yesterday and laid before him a matter of interest to the public, and of special moment to themselves.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27.--Charles G. Simmerman, proprietor of the Gerard House, Atlantic City, was attending the Grand Council of Red Men, in session in this city for the last two days, and while in a bathroom of the Trenton House this morning was stricken with paralysis, dying in a few hours.

Miss Louise Aymar and Mr. Charles Alfred Christian were married yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's mother, Mrs. E.F.R. Aymar, in East Orange, N.J., by the Right Rev. M.A. D'W. Howe, Bishop of Central Pennsylvania, a cousin of the groom.
YORK, Penn., Feb. 27.--The York Gazette publishes to-day the following letter from Speaker Carlisle to Chauncey F. Black, President of the Democratic Society of Pennsylvania:

The four-storied brick residence at 109 West Eleventh-street, until a few weeks ago a quiet and intensely-respectable lodging house, has taken to itself a new distinction as uncanny as a Potter's Field or a Gallows Hill.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 27.--The Elizabeth Dramatic Club, composed of the leading society amateurs, including members of Gov. Green's family, gave a delightful performance this evening to a fashionable audience at the Temple Opera House.
The members of the Federate Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church began assembling, with benign expressions on their faces, at the See House early yesterday morning.

DETROIT, Feb. 27.--The Michigan Steel company is erecting in this city a plant to make steel according to the process invented by Gustave L. Robert of Sterray, France, about a year ago, and improved by J.W. Bookwalter, of Springfield, Ohio.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 27.--In the House today Dr. Weldon explained the provisions of his Extradition bill, which enlarges the list of extraditable offenses.
The prettiest bunch of double figures thus far secured in the continuous pool tournament at Hardman Hall was put together last night by J. Louis Malone in his game with Joseph T. King.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The Senate is getting industrious as the close of the session approaches, and more legislation has been accomplished in the last two days than in a fortnight during midwinter.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Feb. 27.--Two duck hunters--George O'Neil and Henry Partridge-- who have just returned from a season of shooting at Montank Point, L.I., report the novel methods of duck hunting resorted to by a Massachusetts sportsman named Chadwick, who has ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--Senator Stewart, Chairman of the Committee on Mines and Mining, to-day made a report on the resolution authorizing the committee to investigate the subject of the investment of foreign capital in mines in the Territories.

Fireman McGrade of Engine No. 1 was dismissed from the department by the Fire Commissiners yesterday for misconduct while on duty. Building Inspector Michael McEvoy, charged with drankenness and absence without leave, was suspended. Minor offenses in several cases were punished by small fines.

At a meeting held in Canandaigua, N. Y., yesterday preliminary steps were taken for the formation of a New-York State Baseball League. The cities to be represented in the league are Canandaigua, Albany, Troy, Utica, Binghamton, Elmira, Auburn, Batavia, Seneca Falls, and Waterloo.
The annual banquet of the New-York Press Club was celebrated at Delmonico's last night, and the large dining hall was filled with representative newspaper men and their friends.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 27.--The annual report of the Massachusetts Railway Commissioners was submitted to the Legislature this afternoon. It maintains the position of the board in its advocacy of the heating of cars by steam and ...
Many members of the Harlem Democratic Club met in their clubhouse last night and discussed a number of proposed amendments to ...

A motion, made by Louisa Myers, through her guardian, John W. Thomson, for the removal of John R. Rutherford, R. Baring Gould, and J. Champney Morris, Executors and Trustees of the estate of Alfred G. Myers, will be argued this morning before Sarrogate Ransom.

Another step in unearthing fraud in the Brooklyn County Clerk's office was taken yesterday when County Auditor Lake continued his investigation of the bill presented by exCounty Clerk John M. Ranken for $18,500 for copying old records.
Vice-President-elect Levi P. Morten and family took their departure for Washington yesterday morning.

A dispatch from Dallas, Texas, announces semiofficially that ex-Gov. Brown, President of the Texas and Pacific Railroad, is soon to retire at his own request, the reason being his desire to live in St. Louis or some other Northern or Eastern city in preference to living in Texas, especially through ...
HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 27.--Chairman William H. Andrews of the Republican State Committee rose to a question of privilege in the House of Representatives to-day.
"Le Geudre de M. Poirier" will be played at Palmer's to-night by M. Coquelin and Mr. Abbey's company of French actors.
The Senior Class of Columbia College will try to liquidate its boating debt to-night by a dramatic entertainment at the Berkeley Lyceum.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 27.--Patrick Egan has made public a number of the letters on which Richand Pigott founded his forgeries.

If the Pope should promulgate a dogma and subsequently explain to his venerable brethren that he had issued it under a misapprehension which he deeply regretted, the explanation might do him honor as a man, but it would be quite fatal to his pretensions as a Pope.

BRAMPTON, Ontario, Feb. 27.--As a Grand Trunk freight train was crossing the Canadian Pacific track to-day a freight train on the latter road dashed into it, cutting its way through and never stopping. Not a wheel on the Canadian Pacific train left the track.

The Glenmore Rod and Gun Club held its regular monthly match at C. Duerler's, Dexter Park, on the Jamaica plank road, yesterday afternoon. Three handsome prizes had been offered, besides the club badge, the Midas medal, for the winners in the three classes into ...

AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 27.--The Hon. Henry Lord, President of the Maine Senate, to-day received the following telegram from James G. Blaine in Washington: "I have this moment read Mr. Boutelle's letter suggesting that the Legislature ...
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 27.--Michael Kreuger about nine years ago married a Miss Somers of Medford, Long Island, and moved with her to Newmarket, near this city.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 27.--A bold robbery was committed this morning in this city. The saloon of William E. Chamberlain, on Cherrystreet, was broken into, a quantity of wines, liquors, and cigars stolen, and the safe was also blown open and its contents, nearly $300, abstracted.
The men who control the New-York Baseball Club are trying to convince the Aldermen that the Giants will forever relinguish all claim to the Polo Grounds when the playing season of 1889 is ended.
John Cowan of 453 Tenth-avenue was a "sympathizer" with the strikers in the recent horse-car strike.
It would be remarkable if, after having taken the lead in the use of dynamite projectiles, our country should also be the first to produce a thoroughly successful submarine torpedo boat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of the exports of merchandise from the United States during the seven and twelve months ended Jan. 31, 1889 ...

The Board of Education held a special meeting yesterday afternoon, and President Simmons explained that it had been called at the request of the Trustees of the Twenty-third Ward to consider the furnishing of Grammar School No. 85.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27.--The Committee of General Managers appointed to execute the agreement recently signed by the Presidents of the great railway lines continued work to-day.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 27.--There are still a large number of idle workmen in the Pittsburg iron and steel mills and numerous departments are not in operation, but, nevertheless, there has been a marked improvement in the past week.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 27.--The Dominion Government, as a result of the representations of the Canadan book publishers, has decided to introduce important amendments to the Copyright act next week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27.--Jacob Schaefer has been studying George Slesson's latest challenge, and has decided to make a compromise proposal. He now offers to play Slosson in two contests, the first to be of 1,800 points at the 14-inch ...
ST. PAUL, Feb. 27.--Senators Keller and Swenson are anti-trust men. Both of them presented measures to-day making it unlawful to form or organize any trust.

Henry W. Genot, who for 25 years has been familiarly known about town as "Prince Hal," has been for the last two years the victim of a very painful malady, which has completely mystified his physicians.
District Attorney Hamilton of Saratoga County came to the city yesterday to arrange for the trial of ex-Alderman Arthur McQuade.
Wall-street had a ragged stock market yesterday. A few quotations went up a little; a few went down a little; the bulk of the list stoon still and were lifeless.

Probably most intelligent Republicans would resent the statement that their party has become in many essential regards the reactionary party of the United States, the party corresponding more nearly to the Tories of England and the Bourbons of France.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 27.--It is expected that there will be an early solution of the powder problem, which has been a great grievance with the miners of the Lackawanna and Wyoming Valleys for some time.
ST. GEORGE, Ontario, Feb. 27.--The St. George express passing here east-bound at about 6 o'clock this evening went through a bridge just east of the station.

Artie B. Cleveland, President of the A.B. Cleveland Company, Limited, wholesale dealers in seeds at 47 Cortiandt-street, with branches at Cape Vincent, this State, and in England and Canada, has been missing for three weeks, and developments which have arisen since his departure indicate that his accounts must be in a very unsatisfactory condition.
LONDON, Feb. 28.--The steamship Chateau Leoville, (Br.,) Capt. Richardson, from New-York Jan. 24 for China and Japan ports, has arr. at Aden.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28.--Those members of the Sophomore Class of Rutgers College who are members of Delta Upsilon or are not fraternity men have combined and selected a second list of officers for the class, declaring that the election held by the other half of the class is illegal.

LONDON, Feb. 28.--In the event of the Times's counsel asking to be allowed to proceed with the Parnell inquiry, Sir Charles Russell will press the Judges to adjourn until an interim report on the letters has been presented to Parliament.

Charles Pichet Pin, or Chief Red Cow, as he was called on the programmes of the Wild West Show, arrived here from London yesterday on the British steamer Tower Hiil. He was one of three cabin passengers.

SOMERSET, Penn., Feb. 28.--The most terrible tragedy in the annals of Somerset County occurred last evening about two miles north of Jennertown. Herman Umberger, the wealthiest man of Jenner Township, was seated in his comfortable farmhouse in the same room with his wife, a hired girl, and the latter's child, ...

LONDON, Feb. 28.--Mr. Sexton gave notice in the House of Commons this afternoon that he would make a motion to compel Major Saunderson (Conservative) to disclose the names of the officers pledging to associate themselves with Major Saunderson and violate their oaths of obedience to the Crown in the event of a Home Rule Parliament being granted Ireland.
Since the posting of the regular nominations for offices and Governors of the New-York Athletic Club a good deal of talk has been caused.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 28.--In the town of Tusten, Sullivan County, yesterday afternoon, Nicholas Donahue's house took fire, he being absent and his wife and two little children being at home.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 28.--Judge McCormick of the Union County Court of Common Pleas to-day signed an order committing to the Morris Plains Insane Asylum George J. Ryan, a well-known real estate broker of this city, who has lost his reason. His relatives had his mental condition tested by Drs. Green and Pettit, who pronounced the broker incapable of longer managing his affairs. His brother and sister will now take charge of his property.

LONDON, Feb. 28.--The report of Sir Julian Pauncefote's appointment as British Minsiter to the United states is semi-officially confirmed. The Press Association says it has authority to announce the fact and gives a sketch of the new Minister's career.
Mayor Grant has been wandering about town and has made a discovery which he communicated to Public Works Commissioner Smith yesterday.
The Assembly Committee on Charitable Institutions made a favorable report yesterday upon the Batchelier bill providing for the transfer of all insane persons to the care of State institutions.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 28.--The Chattanooga Land, Coal, Iron and Railway Company, owning 25,000 acres of land on the north and west side of the river, opposite the city, embracing valuable coal deposits on Walden's Ridge, large iron ores, mines, and immense timber lands, have sold controlling interests to the Boston, New-York, and Philadelphia syndicate.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 28.--Valentine Winters, Jr., and Miss Helen Clegg, members of wealthy families, were married this evening in the Episcopal Church. The wedding presents in silver, gold, and checks aggregated $100,000. John H. Winters, the father of the groom, presented his two danghters with $50,000 each.
The Columbia Seniors gave an entertainment last evening in the Berkeley Lyceum Theatre which was financially of sufficient success to wipe out the unpaid balance of their Freshman crew debt.

The Treasury Department's statement of foreign commerce and immigration for January, 1889, shows that the value of exported merchandise during that month was $73,470,525, of imported merchandise, $63,348,351. Of gold, $1,197,080 was exported; the imports were $649,006. The exports of silver amounted to $3,003,471; the imports, $1,560,413. The number of immigrants arriving during the month was 10,272, of whom 8,079 came to the port of New-York.

Many brewers is this city made a pilgrimage to Newark yesterday to see what was offered to them in the way of a new beer barrel, which would not splinter, would last twice as long as the ones now used, would not cost much store, and could not be used as kindling wood.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 28.--During the past week there were a number of North Dakota men seen as then were on their way to Washington, and from their remarks it would seem that the politicians at least had figured upon a State ticket, the location of the capital, and various other matters pertaining to Statehood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--Judge James of the District Court to-day refused to quash the subpoena to compel Col. W.W. Dudley to appear and give testimony for the defense in his libel suit against the New-York Evening Post. The hearing of the case was begun before Examiner Hacket. Under the advice of his counsel Col. Dudley declined to answer all the questions that were put to him with reference to the "blocks of five" letter.

Five hundred tickets for the centennial ball April 30 are to be purchased by the Army Committee, of which Col. Cruger is Chairman, for distribution to officers of visiting military organizations as a part of the entertainment proposed to be extended to the stranger guests of New-York on that occasion.
The two rumors which THE TIMES yesterday contained concerning the appointment of the successor of Lord SACKVILLE concurred in suggesting that it was a Canadian who was to be chosen.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The Iowa railroads are in a quandary as to what to do to equalize rates from points in Iowa.

Within the past week the teachers in charge of the industrial schools of the Children's Aid Society have reported many cases of suffering and destitution among the families whose children attend their schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--Mrs. Cleveland gave a pink luncheon to-day at 1 o'clock in honor of Mrs. McElroy, the sister of the late President Arthur. The centre piece on the table was a circle of pink tulips in a bed of asparagus vine, about the base of which a scarf of soft pink silk was arranged in loose, graceful lines.
Frederick W. Wilcox, a New-York commission merchant, was lodged in the Hudson County Jail, in Jersey City, yesterday, for contempt of court. He had lived with his wife and child in Brooklyn.
With a big mirror at their backs the distinguished guests of the Phillips Exeter Alumni sat in the big white dining room of the Hoffman House last night and brought back their academic days.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28.--Two firemen received injuries that will probably prove fatal in a fire in the wholesale millinery establishment of J.E. Jenner, at 380 Broadway, this evening, and 10 more were seriously injured.

The residence of Julius Levine, 28 East Seventy-second-street, was entered and robbed by sneak thieves on the evening of Feb. 5. The thieves effected an entrance by forcing open the iron gate of the basement while the family were at dinner, and ascended to the rooms on the second floor, which they ransacked.

The announcement yesterday from the seat of war was that Mr. HARRISON had declared that he world "give nothing to NewYork" until the leaders in this State could agree what they want and who shall have it.

An effort is being made to introduce a new street-cleaning machine into this city. It is known as the "Hercules" and comes from across the water with testimonials from London, Paris, Berlin, and other large cities where it has been adopted.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 28.--Rumors of the proposed reduction in salaries of officials of the Manitoba Railroad caused some comment and considerable uneasiness among the company's employes to-dar. Traffic Manager Alexander thought that something must be done toward a reduction of expenses, and said:

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 28.--After a debate continuing through nearly the whole of the afternoon the Indiana House of Representatives today suspended John W. Linck, the Jefferson County Representative, who struck James H. Willard, the Democratic leader, when called a liar by Willard during a discussion yesterday.
The Stock Exchange kept open yesterday for some other reason than any interest attaching to its proceedings. Transactions were dull.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 28.--For two years or more three familiar figures have not been seen on the streets of St. Louis, and now comes a strange story about their mysterious disappearance.

The shortest way to dispose of Mr. PETER A.B. WIDENER and his superb project for a cable railway in Broadway capable of carrying "one million passengers a day" would be to set the Arcade Railway people at work upon the first section of their underground road.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--This has been another day of battle over New-York. It ends with the Platt forces on the run for home, defeated, and with no heart at present for the renewal of the conflict.
A.W. Bailey, a lawyer, and one of the oldest and most steadfast Democrats in Brooklyn, yesterday sent his resignation as a member of the First Ward Democratic Club to Alden S. Swan.

Judge Charles Daniels opened his court for the trial of Kerr, the alleged Aldermanic briber, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. It was the beginning of the tenth day and 8 of the 493 talesmen previously examined were in the jury box.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 28.--The centennial celebration of the introduction of Methodism into New-England will begin as the Annual Conferference to be held in Bridgeport in April. The Rev. Dr. George Lansing Taylor will preach the sermon and ex-Gov. Lounsbury will preside at a mass meeting to be addressed by laymen. Mass meetings will be held in June throughout the State.

A scene was enacted in the solemn precincts of the Corporation Counsel's office, yesterday that disturbed the equanimity and perturbed the spirits of the participants and the spectators in an unusual manner.
