The Commissioners of Accounts yesterday dismissed three of their clerks whom they thought incompetent. One of them, they found, had seemingly been employed to give him lucrative leisure to nurse a restaurant into ...

The cheerful work of piling up indictments on the heads of Henry S. Ives, Partner Stayner, and Edward Wilson Woodruff goes bravely on. Two more indictments were found yesterday by the Grand Jury, making six altogether. Should convictions follow on all of them Messrs. Ives and Stayner might each ...
The defense in the trial of James Nolan, accused of killing Annie Buch, was completed yesterday before Judge Cowing. The basis of the defense was insanity.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 28.--The weights in the Kentucky Handicap were announced to-day as follows: Terra Cotta, 122 pounds; Montrose, ...

PARIS, Feb. 28.--The suppression of the Patriotic League was decided upon at a council held at the Elysee Palace. Afterward Premier Tirard, M. Constans, Minister of the Interior, and M. Thevonet, Minister of Justice, had a conference with the Procureur-General and the Prefect of Police with the view of taking concerted action.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 28.--Anthony Laree, a Hollander, age 30, stabbed his young wife today, inflicing mortal wounds. He was married in Holland about six months ago to a young girl, who came with him to America.
ROME, Feb. 28.--Prime Minister Crispi has resiged. He was to have spoken in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, but after a Cabinet council he decided upon resigning in order to avoid the ...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 28.--Robert Watkins was discharged this morning at the conclusion of the preliminary examination.

"Le Gendre de M. Poirier," one of the wittiest, truest, and most popular of modern French comedies, was acted at Palmer's Theatre last evening before a thoroughly appreciative and very demonstrative assemblage.

LONDON, Feb. 28.--Wilson Barrett's new play "Nowadays" was produced at the Princess's this afternoon and is destined to be very popular. It deals entirely with race-track matters, the hero being accused of stealing Thunderbolt, the favorite horse, at long odds, for the Derby.

The Republican members are in so much of a hurry to go to Washington that the proceedings in both houses of the Legislature to-day were marked by listlessness, a natural reactionary consequence after yesterday's turbulence.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 28.--The weather was warm and cloudy to-day and there was a large attendance at the races. The track was in good condition. The winners were:
PITTSBURG, Feb. 28.--Contracts have been let for the construction of the connecting railway bridge across the Ohio River at Brunot's Island, below this city.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The Financial statement of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company for 1888 was filed with the Wisconsin Railroad Commissioners at Madison to-day.
Fifty-three bright, earnest-looking young men, forming the day close of plumbers at Col. R.T. Auchmuty's New-York Trade School, First-avenue and Sixty-seventh-street, graduated yesterday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28.--A fire at the Meyer rubber shops here this afternoon did considerable damage to the building and caused great excitement among the employes, many of the girls fainting in the smoke as they rushed from the building. The fire, which started in the varnish room, did not spread far.

The ball of the Purim Association is the yearly event which brings together all of the best Hebrew families of the city. The ball is unlike any other public affair of the kind, in that everybody who goes to it knows everbody else.

Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an injunction, pondente lite, restraining the New-York and New-England Railroad Company from erecting a shed over Pier (new) 36 (old 46) East River. The action was brought by the East Side Water-Front Protective Association.

The ship Annie M. Law of Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, arrived from Bordeaux, France, yesterday morning. On arriving at Quarantine she signaled that she was on fire in the hold but did not need assistance. She then cast anchor off Red Hook.
Thomas C. Platt is not going to Washington to see Benjamin Harrison inaugurated as President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--Several gentlemen representing the starch manufacturing industry throughout the country are here. This afternoon they began a private meeting which lasted until a late hour, and is to be resumed to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 28.--Plans have been completed for the establishment of a gigantic basic steel plant at Sheffield, Ala., which is to furnish the steel for a proposed shipyard at one of the Southern ports. Mr. Jacob Reese of this city is at the head of the scheme.

The West Point Foundry is rushing work along night and day on the steel shafts for the new cruisers Concord and Bennington. They will be finished by May 1 at the latest. Snuggled up among the hills at Cold Spring, opposite the Military Academy, the West Point Foundry since 1816 has belched forth smoke and flame as it converted iron into implements of war.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 28.--The Democratic State Central Committee met here to-night and fixed the date of holding a Democratic Convention to nominate three candidates for Judges of the Supreme Court on March 21. The election will be held April 2. It is not known whether the Union-Labor or Republican Party will make nominations.

The Senate, in executive session, yesterday confirmed the following nominations: Army.--William S. Rosecraus to be Brigadier-General, to be retired; W.F. Smith to be Major of the Engineer Corps, to be retired; First Cavalry, Servt. Henry A. Barber to be Second Lieutenant; Third Cavalry. First Sergt. Michael M. McNames to be Second ...

Incendiary fires are becoming frequent in New-Rochelle. On Wednesday night a hired man, taking charge of Dr. Noyes's handsome house on Cedar-avenue, found some waste and rubbish saturated with kerosene blazing against a corner of the house. He also saw two men running away. One of them carried a can in his hand. The house was only slightly damaged.
Prof. Kellar devoted himself at Dockstader's yesterday to mystifying and perplexing the actors and actresses who packed the little theatre in response to his invitation to a professional matinee.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 28.--The fact was made public this afternoon that John B. Laidley, known throughout the State for his eminent legal attainments and his connection with the most prominent and wealthy families in West Virginia, had attempted to take his life under sensational circumstances.
The will of Capt. Benjamin Richardson was filed yesterday for probate. Its Executor is William T. Washburn and the Executrix Emma Richardson.

Not more than two dozen people met at the American Institute Building last evening to attend the auction sale of the pictures and art objects left over from the German Hospital Fair, and Messrs. De Frece ...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 28.--The bitter and protracted contest over the election of an Excise Commissioner for the town of Delhi, the county seat of Delaware County, has been settled by the verdict of a jury at the current term of the Circuit Court of the district, Judge C.E. Parker presiding.
RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 28.--The funeral of Anthony Reckless, who died at his home on Broad-street last Sunday, took place yesterday afternoon.

At the Appraiser's stores yesterday there were no removals, as had been anticipated. It is still believed, however, that Secretary Fairchild has the names of six or eight officials whom he will cause to be removed to-day or tomorrow as a parting shot.

The annual meeting of stockholders of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company was held at Taylor's Hotel, in Jersey City, yesterday. There were represented 108,000 shares of stock. The following Directors were elected:

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Feb. 28.--Information was received here to-day to the effect that Gen. F.E. Spinner, ex-Treasurer of the United States, who is receiving treatment in Chicago for cancer of the face, is rapidly recovering. His face is healing and the General expects to leave for Jacksonville, Fla., next week.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--Two weeks ago the Excise Committee appointed a sub-committee of five to draw up an amended Excise bill. This committee consisted of Chairman Curtis and Messrs. Coon, Lewis, Young, and Bush.

The Fish Ceiling Committee met this afternoon, and to-night the members are jubilant over the auspicious opening and the positive declaration from all that politics is not to be brought into the question under any circumstances. Messrs. Fish and Creamer were appointed a committee to procure counsel, and expect to make their selection to-morrow.

Major-Gen. J.M. Schofield has written a letter to Mr. Oliver Downing, Secretary of the New-York Citizens' Committee to Aid the National Confederate Soldiers' Home at Austin, Texas, expressing his hearty sympathy with the movement.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 28.--Prof. William P. Thompson of the Hartford Theological Seminary, whose death was announced in to-day's TIMES, had been connected with the seminary since its founding in 1834.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 28.--The report telegraphed from Fort Dodge regarding contemplated evictions by Mr. Litchfield from Des Meines River lands is greatly exaggerated.

The Board of Emigration held their regular monthly meeting at Castle Garden yesterday, all the members being present except Mayor Grant. Chairman Taintor called the meeting to order promptly at 2 o'clock, and as soon as the sounds of the gavel had died away the music began.

ELIZABETHPORT, Feb. 28.--A meeting will be held to-morrow night by the stockholders of the new Manufacturers' State Bank of this place to formally organize by the election of a President, a Cashier, and Directors.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28.--The convention of the National League of Republican Clubs, representing about 4,000 Republican clubs in nearly all the States and Territories, began its session at Ford's Opera House to-day. The attendance was large and considerable enthusiasm prevailed. These States were represented as follows:
The afternoon performance of "The Electra" of Sophocles, already announced in this column, will be given at the Lyceum Theatre March 11.
Abbott H. Harvey of Seabright, N.J., who seems to be afflicted with a religious manis, jumped overboard from the New-Jersey Central Railroad ferryboat Communipaw yester

Further proof of irregularities in the Kings County Clerk's office during the last three years under John M. Ranken were brought out yesterday by Auditor Lake and Supervisor Rasquin, and Ranken's bill for $18,500 was reduced by another $1,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28.--The Philadelphia Baseball Club will start for the South to-morrow, their first objective point being Jacksonville, Fla. Manager Wright was busy to-day in making the final arrangements. He is full of bright expectations for the coming season, and thinks that the benefits ...

Blitz Langsdorf, clothiers, of Detroit, made an assignment yesterday to E.H. Scott for the benefit of their creditors. Liabilities about $21,000, nearly $16,000 of which is secured by chattle mortgages. The assets are estimated at $34,000. The cause of the assignment is a large stock, and open Winter, and the closeness of money.

ELIZABETH, Feb. 28.--The Union County Agricultural Society proposes on the occasion of Gen. Harrison's visit to Elizabeth on April 29 to display in the procession which will escort him through the city an exact representation on platform wagons of the agricultural implements in use a century ago, with other novel features, contrasting 1789 with 1889.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--The meeting of the International Marine Conferance, for securing greater safety for life and property at sea, has been fixed by President Cleveland for Wednesday, Oct. 16, 1889, and he has appointed as delegates on the part of ...
A brief dispatch was published in several newspapers last evening telling of the "horrible assault and murder" of a young girl in the little hamlet of Lakeville, Long Island.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28.--Bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day repealing the act allowing insolvent savings banks to apply to the Chancellor for Receivers, and anthorizing the appointment of two agents by the Governor for the purchase of the Sea Girt encampment grounds.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28.--The attempt to settle by arbitration the bill of W.J. Dey Son, the plumbers whose charges for extensive repairs at the schools have been disputed by the Board of Education, has failed, Mr. Dey appointed Mayor William S. Strong arbitrator, and the board made Alderman L.T. Ives its member of the commission.

The pool enthusiasts were made joyful last night at the tournament in Hardman Hall. J. Louis Malone, who has thus far been invincible in the tourney, and William H. Clearwater, who bad only been beaten once, played a great game, by far the best of the series.

Miss Caroline Remsen, danghter of Robert G. Remsen, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Albert McKim in Grace Church. The ceremony occurred at 3:30, and the altar and chancel were heavily banked with palms and flowers. The large church was entirely filled with guests, fully 1,800 having been invited to the church.
Adolphus Hughes, colored, went to 178 Thompson-street yesterday and there found David Watson, another colored man, with whom he was on bad terms.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 28.--After an examination to-day and arguments, the Justice of the Peace heere ordered the return to the two brewing companies ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 28.--The official weights of the Louisville handicap show Terra Cotta at the top. with 122 pounds, followed by Montrose and Badge, 118; Los Angeles, 115, and scaled on down from 114 on Libretto to 90 on Half Sister. There is $2,500 added to this race, making it the richest all-aged event to be run in Kentucky this Spring.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 28.--The Worcester Baseball Association to-day purchased of the Boston League club the release of Pitcher Richard B. Conway for $1,000. Conway will receive $2,580 salary. The Worcester management is sparing no effort to strengthen its team in order that it may be able to compete successfully with Newark and Jersey City.

OTTAWA, Feb. 28.--The Senate devoted two hours to-day to a discussion on the advisability of urging the Imperial Government to hasten the completion of the proposed forts and other defenses in British Columbia. Senator McInnes, who hails from the Pacific coast, spoke at great length.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 28.--The carnival season was inaugurated to-night by the grand ball of the Knights of Momus. There was no street parade, but before the dance a series of brilliant tableaux was presented on the stage of the Grand Opera House, representing scenes in James Rodman Drake's poem, "The Culprit Fay."
That time-honored organist, Mr. Armin Schotte, played Reissiger's "Felsenmuhle" as the overture to the concert given at Stein way Hall Wednesday evening for the benefit of the German Emigrant House.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 28.--The liquor dealers of Monmouth County met recently in secret convention at this place. Representatives from Long Branch, Red Bank, Keyport, Eatontown, and Freehold were present.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, Feb. 28.--Great excitement prevails at Wallace, Idaho, over the decision of the Secretary of the Interior in the case of Allen against Morrill, involving the validity of land "located" with Sioux half-breed sorip.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28.--The big chandelier in the grand parlor of the Southern Hotel looked down upon the deliberations of 60 men to-day who probably represented millions enough to go around more than once.
Two hours after the release of Charles Miller in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon on a charge of counterfeiting, he and his two companions, Asa A. Packer and John Simpson, who ...

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 28.--William Henry Harrison, the colored man who was recently acquitted of the charge of murdering William Barnett near Believille last July, obtained work as a cart driver for Contractor Wells of Belleville a few days ago. Now all Mr. Wells's laborers have struck. They say they will not associate with a man suspected of homicide. Harrison has a wife and a large famils of young children depending upon him for support.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Central Railroad in Baltimore yesterday the following were elected Directors: George B. Roberts, Wistar Morris, George Small, J.N. Hutchinson, B.F. Newcomer, John P. Green, Harry Walters, Henry James, J.N. Du Barry, Louis W. Hall, E.B. Parsons, and J.D. Cameron.
Robert A. Crawford of 460 West Twentyninth-street recently turned Nathan Brown, a negro, out of a house of which he was agent, and Brown said he would have revenge.

PALESTINE, Texas, Feb. 28.--At a meeting of the Directcrs of the International and Great Northern Railroad here to-day Jay Gould and Russell Sage resigned from the directory, and J.A. Eddy and W.C. Cross were elected in fill the vacancies. This action appears in the minutes to have occurred on the 15th of this month.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28.--The Supreme Court of this State has decided in favor of the constitutionality of the law which authorizes a portion of the expense for removing grade crossings to be assessed by the Railroad Commissioners upon the town in which the crossing at grade is removed. The decision has just been made in the case of the town of Westbrook against the Consolidated Road.

Nicholas Wagner, a German widower, 75 years old, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself with a piece of rope to the transom over the door of his bedroom at 442 Ninth avenue, where he lived with his sonin-law, Valentine Schmidt. The old man had been despondent since the death of his wife over six years ago.

Presiding Justice Van Brunt has issued an order to show cause, returnable to-day, why the Bleecker-Street and Fulton Ferry Railroad Company should not issue certificates for 650 shares of its capital stock to Peter B. Sweeny.
Steamship Waesland, (Belg.,) Buschmann, Antwerp 12 ds., with mdse, and passengers to Peter Wright Sons.

There was but a small audience in Chickering Hall last night at the John H. Draper sale of paintings, including the private collection of G.T. Russell of Boston, despite the fact that examples by Corot, Dupre, Treyon, Edward Frera, Diaz, Robie, Delecroix, Rousseau, Vibers, Jacque, Fortuny, Millet, Bouguereau, Philip ...
Early yesterday morning thieves went into the cellar of the house at 247 Bergen-avenue, Jersey City, and cut out all of the lead pipe. Five minutes later flames broke out in the building.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 28.--The voluntary assignment of Folds Griffth to A.M. Scott late yesterday created a great deal of surprise in business circles, and although the fact was well known-that the firm was financially embarrassed no one doubted the stability of the house.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28.--The Grand Commandery of Knights Templar in this State will hold its annual session in New-London, March 19. Grand Commander Charles B. Ware of that city will deliver the address. Palestine Commandery of New-London will receive the Grand Commandery officers and distinguished masonic guests from outside of the State during the evening prior to the annual conclave.

The last of the Assembly balls for the season was held last night in Delmonico's and was well attended. The decorations were similar to those of the previous dances of the Matriarchs, consisting of bunches of roses and flowers, with a little green to soften the effect.

Four handsomely-attired young men who gave the names of Johnson, Clark, Jones, and Almes, were found struggling with W.B. Kird, a porter at the Sturtevant House, in Broadway, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth ...

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--Senator Murphy introduced a bill this morning which was immediately ordered to a third reading and passed without delay. It authorizes the authorities of NewYork City to issue $100,000 of bonds for the purpose of perfecting the parade ground in Van Cortlandt Park.

The Executive Committee of the National Canvention of French Canadians had a banquet last evening at Delisle's in Beaver-Street. There were present Leon Bossne Dit Lyonnais, Joseph Sausville, Adolph Bell, Charles G. Lecuyer, ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--The Secretary of the Intorior this afternoon accepted the following bonds: ...

The new twin screw steamer of the Hamburg-American Packet Line built by the Laird Brothers at Birkenhead, England, was successfully floated from her dock yesterday. She is 463 feet long, 56 feet wide, 38 feet deep, 10,000 tons displacement, and registers 12,500 horse power to her engines. She will run between this port and Hamburg, Germany.

One of the most pathetic incidents ever connected with the old "Jerry McAuley Mission," at 316 Water-street, was enacted there last night. It was the funeral service over the remains of Thomas Winn, alias Capt. William Lloyd, familiarly known to the frequenters of the mission as "Pop" Lloyd.

The Dutch steamship Prins Willem I., from Hayti, arrived at her dooks in Brooklyn early last evening. She left Port au Prince on the afternoon of Washington's Birthday, and had a good run to this city. The Captain said: "I have heard no news whatever of fighting since the last news of the battle near St. Mare, published in the New-York papers.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 28.--James Dolan, a dwarf less than 4 feet in height, was committed to the jail in Morris County some weeks ago for habitual drunkenness ana disorderly conduct.

BOSTON, Feb. 28.--A meeting of the creditors of the Pacific Guano Company, Glidden Curtis, John M. Glidden, and G.W. Dove, was held this morning. John C. Ropes, the assignee, made a statement to the effect that he only ac cepted the assigneeship to hold the proverty together and prevent attachments until an assignee could be chosen by the creditors, and that he could not continue in that capacity.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28.--A new point has been raised for the Newark Excise Board. Giacomo Fera, an Italian, kept a saloon on Ferry-street. George Brown was killed on the sidewalk in front of his place, and his license was revoked as a result.

NEWARK, Feb. 28.--Dan Herty, Noremac, Day, Golden, Hegelman, Taylor, Sherlock, and other pedestrians were advertised to begin a 51-hour walking match to-night at 8 o'clock in the Bellevue-Avenue Rink, but the doors were not opened and "Ben" Washburn, the manager, could not be found.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 28.--James Dolan, a dwarf less than 4 feet in height, was committed to the jail in Morris County some weeks ago for habitual drunkenness ana disorderly conduct.

Capt. Stephen Losee, who for many years was in the lighterage business in this city with Tuttle Co., disappeared from his home at 424 Manhattan-avenue, Brooklyn, an Tuesday, and has not yet been found. It is feared that he has committed suicide. Yesterday his niece, who kept house for him, received the following letter dated Feb. 26:

BOSTON, Feb. 28.--A meeting of the creditors of the Pacific Guano Company, Glidden Curtis, John M. Glidden, and G.W. Dove, was held this morning. John C. Ropes, the assignee, made a statement to the effect that he only ac cepted the assigneeship to hold the proverty together and prevent attachments until an assignee could be chosen by the creditors, and that he could not continue in that capacity.

Much care and study had evidently been, expended in preparing for the presentation of the opera of "Martha" in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night by the Amateur Opera Association. Doubtless all who were concerned in it went home happy, and to-day they will all with equal certainty receive the abundant congratulations of their friends.
Mme. Hading will not be seen on the stage again in this country after to-morrow night, but she will not sail for France until Saturday, March 9, when she will be a passenger on the Bourgogne.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 28.--Gov. Lee to-day accepted the invitation of Capt. Lorragan of the Ninth New-York on behalf of the First Virginia Regiment, the latter regiment to be the guests of the Ninth during the celebration of Washington's centennial inauguration.

The arrangements recently made for placing the gas supply of Boston under the control of one corporation that has at last-succeeded in getting possession of all the prominent local gas companies, lead the Boston papers to express a hope that consolidation will cause a reduction of prices.

PESTH, Feb. 28.--A stormy scene was enacted in the lower house of the Hungarian Diet today, the resumption of the debate on the Army bill giving rise to a violent demonstration by the members of the Opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--The Arlington Hotel is the focus of all the political excitement in Washington new. Within its walls the incoming Administration is not only arranging its political affairs, but is laying the foundation of its social fabric. Gen. Harrison is still a listener to all and the few who have his confidence are not communicative of his secrets.

CHICAGO, March 1.--The Grand Jury this morning took up the charges of criminal libel made by ex-Police Inspector John Bonfield and ex-Police Captain Schaack against J. J. West and Joseph R. Dunlop of the Chicago Times, and in less than two hours threw the cases out and adjourned.
WASHINGTON, March 1.--There was no decided change in Representative Spinola's condition to-day, although his physician reports that his ailment is progressing favorably.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--Secretary Fairchild to-day sent to the Senate copies of reports and other communications relating to investigations of alleged irregularities in the importation and classification of sugars at New-York, Philadelphia, Boston, and San Francisco; also, reports respecting improper allowances for ...
HAVANA, Feb. 23.--The scarcity of good field laborers compels planters to pay extravagant prices.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 1.--The body of a woman known as Rosalie was discovored in a room over the Turf Club saloon at Calgary last night. The woman had been in the company of William Fisk during the afternoon.

CHICAGO, March 1.--A dispatch from Des Moines, Iowa, says: The Iowa Railroad Commissioners are in a quandary. The alleged injustice of their recently-adopted schedule is being continually held up before them.

Three hundred educators connected with the colleges and schools of New-York attended an invitation meeting in the Assembty Hall of the College for the Training of Teachers, in University-place, yesterday afternoon, to discuss plans for introducing into the schools the study ol history, and especially of American history.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 1.--Earnest Merrill, a lad, abed 17, living at Townsbury, fell on the` ice yesterday, receiving spinal injuries from which he died in a few hours. while assisting him his brother broke though the ice and narrowly escaped drowning.
Fourteen hundred immigrants were landed at Castle Garden yesterday from the steamships Germanic from Liverpool, the Trave from Bremon, and the Amsterdam from Rotterdam.

HARTFORD, March 1.--The Supreme Court opinion in the Fairfield grade-crossing case, which has occasioned widespread interest in the State since its announcement, was given to the public this afternoon. It was prepared by Judge Pardee of this city.

LONDON, March 1.--The statement that Sir Julian Pauncefote has been appointed British Minister to the United States is officially confirmed. It is said that Lord Salisbury made this selection on account of Sir Julian's knowledge of the fishery question.

For the benefit of inaugural visitors who desire to remain for the ball and return home immediately thereafter the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will run a special train to New-York, leaving Washington, Baltimore and Potomac station,...

NEW-ORLEANS, March 1.--The Oaks, the famous dueling ground in the rear of the city, was the scene of a hostile meeting at daybreak this morning between State Senator E.A. O'Sullivan and Clay L. Knobloch, ex-Lieutenant-Governor of Louisiana.

BALTIMORE, March 1.--In the concluding session to-day of the convention of the National League of Republican Clubs, the main feature was the selection of the new President. The man chosen was ex-Judge John M. Thurston of Kansas,who was the temporary presiding officer of the Republican National convention in Chicago last June and who praised Blaine as "the uncrowned King."

John Collier, Kiernan Graham, Moses Stenson, and John Schoonmaker, who during the recent tie-up on the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad in Brooklyn forced their way into the Ninth-avenue stable and attacked Henry W. ...

ALBANY, March 1.--Gen. Harrison is not a popular man in Albany to-day. The Platt men, feel that they have been sold out; that an invidious comparison has been made between their leader, through whose efforts the State was ...

The thirty-eighth annual report of the Demilt Dispensary, whose charities comprise the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Wards of this city, shows that it accomplished a vast work of benevolence during 1888. The total number of patients treated was 66,885, which is 10,284 more than in 1887.
The ship Annie M. Law, which entered this port with fire in her hold, was towed from her anchorage off Bedlow's Island to a new anchorage near Robbin's Reef Light yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--Secretary Fairchild has sent a letter to Chairman Mills in answer to his request for further information as to the general effect the Senate substitute for the House Tariff bill would have upon the customs revenue. The Secretary says:

LIGONIER, Penn., March 1.--Chief of Police Harris of Johnstown and a posse of deputies arrested Collins Hamilton on the mountain, four miles east of here, about 3 o'clock this morning, on suspicion of having been one of the parties who brutally murdered Herman Umberger at his home last Wednesday night, near Jennerstown.

Mrs. Louisa Eldridge, the well-known actress, who has been seriously ill for a week, was better last night, although she is still too sick to receive visitors. The cause of her illness is the bursting of a bloodvessel of the brain. Her physician thinks that she is now in a fair way to recover.

Minnie Achille, a 7-year-old girl, started a fire with kerosene at her home, 17 Grace-street, Jersey City Heights,, yesterday morning. The oil set fire not only to the child but to the bed on which her infant sister lay. The baby was burned to death. The older girl may recover from her injuries.
OTTAWA, Ontario, March 1.--Mr. Kirkpatrick's bill for the admission of American vessels to wrecking privileges in Canada, which was recently introduced in the Dominion Parliament, ...

Many of the merchants doing business on Broadway, near Canal-street, complain bitterly of the prevalence of bunko men in that neighborhood. A member of a large dry goods firm, just below Canal-street, said yesterday that a day never passed without his seeing at least a dozen of these fellows loitering on either side of Broadway, or working the confi- ...

Recorder Smyth yesterday showed clemeney in the case of ex-Receiving Teller John H. Stopford of the Nineteenth Ward National Bank, who was convicted of taking $2,050 from that institution, by suspending sentence.

LONDON, March 1.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Home Secretary Matthews, in reply to a quetion, said that Constable Preston had twice visited a prisoner named Tracy at the instance of Mr. Soames, the solicitor for the Times.

CHICAGO, March 1.--Thomas R. Vines, the clerk who had himself shipped in a trunk to St. Louis with $4,062 stolen from his employers, Adams, Westlake Co., was tried to-day for the act. The defense was insanity.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--The joint resolution to promote commercial union with Canada, which was introduced by Mr. Hitt of Illinois and reported unanimonaly from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, was passed by the House today. It provides that when the Canadian Gov- ...

Peter mcGrath, age 26, of 241 East Forty-second-street, rolled a big stone on the track of the Third-Avenue Railroad on the night of Feb. 2 during the street-railroad strike. He was arrested, and yesterday he was found guilty. He was not a striker. Judge Martine gave him three months in the penitentiary, and said:

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 1.--About four years ago Wellington J. Rodgers and wife came to St. Paul from Hartford, Conn. At that time Rodgers was in the office of C.D. O'Brien, and lived with his wife at Ryan's Hotel.
HARTFORD, March 1.--The Connecticut Senate adjourned to-day until Wednesday, March 6, in order to allow the members to go to Washington.

A publication of interest and value to advertisers in the metropolitan press has just been issued by M. Heimerdinger, the newspaper advertising agent at 31 and 32 Park-row. It is a beautiful little example of the printers' and binders' arts, and is full of information ...

The Board of City Record having incurred liabilities beyond its appropriation, the Board of Estimate and Apportionment last December set apart $40,000 to wipe them out. It was supposed that this sum would be sufficient.

The eleventh day of the Extraordinary Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, convened for the trial of Thomas B. Kerr for bribery, was wearisome. One additional juror to the nine already in the box was the not yield of the search for men qualified to sit in unbiased judgment on the ease.

HAVANA, March 1.--The second game in the new chess contest of three games, in which Tschigorin and Ponce are pitted against Steinitz and Gavilan, has been played. It was begun with the Zukertort gambit and lasted five hours.

The performance of "Die Meistersinger" at the Metropolitan. Opera House last evening, though attended by a large audience and followed with the interest which this admirable, many-sided work always awakens, was not as ...
CHICAGO, March 1.--An important conference, having for its object the correction of abuses which have recently become so common as to demoralize rates on through traffic, was held to-day ...

NORWIC, Conn., March 1.--A select party of a dozen experienced fox hunters returned to this city late last night. They presented a sorry spectacle. Not one able-bodied man, dog, or horse was numbered in their caravan.

About the middle of last month Lieut. V. L. Cottman, United States Navy, in charge of the Branen Hydrographic Office in the Maritime Exchange, posted in the Exchange a notice requesting ship owners and Captains to report to the Hydrographic Office cases of dangerous derelicts coming to their knowledge.
The Rev. Nicholas Balleis, the oldest priest in the province of New-York, is lying seriously ill at the rectory of St. Francis's Church, Brooklyn. He was born at Salzburg, Austria, on Nov. 22, 1808.

A meeting of the Plan and Scope Committee of the Centennial Celebration of Washington's Inauguration was held yesterday, all members present excepting Cornolius N. Bliss, who is in Washington. Elbridge T. Gerry received a telegram from the Hon. James W. Husted, at Albany, saying that the Centennial ...

Many readers of the newspapers have Written letters to THE TIMES asking "why the true character of William Windom is not exposed" to save Gen. Harrison from the dilemma of having "such a man" in his Cabinet.

The Directors of the Illinois Central Railroad Company yesterday issued an aavance copy of their report, including balance sheet and principal abstracts, in anticipation of the stockholders' meeting in Chicago on March 13.

Representatives of the newly-organized Atlantic League of baseball clubs held a meeting at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon for the purpose of selecting an eighth club to complete the required quota. After some routine work Hartford was admitted and given until March 9 to raise a fund of $5,000 for the organization of a club.

A play by the author of "La Tentation" and "Un Roman Parisien," called "Chamillac," had its first performance in this country at Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon. It was produced at the Theatre Francais in April, 1886, and much curiosity was excited at that time by the reports of Coquelin's successful treatment of a purely sentimental role.

William B. Schulhoff, 32 years old, a crayon artist of 103 East Fourteenth-street, was taken sick in the elevated railroad station at Fifty-third-street and Third-avenue yesterday afternoon and died before medical assistance could be obtained. He had been troubled with heart disease for some time.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1.--The Princeton Class of '79 has decided, as its decennial class memorial, to place in Marquand Chapel a mural statue of the venerable ex-President, Dr. McCosh. The artist is Saint-Gandens. Thus Princeton will not only have a suitable memorial of one who has done so much for the college, but a valuable work of art as well.

It is safe to say that not one woman in ten thousand lives a single week in which she does not either cry or feel like crying. The cares of life, disappointments, and, more than all else, weaknesses and pains make all women more or less miserable. This is all wrong.

D'Oro, the Cuban wonder, distinguished himself and astonished the veteran experts at pool by defeating both Frey and Malone in the prize tournament at Hardman Hall yesterday. His essays were desperately bold, and his execution marvelously brilliant.

Mr. Thomas C. Platt was as cheerful last night as if he had never thought of going into the Harrison Cabinet. He sat in the Fifth Avenue Hotel and talked so pleasantly that a New-Zealander would never have suspected him of being the victim of an unsatisfied desire.

ALBANY, March 1.--No legislation of any import was accomplished in either house to-day. Everybody seemed anxious to get out of town as soon as possible. Adjournment was taken until March 11 at 8 o'clock.

Large amounts of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy stock, and stock of other Western roads, are owned in and about Hartford, and, at the request of many stockholders. Francis B. Cooley and Daniel R. Howe, two well-known business men of Hartford, have consented to represent Eastern shareholders at the several Western meeting. They announce that they will, if requested, forward to stockholders of the Burlington, Illinois Central, St. Paul, ...

Rucqnoy, flute, late of the Pasdoloup orchestra, Paris; Felix Bour, oboe; J. Schreurs, clarionet; A. Hackebarth, horn, of the Thomas orchestra, and J. ...
Commander Forde of the British Navy is at the Victoria Hotel. Prof. C.S. Sargent of Brookline, Mass., is at the Brevoort House.

MADISON, Wis., March 1.--John Kuhni, a Swiss, who was brought back from London, England, to answer the charge of murdering William Christen in this county in December, was examined in the Municipal Court to-day.
Gen. H.A. Barnum, the Marshal of the New-York Brigade of the inaugural procession, went to Washington yesterday afternoon and opened his headquarters at the Randall.

Persons who had the best possible means of obtaining information, estimated, yesterday, that the amount of money which should have gone to the A.B. Cleveland Company, and which President A.B. Cleveland, appropriated to his own use, is about $38,000. There is a question as to whether the company will stand the loss or the parties who let Mr. Cleveland have their notes supposing they were giving them to the company.

CHICAGO, March 1.--Provisions were influenced at the opening to-day by another large run of Hogs, and the first sales reported were made at prices showing a decline from Thursday's closings of 5c. on Pork and 2 c. on Lard and Short Ribs.

SING SING, N.Y., March 1.--A curious accident occurred this afternoon at Shaft No. 4 of the new Croton Aqueduct. A number of barrels were being lowered into the shaft and 15 were loaded upon the cage.

The Board of Police Commissioners, acting as Trustees of the Police Pension Fund, are in a dead-lock over the preffered gift of the Breadway and Sixth-Avenue Railway Companies, in all $1,500. The Corporation Counsel was asked if the board could refuse to accept the gifts, and yesterday he rendered the following opinion:

MADRID, March 1.--An Englishman, supposed to be Richard Pigott, was arrested at the Hotel des Ambassadeurs to-day under the name of Ronald Ponsonby. The man afterward sommitted suicide with a revolver.

The games of the National Association of Amateur Athletes of America, which take piece at the Madison-Square Garden this afternoon and evening, have the largest number of entries that has yet been known in American athletics. The number of entries is about 800, and the handling of this immense throng necessitates trial heats in the afternoon.
Eleven members of the Philadelphia League Baseball Club sailed on the Mallory Line steamer San Antonio for Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday.
When at the beginning of the legislative session last year a tremendous scare was got up over the condition of the Assembly Chamber ceiling there were immediate suspicions of an intended job.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1.--The terrapin market in Philadelphia, New-york, and Baltimore has been "cornered." When, early this morning, the stewards of the various city clubs went to market to procure the great American delicacy they were informed that there was not a genuine terrapin in the city.

NEW-HAVEN, March 1.--President Clark, when asked to-day about the rumored deal between the New-Haven and New-England Roads, declared emphatically that there was nothing in it. The subject had not been mentioned at any meeting of the New-Haven Road. No documents had been exchanged and there had not been and negotiations between the two companies. "Nor is there likely to be at present," he added.
CHICAGO, March 1.--With the ringing down of the curtain Sunday night, Baker's Theatre, Wabash-avenue and Nineteenth-street, will be closed for the season, and some doubts exist as ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1.--Nearly every member of the General Assembly, Democrats and Republicans, leaves on a special train in the morning for Washington to take part in the inaugural ceremonies. The distinguished junketers go by the Baltimore and Ohio and return by the Pennsylvania Road.

Nevr before in the history of the United States has a party been able to retire from office with the satisfaction of knowing that during its four years' term of power, it has done so much toward strengthening the defensive system of the country, and at the same time developed so many material resources for the maintenance of a modern naval establishment.

The First Ward Industrial School and Workingmen's Public Reading Room and Free Circulating Library has just issued its thirtieth annual report. The difficulties of teaching the children of the vicinity are described as very great. There were 324 pupils on the roll dur- ...

Mr. WALTERS of Baltimore, one of the most liberal and judicious of American collectors of works of art, has declared, over his own signature, that he has offered to the Metropolitan Museum the sum estimated to be necessary to make its collections available to the public on Sundays for three years.

Ex-County Clerk Ranken of Brooklyn yesterday produced the receipts for copying the books charged for in his bill of $18,500. Every one of them was signed by John F. Neeson. It was not until County Auditor Lake refused to take even his sworn affidavit that the books had been paid for that Ranken revealed the name signed to the receipts.

There was satisfaction in the heart of Capt. O'Connor of the East Eighty-eighth-street police station yesterday, for he knew that he had locked up in the station house a thief who has caused a grest deal of trouble for nearly two months.

The testimony before the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday in the course of the inquiry into the manner in which the stands in the new West Washington Market were distributed was of the same general character as that given on previous days.
The Titan order of Genial Giants met at the Hotel Brunswick last night and celebrated the return of Spring by partaking of a banquet and indulging in the singing of songs and merrymaking generally.
PATERSON, N.J., March 1.--Katie Labbo, the wife who was so horribly stabbed by her husband, Tunis Labbe, yesterday afternoon, died this morning at 5 o'clock. She was only 19 years old.

Marcus R. Mayor was a passenger on the Trave, which arrived yesterday morning. He was not expected until late in the afternoon, so that nobody greeted him at the dock, and the brass band which he had a right to expect would welcome him was not in attendance.
Three bright-eyed and flaxen-haired little travelers from a foreign land were entered as immigrants from Germany, per steamer Travo, at Castle Gardon yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1.--At the annual meeting of the Princeton College Gymnasium Association to-day the following officers were elected: President--H.K. Denlinger, '90, Pennsylvania; Secretary and Treasurer--B.L. Morgan ...

DETROIT, March 1.--George Morley, wholesale lumber dealer of this city, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors. The liabilities are placed in the vicinity of $100,000, while the assets will inventory about $70,000.

BOSTON, March 1.--Henry A. Gould, dealer in dye stuffs, rubber, gutta percha, , at 17 Pearl-street, under the firm name of Henry A. Gould Co., made a voluntary assignment today, with liabilities approaching $1,000,000 and assets at present unknown.

ST. LOUIS, March 1.--The delegates to the bankruptcy convention were slow in assembling this morning. The Committee on Bills was at work until 4 o'clock this morning, and during the night session disposed of an immense amount of business.
DANVILLE, Va., March 1.--The sales by auction of leaf tobacoo in the market for February amounted to 3,610,689 pounds, a decrease, as compared with last year, of 1,478,745 pounds.

The Manhattan Single Tax Club gave Henry George a send-off last evening on the occasion of his departure to Europe. The members met at their headquarters in St. Mark's place, and at 9 o'clock they started with a brass band and marched across to Christopher-street ferry.
ELIZABETH, March 1.--The first charity ball ever given in this city was held last night at the Veteran Zouavea' Armory for the benefit of the City Hospital. The ball proved a brilliant society event.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 1.--The death is announced of Wickliffe Preston's o.f. Thrifty, 2 years, by Spendthrift, dam Leonora, by Donerail. She worked a quarter in 0:25 last Fall, and gave every indication of developing into a first-class filly.

RINGWOOD, N.J., March 1.--Mr. Robert Garrett is much improved in health, and, according to present arrangements, will start on Wednesday for Mexico. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Garrett, Dr. Jacobs, and several friends. The party will go West over the Erie Road.

Sir Charles and Lady Tupper arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd steamship Trave. They remained in the city only a few hours, starting for Montreal on the afternoon train.

An excited Frenchman ran up to a policeman at Broadway and Thirty-sixth-street yesterday afternoon, and, pointing to a dapper, welldressed men passing along, asked the officer to arrest him for robbery. The arrest was made and both men were taken before Justice Patterson at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 1.--The resolution of the Hon. Wilfred Laurier, leader of the Opposition, in favor of closer trade relations with the United States, and the continuance of the modus vivendi in connection with the fishery treaty, was voted down by the Government supporters to-night, the vote standing yeas 65, nays 108; majority, 43.

Jules Lemaltre, the distinguished French critic, has a play in rehearsal at the Odeon in Paris, which is waited for with great expectations. It is called "Revoltee," and Dumeny and Tessandier will have the principal roles. The title means that the heroine is a woman, who objects to the prejudices of society.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 1.--G.D. Wilson of this city has sold the b.g. Pat Moran, 4 years old, by Leonatus, dam Sunbeam, by Leamington, to J.E. McDonald of New-York City for $1,000.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 1.--The Wesleyan Faculty have at last come to a decision in the bomb explosion case. The punishments are as follows: Suspended for the rest of the college year--H.P. Queal, Auburn, N.Y.; C.H. Pierce, Tuilahoma, Tenn.; F.H. Tackaberry, NewYork; W.H. Hall, South Wellington, Conn.; R.E. Smith, Mauch Chunk, Penn.; H.S. Rocksby, Philadelphia.

A new corporation for the manufacture of cotton goods, to be known as the Cornell Mills, was organized at Fall River yesterday, with a capital of $400,000, $360,000 of which has been subscribed. A factory of over 35,000 spindles will be erected, work upon which will be commenced at once.
Activity and strength were displayed pretty generally throughout the whole Stock Exchange list yesterday, but the Gould stocks and the Villard stocks made their friends happiest.

John J. Collins, who last Summer experienced a terrible night on the Hackensack Meadows fighting mosquitoes, died yesterday in the County Insane Asylum in Jersey City. Since the light he encountered the mosquitoes he had been hopelessly insane. He lived in Jersey City.
Judge Henry A. Gildersleeve last evening gave a dinner to his colleagues on the bench of the Court of the General Sessions, the Supreme Court Judges, and a few friends at the Union League Club.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 1.--A day or two ago the family of Mr. Bud Hynes, nine in all, were drowned in a swamp in Decatur County, near the Tennessee River, a colored man who was with them escaping to tell the story.

Patrolman Francis Gerrity of the Nineteenth Precinct died yesterday from injuries received during the street car strike. While riding to a riot in Tenth-avenue he was thrown from a patrol wagon, and injured about the head and body.

News from Hayti received in this city yesterday chronicles the arrest of Clerville Saintville, the body servant of American Minister Thompson at Port au Prince. Minister Thompson has been under the suspicion of the Legitimist Party having control of the Government for some time, and has, in consequence, been closely watched.

Rumors of irregular proceedings in the United States Pension Agency at 398 Canalstreet, this city, reached the ears of the authorities at Washington about three weeks ago. Gen. Franz Sigel has charge of this agency.

Bishop Henry C. Potter addressed the Phi Beta Kappa Society at Clark's, in West Twenty-third-street, last night on "The Place of the Scholar in American Life." He said that the opportunity for high-class scholarship in this country was never so rare as it is to-day.

ELIZABETH, March 1.--The famous Veteran Zouaves of this city, Gen. J. Madison Drake commanding, start on Sunday morning for Washington to participate in President Harrison's inauguration.
Conrad Franz, a German tailor who lived at 65 Avenue C, in a fit of despondency committed suicide last night by hanging himself to the casing of the door to his room.

CHICAGO, March 1.--It has been noised about for the last month that a combination was to be formed by the cattle raisers of the Southwest to handle their cattle in the Chicago market irrespective of the commission merchants.

The French comedians closed their engagement at Palmer's Theatre last evening with Augier's charming comedy in verse, "L'Aventuriere," and Jane Hading then made her last appearance in this country for the present.

A St. Louis wedding which attracted much attention in New-York society was that of Miss Helen Stafford of St. Louis to Mr. Oakleigh Thorne of New-York. It was celebrated at Christ Church, in St. Louis, at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of Feb. 26.
The anniversary of the birth of Robert Emmet will be celebrated with more than usual ceremony at Cooper Union to-morrow evening.

ALBANY, March 2.--Ancient Albany has almost as much social life nowadays as any other Northern city. Up to Lent the calendar is pretty well crowded. With the toboggan slides, which have proved great society events, coaching clubs, and snowshoe clubs out of doors, the receptions, afternoon teas, and balls within doors, the society slave has not had much time to himself.

But Fish Commissioner Blackford saw no reason for anybody to be alarmed.
Judge Benedict, in the United States court, in Brooklyn, after listening for a week to evidence in the case of the libeled steamer Conserva yesterday dismissed the libel and declared the vessel free.

PATERSON, N.J., March 2.--The autopsy on the body of Katie Labbe, who was murdered by her husband, Tunis Labbe, showed 34 separate wounds.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 2.--The last game but one in the American Football Association championship series was played here to-day between the Rovers of this city and the O.N.T.s of Newark, N. J., resulting 7 to 0 in favor of the former.

An enthusiastic meeting in aid of the National Confederate Soldiers' Home, at Austin, Texas, was held in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last night. Capt. Walter Sprague presided, and there were present about 150 gentlemen from different parts of the Union.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has been enriched by the receipt of a volume entitled "The Austro-Hungarian Monarchy in Word and Picture."

FLUSHING, Long Island, March 2.--A bill recently introduced in the State Legislature by Assemblyman Townsend of Oyster Bay provides for an appropriation of $100,000 for a normal school in the village of Flushing.

The success of the double series of Lenten matinees, consisting of illustrated lectures by Mr. Stoddard, given at Daly's Theatre last year, was so pronounced that Mr. Daly has decided to again offer the series in duplicate this year.
BISMARCK, Dakota, March 2.--A case in the Black Hills brings to light something in the Penal Code that the Legislature will undoubtedly correct.

HARTFORD, March 2.--The New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad Company has cut 2,000 tons of ice at Windsor Locks for the Summer consumption on its lines, and has stored it in this city, New-Haven, and at the Harlem River icehouses.

ISHPEMING, Mich., March 2.--The recent discovery of gold on an acre tract of land under option to the Finn Brothers and others of Grayling, Mich., is the richest made since the big strike in the Michigan mine last August. The gold was found near the surface in a 16-inch vein. The quartz is charged with virgin gold in grains, and the estimates of its value run from $30,000 to $60,000 a ton.

For over seven hours yesterday the representatives of the new Inter-State Railway Association were in conference at the Windsor Hotel with Mr. Aldace H. Walker, who has been unanimously nominated for permanent President of the association.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 2.--News has just reached here from Okeechobee of a deadly affray among the Seminole Indians in the Everglades. "Jim," a young buck, went crazy, and, with a Winchester rifle, started out on the warpath through the camp and settlement. He first sent a bullet through the brain of "Waukee Mieco," chief of the Miamis, killing him instantly. He next killed "Old Tiger."

The publication in THE TIMES of yesterterday concerning the prevalence of "bunko" men on Broadway in the neighborhood of Canal-street had the beneficial effect of lessening their operations for the time at least.

The work of reform in the public school system of this city began in September last with the appointment of a special committee of eight Commissioners of the Board of Education for the investigation of certain complaints against the examination and marking systems in vogue.

The passenger traffic to Washington yesterday morning was very heavy, every train from the Pennsylvania station being run in sections to accommodate the crowd. The 8 o'clock train was run out in three sections, the 8:43 in two sections, and the 10 o'clock limited in two sections. In addition to these trains a special was started at 10:23 o'clock.

The historian, J.R. Green, died at Mentone on March 7, 1883, and was buried in the cemetery of that place. Owing to some unavoidable causes there was considerable delay before any memorial stone recorded the place of his interment.

PARIS, Feb. 20.--Sardou's wit and Rejane's-elegance combined have been enough to excite critical interest and feminine curiosity. Before going into gown and fashion lore let me say that there is a new kink in parlor decoration in the stage fitting of the first two acts.

The souvenir handicap meeting of the National Association of Amateur Athletes of America was held in Madison-Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening. There were more than 800 entries in the various events. It was one of the largest athletic meetings ever held indoors in this city, and, as was sure to be the case, it attracted many spectators, made up of lovers of all kinds of manly sports.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2.--The boat race between William O'Connor and Jacob Gaudaur for a purse of $2,000 occurs to-morrow on the Alameda course. There is little betting on the race owing to the uniform declaration of the local sports that O'Connor is a sure winner.
The jury box in the Kerr trial in the extraordinary session of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Daniels, came very near being filled yesterday.

Robert Sigel, the head clerk of the United States Pension Agency in this city, who is accused of forgery and unlawful appropriation of money, still remains in Ludlow-Street Jail in default of $20,000 bail for his appearance before the United States Commissioner Tuesday morning. CINCINNATI, March 2.--Gov. Foraker's recent attempts to convince people in Ohio that he was not guilty of treachery to Senator John Sherman while the Republican National Convention was in session at Chicago last June have not been quite as successful as he desired.

PARIS, March 2.--It is not a very great pity that the so-called Patriotic League should be interfered with and even suppressed. The great mystery to the outsider is why this bothersome, muddling, noisy association should so long have been allowed the right of way.
MASON CITY, Iowa, March 2.--The farmers of this and adjoining States are quietly organizing to resist the demands of the Binding Twine Trust.

The tenants in the five-story tenement house at 303 East Seventy-sixth-street were badly scared yesterday by the explosion of a blast in the open lot adjoining the house which blew in a portion of the side wall of the house.
ROME, Feb. 13.--Letters are pouring in from the Roman Catholics of various countries to the Pope in protest against the new Italian Penal Code, which goes into effect next June.

NEW-HAVEN, March 2.--Prof. Abdonk Abakanowicz of Paris exhibited his newly-invented "integraph" at Wednesday's meeting of the Yale Mathematical Club in Sloane Laboratory. This apparatus is a marvel of scientific ingenuity, its use being to determine by mechanical processes the areas inclosed by curves of any shape, however irregular. The inventor operated the machine, proving by several tests that it was accurate.
Col. William W. Stephensen, a well-known lawyer and formerly a member of the Assembly, is dying at his home, 216 Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, from a complication of heart trouble and Bright's disease.

HARTFORD, March 2.--The friends of Dr. George S. Miller of this city are pressing his name very strongly for the appointment of National Bank Examiner in this district. The place is now held by Michael F. Dooley of Hartford, who was appointed by President Cleveland 18 months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--The United States ConsulGeneral at Shanghai reports to the State Department that the recent droughts and floods in China have caused widespread destitution, and although generous contributions have already been made for the relief of the people, there is pressing need of further aid.

NEW-HAVEN, March 2.--J.C. Hollister of Tarrytown, N.Y., has bequeathed to Jailer Odber of Haddam an estate of several thousand dollars. Capt. Odber saved Hollister's life in a steamer disaster at New-Berne, N.C., during the war, when only 4 of a company numbering 98 survived. Mr. Hollister, having no direct heirs, left his entire property to Odber.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--The Secretary of War to-day ordered a court martial for the trial of Major Garrett J. Lydecker, Corps of Engineers, on charges of neglect of duty in connection with the work of constructing the aqueduct tunnel. The court will meet at the War Department, Tuesday, March 12.

PARIS, March 2.--The members of the Chicago and All America Baseball Clubs are expected to arrive here to-night. President Spalding arrived to-day and went to the Hotel de St. Petersbourg, where he is to meet Manager Lynch for the purpose of arranging for the games. SARANAC LAKE, March 3.--This month opens under the most favorable circumstances. March, with its bright, sunshiny days, sheltered as one is here, is the most attractive of all the Winter months, and one gets a better idea of how enjoyable a Winter is in the mountains by a visit now. BUFFALO, N.Y., March 3.--The jouneyman carpenters and joiners of this city, on Saturday, presented to the bosses a circular in which they demand that on and after April 1 nine hours shall constitue a day's work, to be paid for at the rate of 25 cents an hour, and that over time shall be paid for at extra rates, this arrangement to remain in force for one year.

Redfield Proctor of Vermont brings into the Cabinet a record as a successful business man an average soldier, and a skillful politician. In business he has made a fortune out of a wreck. As a soldier he obeyed orders, which gave him seant opportunity for renown.

The matter of the steamer Conserva has been appealed to the United States Supreme Court. Leoncio Julia, the Dominican Consul, said yesterday that she had her crew aboard and was ready to sail at a moment's notice, but would now be detained, no doubt, for several days longer by the new proceedings.
NEW-HAVEN, March 4.--It is now expected that the soldiers' monument, which towers among the clouds on top of East Rock, will be fully completed this year.

LONDON, March 5.--The Parnell Commission resumed its sitting this morning. AttorneyGeneral Webster narrated the facts in relation to Pigott's communication from Madrid to Mr. Soames, the Times's solicitor.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5.--The Democrats today showed signs of uniting on the liquor question. The Senators were afraid to take up the measure this morning and adopt Senator Baker's township option amendments, but called a, caucus for noon.
The trial of Mrs. Mary Griffths's suit against Dr. Joseph B. Bennett for $10,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage was continued yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

A general alarm, sent out to the police yesterday, called for the arrest of a man who had been bitten on the cheek, and who was wanted on a charge of having seriously injured John Schultz of 1,092 Third-avenue by thrusting the end of an umbrella into his right eye.

CHICAGO, March 5.--The fast trains between Chicago and the Missouri River, which were taken off by all the roads early last summer, are to be restored at once.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 5.--The steamship City of New-York, which arrived last night, brings mail advices respecting the promulgation of the new Constitution of Japan on Feb. 11.

BERLIN, March 5.--Excepting the Tageblatt and the Vossische Zeitung the papers here reserve their opinions on President Harrison's inaugural address. The Taqeblail says that the address shows an arrogant spirit and that it does not display particularly friendly feelings toward other powers.

The management of the Illinois Central Railroad has decided, according to Memphis dispatches, to build a connecting link between the main line and the Mississippi River below Memphis.

RINGWOOD, N.J., March 5.--Mr. Garrett spent his last day at Ringwood in a very quiet manner. Notwithstanding the inclement weather he had his daily exercise out of doors, and took a short walk about the grounds of the Miller mansion.

The doors of the new Twents-thirdStreet Theatre were opened to the public last evening. As is often the case on such occasions, the persons whose business it was to look after the comfort of that portion of the public who entered the doors were incompetent. The entries for the 12 stakes of the NewYork Jockey Club, closing March 1, to be decided at the inaugural meeting during the last two weeks in August at the club's race course at Westchester, up to last night had reached the large number of 1,346.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5.--The venerable Isaiah V. Williamson was stricken with paralysis this morning and now lies in a critical condition. Few names have been made more ramiliar through the agency of charitable gifts and when the sum total of his benefactions is given it will be found to be from $13,000,000 to $15,000,000, including his recent contribution for the establishment of a school for manual training.

Mr. T. Haustedt of the firm of Jimenes, Haustedt Co. of 5 South William-street, signing himself agent for the Provisional Government of North Hayti, sent a letter to Collector Magone yesterday protesting against the shipment of arms to President Legistime in Hayti.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 5.--According to Statistician Sheridan of Dakota there is a shortage in the State of 3,415,351 bushels of wheat to supply seed and bread to the next crop. Of course few at all conversant with the situation believe it.

The Berkeley Athletic Club having pulled over the line every team it has encountered in the "tug-of-war," is looking for new worlds to conquer, and is yearning for the light-weight championship of the country.

The annual report of the New-York Mercantile Exchange has just been published. The receipts during the past year from dues, rentals, and other sources were $47,306 46, and the expenditures for bonds redeemed, improvements, conducting the building, salaries, and other items, $46,199 22, leaving a balance of $l,107 24.

Cowley, painter of portraits, who created some excitement about a week aago by offering a large reward for the return of diamonds alleged to have been stolen from his studio in West Fourteenth-street, and later by the scientific manner in which he toyed with truth, seems to have disappeared.

Robert Sigel, the head clerk in the NewYork agency of the United States Pension Bureau, was examined before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday on the charge of having forged checks. The testimony was decidedly adverse to the young man. The examination was conducted by Assistant District Attorney Rose.
That "inauguration boom" flattened out sadly yesterday. Not only did the soda water rise of Monday stop its fizzing, but with one or two exceptions the whole list scored declines.

The corvette Juniata will, it is understood, be sent to the United States Naval Academy to relieve the Wyoming as a gunnery ship for the naval cadets. The Juniata is a thirdrate corvette, carrying a battery of eight guns.

Dullness reigned on the Metal Exchange yesterday, and the dealers in copper were particularly inactive. Only one sale was reported, 25,000 pounds of Lake copper, March, at 15 cents a pound, which was cent lower than the price of the day before. WASHINGTON, March 5.--The following bonds were offered and accepted to-day: Four and onehalf per cents, registered, $330,000, $200,000, $100,000, $50,000, $25,000, $15,000, $10,000, $25,000, total $700,000 at 10s.
NEWBURG, N.Y., March 5.--Highland Chapter, No. 52, Royal Arch Masons, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary to-night. High Priest Charles Estabrook gave a historical sketch of the chapter.

The Photographic Section of the American Institute, at its meeting last night in Clinton Hall, listened to reminiscences of some of the old photographers of the city as regards the early days of the art.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 5.--An important movement on the part of milk producers engaged in supplying the New-York City market took practical shape at the convention of representative producers just held at Oxford, Chenango County.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--In an opinion ren dered by Justice Miller in the United states Supreme Court, yesterday, in the case of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, plaintiff in error, against the Oregonian Railway Company, (Limited,) the court holds that the Oregonian Company had no power to lease its railroad, and that she Navigation Company had no power to take the lease.

While coming up the Lower Bay on Monday afternoon the North German Lloyd steamship Fulda ran around on the Sandy Hook Bar near South west Spit. She was detained thereby for about two hours.
PARIS, March 5.--The appeal of the Panama Canal Company against the decision of the Tribunal of Commerce was again before the Court of Appeals to-day.

Rich Harris, managers of the Hollisstreet Theatre and Howard Athenaeum, Boston, will arrive in New-York to-day, prepared to negotiate for a theatre in this city, to be under their management all next season.

Two new Commissioners of the Supervisory Board of the Municipal Service were appointed yesterday by Mayor Grant. The third will probably be chosen to-day. The appointees of yesterday are James Thomson and Henry Marquand.

ALBANY, March 5.--The Hotel Kenmore is swarming with detectives. It has just come out that during the past four or five days certain guests of the hotel have missed valuable articles of jewelry and wearing apparel.
The Amateur Sportsman is a new publication of which the first number has just been issued from 58 Liberty-street.
A very pretty ball was held in the Lex ington-Avenue Opera House Monday evening under the auspices of the employes of Harper Brothers, the publishers.

A serious accident for which no one seems to be responsible occurred early yesterday afternoon on the second floor of Travers Brothers' twine, cord and hammock manufactory, a new six-story building known as 556 West Fifty-second-street.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5.--The steamer City of New-York from China and Japan brings advices that relief is now coming in from all sides for the great distress in North China caused by last season's flood, but nevertheless it is feared that many thousands of people will perish in the cold of Winter.

MONTREAL, March 5.--To-day Messrs. Trudel, Charbonneau, and Lamothe, acting under instructions from the Society of Jesus, entered an action against the Mail Printing Company of Toronto for $50,000 for libel.

Druggist Am Ende of Hoboken, to whose mistake in compounding a prescription the death of the Misses Holz was said, is in fresh trouble.

NEW-HAVEN, March 5.--There are many applications for the clerkship of the Superior Court since Jonathan Ingersoll sent in his resignation.
The poor health of Deputy Controller Aaron Brinkerhoff of Brooklyn, who is now Acting Controller, causes much anxiety to the many persons who draw salaries from the City Government.

The Court of Appeals yesterday affirmed the judgment of the General Term of the Supreme Court, deciding that the will of Jesse Hoyt is a valid instrument. Surrogate Rollins confirmed the probate of the will in 1886 and the Supreme Court sustained his finding in 1887.
Contributions for the Confederate Soldiers' Home at Austin, Texas, continue to be sent daily to Chauncey M. Depew, Treasurer. The amount received yesterday was $282.

LONDON, March 5.--There was a large attendance of English operators, with a fair sprinkling of Continental buyers, at the sale to-day of wool salved from the ship Sir Walter Raleigh. There were offered without reserve 2,457 bales of Australian.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 5.--This morning about 3 o'clock a fire occurred at 2,809 Pennavenue, occupied as a barber's shop and dwelling by A. Schloll. The upper rooms were occupied by lodgers, three of whom were seriously burned.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 5.--The bill introduced by Senator Hall in amendment of the tax law relating to the assessment of taxes on land omitted from the tax list in years past has an interesting history behind it.

Members of the Ladies' Health Protective Association discussed matters of public concern in Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison-avenue, yesterday. Mrs. Clark Bell, vice-President, occupied the chair.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The annual Spring meeting of the National League of Baseball Clubs convened in the Arlington Hotel to-day. The principal object of this meeting was to adopt a schedule for the coming season.

The Sisters of the Sacred Heart, whose convent in Manhattanville Was destroyed by fire last August, are endeavoring to sell some of their property for an armory site, and the Armory Commissioners are considering their proposition.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5.--It is not expected that the Legislature will attend to much important business this week, owing to the absence of Gov. Bulkeley and prominent members of both houses in Washington, representing the State at the inaugural festivities.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 5.--The Czar will visit Emperor William of Germany at Berlin in April. The imperial programme of business has been filled until the second week of April.

READING, Penn., March 5.--Announcement was made here this afternoon of the failure of the Reading Iron Works, which operates in this city blast furnaces, rolling, sheet, tube, and pipe mills, forges, and machine shops, employing in all over 2,500 hands.
A private letter from Bongalo, on the Congo, gives, under date of Nov. 5, 1888, some information about Henry M. Stanley, which has not yet appeared in any of the published accounts of his movements.

The most novel audience of the season is promised for the London Gaiety Company at the Standard Theatre next week. The students of Columbia College are now negotiating with Manager Slater for the purchase of the entire house for one night.

With the observance of the beginning of Lent to-day the Columbia College students have release from their colloge duties. And during the coming Lenten season lectures will be delivered once a week in the chapel by prominent New-York and Brooklyn divines.
WASHINGTON, March 5.--The Pennsylvania troops became very disorderly to-day and at one time it looked as it there might be serious trouble.

HANOVER, N.H. March 5.--Five Dartmouth students--three Seniers and two Juniors--have been suspended from college for periods ranging from four weeks to four months for disregard of college law and disorderly conduct. Among them is a member of the college baseball nine who is suspended for the remainder of the college year.

PROVIDENCE, March 5.--The joint special committee on constitutional changes favorably reported to the House to-day a bill to annul amendment 5 of the Constitution, (the prohibitory amendment.) The bill will be made the special order on Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 5.--Mrs. L.D. Merriman of Allegheny City. Penn., arrived in this city yesterday on route to Omaha, Neb., with the intention on opening a millinory establishment. She carried with her a hand sachel, between the lining and leather of which she had placed $3,000 in greenbacks. Soon after leaving the train she discovered that the sachel had been cut open and the money stolen.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--In the second session of the Fiftieth Congress President Cleveland sent to the Senate nearly 450 nominations, about one-half of which were confirmed. Of the latter a great majority were promotions in the army and navy and Presidential Postmasters, the terms of whose predecessors had expired, or whose offices had become Presidential. Among these which failed are the following:

The "Legal Protective Association of Cigar Manufacturers" will hold their annual meeting for the election of officers and the transaction of other business at 239 East Fiftyseventh-street to-night at 8 o'clock. These questions will be discussed: "A resolution having in view the abolition of the cigar import stamp;" "a resolution to secure a uniform tariff on imported leaf tobacco;" "a resolution favoring the abolition of the internal revenue system."

One of the last official acts of President Cleve land was the appointment of Charles G. Sawtelle, Jr., and Robert P. Bradley to be cadets at large and William Mackay Cruikshank of the District of Columbia to be cadet at the United States Military Academy.

Police Captain Henry Kellett of the Eighteenth Precinct, Brooklyn, was married on Monday night to Miss Katie M. Gibney. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Father O'Reilly at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Summit-street. Many friends were present, but very few went to the reception held later at the bride's residence, 89 Amitystreet.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--A cable message was received at the State Department to-day from the United States Minister to Persia, conveying the Shah's congratulations to President Harrison and asking for instructions in the matter. The message was submitted to the President, who requested Secretary Bayard to make a suitable reply.

Mayor Grant, Congressman Miller, and other prominent officials, were among the invited guests of the Eleventh Regiment Veterans who last night took possossion of the Germania Assembly Rooms for their eleventh annual reunion and masquerade ball.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 5.--This town is astir to-day over the result of the primary held here Saturday for the nomination of a Democratic ticket. William Lynsky, who is charged with stuffing the ballot box at the primaries, was arraigned before Judge Alfred D. Van Doren this afternoon in the presence of a great crowd of people.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 5.--The storm that has been raging here for three days past has played havoc at various sections along the coast. Several wash-outs at Monmouth Beach have occurred, and the great wrought-iron pier has been warped and shattered by the high winds and huge waves. Richard J. Dobbins's famous bulknead adjoining the West End Hotel and fronting the Howland Hotel, has been damaged to the extent of $800.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 5.--In the State Senate a bill was introduced to-day permitting the formation of State mutual cyclone insurance companies; also one prohibiting baseball playing on Sunday.
Theodore Harzhaus, a German steerage passenger who arrived on the Aurania on Sunday, returned to Castle Garden yesterday morning and complained that he had been swindled in Liverpool.

PORT EATON, Long Island, March 5.--The schooner Holmes. Capt. Saunders, of St. John, New-Brunswick, with lumber, consigned to A. F. Henry. New-York, went ashore on Eaton's Neck this morning. The vessel lies easy and will probably be got off when some of her cargo is lightered.
Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday ordered that the United States Trust Company become the custodian of Frances Coster Jones's share under the will of Joshua Jones.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--People began flocking to the Capitol early this morning. There were many hundreds who had reached the city too late to take in the Capital before yesterday andwho were unable to get in the building while the inauguration ceremonies were in progress.

Miss Cora May Gallaudet and Gustavus Conover Walton were married at 8 o'clock last evening under a handsome canopy of smilax and illies in the parlors of the bride's parents, 10 East Fifty-third-street, by her uncle, the Rev. NEWBURG, N.Y., March 5.--The propeller Newburg of the Ramsdell Line will leave NewYork to-morrow afternoon to open navigation between the metropolis and Newburg. She will come as far as West Point in the afternoon and lay over until Thursday morning in order to combat the thick ice in the Highlands by day light. The river has bean closed exactly four weeks.

SAN FRACISCO, Cal., March 5.--Cyrus Hall McCormick, Jr., President of the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company of Chicago, was married to-day to Harriett Bradley Hammend in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary's-by-the Sea, two miles from Monterey, Cal.
Shortly after midnight last night the saloon kept by Henry Lentz on the northeast corner of Hester and Centre streets caught fire and the flames spread rapidly and with damaging effect.

LANSING, Mich., March 5.--The Governor has fully considered the case of Olive E. Friend and her relatives, who were arrested on charges of fraud in connection with the Electric Sugar Refining muddle, and he has decided not to recall his extradition warrant. This means that Mrs. Friend and the Howards and the Halsteads must go to New-York for trial.

Meetings of the South Ferry Railroad Company, successor to the South Ferry Railway Company, and of the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railway Company, were held yesterday at 761 Seventh-avenue, at which the final arrangements were completed by which the latter company acquires the exclusive use of the property and franchises of the former for a consideration of $355,000.
PARIS, March 5.--The management of the Paris Exposition has set apart space free of charge for the proposed American exhibit of Indian corn.

The inquest in the case of Mrs. Catherine Storch, who died at her home, 338 West Fiftysecond-street, on Tuesday, Feb. 26, of an overdose of morphine obtained by her 13-year-old sister from Druggist Humphrey T. Jones, at Fifty-third-street and Ninth-avenue, was concluded by Coroner Messemer yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 5.--The stockholders of the Englewood Lyceum Company last night voted to erect a lyceum building on the northeast corner of Palisade-avenue and Englestreet. Work upon the building will be begun at once.

CHICAGO, March 5.--A permanent association of creamery supply manufacturers was effected this afternoon under the name of the Association of Creamery Supply Houses of the West. It was a result of several previous gatherings.

PARIS, March 5.--The Bishops of Nashville and Newark and 40 priests started with the American pilgrims for Palestine to-night. They go by way of Rome, where they will be received by the Pope. The organizers of the pilgrimage have sent messages to President Harrison and Mr. Cleveland.

ALBANY, March 6.--To furnish recreation and mutual intercourse among members, the Merchants' Republican Club of New-York has been incorporated, with Samuel A. Sancier, Louis Lehman, and Charles Goldzier as Trustees. The object of the society is also to disciss publicly questions of genaral interest.

Manhattan Elevated stock has been one of the live features in recent Wall-street speculation. It was hanging listlessly around 94 and 95 only a little while ago, when, of a sudden, the Street began to receive an abundance of cheery bulletins promising the immediate accomplishment of wonders toward improving the market value of the property.
SANTA FE, New-Mexico, March 6.--The new meat inspection law, framed with a view of prohibiting the sale of "Big Four" products in New-Mexico, went into effect to-day.
